)@@G@@HE LIST, THE@B@@@@ VARIABLE IS SET EQUAL TO THE EXPRESSION. @[@@@@      BC
)@@G@@@F@@@@       IF A SIMPLE ARITHMETIC STATEMENT IS INCLUDED IN THE <EXPI>,BD
)@@G@@@F@@@@ IT IS PROCESSED, THE VARIABLE IS NOT CHANGED, AND THE NEXT <EXPI>BE
)@@G@@@]@@@@ TAKEN.     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DBF
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          3- 31@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      BG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE VALUE OF AN ITERATIVE EXPRESSION IS DEFINEDBH
)@@G@@ TO BE THE  @D@@@@ VALUE OF <VARIABLE> WHEN THE ITERATION TERMINATES.   BI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF DESIRED, THE INITIAL VALUE ASSIGNED TO THE IBJ
)@@G@@TERATION    @F@@@@ VARIABLE MAY BE OMITTED:  THE FOLLOWING CONSTRUCTION BK
)@@G@@IS LEGAL--  @[@@@@      @D@@@@ (<VARIABLE>,<ITERATION CONTROL>,<EXP1>,<EBL
)@@G@@XP2>,...)   @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE BEHAVIOR OF THIS FORM IS EXACTLY THE BM
)@@G@@SAME AS THAT OF THE ONE @F@@@@ DISCUSSED ABOVE SAVE THAT THERE IS NO INIBN
)@@G@@TIAL VALUE ASSIGNED TO  @#@@@@ THE <VARIABLE>.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@      BO
)@@G@@         EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @B@@@@      BP
)@@G@@ MEAN=(SUM=0,I=1,1,I.G.N,SUM+X(I))/N@[@@@@      @E@@@@       STDEV=SQRT.BQ
)@@G@@((SUM=0,I=1,1,I.G.N,SUM+(X(I)-MEAN)**2)/N)@[@@@@      @E@@@@       A=(X(BR
)@@G@@J)=23,I=-3,4,I.G.PP,X(I)=X(I-1)*I,X(J)+SIN(I))  @[@@@@      @D@@@@      BS
)@@G@@ ANSWER = (ANSWER,I=1,1,I.G.N,ANSWER+OB(I,J))   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      BT
)@@G@@@F@@@@       AN ITERATIVE EXPRESSION IS LEGAL IN ANY CONTEXT WHERE AN   BU
)@@G@@@F@@@@ EXPRESSION IS LEGAL.  IF AN ITERATIVE EXPRESSION IS USED IN A    BV
)@@G@@@F@@@@ FORTRAN I/O LIST, IT MUST BE ENCLOSED IN AN EXTRA SET OF PAREN-  BW
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THESES TO ENABLE THE COMPILER TO DISTINGUSH IT FROM AN ITERATIVE BX
)@@G@@@[@@@@ LIST.@[@@@@      @B@@@@  3. 4. 4.   OPERATOR-MODE COMBINATIONS   BY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE OPERANDS OF ALL OPERATORS MUST BE OF APPROPBZ
)@@G@@RIATE MODE. @F@@@@ AN ERROR MESSAGE WILL BE GENERATED, AND THE COMPUTATICA
)@@G@@ON IGNORED, @F@@@@ IF AN OPERATOR IS USED WITH OPERANDS OF ILLEGAL MODE.CB
)@@G@@  FOR THE   @F@@@@ 'COMPUTATIONAL' OPERATORS, IF THE LEFT AND RIGHT OPERCC
)@@G@@AND MODES   @F@@@@ DIFFER, THE OPERAND WHOSE MODE NUMBER IS LOWER WILL BCD
)@@G@@E CONVERTED @F@@@@ TO THE HIGHER MODE (SEE SECTION 3.1 FOR A TABLE OF MOCE
)@@G@@DE NUMBERS).@F@@@@ THOSE MODES WHOSE NUMBER IS 4 OR LESS ARE DENOTED 'COCF
)@@G@@MPUTATIONAL'@]@@@@ MODES.     @[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 4. 5.   MODE CONVERCG
)@@G@@SION  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       AT THE TIME THAT RALPH IS BREAKING AN EXPCH
)@@G@@RESSION DOWN INTO @F@@@@ TRIPLES, MODES ARE IGNORED.  IN A LATER PASS OFCI
)@@G@@ THE COMPILER,    @F@@@@ MODES ARE TAKEN INTO CONSIDERATION AND CODE PROCJ
)@@G@@DUCED.  IF DEFINED@F@@@@ FOR THE OPERATOR AT HAND (COMPUTATIONAL OPERATOCK
)@@G@@RS), A TRIPLE IS  @F@@@@ EVALUATED IN THE HIGHER OF ITS TWO MODES, AND ICL
)@@G@@TS OUTPUT IS ALSO @A@@@@ DEFINED TO BE OF THIS HIGHER MODE. @[@@@@*****^CM
)@@G@@@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)         CN
)@@G@@ 3- 32@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       FOR ECO
)@@G@@XAMPLE, THE TRIPLE 1+2.0 WILL BE EVALUATED IN FLOATING@F@@@@ POINT AND PCP
)@@G@@RODUCE A FLOATING-POINT 3.0 FOR A RESULT.  THE TRIPLE @C@@@@ 1+2, HOWEVECQ
)@@G@@R, WILL BE EVALUATED IN INTEGER.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ALTHOUGH THCR
)@@G@@E COMPILER WILL READILY CONVERT MODES AS NEEDED,@F@@@@ THE OBJECT CODE PCS
)@@G@@RODUCED IS LESS EFFICIENT WHEN LARGE NUMBERS OF @F@@@@ MODE CONVERSIONS CT
)@@G@@ARE BEING MADE.  IT IS GOOD PROGRAMMING PRACTICE@F@@@@ TO AVOID MIXED-MOCU
)@@G@@DE EXPRESSIONS WHERE POSSIBLE.  MODE CONVERSIONS@E@@@@ ON CONSTANTS ARE CV
)@@G@@MADE BY THE OPTIMIZER, AND WILL NOT AFFECT@F@@@@ GENERATED OBJECT CODE, CW
)@@G@@SO ONE NEED NOT WORRY ABOUT MODES OF CON- @A@@@@ STANTS IN COMPUTATIONALCX
)@@G@@ USAGE.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IT IS IMPORTANT TO NOTE THAT THE PRCY
)@@G@@ESENCE OF A HIGHER-MODE @F@@@@ OPERAND IN AN EXPRESSION DOES NOT FORCE ACZ
)@@G@@NY COMPUTATIONS TO TAKE @G@@@@ PLACE IN THAT MODE UNTIL THE OPERAND IS ADA
)@@G@@CTUALLY REFERENCED.  SOME     @G@@@@ COMPILERS IMMEDIATELY UPGRADE ALL EDB
)@@G@@LEMENTS OF AN EXPRESSION TO THE     @G@@@@ HIGHEST MODE.  IN ORDER TO MIDC
)@@G@@NIMIZE EXECUTION TIME, RALPH DOES NOT     @F@@@@ UPGRADE THE MODE OF A CDD
)@@G@@ALCULATION UNTIL IT IS FORCED TO DO SO.   @[@@@@      @A@@@@  3. 4. 6.  DE
)@@G@@ OPERATOR PRECEDENCE    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       EACH OPERATDF
)@@G@@OR IS ASSIGNED A PRECEDENCE VALUE; IN THE ABSENCE     @F@@@@ OF PARENTHEDG
)@@G@@SES, OPERATORS WITH HIGHER PRECEDENCE ARE EVALUATED   @F@@@@ FIRST.  IN DH
)@@G@@GENERAL, AN EXPRESSION INSIDE PARENTHESES IS EVALUATED@F@@@@ BEFORE ANY DI
)@@G@@EXPRESSION OUTSIDE PARENTHESES.  WITHIN A PARENTHESIS @G@@@@ GROUP, NORMDJ
)@@G@@AL PRECEDENCE RULES APPLY.  DISTINCT PARENTHESIS GROUPS     @F@@@@ ARE EDK
)@@G@@VALUATED IN RIGHT-TO-LEFT ORDER NORMALLY.  FOR A COMPLETE   @G@@@@ DISCUDL
)@@G@@SSION OF THE SCANNING PROCESS FOR ARITHMETIC EXPRESSIONS, SEE     @F@@@@DM
)@@G@@ THE SECTION OF 'PROGRAMMING SYSTEMS AND LANGUAGES' (SAUL ROSEN,  @E@@@@DN
)@@G@@ ED:  MCGRAW-HILL & CO. C. 1967) ENTITLED 'BOUNDED-CONTEXT  @#@@@@ TRANSDO
)@@G@@LATION'.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMDP
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          4-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@DQ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  4.   ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@DR
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS PERFORM CALCULATIONDS
)@@G@@S.  THERE ARE TWO @G@@@@ TYPES OF ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS:  SIMPLE AND ITEDT
)@@G@@RATIVE.  THE SIMPLE     @F@@@@ ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT IS THE ONE MOST COMMDU
)@@G@@ONLY USED; THE ITERATIVE@F@@@@ ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT IS A LUXURY GLEANED DV
)@@G@@FROM ALGOL 60 AND COU-  @F@@@@ SINS, AND IS SIMPLY A COMPACT WAY OF DOINDW
)@@G@@G A LOT OF THINGS AT    @[@@@@ ONCE.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 1DX
)@@G@@.   SIMPLE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      DY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@               A SIMPLE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT IS OF THEDZ
)@@G@@ FORM @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@       <VARIABLE> = <EXPRESSION>    EA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@               (AN ALTERNATE MULTIPLE FORM IS ALLOWED)EB
)@@G@@:     @[@@@@      @E@@@@       <VARIABLE-1> = <VARIABLE-2> = ... = <EXPREC
)@@G@@ESSION>     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE EXAMPLE OF THE FIRSED
)@@G@@T CASE SETS THE VARIABLE ON THE LEFT@F@@@@ SIDE OF THE EQUALS SIGN TO THEE
)@@G@@E VALUE COMPUTED IN THE EXPRESSION  @F@@@@ WHICH IS ON THE RIGHT SIDE OFEF
)@@G@@ THE EQUALS SIGN.  THE SECOND FORM  @F@@@@ SETS ALL OF THE VARIABLES-I TEG
)@@G@@O THE VALUE COMPUTED FOR THE EXPRES-@E@@@@ SION, IN ORDER FROM RIGHT TO EH
)@@G@@LEFT.  THUS, THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      @ @@@@       A(N) = N = A(K) =EI
)@@G@@ K = 7@[@@@@      @E@@@@       WILL SET K=7, THEN A(7)=7, THEN N=7, THENEJ
)@@G@@ A(7)=7.    @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@[@@@@      @]@@@@EK
)@@G@@       X = Y@#@@@@       A(3,1) = 0 @A@@@@       X(4) = B = C = D(1,1) =EL
)@@G@@ 2+H  @E@@@@       A(Y,I+Y*SIN(9)) = 24.2//MIN(A,B,C)**MAX(D,E,F/G)     EM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 2.   ITERATIVE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS EN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@       AN ITERATIVE ASSIGNMENTEO
)@@G@@ STATEMENT IS OF THE FORM     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WEP
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          4-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      EQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@ (<ITERATION CONTROL>,<BODY OF ITERATION>)ER
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHERE <BODY OF ITERATION> IS EITHER A STRING OFES
)@@G@@ SIMPLE     @G@@@@ ASSIGNMENT STATEMENTS SEPARATED BY COMMAS, OR A COMPLET
)@@G@@ETE ITERATIVE     @F@@@@ ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT.  THIS LAST CONSTRUCTION PEU
)@@G@@ERMITS NESTING OF @^@@@@ ITERATION CONTROL.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@      EV
)@@G@@ THE <ITERATION CONTROL> IS OF EXACTLY THE SAME FORM AS THE @F@@@@ ITERAEW
)@@G@@TION CONTROL DISCUSSED IN SECTION A.B FOR THE 'ITERATED I/O @G@@@@ LIST'EX
)@@G@@.  EFFECTIVELY, THE ITERATIVE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT SETS UP AN     @F@@@@EY
)@@G@@ IMPLIED LOOP STRUCTURE, WITH AN EVENTUAL STRING OF SIMPLE ASSIGN-@C@@@@EZ
)@@G@@ MENT STATEMENTS FORMING THE BODY OF THE LOOP.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@      FA
)@@G@@         EXAMPLES:@[@@@@      @D@@@@       (I=1,1,I.G.N,A(I)=B(I)=C(I)=0FB
)@@G@@,A(J-I)=B(JI+1))) @[@@@@      @E@@@@       (J=1,1,J.G.4,(K=1,1,K.G.4,X(JFC
)@@G@@,K)=A(K,L)*B(L,J)))     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       NOTE:  IF XFD
)@@G@@ IS A VALID ITERATIVE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT, THEN@F@@@@ (ITERATION CONTROFE
)@@G@@L,(X)) IS ALSO A VALID ITERATIVE ASSIGNMENT     @F@@@@ STATEMENT.  HOWEVFF
)@@G@@ER, (ITERATION CONTROL, (X),OTHER STATEMENT) IS @C@@@@ *NOT*  A VALID ITFG
)@@G@@ERATIVE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT!!@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3.   THFH
)@@G@@E OPERAND REVERSAL STATEMENT  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       OFTENFI
)@@G@@ IT IS NICE TO BE ABLE TO SWITCH TWO VARIABLES; SORTING     @G@@@@ AND CFJ
)@@G@@OLLATING GIVE RISE TO THIS SORT OF NEED.  THE REVERSAL STATE-     @[@@@@FK
)@@G@@ MENT @[@@@@      @B@@@@               <VARIABLE>==<VARIABLE>     @[@@@@FL
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ WILL SWAP THE TWO OPERANDS.  EACH <VARIABLE> MAY BE ANY ITEFM
)@@G@@M WHICH     @F@@@@ IS IN ITSELF LEGAL ON THE LEFT HALF OF AN EQUALS SIGNFN
)@@G@@.  BOTH LEFT@C@@@@ AND RIGHT OPERANDS MUST BE OF THE SAME MODE.   @[@@@@FO
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  4. 4.   MODE CONVERSION IN ASSIGNMFP
)@@G@@ENT STATEMENTS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@       WHEN FQ
)@@G@@A SIMPLE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT IS PROCESSED, THE @G@@@@ RIGHT-HAND SIDE IFR
)@@G@@S EVALUATED COMPLETELY ACCORDING TO THE RULES FOR     @G@@@@ EVALUATION FS
)@@G@@OF EXPRESSIONS AS SET FORTH IN SECTION 3.4.  AFTER THIS     @G@@@@ EXPREFT
)@@G@@SSION HAS BEEN EVALUATED, WITH MODE CONVERSIONS AS NECESSARY,     @[@@@@FU
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   FV
)@@G@@       4-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE RIGHT-HAND EXFW
)@@G@@PRESSION IS THEN CONVERTED TO THE MODE OF THE   @ @@@@ LEFT OPERAND AND FX
)@@G@@STORED.     @[@@@@      @ @@@@       THUS, THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      FY
)@@G@@@#@@@@       X = 3 / 5  @[@@@@      @B@@@@       WILL BE EQUIVALENT TO TFZ
)@@G@@HE STATEMENT@[@@@@      @#@@@@       X = 0.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      GA
)@@G@@ BECAUSE THE DIVISION WILL BE EVALUATED IN INTEGER ARITHMETIC     @C@@@@GB
)@@G@@ AND WILL YIELD ZERO BY TRUNCATION.  HOWEVER,   @[@@@@      @#@@@@      GC
)@@G@@ X = 3. / 5 @[@@@@      @B@@@@       WILL BE EQUIVALENT TO THE STATEMENTGD
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@       X = 0.6    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       BECAUSE THEGE
)@@G@@ PRESENCE OF THE FLOATING POINT OPERAND (3.) WILL     @F@@@@ FORCE THE EGF
)@@G@@NTIRE DIVISION TO BE CARRIED OUT IN FLOATING POINT.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@GG
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   GH
)@@G@@       5-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5.   CONTROL STAGI
)@@G@@TEMENTS     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       CONTROL STAGJ
)@@G@@TEMENTS GOVERN PROGRAM FLOW, I.E. THE TRANSFER OF     @G@@@@ CONTROL FROGK
)@@G@@M ONE SECTION OF THE PROGRAM TO ANOTHER, THE REPETITION     @A@@@@ OF SEGL
)@@G@@CTIONS OF THE PROGRAM, ETC.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 1.   TRGM
)@@G@@ANSFER OF CONTROL @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       RALPH-COMPILED STGN
)@@G@@ATEMENTS ARE NORMALLY EXECUTED SEQUENTIAL-@F@@@@ LY.  ANY DEVIATION FROMGO
)@@G@@ THIS PATTERN MUST BE ACCOMPLISHED THROUGH@F@@@@ THE USE OF A 'TRANSFER GP
)@@G@@OF CONTROL' STATEMENT.  PROGRAM EXECUTION @F@@@@ IS RESUMED AT THE NEW SGQ
)@@G@@TATEMENT, THUS THE NEXT EXECUTABLE STATE- @F@@@@ MENT AFTER A TRANSFER OGR
)@@G@@F CONTROL STATEMENT MUST HAVE A STATEMENT @F@@@@ LABEL, ELSE THERE WILL GS
)@@G@@BE NO POSSIBLE WAY FOR THE PROGRAM EVER TO@^@@@@ REACH THAT STATEMENT.  GT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 1. 1.   UNCONDITIONAL TRANSFER @[@@@@      @G@@@@GU
)@@G@@       AN UNCONDITIONAL TRANSFER STATEMENT CAUSES PROGRAM EXECUTION     GV
)@@G@@@F@@@@ TO BE TRANSFERRED TO ANOTHER PART OF THE PROGRAM.  THE GENERAL   GW
)@@G@@@E@@@@ FORM OF THE ABSOLUTE (UNCONDITIONAL) TRANSFER STATEMENT IS:@[@@@@GX
)@@G@@      @B@@@@       (FORTRAN):       GO TO  <LABEL>    @[@@@@      @C@@@@GY
)@@G@@       (MAD):           TRANSFER TO <LABEL>     @[@@@@      @F@@@@      GZ
)@@G@@ IN FORTRAN, <LABEL> IS A 5-DIGIT INTEGER CORRESPONDING TO A@F@@@@ 5-DIGHA
)@@G@@IT STATEMENT NUMBER PUNCHED SOMEWHERE IN THE PROGRAM.  IN   @F@@@@ MAD, HB
)@@G@@<LABEL> IS ANY EXPRESSION OF STATEMENT LABEL MODE.  IN ITS  @F@@@@ SIMPLHC
)@@G@@EST FORM, THE MAD <LABEL> IS SIMPLY A STATEMENT LABEL AS    @F@@@@ PUNCHHD
)@@G@@ED ON SOME STATEMENT ELSEWHERE IN THE PROGRAM.  SEE SECTION @D@@@@ 3.2.1HE
)@@G@@.7 FOR FURTHER DISCUSSION OF STATEMENT LABELS.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      HF
)@@G@@@#@@@@       EXAMPLES:  @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @#@@@@      HG
)@@G@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@               GO TO 3  @ @@@@               GO TO 233HH
)@@G@@55    @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @A@@@@               TRANSFER HI
)@@G@@TO GRONK    @B@@@@               TRANSFER TO IDENT(J,K)     @C@@@@      HJ
)@@G@@         TRANSFER TO [DATA>0,START,STOP]  @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@HK
)@@G@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5-  2HL
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@       THE LAST EXAMPLE ILLUSTHM
)@@G@@RATES A USE OF THE ALTERNATIVE@A@@@@ EXPRESSION.  SEE SECTION 3.4.2.    HN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 1. 2.   INDEXED TRANSFER @[@@@@      @F@@@@      HO
)@@G@@ AN INDEXED TRANSFER STATEMENT SELECTS ONE OF A GROUP OF    @F@@@@ STATEHP
)@@G@@MENT LABELS DEPENDING UPON THE VALUE OF AN INDEX VARIABLE.  @C@@@@ IN FOHQ
)@@G@@RTRAN, AN INDEXED TRANSFER HAS THE FORM:  @[@@@@      @C@@@@       GO TOHR
)@@G@@ (<L1>,<L2>,...,<LN>),<EXPRESSION>  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE <EXPRESHS
)@@G@@SION> IS ARBITRARY OF INTEGER MODE.  THE <LI> ARE     @F@@@@ FORTRAN STAHT
)@@G@@TEMENT NUMBERS.  CONTROL WILL GO TO <L1> IF THE VALUE @F@@@@ OF <EXPRESSHU
)@@G@@ION> IS 1, TO <L2> IF THE VALUE OF <EXPRESSION> IS 2, @F@@@@ ETC.  IF <EHV
)@@G@@XPRESSION> IS NEGATIVE, ZERO, OR GREATER THAN 'N', AN @C@@@@ IMMEDIATE EHW
)@@G@@RROR TERMINATION WILL BE GENERATED. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN MAD, THEHX
)@@G@@RE IS NO EXPLICIT FORM OF AN INDEXED TRANSFER,  @F@@@@ BUT IT MAY BE EFFHY
)@@G@@ECTED VIA SUBSCRIPTED STATEMENT LABELS:  THE    @]@@@@ STATEMENT  @[@@@@HZ
)@@G@@      @ @@@@       TRANSFER TO LABEL(I)   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IS FOIA
)@@G@@R ALL PRACTICAL PURPOSES AN INDEXED TRANSFER ON I.    @[@@@@      @^@@@@IB
)@@G@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               ======== @[@@@@      @#@@@@IC
)@@G@@       (FORTRAN)  @C@@@@               GO TO (10,20,20,30,40,10,100),I+JID
)@@G@@@A@@@@               GO TO (21,999),ISLITE@[@@@@      @]@@@@       (MAD)IE
)@@G@@@B@@@@               TRANSFER TO PROCES(K,L)    @B@@@@               TRAIF
)@@G@@NSFER TO GROUP(J*23-JP) @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  5. 1. 3.   STATEIG
)@@G@@MENT-LABEL VARIABLES    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN FORTRAN, A STATEMENTIH
)@@G@@ NUMBER IS AN INTEGER PUNCHED SOME- @G@@@@ WHERE IN COLUMNS 1 THROUGH 5 II
)@@G@@OF THE INPUT CARD, IN MAD A STATEMENT     @F@@@@ LABEL IS A SYMBOL, POSSIJ
)@@G@@IBLY WITH SUBSCRIPTS, IN COLUMNS 1 THROUGH@F@@@@ 10.  THESE, ALTHOUGH TRIK
)@@G@@EATED AS VARIABLES BY THE COMPILER, ARE   @F@@@@ ACTUALLY CONSTANTS; ANYIL
)@@G@@ ATTEMPT TO CHANGE THE VALUE OF AN UNSUBS-@F@@@@ CRIPTED STATEMENT LABELIM
)@@G@@ WILL RESULT IN UTTER DESTRUCTION OF THE  @F@@@@ OBJECT PROGRAM.  BUT OCIN
)@@G@@CASIONALLY IT IS NICE TO BE ABLE TO TRANS-@F@@@@ FER TO A VARIABLE, WITHIO
)@@G@@OUT RESORTING TO AN INDEXED TRANSFER.     @G@@@@ ENTER THE STATEMENT-LABIP
)@@G@@EL VARIABLE.  A STATEMENT-LABEL VARIABLE IS     @G@@@@ A VARIABLE OF STAIQ
)@@G@@TEMENT-LABEL MODE.  ONE DOES NOT COMPUTE WITH IT,     @F@@@@ BUT TRANSFEIR
)@@G@@RS TO IT.  STATEMENT-LABEL VARIABLES MUST BE DIMEN-   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@IS
)@@G@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5-  3IT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ SIONED, ELSE THEY CANNOT BE AIU
)@@G@@SSIGNED STORAGE BY THE COMPILER.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN FORTRAN,IV
)@@G@@ A VARIABLE IS AUTOMATICALLY DECLARED TO BE OF  @F@@@@ STATEMENT-LABEL MIW
)@@G@@ODE IF IT APPEARS IN AN 'ASSIGN' STATEMENT.  IN @F@@@@ MAD A STATEMENT-LIX
)@@G@@ABEL VARIABLE MUST BE DECLARED AND DIMENSIONED. @[@@@@      @F@@@@      IY
)@@G@@ TO SET THE VALUE OF A STATEMENT-LABEL VARIABLE, AN ORDINARY@ @@@@ ARITHIZ
)@@G@@METIC STATEMENT IS USED:@[@@@@      @C@@@@       <VARIABLE> = <STATEMENTJA
)@@G@@ LABEL EXPRESSION>@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHERE THE <STATEMENT LABEL EXJB
)@@G@@PRESSION> MAY BE EITHER A     @F@@@@ STATEMENT LABEL, A STATEMENT-LABEL JC
)@@G@@VARIABLE, OR AN ALTERNATIVE   @G@@@@ EXPRESSION (CONCEIVABLY NESTED) WHIJD
)@@G@@CH HAS A STATEMENT LABEL VALUE.     @ @@@@ IN FORTRAN, THE STATEMENT    JE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@       ASSIGN <LABEL> TO <STATEMENT-LABEL VARIABLE>   JF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       IS ALSO PERMITTED:  <LABEL> MUST BE A VALID FORJG
)@@G@@TRAN STATE- @F@@@@ MENT NUMBER.  THE 'ASSIGN' STATEMENT WILL AUTOMATICALJH
)@@G@@LY DECLARE  @F@@@@ THE VARIABLE TO BE OF STATEMENT-LABEL MODE AND DIMENSJI
)@@G@@ION IT FOR 1@F@@@@ LOCATION.  THIS AUTOMATIC DIMENSIONING CAN BE OVERRIDJJ
)@@G@@DEN BY AN   @D@@@@ EXPLICIT DIMENSION STATEMENT (SEE SECTION 8.1.1).    JK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 1. 4.   ASSIGNED TRANSFERS     @[@@@@JL
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       AN ASSIGNED TRANSFER IS A TRANSFER TO A STATEMENT-LABJM
)@@G@@EL    @ @@@@ VARIABLE.  ONE SIMPLY WRITES:@[@@@@      @^@@@@       GO TOJN
)@@G@@ <VARIABLE> @[@@@@  OR  @ @@@@       TRANSFER TO <VARIABLE> @[@@@@      JO
)@@G@@@D@@@@       WHERE <VARIABLE> IS OF STATEMENT-LABEL MODE.   @[@@@@      JP
)@@G@@@F@@@@       IN FORTRAN, ONE MAY APPEND A LIST OF POSSIBLE DESTINATIONS JQ
)@@G@@@A@@@@ TO THE END OF AN ASSIGNED TRANSFER:@[@@@@      @E@@@@       GO TOJR
)@@G@@ <VARIABLE>,(<LAB1>,<LAB2>,<LAB3>,...,<LABN>)   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      JS
)@@G@@ THE PARENTHESIZED GROUP IS IGNORED BY THE COMPILER EXCEPT  @G@@@@ THAT JT
)@@G@@IT MUST CONTAIN NO ILLEGAL SYNTACTIC ITEMS.  IT IS SCANNED BY     @F@@@@JU
)@@G@@ THE SYNTAX SCANNER FOR ERRORS, BUT IS NEVER LOOKED AT BY THE     @#@@@@JV
)@@G@@ COMPILER PROPER. @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@      JW
)@@G@@         ======== @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN)  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@JX
)@@G@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5-  4JY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@               ASSIGN 100 TO IJZ
)@@G@@SL    @^@@@@               . . .    @^@@@@               GO TO ISL@^@@@@KA
)@@G@@               . . .    @B@@@@               GO TO ISL,(100,200,500)    KB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@               JSL = $232     @^@@@@               . .KC
)@@G@@ .    @B@@@@               GO TO JSL,(300,400,500,232)@^@@@@            KD
)@@G@@   . . .    @^@@@@               GO TO JSL@[@@@@      @]@@@@       (MAD)KE
)@@G@@@ @@@@               KSL = LABEL    @^@@@@               . . .    @ @@@@KF
)@@G@@               TRANSFER TO KSL@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PKG
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5-  5@[@@@@      KH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  5. 2.   THE 'CONKI
)@@G@@TINUE' STATEMENT (FORTRAN AND MAD)  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@      KJ
)@@G@@ THE 'CONTINUE' STATEMENT IS USED AS A CONVENIENT WAY TO DO @G@@@@ NOTHIKK
)@@G@@NG.  ITS USUAL EMPLOYMENT IS AS SOMEPLACE TO HANG A STATEMENT     @F@@@@KL
)@@G@@ LABEL.  THE 'CONTINUE' STATEMENT SIMPLY CONTINUES TO THE NEXT    @F@@@@KM
)@@G@@ STATEMENT.  THE EFFECT OF A 'CONTINUE' STATEMENT WITHOUT A STATE-@E@@@@KN
)@@G@@ MENT LABEL IS ROUGHLY THE SAME AS THAT OF A BLANK CARD.    @[@@@@      KO
)@@G@@@^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      KP
)@@G@@@#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @ @@@@               12    CONTINUE @ @@@@      KQ
)@@G@@         288   CONTINUE @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @A@@@@      KR
)@@G@@         LABEL      CONTINUE  @A@@@@               LOOP       CONTINUE  KS
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 3.   CONDITIONAL STATEMENKT
)@@G@@TS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       CONDITIONAL STATEMENTS TEST PKU
)@@G@@ROGRAM VARIABLES AND PROCEED  @F@@@@ ACCORDING TO THE RESULT OF THE TESTKV
)@@G@@.  THERE ARE 3 TYPES OF CONDI-@F@@@@ TIONAL CONTROL STATEMENTS , BUT ONEKW
)@@G@@ IS UNIQUE TO FORTRAN, AND ONE@#@@@@ UNIQUE TO MAD.   @[@@@@      @D@@@@KX
)@@G@@  5. 3. 1.   SIMPLE CONDITIONALS (MAD AND FORTRAN)    @[@@@@      @F@@@@KY
)@@G@@       A SIMPLE CONDITIONAL WILL ALLOW A SINGLE STATEMENT TO BE   @B@@@@KZ
)@@G@@ CONDITIONALLY EXECUTED.  THE FORM IS     @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTLA
)@@G@@RAN): @D@@@@               IF (<LOGICAL EXPRESSION>) <STATEMENT>  @#@@@@LB
)@@G@@       (MAD):     @E@@@@               WHENEVER <BOOLEAN EXPRESSION>,<STLC
)@@G@@ATEMENT>    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE <BOOLEAN EXPRESSION> OR <LOGICALD
)@@G@@L EXPRESSION> MAY BE ANY@F@@@@ VALID BOOLEAN (LOGICAL) EXPRESSION, THE <LE
)@@G@@STATEMENT> MAY BE ANY   @G@@@@ EXECUTABLE STATEMENT EXCEPT ANOTHER SIMPLLF
)@@G@@E OR COMPOUND CONDITIONAL     @[@@@@ AND  @[@@@@      @ @@@@       (FORTLG
)@@G@@RAN):  'DO', 'END'@[@@@@      @B@@@@       (MAD):  'THROUGH', 'END OF PRLH
)@@G@@OGRAM'@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971LI
)@@G@@ VERSION)          5-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      LJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@       THE ARITHMETIC CONDITIONAL (SECTION 5.3.2) IS PERMITTED AS LK
)@@G@@A     @F@@@@ <STATEMENT> INSIDE A SIMPLE CONDITIONAL, BUT THE COMPOUND CLL
)@@G@@ONDI- @A@@@@ TIONAL (SECTION 5.3.3) IS NOT.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      LM
)@@G@@ IF THE <BOOLEAN EXPRESSION> IS TRUE, THE <STATEMENT> WILL BE     @F@@@@LN
)@@G@@ EXECUTED.  IF THE <BOOLEAN EXPRESSION> IS FALSE, CONTROL PRO-    @B@@@@LO
)@@G@@ CEEDS TO THE NEXT SEQUENTIAL STATEMENT.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@            LP
)@@G@@   EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTLQ
)@@G@@RAN): @D@@@@               IF (A.GT.B.OR. B/6 < 8.33) S = S + 1   @A@@@@LR
)@@G@@               IF (RR.NE.0) GO TO 4 @A@@@@               IF(LOGVAR)  STOLS
)@@G@@P     @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @E@@@@               WHENEVER LT
)@@G@@A.G.B .OR. B/6 < 8.33, S = S + 1    @C@@@@               WHENEVER RR.NE.LU
)@@G@@0, TRANSFER TO &4 @C@@@@               WHENEVER LOGVAR, EXECUTE EXIT.   LV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  5. 3. 2.   ARITHMETIC CONDITIONALS (FORTLW
)@@G@@RAN ONLY)   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       AN ARITHMETIC CONDITIONAL IS A 3-WALX
)@@G@@Y CONDITIONAL TRANSFER, @F@@@@ TAKING ONE OF 3 EXITS DEPENDING UPON WHETLY
)@@G@@HER THE QUANTITY BEING  @E@@@@ TESTED IS NEGATIVE, ZERO, OR POSITIVE.  TLZ
)@@G@@HE GENERAL FORM IS@[@@@@      @D@@@@       IF (<EXPRESSION>) <LABEL-1>,<MA
)@@G@@LABEL-2>,<LABEL-3>@[@@@@      @G@@@@       <EXPRESSION> IS ANY EXPRESSIOMB
)@@G@@N IN A COMPUTATIONAL MODE.  THE     @G@@@@ <LABEL-I> ARE FORTRAN STATEMEMC
)@@G@@NT NUMBERS, OR VARIABLES OF STATEMENT     @]@@@@ LABEL MODE.@[@@@@      MD
)@@G@@@F@@@@       IF <EXPRESSION> IS NEGATIVE, CONTROL GOES TO <LABEL-1>     ME
)@@G@@@F@@@@                          ZERO                      <LABEL-2>     MF
)@@G@@@F@@@@                          POSITIVE                  <LABEL-3>     MG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       FOR THE PURPOSES OF AN ARITHMETIC CONDITIONAL, MH
)@@G@@A VALUE OF  @F@@@@ NEGATIVE ZERO (BIT PATTERN OF ALL 1-BITS) WILL BE TREMI
)@@G@@ATED AS ZERO@F@@@@ AND NOT NEGATIVE.  IF ANY OF THE <LABEL-I> IS NOT PREMJ
)@@G@@SENT, THEN  @D@@@@ THE REPRESENTED FIELD IS TREATED AS 'NEXT STATEMENT'.MK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               ======== ML
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@               STATEMENT               TRANSFERS TO   MM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@                                       ( 20 IF A-B < 0MN
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSIMO
)@@G@@ON)          5-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@            MP
)@@G@@   IF (A-B) 20,30,40       ( 30 IF A-B = 0@D@@@@                        MQ
)@@G@@               ( 40 IF A-B > 0@[@@@@      @E@@@@                        MR
)@@G@@               (20 IF B+C/3.2-X < 0 @E@@@@               IF(B+C/3.2-X) 2MS
)@@G@@0,,      ( NEXT STATEMENT = 0 @E@@@@                                    MT
)@@G@@   ( NEXT STATEMENT > 0 @[@@@@      @F@@@@                              MU
)@@G@@         ( NEXT STATEMENT IF Q<0    @F@@@@               IF (Q)  ,,40   MV
)@@G@@         ( NEXT STATEMENT IF Q=0    @F@@@@                              MW
)@@G@@         ( 40                Q>0    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMX
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@MY
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  5. 3. 3.   COMPOUND CONDITIONALS  MZ
)@@G@@(MAD ONLY)  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE COMPOUND CONDITIONAL IS FAR ANDNA
)@@G@@ AWAY THE MOST POWERFUL @F@@@@ CONDITIONAL STATEMENT IN RALPH.  IN FULL NB
)@@G@@FORM, IT IS A GROUP OF  @^@@@@ STATEMENTS OF THE FORM @[@@@@      @^@@@@NC
)@@G@@       WHENEVER <EXP-1> @A@@@@               (GROUP OF STATEMENTS)@ @@@@ND
)@@G@@       OR WHENEVER <EXP-2>    @B@@@@               ( GROUP OF STATEMENTSNE
)@@G@@)     @ @@@@       OR WHENEVER <EXP-3>    @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@NF
)@@G@@               .  @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@       OTHERWISE  @A@@@@NG
)@@G@@               (GROUP OF STATEMENTS)@ @@@@       END OF CONDITIONAL     NH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE STATEMENTS BETWEEN THE INITIAL 'WHENEVER' SNI
)@@G@@TATEMENT AND@F@@@@ THE NEXT 'OR WHENEVER' STATEMENT WILL BE EXECUTED IF NJ
)@@G@@AND ONLY IF @F@@@@ THE BOOLEAN EXPRESSION <EXP-1> IS TRUE.  THE STATEMENNK
)@@G@@TS BETWEEN  @F@@@@ THE FIRST 'OR WHENEVER' STATEMENT AND THE SECOND 'OR NL
)@@G@@WHENEVER'   @F@@@@ STATEMENT WILL BE EXECUTED IF AND ONLY IF THE BOOLEANNM
)@@G@@ EXPRESSION @E@@@@ <EXP-2> IS TRUE.  THE ABOVE STRUCTURE IS EQUIVALENT TNN
)@@G@@O THE @ @@@@ SIMPLE-CONDITIONAL STURCTURE:@[@@@@      @C@@@@       WHENENO
)@@G@@VER .NOT.<EXP-1>, TRANSFER TO L1    @A@@@@               (GROUP OF STATENP
)@@G@@MENTS)@^@@@@       TRANSFER TO XL   @C@@@@ L1    WHENEVER .NOT.<EXP-2>, NQ
)@@G@@TRANSFER TO L2    @A@@@@               (GROUP OF STATEMENTS)@^@@@@      NR
)@@G@@ TRANSFER TO XL   @C@@@@ L2    WHENEVER .NOT.<EXP-3>, TRANSFER TO L3    NS
)@@G@@@#@@@@               .  @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@               .  NT
)@@G@@@#@@@@ LN    CONTINUE   @A@@@@               (GROUP OF STATEMENTS)@#@@@@NU
)@@G@@ XL    CONTINUE   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ONLY THE INITIAL 'WHENEVER' ANV
)@@G@@ND THE TERMINAL 'END OF CONDI-@G@@@@ TIONAL' ARE REQUIRED--THE 'OR WHENENW
)@@G@@VER' AND 'OTHERWISE' STATEMENTS     @E@@@@ MAY BE USED OR OMITTED AS DESNX
)@@G@@IRED.  A COMPOUND-CONDITIONAL @F@@@@ 'WHENEVER' IS DISTINGUISHED FROM A NY
)@@G@@SIMPLE-CONDITIONAL 'WHENEVER' @B@@@@ BY THE ABSENCE OF THE SEPARATING CONZ
)@@G@@MMA.  @[@@@@      @E@@@@       COMPOUND CONDITIONALS MAY BE NESTED TO A OA
)@@G@@DEPTH OF 30.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEOB
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          5-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@OC
)@@G@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @A@@@@OD
)@@G@@       WHENEVER (B.P.2 - 4*A*C)<0   @C@@@@               PRINT REMARK $ OE
)@@G@@NO REAL ROOTS$    @B@@@@       OR WHENEVER (B.P.2 - 4*A*C).E.0    @D@@@@OF
)@@G@@               PRINT REMARK $ ROOTS ARE IDENTICAL$    @#@@@@       OTHEROG
)@@G@@WISE  @C@@@@               PRINT REMARK $ TWO REAL ROOTS$   @ @@@@      OH
)@@G@@ END OF CONDITIONAL     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@      OI
)@@G@@ WHENEVER X(I).G.X(J)   @A@@@@           WHENEVER Y(I).L.Y(J)     @A@@@@OJ
)@@G@@               WHENEVER Z(I).EQ.Z(J)@C@@@@                   PRINT REMAROK
)@@G@@K $ BAD DATA SET$ @B@@@@                   TRANSFER TO BLOWUP     @A@@@@OL
)@@G@@               END OF CONDITIONAL   @ @@@@           END OF CONDITIONAL OM
)@@G@@@ @@@@       END OF CONDITIONAL     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      ON
)@@G@@@F@@@@       THE INDENTATION OF STATEMENTS INSIDE IS FOR GRAPHIC EFFECT OO
)@@G@@@F@@@@ ONLY, AND LIKE ALL OTHER BLANKS WITHIN A  STATEMENT THE INDENTED OP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ BLANKS ARE IGNORED BY THE COMPILER.  IT IS HIGHLY RECOMMENDED THAOQ
)@@G@@T     @F@@@@ THE USER INDENT STATEMENTS INSIDE COMPOUND CONDITIONALS FOROR
)@@G@@ EASE @ @@@@ IN READING AND DEBUGGING.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO POS
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5- 10@[@@@@      OT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 4.   TERMINATOU
)@@G@@ION OF PROGRAM    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       ONE MAY TERMINATEOV
)@@G@@ EXECUTION OF A  PROGRAM BY TRANSFERRING TO     @F@@@@ THE END OF THE PROW
)@@G@@OGRAM,  VIA THE STATEMENT 'STOP' IN FORTRAN, OR @A@@@@ VIA A CALL TO A SOX
)@@G@@YSTEM EXIT POINT: @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @]@@@@       STOP OY
)@@G@@@[@@@@  OR  @^@@@@       STOP <STRING>    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEREOZ
)@@G@@ <STRING> IS AN OPTIONAL STRING OF UP TO 6 CHARACTERS @F@@@@ NOT INCLUDIPA
)@@G@@NG AN EQUALS SIGN (=).  IF THIS STRING IS PRESENT, THE@]@@@@ MESSAGE    PB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@       ''STOP <STRING>''@[@@@@      @G@@@@       WILL PC
)@@G@@BE PRINTED ON THE OPERATOR'S CONSOLE AND ENTERED IN THE     @E@@@@ PROGRPD
)@@G@@AM LOG FOR THE RUN.  THE ALTERNATIVE CONSTRUCTIONS    @[@@@@      @A@@@@PE
)@@G@@       (FORTRAN):       CALL EXIT   @A@@@@                        CALL SPF
)@@G@@YSTEM @[@@@@      @B@@@@       (MAD):           EXECUTE EXIT.     @ @@@@PG
)@@G@@                        EXIT. @B@@@@                        EXECUTE SYSTPH
)@@G@@EM.   @A@@@@                        SYSTEM.     @[@@@@      @E@@@@      PI
)@@G@@ ARE PERMITTED.  SEE SECTION 6.6, 'SUBROUTINE CALLS'. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@PJ
)@@G@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5- 11PK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 5PL
)@@G@@.   ITERATION STATEMENTS@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       AN ITERATIOPM
)@@G@@N STATEMENT CAUSES THOSE STATEMENTS WHICH FALL  @F@@@@ BETWEEN IT AND A PN
)@@G@@SENTINEL STATEMENT TO BE EXECUTED REPEATEDLY.   @F@@@@ THERE ARE THREE FPO
)@@G@@ORMS OF ITERATION STATEMENTS IN MAD, AND ONE IN @]@@@@ FORTRAN.   @[@@@@PP
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  5. 5. 1.   'DO' STATEMENT   (FORTRAN)   @[@@@@PQ
)@@G@@      @E@@@@       THE GENERAL FORM OF A FORTRAN ITERATION STATEMENT IS:PR
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@       DO <LABEL> <VARIABLE> = <START>,<STOP>,<INCREMEPS
)@@G@@NT>   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ALL STATEMENTS FROM THE 'DO' THROUGH AND PT
)@@G@@INCLUDING THE     @E@@@@ STATEMENT WITH STATEMENT LABEL <LABEL> WILL BE PU
)@@G@@EXECUTED    @[@@@@      @B@@@@       (<STOP> - <START>)/<INCREMENT> + 1 PV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ TIMES.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE <VARIABLE> WIPW
)@@G@@LL BE INITIALIZED TO THE VALUE <START> AND@C@@@@ INCREMENTED BY THE VALUPX
)@@G@@E <INCREMENT> EACH TIME.@[@@@@      @C@@@@       <START> MAY BE ANY INTEPY
)@@G@@GER EXPRESSION    @C@@@@       <STOP> MAY BE ANY INTEGER EXPRESSION     PZ
)@@G@@@E@@@@       <INCREMENT> MAY BE ANY INTEGER EXPRESSION OR NULL.   @F@@@@QA
)@@G@@       <VARIABLE> MAY BE ANY NONSUBSCRIPTED INTEGER VARIABLE.     @[@@@@QB
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       THERE ARE NO RESTRICTIONS ON THE SIGN OR MAGNITUDE OFQC
)@@G@@ ANY OF     @F@@@@ THE ITERATION PARAMETERS OTHER THAN THOSE STANDARD FOQD
)@@G@@R INTEGERS, @F@@@@ BUT IT IS GENERALLY CONSIDERED GOOD FORM TO KEEP THE QE
)@@G@@VALUE OF    @F@@@@ <VARIABLE> WITHIN DIMENSION LIMITS IF IT IS BEING USEQF
)@@G@@D AS A SUBS-@]@@@@ CRIPT.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF THE VALUE OF <QG
)@@G@@INCREMENT> IS NOT SPECIFIED, IT IS ASSUMED@F@@@@ TO BE +1.  IF THE LOOP QH
)@@G@@IS GOING BACKWARDS, IT IS NECESSARY TO    @F@@@@ PUNCH AN INCREMENT:  ONQI
)@@G@@E FINDS IT DIFFICULT TO STEP FROM 14 TO 2 @#@@@@ IN STEPS OF +1.  @[@@@@QJ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       TRANSFERS FROM OUTSIDE THE RANGE OF A 'DO' STATEMENT QK
)@@G@@INTO  @F@@@@ THE RANGE OF THE 'DO' ARE NOT PERMITTED.  ALTERING THE VALUQL
)@@G@@E OF  @F@@@@ THE <VARIABLE> WITHIN THE RANGE OF A <DO> IS NOT PERMITTED.QM
)@@G@@  THIS@F@@@@ IS BECAUSE ALL OF THE PARAMETERS WHICH CONTROL THE 'DO' LOOQN
)@@G@@P ARE @G@@@@ NOT IN CORE AS ONE MIGHT EXPECT, BUT ARE PLACED BY THE COMPQO
)@@G@@ILER IN     @F@@@@ INTERNAL COMPUTATION REGISTERS WHICH ARE NOT AVAILABLQP
)@@G@@E TO THE    @G@@@@ USER.  THUS, EVEN IF ONE WERE TO CHANGE THE VALUE OF QQ
)@@G@@A DO VARIABLE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DQR
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      QS
)@@G@@@F@@@@ WITHIN THE LOOP, THE NEXT ITERATION WOULD RESTORE IT FROM THE    QT
)@@G@@@F@@@@ REGISTER TO ITS NORMAL VALUE, THEREBY CONFUSING EVERYTHING.  TO  QU
)@@G@@@F@@@@ PROTECT THE SANITY OF THE USER, HE IS FORBIDDEN TO ATTEMPT TO    QV
)@@G@@@C@@@@ CHANGE THE VALUE OF THE DO INDEX VARIABLE.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@QW
)@@G@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@QX
)@@G@@      @^@@@@       DO 101 J = 1,14  @A@@@@       IF(CARD(J).NE.' ') GO TQY
)@@G@@O 201 @#@@@@ 101   CONTINUE   @D@@@@ 201   GO TO (1,2,3,4,586,7,8,9,10,1QZ
)@@G@@1,12,13,14),J     @[@@@@      @ @@@@       DO 200 IXXX = 988,-3,-4@D@@@@RA
)@@G@@       IF(ABS(X(IXXX)-Y(IXXX)).GE.EPSLON) I = I + 1   @#@@@@ 200   CONTIRB
)@@G@@NUE   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@       DO 10 I = 1,N    @^@@@@      RC
)@@G@@ DO 10 J = 1,N    @^@@@@       DO 10 K = 1,N    @^@@@@       ARRAY(I,J,KRD
)@@G@@) = 0 @#@@@@ 10    CONTINUE   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  5. 5. 2.  RE
)@@G@@ 'THROUGH' STATEMENT   (MAD)  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THERE ARE 3 TYPESRF
)@@G@@ OF ITERATION STATEMENTS IN MAD.  THE FIRST     @F@@@@ AND FASTEST IS EQRG
)@@G@@UIVALENT TO THE FORTRAN 'DO' STATEMENT.  THE    @G@@@@ SECOND TYPE IS A RH
)@@G@@COMPLETELY GENERAL CALCULATED-LOOP ITERATION, THE     @C@@@@ THIRD IS A RI
)@@G@@SPECIAL SPARSE-DISTRIBUTION TYPE.   @[@@@@      @B@@@@  5. 5. 2. 1.   THRJ
)@@G@@E 'WITH INDEX' LOOP     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE 'WITH INDEX' FORM ORK
)@@G@@F THE THROUGH STATEMENT IS THE FA-  @F@@@@ STEST TYPE OF ITERATION AVAILRL
)@@G@@ABLE TO THE MAD PROGRAMMER.  LOOP   @E@@@@ OVERHEAD IS ABOUT 2 MICROSECORM
)@@G@@NDS PER ITERATION.  IT HAS THE@#@@@@ GENERAL FORM     @[@@@@      @F@@@@RN
)@@G@@   THROUGH <LABEL>,WITH INDEX <VARIABLE>=<START>,<STOP>,<INCR>    @[@@@@RO
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       EXACTLY THE SAME DEFINITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS APPLY FRP
)@@G@@OR THE@G@@@@ 'WITH INDEX' FORM OF THE THROUGH STATEMENT AS FOR THE FORTRRQ
)@@G@@AN 'DO'     @F@@@@ STATEMENT DISCUSSED IN THE PREVIOUS SECTION.  REFER TRR
)@@G@@O THE PRE-  @ @@@@ VIOUS SECTION FOR DETAILS.   @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 5RS
)@@G@@. 2. 2.   THE 'FOR' LOOP@[@@@@      @D@@@@       THE GENERAL FORM OF THERT
)@@G@@ 'FOR' LOOP IN MAD IS:  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RARU
)@@G@@LPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          5- 13@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@RV
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@  THROUGH <LABEL>,FOR<VARIABLE>=<START>,<INCREMERW
)@@G@@NT>,<END CONDITION>     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       ALL STATEMENTS BETWEEN RX
)@@G@@THE 'THROUGH' UP TO AND INCLUDING THE     @E@@@@ INDICATED STATEMENT LABRY
)@@G@@EL WILL BE EXECUTED.  THE VARIABLE  @G@@@@ <VARIABLE> WILL BE GIVEN THE RZ
)@@G@@INITIAL VALUE <START> AND EACH ITERA-     @F@@@@ TION WILL HAVE THE CURRSA
)@@G@@ENT VALUE OF <INCREMENT> ADDED.  THE LOOP @F@@@@ WILL BE TERMINATED WHENSB
)@@G@@ THE BOOLEAN EXPRESSION <END CONDITION> IS@[@@@@ TRUE.@[@@@@      @G@@@@SC
)@@G@@       <LABEL> MAY BE ANY STATEMENT LABEL, POSSIBLY WITH A CONSTANT     SD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SINGLE SUBSCRIPT.  <VARIABLE> MAY BE ANY VARIABLE, POSSIBLY WITH SE
)@@G@@A     @F@@@@ CONSTANT SUBSCRIPT OR SUBSCRIPTS.  <START> MAY BE ANY EXPRESF
)@@G@@SSION.@F@@@@ <INCREMENT> MAY BE ANY EXPRESSION.  <END CONDITION> MAY BE SG
)@@G@@ANY   @F@@@@ BOOLEAN EXPRESSION.  LOOP OVERHEAD TIME IS ABOUD 12 MICROSESH
)@@G@@CONDS @F@@@@ PLUS THE TIME TO CALCULATE <INCREMENT> AND <END CONDITION> SI
)@@G@@FOR   @#@@@@ EACH ITERATION.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE EXPRESSION <ISJ
)@@G@@NCREMENT> IS RE-EVALUATED WITH EACH ITERA-@G@@@@ TION, SO IT MAY CHANGE SK
)@@G@@DURING THE LOOP.  THERE ARE NO RESTRICTIONS     @F@@@@ ON TRANSFERRING ISL
)@@G@@NTO THE LOOP, OR ON ALTERING THE VALUE OF ANY-  @G@@@@ THING INSIDE THE SM
)@@G@@LOOP.  THE 'THROUGH' STATEMENT OUTLINED ABOVE MAY     @F@@@@ BE CONSIDERSN
)@@G@@ED AS EQUIVALENT TO THE FOLLOWING SEQUENCE OF MAD     @]@@@@ STATEMENTS:SO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@               VARIABLE = <START>   @A@@@@SP
)@@G@@               TRANSFER TO BACK2    @D@@@@ BACK1         <VARIABLE> = <VSQ
)@@G@@ARIABLE> + <INCREMENT>  @C@@@@ BACK2         WHENEVER .NOT.<END CONDITIOSR
)@@G@@N>    @A@@@@                (ANY STATEMENTS)    @A@@@@ <LABEL>       TRASS
)@@G@@NSFER TO BACK1    @A@@@@               END OF CONDITIONAL   @[@@@@      ST
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  5. 5. 2. 3.   THE 'FOR VALUES OF' ITERATSU
)@@G@@ION.  @[@@@@      @D@@@@       A THIRD FORM OF ITERATION IS AVAILABLE INSV
)@@G@@ MAD: @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THROUGH <LABEL>,FOR VALUES OF <VARIABLE>=SW
)@@G@@<VAL1>,<VAL2>, ...@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THIS WILL LOOP N TIMES, WHERESX
)@@G@@ N IS THE NUMBER OF <VAL(K)>. @F@@@@ THE FIRST ITERATION WILL SET <VARIASY
)@@G@@BLE> = <VAL1>, THE SECOND     @F@@@@ ITERATION WILL SET <VARIABLE> = <VASZ
)@@G@@L2>, ETC.  LOOP OVERHEAD TIME @F@@@@ IS NOT REALLY OF ANY CONCERN BECAUSTA
)@@G@@E THE 'FOR VALUES OF' LOOP IS @C@@@@ NEVER USED FOR LARGE NUMBERS OF ITETB
)@@G@@RATIONS.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBETC
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          5- 14@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@TD
)@@G@@      @C@@@@  5. 5. 3.   NESTING OF ITERATION STATEMENTS    @[@@@@      TE
)@@G@@@G@@@@       ITERATION STATEMENTS MAY BE NESTED TO A DEPTH OF 50 DEEP.  TF
)@@G@@A     @F@@@@ NEST IS DEFINED AS ONE ITERATION STATEMENT COMPLETELY WITHITG
)@@G@@N THE @G@@@@ RANGE OF ANOTHER.  IF [X] DENOTES THE SET OF STATEMENTS WITTH
)@@G@@HIN THE     @F@@@@ SCOPE OF AN ITERATION, AND [Y] THE SET OF STATEMENTS TI
)@@G@@WITHIN ANO- @F@@@@ THER ITERATION, AND IF ANY ELEMENT OF [Y] IS CONTAINETJ
)@@G@@D IN [X],   @F@@@@ THEN ALL ELEMENTS OF [Y] MUST BE CONTAINED IN [X].  MTK
)@@G@@ORE THAN ONE@D@@@@ ITERATION STATEMENT MAY END ON THE SAME STATEMENT.   TL
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       TO ASSIST THE USER IN DIAGNOSING PRTM
)@@G@@OGRAM ILLS, AND AS A    @F@@@@ VISUAL AID FOR THOSE NOT FAMILIAR WITH THTN
)@@G@@E PROGRAM, THE ITERATION@F@@@@ NESTING DEPTH IS ALWAYS PRINTED AS A TWO-TO
)@@G@@DIGIT NUMBER IN THE     @#@@@@ LEFT-HAND MARGIN.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      TP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@            TQ
)@@G@@   =========@[@@@@      @D@@@@               THROUGH RABBIT, FOR M = 6,1TR
)@@G@@,FP(M).GT.0 @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@      TS
)@@G@@         .  @^@@@@ RABBIT        CONTINUE @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@TT
)@@G@@               BOOLEAN A,B,C  @D@@@@               THROUGH TRUTH, FOR VATU
)@@G@@LUES OF A = 0B,1B @D@@@@               THROUGH TRUTH, FOR VALUES OF B = TV
)@@G@@0B,1B @D@@@@               THROUGH TRUTH, FOR VALUES OF C = 0B,1B @B@@@@TW
)@@G@@               TABLE = A.AND.B.THEN.C.OR.D@B@@@@               PRINT RESTX
)@@G@@ULTS A,B,C,TABLE  @^@@@@ TRUTH         CONTINUE @[@@@@      @[@@@@      TY
)@@G@@@C@@@@               THROUGH END, FOR I = 1,1,I.G.N   @^@@@@            TZ
)@@G@@   X(I) = 0 @^@@@@ END           CONTINUE @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@UA
)@@G@@               THROUGH HOLE, WITH INDEX J = 1,N @#@@@@               .  UB
)@@G@@@#@@@@               .  @#@@@@               .  @^@@@@ HOLE          CONUC
)@@G@@TINUE @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971UD
)@@G@@ VERSION)          6-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6.  UE
)@@G@@ INPUT/OUTPUT STATEMENTS@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@      UF
)@@G@@ IT WOULD BE FRUSTRATING, INDEED, IF AFTER THE LABORIOUS    @G@@@@ CALCUUG
)@@G@@LATION OF SOME ANSWER, ONE HAD NO MEANS OF PRINTING IT OUT FOR    @F@@@@UH
)@@G@@ EXAMINATION.  EQUALLY WOEFUL WOULD BE A PROGRAM WITH NO WAY OF   @G@@@@UI
)@@G@@ ACCESSING RAW DATA.  THE INPUT/OUTPUT STATEMENTS RECOGNIZED BY RALPH   UJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PROVIDE THE PROGRAMMER WITH CHANNELS THROUGH WHICH INFORMATION PAUK
)@@G@@SSES  @ @@@@ TO AND FROM HIS PROGRAM.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       FOR PUL
)@@G@@URPOSES OF DESCRIPTION, LET US GROUP ALL INPUT/OUTPUT INTO  @#@@@@ THREEUM
)@@G@@ CATEGORIES:@[@@@@      @F@@@@       1)  BASIC I/O (CARD-READER, PRINTERUN
)@@G@@, AND PUNCH).  SOMETIMES@A@@@@           CALLED 'UNIT RECORD' I/O.@[@@@@UO
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       2)  FILE I/O.  REFERENCE TAPE AND DRUM FILES.  MOST LUP
)@@G@@ARGE-SCALE  @ @@@@           I/O IS FILE I/O.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      UQ
)@@G@@ 3)  COMMUNICATIONS (REAL-TIME) I/O.  TRANSMIT DATA TO COMPUTER   @H@@@@UR
)@@G@@           OPERATOR, TO OTHER TELETYPES, TO COMPUTER-CONTROLLED MACHINESUS
)@@G@@,     @#@@@@           ETC.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       RALPH HAS NO DIREUT
)@@G@@CT PROVISIONS FOR REAL-TIME I/O--IT IS MENTIONED@A@@@@ MOSTLY FOR THE SAUU
)@@G@@KE OF CONTRAST.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  6. 1.   BAUV
)@@G@@SIC (UNIT RECORD) I/O   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IN BLOCK FOUW
)@@G@@RM, MOST PROGRAMS CAN BE CONSIDERED AS SOME VARIANT   @ @@@@ OF THE FOLLUX
)@@G@@OWING SCHEME:     @[@@@@      @ @@@@       1)  READ A DATA CARD   @C@@@@UY
)@@G@@       2)  CALCULATE RESULTS BASED ON THE DATA  @A@@@@       3)  PRINT OUZ
)@@G@@UT THE ANSWERS    @ @@@@       4)  GO BACK TO STEP 1  @[@@@@      @F@@@@VA
)@@G@@       STEP 1) CAN BE FURTHER SPLIT INTO TWO DISTINCT PHASES:     @[@@@@VB
)@@G@@      @B@@@@       1)  A)  FIND THE DATA ON THE CARD  @E@@@@           BVC
)@@G@@)  AFTER FINDING THE DATA, CONVERT IT FROM ITS  @G@@@@               EXTVD
)@@G@@ERNAL FORMAT INTO A BINARY NUMBER AND STORE IT INTO   @A@@@@            VE
)@@G@@   A PROGRAM VARIABLE.  @[@@@@      @B@@@@       STEP 3) CAN BE SIMILARLVF
)@@G@@Y SEPARATED:@[@@@@      @F@@@@       3)  A)  CONVERT THE BINARY PROGRAM VG
)@@G@@VARIABLES TO DIGITS,    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RAVH
)@@G@@LPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          6-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@VI
)@@G@@      @B@@@@               LETTERS, AND PUNCTUATION.  @G@@@@           BVJ
)@@G@@)  CAUSE THE CONVERTED DIGITS TO BE PRINTED IN APPROPRIATE  @C@@@@      VK
)@@G@@         PLACES ON THE OUTPUT DEVICE.     @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 1. 1.  VL
)@@G@@ FREE-FORMAT I/O  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE SIMPLEST METHOD FOR READIVM
)@@G@@NG AND PRINTING SMALL AMOUNTS OF    @F@@@@ DATA IS CALLED FREE-FORMAT INVN
)@@G@@PUT/OUTPUT--SO CALLED BECAUSE THERE @F@@@@ IS NO FIXED FORMAT TO WHICH TVO
)@@G@@HE DATA MUST CONFORM ON INPUT, AND  @F@@@@ NO FIXED FORMAT TO WHICH IT DVP
)@@G@@OES CONFORM ON OUTPUT.  FREE-FORMAT @A@@@@ I/O IS INVALUABLE IN TWO DOMAVQ
)@@G@@INS:  @[@@@@      @E@@@@       1)  PROGRAMS WHICH NEED ONLY A SMALL AMOUVR
)@@G@@NT OF DATA. @D@@@@       2)  PROGRAMS DESIGNED TO RUN ON A TELETYPE.    VS
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHEN READING ONLY A FEW NUMBERS AS DATA, IT IS VT
)@@G@@INCONVENIENT TO   @E@@@@ SET UP ELABORATE DATA FORMAT SPECIFICATIONS FORVU
)@@G@@ THE DATA.  @^@@@@ IT IS MUCH EASIER TO   @F@@@@ READ THE DATA VIA THE FVV
)@@G@@REE-FORMAT I/O STATEMENTS AND COMPUTE.    @E@@@@ SIMILARLY, WHEN OPERATIVW
)@@G@@NG ON A TELETYPE, IT IS VERY PAINFUL@F@@@@ TO ADHERE TO COLUMN AND FORMAVX
)@@G@@T RESTRICTIONS, SO THAT FREE-FORMAT @ @@@@ I/O IS ALMOST A NECESSITY.   VY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@  6. 1. 1. 1.   THE 'INPUT' AND 'DISPLAY' STATEMENTS  VZ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE 'INPUT' AND 'DISPLAY' STATEMENTS PROVIDE THWA
)@@G@@E RALPH USER WITH @D@@@@ A MEANS OF READING SMALL AMOUNTS OF DATA AND PRWB
)@@G@@INTING@F@@@@ ANSWERS WITH AS LITTLE PAIN AS POSSIBLE.  IDEAL FOR THE BEGWC
)@@G@@INNER,@E@@@@ THEY ARE PATTERNED AFTER THE I/O FEATURES DESIGNED FOR THE WD
)@@G@@@ @@@@ 'BASIC' PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE.@[@@@@      @G@@@@       TO READ IN WE
)@@G@@A NUMBER OR NUMBERS VIA THE 'INPUT' STATEMENT, ONE    @D@@@@ SIMPLY WRITWF
)@@G@@ES 'INPUT' FOLLOWED BY THE VARIABLE LIST: @[@@@@      @^@@@@       INPUTWG
)@@G@@ A,B,I,K(I) @[@@@@      @G@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE, THE STATEMENT ABOVE WILL CAUWH
)@@G@@SE VALUES FOR THE VARIABLES   @G@@@@ 'A', 'B', 'I', AND THE I'TH ELEMENTWI
)@@G@@ OF THE ARRAY 'K' TO BE READ FROM   @#@@@@ A DATA CARD.     @F@@@@ THE NWJ
)@@G@@UMBERS ON THE DATA CARD ARE SEPARATED BY COMMAS, BUT ASIDE  @G@@@@ OF THWK
)@@G@@IS RESTRICTION THEY NEED NOT HAVE ANY PARTICULAR FORMAT.  THERE   @G@@@@WL
)@@G@@ MAY BE INTERVENING BLANKS, DECIMAL POINTS OR NOT AS THE USER SEES FIT, WM
)@@G@@@F@@@@ ETC.  THE NUMBERS WILL BE CONVERTED TO THE PROPER MODE REGARDLESSWN
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OF HOW THEY ARE TYPED:  A VALUE OF 5.2 SPECIFIED FOR AN INTEGER  WO
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VARIABLE WILL BE TRANSMITTED AS AN INTEGER VALUE OF 5, WHILE LEAVWP
)@@G@@ING   @F@@@@ THE DECIMAL POINT FROM A FLOATING-POINT NUMBER WILL NOT CAUWQ
)@@G@@SE    @B@@@@ IT TO BE TRANSMITTED AS AN INTEGER, ETC. @[@@@@      @[@@@@WR
)@@G@@      @#@@@@       EXAMPLES:  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WWS
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          6-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      WT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @#@@@@       INPUT A,B  WU
)@@G@@@B@@@@                                       2,3@C@@@@                  WV
)@@G@@                     4.,6.1   @C@@@@                                    WW
)@@G@@   1E-2,1E+2@[@@@@      @^@@@@       INPUT I,A(I)     @B@@@@            WX
)@@G@@                           2,4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  6. 1. 2.  WY
)@@G@@ DATA FORMAT SPECIFICATIONS   @[@@@@      @H@@@@       STEP (1A) IN 6.1 WZ
)@@G@@ABOVE DICTATES THAT THE PROGRAM MUST FIND THE DATA    @F@@@@ ON THE PUNCXA
)@@G@@HED CARD.  AT FIRST GLANCE, THIS DOES NOT SEEM TO BE A@F@@@@ DIFFICULTY,XB
)@@G@@ IN FACT, THE 'INPUT' STATEMENT SIMPLY SEARCHES FOR   @G@@@@ DATA ON THEXC
)@@G@@ CARD AND INPUTS IT AS DIRECTED.  THIS SEARCHING, HOWEVER,  @G@@@@ TAKESXD
)@@G@@ TIME, AND REQUIRES THAT SEPARATOR CHARACTERS (COMMAS) BE USED    @F@@@@XE
)@@G@@ TO SPECIFY THE END OF ONE NUMBER AND THE BEGINNING OF THE NEXT.  @F@@@@XF
)@@G@@ SUPPOSE THAT ALPHABETIC DATA WERE TO BE INPUT, DATA WHICH WOULD  @G@@@@XG
)@@G@@ INCLUDE COMMAS?  WHAT IF ONE WISHES TO USE ALL 80 COLUMNS OF A CARD    XH
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OR TELETYPE LINE TO CONTAIN DATA?  SOME AGREEMENT MUST BE REACHEDXI
)@@G@@@F@@@@ BETWEEN PROGRAMMER AND PROGRAM AS TO WHAT KIND OF INFORMATION IS XJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ EXPECTED, WHICH CARD COLUMNS CONTAIN THE INFORMATION, ETC.  ENTERXK
)@@G@@@^@@@@ THE 'FORMAT' STATEMENT.@C@@@@  6. 1. 2. 1.   INPUT DATA FORMAT DEXL
)@@G@@SCRIPTION   @G@@@@       AS AN EXAMPLE OF THE TYPE OF INFORMATION WHICH XM
)@@G@@MAY BE PUT INTO   @G@@@@ A FORMAT DEFINITION STATEMENT (CALLED A FORMAT XN
)@@G@@STATEMENT FOR SHORT),   @G@@@@ CONSIDER THE FOLLOWING VERBAL DESCRIPTIONXO
)@@G@@ OF AN INPUT DATA FORMAT.     @[@@@@      @B@@@@       THE FIRST SIX COLXP
)@@G@@UMNS ARE BLANK.   @G@@@@       THE NEXT THREE COLUMNS CONTAIN A RIGHT-JUXQ
)@@G@@STIFIED INTEGER NUMBER  @D@@@@       IGNORE ALL DATA UP TO AND INCLUDINGXR
)@@G@@ COLUMN 19  @F@@@@       FIND A 10-DIGIT (OR SMALLER) FLOATING-POINT NUMXS
)@@G@@BER, WITH   @D@@@@       FOUR DECIMAL PLACES, STARTING IN COLUMN 20     XT
)@@G@@@^@@@@       SKIP SIX COLUMNS @F@@@@       FIND AN ALPHANUMERIC ITEM WHIXU
)@@G@@CH CONSISTS OF 4 CHARACTERS.  @[@@@@      @I@@@@       IF ALL DATA FORMAXV
)@@G@@TS HAD TO BE WRITTEN THAT WAY, MOST FORTRAN PROGRAMMERS     @G@@@@ WOULDXW
)@@G@@ LONG SINCE HAVE BEEN PRIME CANDIDATES FOR A LOONEY BIN.  THE     @G@@@@XX
)@@G@@ RALPH SYSTEM (LIKE ALL FORTRAN SYSTEMS) ALLOWS A SHORTHAND METHOD OF   XY
)@@G@@@F@@@@ WRITING DATA FORMAT DESCRIPTIONS.  IN THIS SHORTHAND (WHICH WAS  XZ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ DEVELOPED FOR THE IBM 704 COMPUTER FOR USE WITH FORTRAN 1), THE  YA
)@@G@@@D@@@@ ABOVE DESCRIPTIVE PARAGRAPH WOULD BE REDUCED TO:     @[@@@@      YB
)@@G@@@ @@@@       (6X,I3,T20,F10.4,6X,A4)@[@@@@      @G@@@@       ANALYTICALLYC
)@@G@@Y FROM THIS EXAMPLE, THIS SHORTHAND CONSISTS OF A     @E@@@@ STRING OF CYD
)@@G@@ODES SEPARATED BY COMMAS, WITH THE ENTIRE STRING@F@@@@ ENCLOSED IN PARENYE
)@@G@@THESES.  THE COMPLETE STRUCTURE IS EXACTLY THAT:@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDYF
)@@G@@E TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          6-  4@[@@@@YG
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ A STRING OF FIELD DESCRIPTORS SEPARYH
)@@G@@ATED BY COMMAS.  EACH DESCRIPTOR,   @F@@@@ SUCH AS 'F10.4' OR '6X', IS CYI
)@@G@@ALLED A 'DATA FORMAT SPECIFIER', OR @G@@@@ SIMPLY A 'SPECIFIER'.  THUS, YJ
)@@G@@TO WRITE A DATA FORMAT DESCRIPTION SO     @F@@@@ THAT HE CAN READ (OR PRYK
)@@G@@INT) DATA, ONE SIMPLY ASSEMBLES A STRING  @G@@@@ OF FORMAT SPECIFIERS WHYL
)@@G@@ICH DESCRIBE THE EXPECTED FORMAT OF THE DATA.   @G@@@@ THE DESCRIPTION PYM
)@@G@@ROGRESSES FROM LEFT TO RIGHT STARTING IN COLUMN 1,    @G@@@@ WITH EACH SYN
)@@G@@PECIFIER DESCRIBING A 'FIELD' IN WHICH A SINGLE ITEM IS     @#@@@@ TO BEYO
)@@G@@ FOUND.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AN IMPORTANT POINT ABOUT SPECIFIERSYP
)@@G@@ IS THEIR ONE-TO-ONE RELATION-@F@@@@ SHIP MATCHING THEM WITH DATA ITEMS:YQ
)@@G@@  EXACTLY ONE ITEM (NUMBER OR @G@@@@ WORD) IS DESCRIBED BY ONE SPECIFIERYR
)@@G@@.  FOR EXAMPLE, IF WE ARE EXPECTING @G@@@@ TEN NUMBERS OF TWO DIGITS EACYS
)@@G@@H, THE SPECIFIER CANNOT BE 'I20' (TWENTY  @G@@@@ COLUMNS OF INTEGERS), BYT
)@@G@@UT MUST BE I2,I2,I2,I2,I2,I2,I2,I2,I2,I2.  FOR  @G@@@@ THE SAKE OF PROGRYU
)@@G@@AMMER SANITY, ONE MAY ABBREVIATE SAME BY PUTTING A    @G@@@@ MULTIPLIER YV
)@@G@@IN FRONT OF IT:  10I2.  NOTE, HOWEVER, THAT IN EITHER CASE  @D@@@@ A SEPYW
)@@G@@ARATE SPECIFIER IS PROVIDED FOR EACH NUMBER.    @[@@@@      @H@@@@      YX
)@@G@@ NOT ALL SPECIFIERS DESCRIBE NUMBERS--SOME DESCRIBE A LACK OF NUMBERS,  YY
)@@G@@@G@@@@ I.E. A SPACE TO BE IGNORED.  THUS, THE 'X' SPECIFIER IS A NON-DATYZ
)@@G@@A     @G@@@@ SPECIFIER, USED TO IGNORE UNWANTED COLUMNS.  ALL AVAILABLE ZA
)@@G@@SPECIFIERS, @G@@@@ BOTH DATA-DESCRIBING AND DATA-IGNORING, ARE DOCUMENTEZB
)@@G@@D IN SECTION A.B. @[@@@@      @C@@@@  6. 1. 2. 2.   OUTPUT DATA FORMAT DZC
)@@G@@ESCRIPTION  @[@@@@      @H@@@@       THE SAME SHORTHAND NOTATION AS DESCZD
)@@G@@RIBED ABOVE FOR INPUT IS USED FOR   @H@@@@ OUTPUT DATA FORMAT DESCRIPTIOZE
)@@G@@N.  ITS MEANING IS SLIGHTLY DIFFERENT:  FOR     @G@@@@ EXAMPLE, THE SAMEZF
)@@G@@ FORMAT DESCRIPTION USED IN THE PREVIOUS SECTION:     @[@@@@      @ @@@@ZG
)@@G@@       (6X,I3,T20,F10.4,6X,A4)@[@@@@      @F@@@@ MAY BE USED AS AN OUTPUZH
)@@G@@T DATA FORMAT DESCRIPTION.  EACH SPECIFIER@G@@@@ DICTATES NOT WHERE TO FZI
)@@G@@IND A NUMBER, BUT WHERE TO PUT IT:  I.E. INTO   @F@@@@ WHICH COLUMNS ON ZJ
)@@G@@THE PRINTED PAGE (OR PUNCHED CARD) IS THE EDITED@H@@@@ NUMBER TO BE PLACZK
)@@G@@ED.  THUS, THE SPECIFIER 'I3' MEANS 'PRINT A RIGHT-JUSTIFIED@A@@@@ INTEGZL
)@@G@@ER UP TO THREE DIGITS LONG.'  @G@@@@ THERE IS AN IMPLICIT PROMISE MADE WZM
)@@G@@ITH AN OUTPUT SPECIFIER THAT THE    @G@@@@ PROGRAM WILL NEVER PROVIDE A ZN
)@@G@@NUMBER WHICH IS TOO LARGE TO FIT INTO     @G@@@@ THE REQUESTED NUMBER OFZO
)@@G@@ COLUMNS.  IF A FORMAT SPECIFIER PROVIDES, FOR  @F@@@@ EXAMPLE, FOR A 4-ZP
)@@G@@COLUMN WORD, AND THE PROGRAM ATTEMPTS TO PRINT  @G@@@@ '757332' THROUGH ZQ
)@@G@@THAT SPECIFIER, THE END RESULT WILL NOT BE '7573'     @G@@@@ OR '7332' BZR
)@@G@@UT '****'.  THE ASTERISKS ARE PRINTED WHENEVER A NUMBER     @B@@@@ IS TOZS
)@@G@@O LARGE FOR THE FORMAT SPECIFIER.   @[@@@@      @A@@@@  6. 1. 3.   FORMAZT
)@@G@@TTED INPUT/OUTPUT.@[@@@@      @G@@@@       FORMATTED I/O COMBINES A FORMZU
)@@G@@AT STATEMENT WITH AN I/O STATEMENT. @F@@@@ TO READ, PRINT, OR PUNCH CARDZV
)@@G@@S VIA FORMATTED I/O, ONE WRITES:    @[@@@@      @ @@@@       READ <FORMAZW
)@@G@@T>,<LIST>   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEZX
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          6-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@ZY
)@@G@@       PRINT <FORMAT>,<LIST>  @ @@@@       PUNCH <FORMAT>,<LIST>  @[@@@@ZZ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       IN EACH CASE, <FORMAT> IS A FORMAT STATEMENT NUMBER OAA
)@@G@@R A   @F@@@@ VARIABLE CONTAINING FORMAT INFORMATION, AND <LIST> IS A LISAB
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ OF VARIABLES AS DESCRIBED IN SECTION X.Y.  IN THE CASE OF TAC
)@@G@@HE 'READ'   @G@@@@ STATEMENT, A CARD WILL BE READ AND THE DATA FROM THE AD
)@@G@@CARD UNPACKED     @G@@@@ ACCORDING TO THE <FORMAT> AND STORED SEQUENTIALAE
)@@G@@LY IN THE VARIABLES     @G@@@@ NAMED IN <LIST>.  FOR THE 'PRINT' AND 'PUAF
)@@G@@NCH' STATEMENTS, THE DATA     @F@@@@ CONTAINED IN THE VARIABLES SPECIFIEAG
)@@G@@D BY <LIST> WILL BE COMPOSED  @E@@@@ ACCORDING TO <FORMAT> AND SENT TO TAH
)@@G@@HE PRINTER OR PUNCH.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@           EXAMPLEAI
)@@G@@S:    @^@@@@           ========     @[@@@@      @ @@@@ (DATA CARD: '1234AJ
)@@G@@.56789')    @[@@@@      @^@@@@       READ 1,A,B,C     @ @@@@ 1     FORMAAK
)@@G@@T(I3,F4.2,I3)     @[@@@@      @B@@@@               SETS A=123, B=4.56, CAL
)@@G@@=789  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@       READ 2,J,K,A(J,K)@^@@@@ 2    AM
)@@G@@ FORMAT(2I1,F8.5) @[@@@@      @C@@@@               SETS J=1, K=2, A(1,2)AN
)@@G@@ = 34.56789 @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@       READ 3,I   @^@@@@ 3    AO
)@@G@@ FORMAT(8X,I2)    @^@@@@               SETS I=89@B@@@@ (NOW ASSUME A=1, AP
)@@G@@B=89, C=6.63, D='DOG')  @[@@@@      @^@@@@       PRINT 4,A,B,C,D  @[@@@@AQ
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   AR
)@@G@@       7-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  7.         FORMAAS
)@@G@@T(1X,I1,I2,F4.2,A3)     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      AT
)@@G@@@B@@@@               PRODUCES '   *  6.6DO'     @[@@@@ ===  @[@@@@*****^AU
)@@G@@@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)         AV
)@@G@@ 8-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  8.   SUBROUTINE STATEMAW
)@@G@@ENTS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       SUBROUTINE STATEMAX
)@@G@@ENTS ENABLE THE USER TO DEFINE AND CONTROL@F@@@@ FUNCTIONS AND SUBROUTINAY
)@@G@@ES.  THERE ARE FOUR BASIC KINDS OF FUNC-  @F@@@@ TIONS, TWO OF WHICH AREAZ
)@@G@@ PREDEFINED BY THE COMPILER.  THESE ARE   @[@@@@      @B@@@@       (1)  BA
)@@G@@EXTERNAL SUBROUTINES/FUNCTIONS@B@@@@       (2)  INTERNAL SUBROUTINES/FUNBB
)@@G@@CTIONS@A@@@@       (3)  INTRINSIC 'FUNCTIONS'   @ @@@@       (4)  GENERIBC
)@@G@@C FUNCTIONS @[@@@@      @F@@@@       TYPES (3) AND (4) ARE PREDEFINED BYBD
)@@G@@ THE COMPILER, WHILE    @C@@@@ TYPES (1) AND (2) MAY BE DEFINED BY THE UBE
)@@G@@SER.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE RULES FOR THE NAME OF A FBF
)@@G@@UNCTION ARE EXACTLY THE SAME AS     @G@@@@ THOSE FOR THE NAME OF A VARIABG
)@@G@@BLE:  FROM 1 TO 6 CHARACTERS FROM THE     @G@@@@ SET [A,B,...,Z, 0,1,...BH
)@@G@@,9,^], AND BEGINNING WITH A LETTER.  IF THE     @F@@@@ NAME OF A FUNCTIOBI
)@@G@@N IS THE SAME AS ONE OF THE IMPLICIT OR GENERIC @F@@@@ FUNCTIONS, THEN IBJ
)@@G@@T MUST BE TYPED 'ABNORMAL' OR 'EXTERNAL' TO     @F@@@@ CIRCUMVENT THE NOBK
)@@G@@RMAL COMPILER ACTION OF CALLING THE INTRINSIC OR@#@@@@ GENERIC FUNCTION.BL
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  8. 1.   EXTERNAL SUBROUTINES@[@@@@      BM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       AN EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE IS A SEPARATE, INDEPENDEBN
)@@G@@NT COMPILA- @G@@@@ TION, REQUIRING A SEPARATE CALL TO THE COMPILER.  IT BO
)@@G@@MAY THUS HAVE     @F@@@@ TOTALLY INDEPENDENT VARIABLES WITH THE SAME NAMBP
)@@G@@E.  AN EXTERNAL   @F@@@@ SUBROUTINE CAN COMMUNICATE WITH THE CALLING PROBQ
)@@G@@GRAM ONLY THROUGH @F@@@@ ITS ARGUMENT LIST AND THROUGH COMMON STORAGE.  BR
)@@G@@EXTERNAL SUBROU-  @F@@@@ TINES ARE LINKED BY NAME TO THE CALLING PROGRAMBS
)@@G@@ BY THE COLLECTOR @F@@@@ WHEN A '@MAP' OR '@XQT' CONTROL STATEMENT IS ENBT
)@@G@@COUNTERED.  AN    @G@@@@ EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE MAY CONTAIN FOR ITS OWN USEBU
)@@G@@ ONE OR MORE INTER-     @F@@@@ NAL SUBROUTINES, WHICH ARE INTERNAL TO THBV
)@@G@@E EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE STATEMENT DECLARINGBW
)@@G@@ AN EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE MUST BE THE @F@@@@ FIRST STATEMENT IN THE PROGRABX
)@@G@@M WHICH IS NOT OF THE 'COMPILER     @#@@@@ CONTROL' VARIETY.@[@@@@      BY
)@@G@@@G@@@@       SOME EXAMPLES OF EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE AND FUNCTION DEFINITIOBZ
)@@G@@NS    @D@@@@ FOLLOW AT THE END OF THIS SECTION.  THE GENERAL FORM @ @@@@CA
)@@G@@ DEFINITION STRUCTURE IS:     @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@      CB
)@@G@@ SUBROUTINE <NAME>@D@@@@       SUBROUTINE <NAME> (<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGCC
)@@G@@N>)   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971CD
)@@G@@ VERSION)          8-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@      CE
)@@G@@ FUNCTION <NAME>(<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     CF
)@@G@@@A@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION <NAME>.    @D@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTIONCG
)@@G@@ (<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)   @E@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION <NAME>.(<ARCH
)@@G@@G1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN MAD, THECI
)@@G@@ BODY OF THE SUBROUTINE DETERMINES WHETHER IT IS@F@@@@ A FUNCTION OR A SCJ
)@@G@@UBROUTINE.  IN FORTRAN, ONE MUST SPECIFY IN     @G@@@@ ADVANCE, VIA A 'FCK
)@@G@@UNCTION' OR 'SUBROUTINE' STATEMENT.  OPERATIONAL-     @F@@@@ LY, THE ONLCL
)@@G@@Y DIFFERENCE BETWEEN A FUNCTION AND A SUBROUTINE IS   @F@@@@ THAT A FUNCCM
)@@G@@TION HAS THE ABILITY TO RETURN A VALUE ASSOCIATED WITH@C@@@@ ITS NAME, WCN
)@@G@@HILE A SUBROUTINE DOES NOT.  THUS   @[@@@@      @#@@@@       X = P(X,Y) CO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@ REFERENCES A FUNCTION P WITH ARGUMENTS X AND Y, BUT  CP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@       CALL P(X,Y)@[@@@@      @G@@@@ REFERENCES A SUBRCQ
)@@G@@OUTINE P WITH ARGUMENTS X AND Y.  IN EITHER CASE,     @F@@@@ THE VALUE OCR
)@@G@@F EITHER ARGUMENT MIGHT BE CHANGED; THIS MIGHT BE     @F@@@@ CONSTRUED ACS
)@@G@@S 'RETURNING A VALUE', BUT FOR THE PURPOSES OF THIS   @F@@@@ DISCUSSION CT
)@@G@@IS NOT.  A FUNCTION MAY BE REFERENCED AS A SUBROUTINE,@G@@@@ BUT A SUBROCU
)@@G@@UTINE MAY NOT BE REFERENCED AS A FUNCTION.  NOTICE THAT     @F@@@@ THE NCV
)@@G@@AME OF A FUNCTION OR SUBROUTINE IN MAD IS ALWAYS FOLLOWED BY@]@@@@ A PERCW
)@@G@@IOD.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       <NAME> IS THE NAME BY WHICH THE SUBROUTINCX
)@@G@@E OR FUNCTION IS TO     @F@@@@ BE ERENCED.  THE DUMMY ARGUMENTS <ARGI> ACY
)@@G@@RE THE SYMBOLIC NAMES BY@F@@@@ WHICH ONE REFERENCES THE CALLING ARGUMENTCZ
)@@G@@S, OR ELSE (FORTRAN     @F@@@@ ONLY) A SPECIAL SYMBOL (*) OR (&) DENOTINDA
)@@G@@G AN ALTERNATE RETURN   @F@@@@ (SEE SECTION 7.3.2). THUS, INSIDE A FORTRDB
)@@G@@AN SUBROUTINE DEFINED BY@#@@@@ THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      @ @@@@      DC
)@@G@@ SUBROUTINE HDIAG(A,B)  @[@@@@      @B@@@@ THEN IF IT IS CALLED BY THE SDD
)@@G@@TATEMENT,   @[@@@@      @ @@@@       CALL HDIAG(BB,X+Y)     @[@@@@      DE
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THE DUMMY ARGUMENT 'A' STANDS FOR BB, AND THE DUMMY ARGUMENT 'B' DF
)@@G@@@E@@@@ STANDS FOR X+Y.  NOTE THAT IT WOULD BE TOTALLY MEANINGLESS,@F@@@@DG
)@@G@@ ALTHOUGH SYNTACTICALLY LEGAL, TO CHANGE THE VALUE OF THE DUMMY   @F@@@@DH
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT 'B', AS BY REFERENCING IT ON THE LEFT SIDE OF AN EQUALS @F@@@@DI
)@@G@@ SIGN:  ASSIGNING A VALUE TO THE SUM OF X AND Y DOES NOTHING DE-  @]@@@@DJ
)@@G@@ FINABLE.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       FOR COMPATIBILITY WITH OTHER VERSIODK
)@@G@@NS OF FORTRAN, AN ARGU- @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RADL
)@@G@@LPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@DM
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ MENT IN A 'SUBROUTINE' STATEMENT MAY BE ENCLOSED IN SLASHESDN
)@@G@@:     @ @@@@ /<ARG>/.  THEY ARE IGNORED.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF THDO
)@@G@@E CALLING ARGUMENT IS AN ARRAY NAME WITHOUT CONSTANT  @F@@@@ SUBSCRIPT, DP
)@@G@@AND THE DUMMY ARGUMENT IN THE FUNCTION DEFINITION IS  @F@@@@ NEVER REFERDQ
)@@G@@ENCED WITH A SUBSCRIPT, THEN THE SUBROUTINE, HAVING NO@F@@@@ WAY OF KNOWDR
)@@G@@ING THAT IT WAS BEING CALLED WITH AN ENTIRE ARRAY AS A@F@@@@ CALLING ARGDS
)@@G@@UMENT, WILL PICK UP AND USE THE ADDRESS PROVIDED.  IF @F@@@@ THE CALLINGDT
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT ARRAY HAS NO ZERO ELEMENT, NO HARM IS DONE, @F@@@@ FOR THE BASDU
)@@G@@E OF THE ARRAY IS ARRAY(1), WHICH IS TRANSMITTED.  IF,@F@@@@ HOWEVER, THDV
)@@G@@E CALLING ARRAY DOES HAVE A ZERO ELEMENT, THE ADDRESS @G@@@@ TRANSMITTEDDW
)@@G@@ WILL STILL BE ARRAY(1), WHICH IS NO LONGER THE BASE OF     @F@@@@ THE ADX
)@@G@@RRAY.  THUS, THE UNSUBSCRIPTED NAME OF THE ARRAY WILL STAND @F@@@@ FOR ADY
)@@G@@RRAY(0) IN THE CALLING PROGRAM AND ARRAY(1) IN THE SUBROU-  @F@@@@ TINE,DZ
)@@G@@ WITH POSSIBLY DISASTROUS RESULTS.  THE PROGRAMMER MAY AVOID@F@@@@ THIS EA
)@@G@@DIFFICULTY BY ENSURING THAT EITHER (1) A CONSTANT SUBSCRIPT @F@@@@ IS ALEB
)@@G@@WAYS INCLUDED ON ARRAY NAMES WHEN CALLING A SUBROUTINE WHICH@F@@@@ PLANSEC
)@@G@@ TO USE THEM AS UNDIMENSIONED VARIABLES, OR (2) A SUBROUTINE@F@@@@ WHICHED
)@@G@@ EXPECTS TO BE CALLED WITH AN UNSUBSCRIPTED ARRAY NAME AS AN@F@@@@ ARGUMEE
)@@G@@ENT ALWAYS DIMENSIONS THE DUMMY ARGUMENT, USES IT WITH SUBS-@#@@@@ CRIPTEF
)@@G@@S, OR BOTH. @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IF THE USER IS NOT EMPLOYING THE ZEEG
)@@G@@RO-ELEMENT FEATURE OF THE     @F@@@@ COMPILER, HE NEED NOT CONCERN HIMSEEH
)@@G@@LF WITH THE ABOVE PARAGRAPH.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE SECOND FORM OEI
)@@G@@F EXTERNAL FUNCTION DECLARATION LISTED FOR@F@@@@ MAD DOES NOT SPECIFY ANEJ
)@@G@@ ENTRY POINT, ONLY AN ARGUMENT LIST.  THIS@G@@@@ ARGUMENT LIST WILL BE TEK
)@@G@@ACKED ONTO ANY SUBSEQUENT 'ENTRY TO' STATE-     @C@@@@ MENT WHICH HAS NOEL
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT LIST OF ITS OWN.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@       EXAMPEM
)@@G@@LES:  @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@      EN
)@@G@@ SUBROUTINE GLOTCH@A@@@@       SUBROUTINE BOOL(I,H,T,S)     @A@@@@      EO
)@@G@@ FUNCTION PSI(ALPHA,/OMEGA/)  @A@@@@       SUBROUTINE SQUARE(R,S,*)     EP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @A@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION GLOTCH.    EQ
)@@G@@@B@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION BOOL.(I,H,T,S)   @B@@@@       EXTERNAL FUER
)@@G@@NCTION PSI.(ALPHA,OMEGA)@B@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION SQUARE.(R,S,T)   ES
)@@G@@@A@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION (B,C,Q,R)  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@ET
)@@G@@  8. 2.   INTERNAL SUBROUTINES@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WEU
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      EV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE IS A SUBROUTINE TOTALLY EW
)@@G@@CONTAINED IN,     @F@@@@ AND REFERENCED ONLY FROM, THE CALLING PROGRAM. EX
)@@G@@ AN INTERNAL SU-  @G@@@@ BROUTINE HAS ACCESS TO ALL VARIABLES IN THE CALEY
)@@G@@LING PROGRAM EXCEPT     @F@@@@ THOSE WHICH MIGHT HAVE THE SAME NAME AS OEZ
)@@G@@NE OF THE DUMMY ARGU-   @G@@@@ MENTS.  IF THE PROGRAMMER AVOIDS DUPLICATFA
)@@G@@ING THE NAME OF A PROGRAM     @F@@@@ VARIABLE WITH THAT OF A DUMMY ARGUMFB
)@@G@@ENT, THEN HE HAS ACCESS TO ALL@B@@@@ OF THE CALLING PROGRAM VARIABLES BYFC
)@@G@@ NAME.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THERE ARE TWO TYPES OF INTERNAL SUBROUTINFD
)@@G@@ES:  THE ONE-LINE @E@@@@ INTERNAL SUBROUTINE, WHICH IS ACTUALLY A FUNCTIFE
)@@G@@ON, AND THE @F@@@@ MULTI-LINE INTERNAL SUBROUTINE.  THE ONE-LINE INTERNAFF
)@@G@@L SUBROUTINE@D@@@@ IS ALSO CALLED AN ARITHMETIC STATEMENT FUNCTION.     FG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  8. 2. 1.   ONE-LINE INTERNAL FUNCTIONS  FH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       A ONE-LINE INTERNAL FUNCTION DEFINITION TAKES TFI
)@@G@@HE FORM:    @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @C@@@@       <NAME>(<ARG1>,...FJ
)@@G@@,<ARGN>) = <EXPRESSION> @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @F@@@@       INTERFK
)@@G@@NAL FUNCTION <NAME>.(<ARG1>,...,<ARGN>) = <EXPRESSION>@[@@@@      @[@@@@FL
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       A FORTRAN ONE-LINE INTERNAL FUNCTION IS DISTINGUISHEDFM
)@@G@@ FROM @F@@@@ AN ORDINARY ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT BY THE REQUIREMENT THAT ITFN
)@@G@@ OCCUR@F@@@@ BEFORE ANY EXECUTABLE STATEMENT IN THE PROGRAM.  THE MAD ONFO
)@@G@@E-LINE@D@@@@ INTERNAL FUNCTION MAY APPEAR ANYWHERE IN THE PROGRAM.@[@@@@FP
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       <NAME> IS DEFINED EXACTLY AS FOR AN EXTERNAL FUNCTIONFQ
)@@G@@ OR   @F@@@@ SUBROUTINE.  THE DUMMY ARGUMENTS <ARGI> ARE DEFINED AS FOR FR
)@@G@@THE   @F@@@@ EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE, WITH THE EXCEPTION THAT THE ALTERNATE-FS
)@@G@@RETURN@F@@@@ ARGUMENTS (*) AND (&) ARE NOT MEANINGFUL.  IF MODE DECLARATFT
)@@G@@IONS  @F@@@@ ARE MADE INVOLVING THE DUMMY ARGUMENTS OF A ONE-LINE INTERNFU
)@@G@@AL    @E@@@@ FUNCTION, THEN THE ARGUMENT NAME CANNOT BE THE SAME AS ANY FV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VARIABLE NAME WHICH HAS OCCURRED PREVIOUS TO THE ONE-LINE INTERNAFW
)@@G@@L     @F@@@@ FUNCTION, ELSE THERE IS AN AMBIGUITY AS TO WHICH SYMBOL IS FX
)@@G@@BEING @F@@@@ REFERENCED BY THE MODE DECLARATION.  ALL MODE DECLARATIONS FY
)@@G@@RE-   @F@@@@ FERENCING DUMMY ARGUMENTS OF A ONE-LINE INTERNAL FUNCTION MFZ
)@@G@@UST   @A@@@@ APPEAR BEFORE THE FUNCTION ITSELF. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      GA
)@@G@@@C@@@@  8. 2. 2.   MULTI-LINE INTERNAL SUBROUTINES    @[@@@@      @[@@@@GB
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       THE STATEMENT DEFINING THE BEGINNING OF A MULTI-LINE GC
)@@G@@INTER-@F@@@@ NAL SUBROUTINE (HEREAFTER REFERRED TO AS SIMPLY AN INTERNALGD
)@@G@@ SU-  @E@@@@ BROUTINE UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED) TAKES THE GENERAL FORM    GE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEGF
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          8-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @]@@@@GG
)@@G@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@       SUBROUTINE <NAME>@D@@@@       SUBROUTINE <NAME>GH
)@@G@@(<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)    @D@@@@       FUNCTION <NAME> (<ARG1>,<ARG2GI
)@@G@@>,...,<ARGN>)     @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @A@@@@       INTERNAL FUGJ
)@@G@@NCTION <NAME>.    @D@@@@       INTERNAL FUNCTION (<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGGK
)@@G@@N>)   @E@@@@       INTERNAL FUNCTION <NAME>.(<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)  GL
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN FORTRAN, AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE IS DETERMINEGM
)@@G@@D BY THE    @E@@@@ POSITION OF THE STATEMENT DECLARING THE SUBROUTINE.  GN
)@@G@@IF A  @G@@@@ 'SUBROUTINE' OR 'FUNCTION' STATEMENT OCCURS AS THE FIRST STGO
)@@G@@ATEMENT     @F@@@@ IN THE COMPILATION WHICH IS NOT A 'COMPILER CONTROL' GP
)@@G@@STATEMENT,  @F@@@@ THEN IT IS TREATED AS AN EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE DEFINITIGQ
)@@G@@ON; OTHER-  @G@@@@ WISE, IT IS TREATED AS AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE DEFINITGR
)@@G@@ION.  IN MAD,     @D@@@@ AS NOTED, ONE MUST SPECIFY 'EXTERNAL' OR 'INTERGS
)@@G@@NAL'. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE BODY OF AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE MAY, AGT
)@@G@@S NOTED ABOVE,    @F@@@@ REFERENCE BY NAME ANY VARIABLE IN THE CALLING PGU
)@@G@@ROGRAM.  IF THE   @F@@@@ NAME OF AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE DUMMY ARGUMENT IGV
)@@G@@S THE SAME AS THE @F@@@@ NAME OF A VARIABLE IN THE CALLING PROGRAM, THENGW
)@@G@@ THE VARIABLE NAME@F@@@@ WILL BE 'DEACTIVATED' IN FAVOR OF THE DUMMY ARGGX
)@@G@@UMENT NAME FOR THE@F@@@@ DURATION OF THE INTERNAL SUBROUTINE.  IF A DUMMGY
)@@G@@Y ARGUMENT OCCURS @F@@@@ ONLY IN AN 'ENTRY' OR 'ENTRY TO' STATEMENT, ANDGZ
)@@G@@ A VARIABLE WITH  @F@@@@ THE SAME NAME IS REFERENCED PRIOR TO THE ENTRY HA
)@@G@@STATEMENT WITHIN  @F@@@@ THE INTERNAL SUBROUTINE, THEN IT WILL BE AS THEHB
)@@G@@ VARIABLE AND NOT @F@@@@ AS THE DUMMY ARGUMENT.  'DEACTIVATION' DOES NOTHC
)@@G@@ OCCUR UNTIL THE  @F@@@@ DUMMY ARGUMENT IS FIRST ENCOUNTERED IN AN ARGUMHD
)@@G@@ENT LIST, AND IS  @#@@@@ NOT RETROACTIVE. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@HE
)@@G@@       EXAMPLES:  @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @ @@@@ ONE-LINE INHF
)@@G@@TERNAL FUNCTIONS: @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @ @@@@       SUM(A,B,C,DHG
)@@G@@) = A+B+C+D @D@@@@       ROOT1(A,B,C) = (-B+SQRT(B**2 - 4*A*C))/(2.*A)  HH
)@@G@@@D@@@@       ROOT2(A,B,C) = (-B-SQRT(B**2 - 4*A*C))/(2.*A)  @[@@@@      HI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @D@@@@       INTERNAL FUNCTION SUM.(A,B,C,HJ
)@@G@@D) = A + B + C + D@E@@@@       INTERNAL FUNCTION GAG.(CHOKE) = SQRT.(.NAHK
)@@G@@BS.CHOKE)   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@ MULTI-LINE INTERNAL SUBROUTINHL
)@@G@@E DEFINITIONS:    @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WHM
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      HN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@       SUBROUTINE MERD  @A@@@@      HO
)@@G@@ SUBROUTINE CLOCK(TIME1,TIME2)@A@@@@       FUNCTION NSQRT(ARG,ERRVAL)   HP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  8. 3.   THE RETURN STATEMENTS     @[@@@@HQ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  8. 3. 1.   NORMAL RETURN    @[@@@@HR
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       WHEN A SUBROUTINE OR FUNCTION IS FINISHED PROCESSING,HS
)@@G@@ AND  @F@@@@ WOULD LIKE TO RETURN CONTROL TO THE CALLING PROGRAM, A RETUHT
)@@G@@RN    @B@@@@ STATEMENT IS USED.  THE GENERAL FORM IS  @[@@@@      @]@@@@HU
)@@G@@ (FORTRAN): @#@@@@       RETURN     @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @^@@@@HV
)@@G@@       FUNCTION RETURN  @ @@@@       FUNCTION RETURN <VALUE>@[@@@@      HW
)@@G@@@F@@@@ IN FORTRAN, IF A VALUE IS TO BE RETURNED VIA THE NAME OF THE     HX
)@@G@@@F@@@@ FUNCTION, THIS FUNCTIONAL VALUE IS SPECIFIED ELSEWHERE IN THE    HY
)@@G@@@F@@@@ PROGRAM BY REFERENCING THE FUNCTION NAME ON THE LEFT SIDE OF AN  HZ
)@@G@@@#@@@@ EQUALS SIGN:     @[@@@@      @#@@@@ <NAME> = <VALUE> @[@@@@      IA
)@@G@@@F@@@@ IN MAD, THE VALUE TO BE RETURNED MUST BE SPECIFIED EXPLICITLY ON IB
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THE RETURN LINE.  THE MODE OF <VALUE> WILL BE CONVERTED TO THE   IC
)@@G@@@F@@@@ DECLARED MODE OF THE FUNCTION.  THE SIMPLE 'FUNCTION RETURN' WITHID
)@@G@@@F@@@@ NO ATTACHED VALUE IS USED WHERE NO RETURNED VALUE IS EXPECTED,   IE
)@@G@@@F@@@@ I.E. WHERE THE REFERENCE WAS AS A SUBROUTINE RATHER THAN AS A    IF
)@@G@@@]@@@@ FUNCTION.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       EITHER FORM OF RETURN STATEMEIG
)@@G@@NT WILL CAUSE EXECUTION TO BE @D@@@@ RESUMED WHERE IT LEFT OFF IN THE CAIH
)@@G@@LLING PROGRAM.    @[@@@@      @B@@@@  8. 3. 2.   ALTERNATE (ERROR) RETURII
)@@G@@NS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       SOMETIMES A SUBROUTINE OR FUNIJ
)@@G@@CTION WILL DETERMINE THAT IT  @G@@@@ HAS ENCOUNTERED AN ERROR CONDITION IK
)@@G@@WHICH FORCES AN ABNORMAL RETURN     @F@@@@ (TO OVERRIDE THE STANDARD ACTIL
)@@G@@ION OF RESUMING EXECUTION WHERE LEFT@F@@@@ OFF).  A STATEMENT IS AVAILABIM
)@@G@@LE WHICH WILL TRANSFER CONTROL TO AN@F@@@@ ARGUMENT IN THE CALLING LIST,IN
)@@G@@ WHICH MUST BE A STATEMENT LABEL!.  @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @[@@@@IO
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   IP
)@@G@@       8-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@       RETURN <INTIQ
)@@G@@EGER EXPRESSION>  @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @^@@@@       ERROR RETURIR
)@@G@@N     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE FORTRAN FORM IS CALLED A IS
)@@G@@'VARIABLE RETURN', AND WILL   @F@@@@ RETURN TO THE I'TH CALLING PARAMETEIT
)@@G@@R, WHERE 'I' IS THE POSITIVE  @F@@@@ VALUE OF <INTEGER EXPRESSION>.  IF IU
)@@G@@<INTEGER EXPRESSION> IS TOO   @G@@@@ LARGE, NEGATIVE, OR INDICATES AN ARIV
)@@G@@GUMENT WHICH IS NOT A STATEMENT     @F@@@@ LABEL, THEN THE PROGRAM WILL IW
)@@G@@BE TERMINATED IN ERROR BY THE EXECU-@F@@@@ TION MONITOR.  IF <INTEGER EXIX
)@@G@@PRESSION> IS 0, THEN THE RETURN WILL@F@@@@ BE MADE INTO A NORMAL RETURN.IY
)@@G@@  ALL VARIABLE RETURN ARGUMENTS     @F@@@@ SHOULD BE INDICATED ON THE 'SIZ
)@@G@@UBROUTINE' OR 'FUNCTION' CARD AS AN @C@@@@ ASTERISK (*) AMPERSAND (&), OJA
)@@G@@R DOLLAR SIGN ($).@[@@@@      @G@@@@       MAD SYNTAX ALLOWS ONLY ONE ALJB
)@@G@@TERNATE RETURN.  TO USE THE MAD     @F@@@@ ALTERNATE RETURN FEATURE, THEJC
)@@G@@ SUBROUTINE OR FUNCTION SHOULD BE   @F@@@@ CALLED WITH AN EXTRA ARGUMENTJD
)@@G@@ OF STATEMENT-LABEL MODE.  IF THIS  @F@@@@ EXTRA ARGUMENT IS PRESENT, THJE
)@@G@@EN 'ERROR RETURN' WILL CAUSE CONTROL@G@@@@ TO BE TRANSFERRED TO THAT LABJF
)@@G@@EL.  IF THIS ARGUMENT IS NOT PRESENT,     @F@@@@ THEN CONTROL WILL GO TOJG
)@@G@@ THE EXECUTION MONITOR, WHICH WILL PRINT  @]@@@@ THE MESSAGE@[@@@@      JH
)@@G@@@^@@@@ UNDEFINED ERROR RETURN.@[@@@@      @D@@@@ FOLLOWED BY A WALK-BACKJI
)@@G@@ AND AN ERROR TERMINATION.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN THE ORIGINAL UJJ
)@@G@@NIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN MAD TRANSLATOR, ANY @F@@@@ NUMBER OF ALTERNATE RETJK
)@@G@@URNS COULD BE EFFECTED BY SIMPLY TRANSFER-@F@@@@ RING TO A PARAMETER WHIJL
)@@G@@CH WAS A STATEMENT LABEL.  THIS CONSTRUC- @F@@@@ TION, ALONG WITH THE PAJM
)@@G@@RALLEL FORTRAN CONSTRUCTION OF DOING AN   @F@@@@ ASSIGNED TRANSFER TO ANJN
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT, CAN LEAD TO TROUBLE BECAUSE IT @F@@@@ DOES NOT PERMIT THE PROJO
)@@G@@GRAM'S RETURN CODE TO RESTORE REGISTERS TO@G@@@@ THEIR EXPECTED STATE FOJP
)@@G@@R THE CALLING PROGRAM.  IT IS NOT RECOMMEN-     @F@@@@ DED THAT THE PROGJQ
)@@G@@RAMMER EMPLOY ARGUMENT (OR COMMON) TRANSFERS    @G@@@@ UNLESS HE UNDERSTJR
)@@G@@ANDS WHY THEY ARE DANGEROUS GIVEN ONLY THE INFOR-     @F@@@@ MATION IN TJS
)@@G@@HIS PARAGRAPH.  (I.E. IF YOU HAVE READ THIS PARAGRAPH @F@@@@ AND CANNOT JT
)@@G@@SEE HOW TRANSFERRING TO AN ARGUMENT OR TO A COMMON    @D@@@@ VARIABLE CAJU
)@@G@@N GET YOU INTO TROUBLE, THEN DON'T DO IT!)@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PJV
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8-  8@[@@@@      JW
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  8. 4.   AUXILLIAJX
)@@G@@RY ENTRY POINTS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       A SUBROUTINE OR FJY
)@@G@@UNCTION MAY HAVE ANY NUMBER OF NAMES BY   @F@@@@ WHICH IT MAY BE CALLED;JZ
)@@G@@ EACH NAME MAY BE ASSOICATED WITH ANY     @F@@@@ DESIRED SECTION OF THE KA
)@@G@@SUBROUTINE, AND MAY HAVE ITS OWN ARGUMENT @F@@@@ LIST SEPARATE FROM THATKB
)@@G@@ OF THE MAIN ENTRY POINT DECLARED ON THE  @G@@@@ 'SUBROUTINE' OR 'FUNCTIKC
)@@G@@ON' LINE.  AN AUXILLIARY ENTRY POINT MAY BE     @G@@@@ PLACED ANYWHERE IKD
)@@G@@N AN INTERNAL OR EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE, EXCEPT THAT     @G@@@@ AN AUXILLIAKE
)@@G@@RY ENTRY TO AN EXTERNAL SUBROUTINE MAY NOT OCCUR INSIDE     @F@@@@ AN INKF
)@@G@@TERNAL SUBROUTINE, ELSE IT WILL BE TAKEN AS AN ENTRY TO THE @^@@@@ INTERKG
)@@G@@NAL SUBROUTINE.   @[@@@@      @ @@@@       THE GENERAL FORM IS    @[@@@@KH
)@@G@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@       ENTRY <NAME>     @C@@@@       ENTRYKI
)@@G@@ <NAME>(<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,<ARGN>)   @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @^@@@@KJ
)@@G@@       ENTRY TO <NAME>. @D@@@@       ENTRY TO <NAME>.(<ARG1>,<ARG2>,...,KK
)@@G@@<ARGN>)     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       EXCEPT FOR A SPECIAL CASE IN MAD WHKL
)@@G@@ICH WILL BE DISCUSSED IN@F@@@@ A LATER PARAGRAPH, THE FIRST FORM IN EITHKM
)@@G@@ER LANGUAGE SPECIFIES AN@F@@@@ ENTRY WITH NO ARGUMENTS, WHILE THE SECONDKN
)@@G@@ FORM SPECIFIES AN ENTRY@F@@@@ WITH ARGUMENTS.  THE RULES FOR <NAME> ANDKO
)@@G@@ <ARG1>...<ARGN> ARE    @F@@@@ EXACTLY THE SAME AS THOSE GIVEN IN SECTIOKP
)@@G@@N 7.0 FOR FUNCTIONS OR  @#@@@@ SUBROUTINES.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@      KQ
)@@G@@ IF ANY ENTRY TO A SUBROUTINE IS MODE WITH A DIFFERENT ARGU-@F@@@@ MENT KR
)@@G@@LIST THAN SOME OTHER ENTRY, THEN ONE MUST BE CAREFUL IF     @G@@@@ REFERKS
)@@G@@ENCING AN ARGUMENT TO AN ENTRY POINT OTHER THAN THE ONE USED.     @#@@@@KT
)@@G@@ FOR EXAMPLE:     @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@       SUBROUTINE KU
)@@G@@P(A,B)@]@@@@       .    @]@@@@       .    @]@@@@       .    @^@@@@      KV
)@@G@@ ENTRY Y(C,A)     @#@@@@       B = A+C    @#@@@@       RETURN     @]@@@@KW
)@@G@@       END  @F@@@@       THE ADDRESS USED FOR 'B' WILL BE THE ADDRESS USKX
)@@G@@ED IN THE   @F@@@@ LAST CALL TO 'P'.  IF A CALL TO 'Y' IS MADE BEFORE A KY
)@@G@@CALL TO 'P',@F@@@@ THEN THE FUNCTION PARAMETER 'B' WILL NOT EVER HAVE BEKZ
)@@G@@EN DEFINED, @F@@@@ AND NOTHING MEANINGFUL WILL HAPPEN.  IN GENERAL, A FULA
)@@G@@NCTION PARA-@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBELB
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          8-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@LC
)@@G@@ METER WILL HAVE THE SAME MEANING IT HAD FOR THE LAST CALL TO A   @F@@@@LD
)@@G@@ NAME CONTAINING THAT FUNCTION PARAMETER IN ITS ARGUMENT LIST     @F@@@@LE
)@@G@@ REGARDLESS OF THE NUMBER OF INTERVENING CALLS TO OTHER ENTRY     @F@@@@LF
)@@G@@ POINTS NOT REFERENCING THAT FUNCTION PARAMETER.  LET'S REPHRASE  @F@@@@LG
)@@G@@ THAT LAST SENTENCE:  IF A CALL TO AN ENTRY OR A SUBROUTINE IS    @F@@@@LH
)@@G@@ MADE, AND THE STATEMENTS WHICH ARE EXECUTED REFERENCE A FUNCTION @G@@@@LI
)@@G@@ PARAMETER WHICH DID NOT HAPPEN TO BE INCLUDED IN THE ARGUMENT LIST     LJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ TO THE ENTRY POINT WHICH WAS CALLED, THEN THE DEFINITION IS RE-  LK
)@@G@@@F@@@@ TAINED FROM THE LAST CALL WHICH DID REFERENCE IT,  *IF ANY*.  IF LL
)@@G@@@F@@@@ NO CALL HAS REFERENCED IT, THE THEN IT IS NOT DEFINED.  THIS     LM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CONDITION IS HEAVILY DEPENDENT UPON PROGRAM LOGIC, AND THUS IS NOLN
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ CHECKED BY THE COMPILER OR EXECUTION MONITOR.  NO ERROR MESLO
)@@G@@SAGE OR     @F@@@@ WARNING OF ANY KIND CAN BE PRINTED FOR AN UNDEFINED FLP
)@@G@@UNCTION     @C@@@@ PARAMETER, EVEN THOUGH IT IS A LOGICAL ERROR.  @[@@@@LQ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       A SPECIAL FORM OF ALTERNATE ENTRY IS PERMITTED IN MADLR
)@@G@@:  IF @G@@@@ THE FUNCTION DECLARATION CARD DID NOT SPECIFY AN ENTRY POINLS
)@@G@@T NAME,     @F@@@@ BUT ONLY ARGUMENTS, THEN THESE ARGUMENTS WILL BE USEDLT
)@@G@@ FOR ANY    @G@@@@ 'ENTRY TO' STATEMENT WITH NO ARGUMENTS OF ITS OWN.  TLU
)@@G@@HUS, ASSUMING     @#@@@@ THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      @ @@@@ INTERNAL FULV
)@@G@@NCTION (A,B,C)    @[@@@@      @B@@@@ THEN AN AUXILLIARY ENTRY OF THE FORLW
)@@G@@M:    @[@@@@      @]@@@@ ENTRY TO X.@[@@@@      @^@@@@ WILL BE EQUIVALENLX
)@@G@@T TO  @[@@@@      @^@@@@ ENTRY TO X.(A,B,C)     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THIS LY
)@@G@@FORM HAS BEEN INCLUDED FOR THE SAKE OF COMPATIBILITY WITH THE     @E@@@@LZ
)@@G@@ ORIGINAL MAD LANGUAGE, AT THE EXPENSE OF TOTAL GENERALITY. @[@@@@*****^MA
)@@G@@@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)         MB
)@@G@@ 8- 10@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@MC
)@@G@@  8. 5.   SPECIFYING THE MODE OF A FUNCTION     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      MD
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       IT IS MEANINGLESS TO SPECIFY THE MODE FOR A PURME
)@@G@@E SUBROUTINE,     @F@@@@ BUT A MODE DECLARATION FOR A FUNCTION REFERS TOMF
)@@G@@ THE MODE OF THE  @F@@@@ VALUE RETURNED BY THAT FUNCTION.  THE MODE OF AMG
)@@G@@ FUNCTION MUST BE @F@@@@ SPECIFIED BOTH IN THE FUNCTION ITSELF, AND IN AMH
)@@G@@LL PROGRAMS WHERE @F@@@@ THE FUNCTION IS REFERENCED.  STANDARD DEFAULT MMI
)@@G@@ODES ARE HONORED  @F@@@@ FOR FUNCTIONS AS WELL AS FOR VARIABLES:  IN FORMJ
)@@G@@TRAN, THOSE FUNC- @F@@@@ TIONS WHOSE NAMES BEGIN WITH THE LETTERS I,J,K,MK
)@@G@@L,M, OR N ARE     @F@@@@ INTEGER, ALL OTHERS ARE REAL.  IN MAD, ALL FUNCML
)@@G@@TIONS ARE FLOATING@A@@@@ POINT UNLESS OTHERWISE DECLARED.   @[@@@@      MM
)@@G@@@G@@@@       THERE ARE TWO WAYS THAT THE MODE OF A FUNCTION MAY BE SPECIMN
)@@G@@-     @G@@@@ FIED WITHIN THAT FUNCTION.  THE FIRST IS TO REFERENCE THE FMO
