)@@G@@UNCTION     @E@@@@ NAME IN A MODE-DECLARATION STATEMENT WITHIN THE FUNCTMP
)@@G@@ION:  @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @ @@@@       <MODE NAME> <NAME>     MQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @ @@@@       <MODE NAME> <NAME>.    @[@@@@MR
)@@G@@      @E@@@@ (REFERENCE SECTION 8.2 FOR A DEFINITION OF <MODE NAME>).   MS
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE SECOND METHOD, AVAILABLE ONLY IN FORTRAN, IMT
)@@G@@S TO SPECIFY@D@@@@ THE MODE OF THE FUNCTION ON THE DEFINITION STATEMENT:MU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @D@@@@       <MODE NAME> FUNCTION <NAME> (MV
)@@G@@<ARG1>,...,<ARGN>)@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHERE <MODE NAME> IS DEFINED MW
)@@G@@AS IN SECTION 3.1, AND AS     @]@@@@ ABOVE.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      MX
)@@G@@@#@@@@       EXAMPLES:  @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD)MY
)@@G@@:     @A@@@@       EXTERNAL FUNCTION P.(Q,R)    @^@@@@       INTEGER P.,MZ
)@@G@@R     @[@@@@      @B@@@@       INTERNAL FUNCTION SMR.(ONE,TWO)    @ @@@@NA
)@@G@@       DOUBLE PRECISION SMR.  @#@@@@       BOOLEAN TWO@[@@@@      @]@@@@NB
)@@G@@ (FORTRAN): @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBENC
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          8- 11@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@ND
)@@G@@       FUNCTION GREEN (GRASS) @^@@@@       REAL GREEN, GRASS@[@@@@      NE
)@@G@@@A@@@@       COMPLEX FUNCTION IMAG(P1,P2) @[@@@@      @A@@@@       LOGICNF
)@@G@@AL FUNCTION TRUTH(X)    @[@@@@      @^@@@@       FUNCTION H(I)    @#@@@@NG
)@@G@@       INTEGER H  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  8. 6.   FUNCTION AND SNH
)@@G@@UBROUTINE CALLS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       AS DEFINED IN SECNI
)@@G@@TION 3.2.4, A FUNCTION IS AN EXTERIOR     @F@@@@ SEGMENT OF CODE TO WHICNJ
)@@G@@H ONE TRANSFERS WITH THE INTENT THAT IT   @F@@@@ RETURN AFTER PERFORMINGNK
)@@G@@ ITS ASSIGNED TASK.  A FUNCTION WHICH DOES@E@@@@ NOT RETURN A VALUE, BUTNL
)@@G@@ MERELY PERFORMS A TASK, IS CALLED A@F@@@@ 'SUBROUTINE'.  A 'FUNCTION' PNM
)@@G@@ERFORMS A TASK, THEN RETURNS A VALUE@F@@@@ BASED ON SAME.  THUS, A HYPOTNN
)@@G@@HETICAL FUNCTION TO INVERT A MATRIX @B@@@@ MIGHT RETURN AS A VALUE ITS DNO
)@@G@@ETERMINANT: @[@@@@      @]@@@@ FORTRAN):  @^@@@@       DET = INVERT(A,N)NP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @ @@@@       DET = INVERT.(A,N)     @[@@@@NQ
)@@G@@      @D@@@@ BUT ANOTHER FUNCTION MIGHT SIMPLY INVERT THE MATRIX: @[@@@@NR
)@@G@@      @]@@@@ FORTRAN):  @^@@@@       CALL INVRSE(A,N) @[@@@@      @]@@@@NS
)@@G@@ (MAD):     @ @@@@       EXECUTE INVRSE.(A,N)   @[@@@@      @ @@@@ THE ANT
)@@G@@BBREVIATED CONSTRUCTION @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @^@@@@       INVRSNU
)@@G@@E.(A,N)     @[@@@@      @^@@@@ IS ALSO PERMITTED.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@NV
)@@G@@       A REFERENCE TO A VALUE-RETURNING FUNCTION CAN, AS NOTED IN @G@@@@NW
)@@G@@ SECTION 3.2.4, BE INCLUDED AS AN OPERAND IN ANY EXPRESSION WHERE AN    NX
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OPERAND OF THAT MODE IS LEGAL.  A SUBROUTINE REFERENCE MUST STANDNY
)@@G@@@F@@@@ BY ITSELF.  BOTH TYPES WILL CAUSE A TRANSFER OF CONTROL TO THE   NZ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ INDICATED FUNCTION.  IT IS UP TO THE FUNCTION TO RETURN AT THE   OA
)@@G@@@#@@@@ PROPER TIME.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMOB
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@OC
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  8. 6. 1.   GENERATED CALLING SEQUENCES  @[@@@@OD
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       EACH ARGUMENT TO A FUNCTION OR SUBROUTINE CALL IS OUTOE
)@@G@@PUT AS@D@@@@ A SEPARATE WORD IN THE CALLING SEQUENCE.  RULES FOR  @C@@@@OF
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT-PARAMETER FORMATION ARE AS FOLLOWS.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      OG
)@@G@@ 1)  IF AN ARGUMENT IS A CONSTANT, UNDIMENSIONED VARIABLE,  @F@@@@      OH
)@@G@@     ARRAY VARIABLE WITH CONSTANT SUBSCRIPT, OR TEMPORARY   @F@@@@      OI
)@@G@@     RESULT, THEN THE ADDRESS OF THE ARGUMENT IS PASSED.    @[@@@@      OJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@       2)  IF AN ARGUMENT IS THE NAME OF AN ARRAY DIMENSIONED FOR OK
)@@G@@@F@@@@           LINEAR SUBSCRIPTING, THEN THE ADDRESS OF ARRAY(1) IS   OL
)@@G@@@G@@@@           PASSED, REGARDLESS OF WHETHER OR NOT THE ZERO ELEMENT IOM
)@@G@@S     @F@@@@           PRESENT.  THUS, IF THE ZERO ELEMENT IS PRESENT, AON
)@@G@@ND IF @F@@@@           THE ARRAY NAME WITHOUT SUBSCRIPTS IS USED AS AN AOO
)@@G@@RGU-  @F@@@@           MENT, THE  *SECOND*  WORD OF THE ARRAY IS PASSED.OP
)@@G@@  THIS@G@@@@           IS COMPLETELY COMPATIBLE WITH ALL FORTRAN OR MAD OQ
)@@G@@SUBROU-     @G@@@@           TINES, REGARDLESS OF THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCOR
)@@G@@E OF THE ZERO     @G@@@@           ELEMENT IN THE SUBROUTINE, PROVIDED TOS
)@@G@@HAT THE ARGUMENT IS     @G@@@@           REFERENCED AS AN ARRAY IN THE COT
)@@G@@ALLED SUBROUTINE.  IF THE     @F@@@@           SUBROUTINE REFERENCES THEOU
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT AS AN UNDIMENSIONED @G@@@@           VARIABLE, IT MUST REALIZEOV
)@@G@@ THAT IT IS GETTING THE ADDRESS     @F@@@@           OF ARRAY(1) THROUGHOW
)@@G@@ THE CALLING SEQUENCE, WHICH IS NOT @B@@@@           NECESSARILY THE ARROX
)@@G@@AY BASE.    @[@@@@      @E@@@@       3)  IF AN ARGUMENT IS THE UNSUBSCRIOY
)@@G@@PTED NAME OF A    @F@@@@           MULTIPLY-DIMENSIONED ARRAY, THEN THE OZ
)@@G@@ADDRESS OF A 'DOPE@F@@@@           VECTOR' ENTRY IS PASSED.  THIS 'DOPE PA
)@@G@@VECTOR' CONTAINS  @G@@@@           DIMENSION INFORMATION AND A POINTER TPB
)@@G@@O THE 1-SUBSCRIPTED     @F@@@@           ENTRY OF THE ARRAY.  ALL OF THEPC
)@@G@@ RULES IN 2) ALSO APPLY.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHENEVER A SYSTEM ROUTIPD
)@@G@@NE LOCATES AN ERROR IN A FORTRAN    @^@@@@           PROGRAM, A   @G@@@@PE
)@@G@@ WALK-BACK TRACE IS PRINTED.  THE WALK-BACK TRACE IS A TABLE OF THE     PF
)@@G@@@F@@@@ SUBROUTINE CALLS MADE, WITH DECK NAME AND LINE NUMBER, WHICH LED PG
)@@G@@@#@@@@           TO THE @]@@@@ ERROR.     @[@@@@      @A@@@@  8. 6. 2.  PH
)@@G@@ THE 'WALK-BACK' FEATURE@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  8. 6. 2. 1.   THPI
)@@G@@E WALK-BACK WORD IN SUBROUTINE CALLS@[@@@@      @F@@@@       ALL SUBROUTPJ
)@@G@@INE CALLING SEQUENCES, INCLUDING THOSE AUTOMATI-@F@@@@ CALLY GENERATED BPK
)@@G@@Y THE COMPILER, HAVE A 'WALK-BACK' WORD AS THE  @G@@@@ LAST ARGUMENT.  TPL
)@@G@@HIS 'WALK-BACK' WORD IS NOT DIRECTLY AVAILABLE TO     @F@@@@ THE PROGRAMPM
)@@G@@MER; IT IS USED BY THE MONITOR SYSTEM TO TRACE ERRORS,@F@@@@ AND BY SOMEPN
)@@G@@ LIBRARY SUBROUTINES TO LOCATE THE SYMBOL TABLE IN THE@#@@@@ CALLING PROPO
)@@G@@GRAM. @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DPP
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          8- 13@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PQ
)@@G@@@E@@@@       THE INFORMATION CONTAINED IN THE WALKBACK WORD IS:   @[@@@@PR
)@@G@@      @E@@@@               1)  THE LINE NUMBER IN THE SOURCE PROGRAM    PS
)@@G@@@F@@@@               2)  THE ADDRESS OF A WALK-BACK PACKET OF INFORMA-  PT
)@@G@@@^@@@@                   TION.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  8. 6. 2. 2PU
)@@G@@.   THE WALK-BACK PACKET@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE WALK-BACK PACKET ISPV
)@@G@@ A 3-WORD PACKET OF INFORMATION WHICH     @F@@@@ IS REFERENCED BY ALL OFPW
)@@G@@ THE VARIOUS WALK-BACK WORDS IN A GIVEN   @F@@@@ PROGRAM.  A UNIQUE WALKPX
)@@G@@-BACK PACKET IS GENERATED FOR EACH SUBROU-@F@@@@ TINE, EITHER INTERNAL OPY
)@@G@@R EXTERNAL, AND FOR THE MAIN PROGRAM.     @F@@@@ DURING EXECUTION, THE 3PZ
)@@G@@-WORD WALK-BACK PACKET CONTAINS THE FOLLO-@#@@@@ WING INFORMATION:@[@@@@QA
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@       1)  A HOLLERITH (FIELDATA) 6-CHARACTER DEQB
)@@G@@CKNAME@F@@@@       2)  THE POINT FROM WHICH THIS SUBROUTINE WAS LAST CALQC
)@@G@@LED   @F@@@@       3)  THE NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS EXPECTED FOR THE CALL IN QD
)@@G@@2)    @C@@@@       4)  THE ADDRESS OF THE SYMBOL TABLE.     @F@@@@      QE
)@@G@@ 5)  AN INDICATION OF WHETHER THE SOURCE PROGRAM IS CODED IN@A@@@@      QF
)@@G@@        MAD OR IN FORTRAN     @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PQG
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  1@[@@@@      QH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  9.   DECLARATION STATEMENTS @[@@@@      QI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       DECLARATION STATEMENTS ARE USED TO QJ
)@@G@@ADJUST THE RALPH COMPILER     @F@@@@ ACTION ACCORDING TO SPECIFIC PROGRAQK
)@@G@@M NEEDS.  DECLARATION STATE-  @F@@@@ MENTS CAN BE GROUPED INTO THE CATEGQL
)@@G@@ORIES OF STORAGE ALLOCATION   @F@@@@ CONTROL, MODE DECLARATIONS, DATA INQM
)@@G@@TRODUCTION, PARAMETER DEFINI- @E@@@@ TION, MACROEXPRESSION DEFINITION, AQN
)@@G@@ND COMPILER CONTROL.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  9. 1.   STORAGE QO
)@@G@@ALLOCATION CONTROL@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       STORAGE ALLOCATIOQP
)@@G@@N CONTROL STATEMENTS DEFINE AND REGULATE  @A@@@@ DATA STORAGE ALLOCATIONQQ
)@@G@@ BY RALPH.  @[@@@@      @E@@@@  9. 1. 1.   THE 'DIMENSION' STATEMENT (FOQR
)@@G@@RTRAN AND MAD)    @[@@@@      @E@@@@       THE DIMENSION STATEMENT SPECIQS
)@@G@@FIES SUBSCRIPT RANGE AND@G@@@@ ASSIGNS STORAGE ACCORDINGLY, AND IF MULTIQT
)@@G@@PLE SUBSCRIPTING IS BEING     @F@@@@ SPECIFIED, ALSO SETS UP A 'STRUCTURQU
)@@G@@E VECTOR'.  IN SIMPLEST FORM, @ @@@@ THE DIMENSION STATEMENT IS   @[@@@@QV
)@@G@@      @A@@@@       DIMENSION <VARIABLE> (<SIZE>)@[@@@@      @[@@@@      QW
)@@G@@@F@@@@      THIS SPECIFIES A MAXIMUM SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF <SIZE> FOR THE  QX
)@@G@@@F@@@@ VARIABLE <VARIABLE>.  DEPENDING UPON WHETHER OR NOT THE 'Z' CAL- QY
)@@G@@@F@@@@ LING OPTION IS IN EFFECT, THE MINIMUM LEGAL SUBSCRIPT WILL BE    QZ
)@@G@@@#@@@@ EITHER 0 OR 1.   @[@@@@      @A@@@@       FOR EXAMPLE, THE STATEMRA
)@@G@@ENT   @[@@@@      @^@@@@       DIMENSION X(20)  @[@@@@      @B@@@@      RB
)@@G@@ WILL HAVE THE FOLLOWING EFFECTS:   @[@@@@      @^@@@@ 'Z' OPTION IN EFFRC
)@@G@@ECT:  @B@@@@       -RESERVES 21 WORDS OF CORE STORAGE @C@@@@       -ALLORD
)@@G@@WS SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF X(0),...,X(20)@[@@@@      @ @@@@ 'Z' OPTION NOT INRE
)@@G@@ EFFECT:    @B@@@@       -RESERVES 20 WORDS OF CORE STORAGE @C@@@@      RF
)@@G@@ -ALLOWS SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF X(1),...,X(20)@[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 1. 1. 1RG
)@@G@@.   MULTIPLE-SUBSCRIPT DIMENSIONING @[@@@@      @F@@@@       FOR MULTIPLRH
)@@G@@E-SUBSCRIPT DIMENSIONING, THERE ARE A FEW MORE  @B@@@@ THINGS GOING ON: RI
)@@G@@ THE GENERAL FORM IS    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RARJ
)@@G@@LPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@RK
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @[@@@@      @E@@@@       DIMENRL
)@@G@@SION <VARIABLE>(<SIZE-1>,<SIZE-2>,...,<SIZE-N>) @[@@@@      @#@@@@      RM
)@@G@@ (MAD):     @[@@@@      @E@@@@       DIMENSION <VARIABLE>(<SIZE-1>*<SIZERN
)@@G@@-2>*...*<SIZE-N>) @[@@@@      @G@@@@       REGARDLESS OF THE SETTING OF RO
)@@G@@THE 'Z' OPTION, THIS WILL ALLOW     @F@@@@ A SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF 1 TO <SIRP
)@@G@@ZE-K> FOR THE K'TH SUBSCRIPT.  FOR  @^@@@@ EXAMPLE, THE STATEMENT @[@@@@RQ
)@@G@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @ @@@@       DIMENSION P(3,4,5)     @[@@@@      RR
)@@G@@@]@@@@ (MAD):     @ @@@@       DIMENSION P(3*4*5)     @[@@@@      @F@@@@RS
)@@G@@       WILL ALLOW A SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF P(1,1,1) TO P(3,4,5).  IF  @F@@@@RT
)@@G@@ THE 'Z' OPTION IS SET, THEN AN ADDITIONAL ELEMENT, P(0), WILL BE @F@@@@RU
)@@G@@ ASSIGNED, ALLOTTING 3*4*5 + 1 WORDS, OR 61 WORDS OF CORE STORAGE @G@@@@RV
)@@G@@ FOR THE ARRAY P.  IF THE 'Z' OPTION IS NOT SET, THEN ONLY 60 WORDS     RW
)@@G@@@F@@@@ WILL BE ASSIGNED, AND THE BASE OF THE ARRAY WILL BE P(1,1,1).    RX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 1. 1. 2.   STORAGE OF MULTIPLY-SUBSCRIPTED ARRAYSRY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       MULTIPLY-SUBSCRIPTED ARRAYS CAN BE STORED IN ONRZ
)@@G@@E OF TWO    @F@@@@ WAYS, BY COLUMNS OR BY ROWS.  IF X(I,J,K) IS STORED BSA
)@@G@@Y ROWS, THEN@G@@@@ SEQUENTIAL CORE CELLS ARE OCCUPIED BY X(I,J,K) AND X(SB
)@@G@@I,J,K+1).  IF     @F@@@@ X(I,J,K) IS STORED BY COLUMNS, THEN SEQUENTIAL SC
)@@G@@CORE CELLS ARE    @B@@@@ OCCUPIED BY X(I,J,K) AND X(I+1,J,K).     @[@@@@SD
)@@G@@      @#@@@@       EXAMPLES:  @#@@@@       =========  @[@@@@      @ @@@@SE
)@@G@@       SUPPOSE THE STATEMENT  @[@@@@      @^@@@@       DIMENSION P(3,5) SF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@ HAS BEEN PUNCHED.  THEN IF P IS STORED BY COLUMNS, THSG
)@@G@@E CELLS     @^@@@@ ALLOTTED ARE, IN ORDER,@[@@@@      @G@@@@ P(1,1),P(2,SH
)@@G@@1),P(3,1),P(1,2),P(2,2),...,P(3,4),P(1,5),P(2,5),P(3,5)     @[@@@@      SI
)@@G@@@F@@@@       IF P IS STORED BY ROWS, THEN THE CELLS ALLOTTED ARE, IN    SJ
)@@G@@@]@@@@ ORDER,     @[@@@@      @D@@@@ P(1,1),P(1,2),P(1,3),P(1,4),P(1,5),SK
)@@G@@...,P(3,4),P(3,5) @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WSL
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      SM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@ IN MATHEMATICS IT IS CUSTOMARY TO THINK OF A MATRIX ISN
)@@G@@N TERMS OF  @F@@@@ ITS ROWS, BUT THE ASA FORTRAN STANDARDS SPECIFY STORASO
)@@G@@GE BY CO-   @F@@@@ LUMNS.  RALPH CAN STORE EITHER BY ROWS OR BY COLUMNS.SP
)@@G@@  IF THE    @F@@@@ INITIAL COMPILATION MODE IS FORTRAN, THEN STORAGE WILSQ
)@@G@@L BE BY     @F@@@@ COLUMNS.  IF THE INITIAL COMPILATION MODE IS MAD, THESR
)@@G@@N STORAGE   @#@@@@ WILL BE BY ROWS. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN MAD, ONESS
)@@G@@ MAY SPECIFY ARBITRARY RANGES FOR MULTIPLE SUBS-@F@@@@ CRIPTS, RATHER THST
)@@G@@AN JUST A RANGE OF 1 TO N.  THE GENERAL FORM IS @[@@@@      @F@@@@  DIMESU
)@@G@@NSION <VARIABLE>((<LOW1>...<HIGH1>)*(<LOW2>...<HIGH2>)*...) @[@@@@      SV
)@@G@@@F@@@@       WHERE <LOW1> AND <HIGH1> ARE THE LOWER AND UPPER LIMITS    SW
)@@G@@@F@@@@ RESPECTIVELY OF THE LEGAL SUBSCRIPT RANGE BEING SPECIFIED FOR THESX
)@@G@@@C@@@@ FIRST SUBSCRIPT.  FOR EXAMPLE, THE STATEMENT   @[@@@@      @]@@@@SY
)@@G@@ (MAD):     @C@@@@       DIMENSION B((-8...2)*(5...7)*(-19...-3)) @[@@@@SZ
)@@G@@      @ @@@@ ALLOWS A SUBSCRIPT RANGE OF  @ @@@@       B(-8,I,J) TO B(2,TA
)@@G@@I,J)  @ @@@@       B(I,5,J) TO B(I,7,J)   @ @@@@       B(I,J,-19) TO B(ITB
)@@G@@,J,-3)@[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE NUMBER OF WORDS OF CORE ALLOCATED INDEPENDETC
)@@G@@NT OF A POSSIBLE  @#@@@@ ZERO ELEMENT IS  @[@@@@      @E@@@@       N = (TD
)@@G@@2-(-8)+1)*(7-5+1)*(-3-(-19)+1) =  561 WORDS.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@      TE
)@@G@@ IF THE 'Z' OPTION IS SET, THEN 562 WORDS WILL BE ALLOCATED.@[@@@@      TF
)@@G@@@A@@@@  9. 1. 1. 3.   GROUP DIMENSIONING  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN MATG
)@@G@@D, IF IT IS DESIRED TO DIMENSION A NUMBER OF VARIABLES@B@@@@ WITH THE SATH
)@@G@@ME LIMITS, THEN THE NOTATION  @[@@@@      @E@@@@ DIMENSION (<VAR1>,<VAR2TI
)@@G@@>,<VAR3>,...,<VARN>)(<DIMENSIONS>)  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       WILL GIVE ETJ
)@@G@@ACH OF THE <VARI> THE SAME DIMENSIONING AS SPECI-     @[@@@@ FIED.@[@@@@TK
)@@G@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@TL
)@@G@@      @ @@@@       DIMENSION (A,B,C)(100) @A@@@@       DIMENSION (X,Y,Z)TM
)@@G@@(25*20)     @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 1. 1. 4.   DIMENSIONING FUNCTION PARATN
)@@G@@METERS@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE DIMENSION STATEMENT AS APPLIED TO FUNTO
)@@G@@CTION PARAMETERS  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DTP
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      TQ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ DOES NOT ASSIGN STORAGE, FOR THEY ARE STORED IN THE CALLING PRO- TR
)@@G@@@A@@@@ GRAM.  IT SERVES TWO PURPOSES:     @[@@@@      @A@@@@       SPECITS
)@@G@@FYING SUBSCRIPT RANGE   @E@@@@       DISTINGUISHING DIMENSIONED ARRAYS FTT
)@@G@@ROM FUNCTIONS.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IN FORTRAN, IF A FUNCTION PARTU
)@@G@@AMETER IS USED WITH SUBSCRIPTS,     @F@@@@ BUT IS NOT DIMENSIONED, IT WITV
)@@G@@LL PROBABLY BE TREATED AS A FUNCTION@G@@@@ INSTEAD OF A VARIABLE.  THE PTW
)@@G@@RESENCE OF A DIMENSION STATEMENT WILL     @F@@@@ CLEARLY ANNOUNCE ONE'S TX
)@@G@@INTENTION TO USE A FUNCTION PARAMETER AS A@A@@@@ VARIABLE RATHER THAN ASTY
)@@G@@ A FUNCTION.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF A FUNCTION PARAMETER IS USED WITTZ
)@@G@@H MULTIPLE SUBSCRIPTS,  @F@@@@ BUT DIMENSIONED WITH ONLY A SINGLE SUBSCRUA
)@@G@@IPT, THEN THE SUBSCRIPT @F@@@@ RANGE SPECIFIED IN THE CALLING PROGRAM ISUB
)@@G@@ USED.  IF IT IS DIMEN- @F@@@@ SIONED WITH MULTIPLE SUBSCRIPTS, THEN THIUC
)@@G@@S WILL OVERRIDE THE     @D@@@@ SUBSCRIPT RANGE SPECIFIED IN THE CALLING UD
)@@G@@PROGRAM.    @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 1. 1. 5.   VARIABLE-LIMIT DIMENSIONINUE
)@@G@@G     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       SOMETIMES A FUNCTION PARAMETER'S DIMENSIOUF
)@@G@@NS ARE VARIABLE;  @G@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE, A SUBROUTINE TO INVERT AN N X N MAUG
)@@G@@TRIX MUST ALTER THE     @F@@@@ DIMENSION OF THE ARRAY TO N X N DEPENGINGUH
)@@G@@ UPON THE VALUE OF N.   @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @^@@@@       DIMENUI
)@@G@@SION A(N,N) @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF VARIABLE DIMENSIONING IS USED, TUJ
)@@G@@HE ARRAY WHICH IS DIMEN-@G@@@@ SIONED AND ALL OF THE VARIABLE LIMITS MUSUK
)@@G@@T BE FUNCTION PARAMETERS.     @F@@@@ VARIABLE DIMENSIONING DOES NOT ALTEUL
)@@G@@R STORAGE ALLOCATION, ONLY    @^@@@@ SUBSCRIPT STRUCTURE.   @[@@@@      UM
)@@G@@@E@@@@  9. 1. 2.   THE 'EQUIVALENCE' STATEMENT (FORTRAN AND MAD)  @[@@@@UN
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       THE EQUIVALENCE STATEMENT CAUSES THE STORAGE ALLOCATOUO
)@@G@@R TO  @F@@@@ ASSIGN MORE THAN ONE VARIABLE TO THE SAME STORAGE LOCATION.UP
)@@G@@  IT  @F@@@@ CAN BE USED FOR CONSERVING STORAGE, OR FOR PROGRAMMING 'TRIUQ
)@@G@@CKS'  @G@@@@ INVOLVING MODE FAKERY.  IN GENERAL FORM, THE EQUIVALENCE STUR
)@@G@@ATEMENT     @[@@@@ IS   @[@@@@      @E@@@@  EQUIVALENCE (<V1>,<V2>),(<V3US
)@@G@@>,<V4>,<V5>,...),(...),...    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WHERE THE <VI> ARE VARIUT
)@@G@@ABLES, POSSIBLY WITH CONSTANT SUBSCRIPTS. @F@@@@ AN EQUIVALENCE GROUP ISUU
)@@G@@ ONE OF THE OUTERMOST, COMMA-SEPARATED    @G@@@@ PARENTHESIS GROUPS.  ALUV
)@@G@@L VARIABLES IN AN EQUIVALENCE GROUP WILL BE     @B@@@@ ASSIGNED TO THE SUW
)@@G@@AME STORAGE LOCATION.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF ONE OF THE VARIABLESUX
)@@G@@ IN AN EQUIVALENCE GROUP IS DECLARED@F@@@@ TO BE IN COMMON STORAGE, THENUY
)@@G@@ ALL OF THE VARIABLES IN THE EQUIVA-@F@@@@ LENCE GROUP WILL BE IN COMMONUZ
)@@G@@ STORAGE.  MORE THAN ONE DECLARED   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMVA
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@VB
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ COMMON VARIABLE IN AN EQUIVALENCE GROUP IS NOT VC
)@@G@@PERMITTED.  IF A  @F@@@@ SUBSCRIPTED VARIABLE IS INCLUDED IN AN EQUIVALEVD
)@@G@@NCE DECLARATION,  @C@@@@ THEN THE ENTIRE ARRAY IS CARRIED ALONG.  THUS: VE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@               EQUIVALENCE (A(1),B(5))    @[@@@@      VF
)@@G@@@F@@@@       WILL FORCE INTO EQUIVALENCE A(2) AND B(6), A(3) AND B(7),  VG
)@@G@@@F@@@@ ETC.  IF AN ARRAY EQUIVALENCE OF THIS SORT IS BEING DONE INSIDE  VH
)@@G@@@F@@@@ COMMON STORAGE, CARE MUST BE TAKEN TO ENSURE THAT AN EQUIVALENCE VI
)@@G@@@F@@@@ STATEMENT DOES NOT FORCE AN ARRAY OFF THE LOWER END OF THE BLOCK.VJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ IF AN ARRAY EQUIVALENCE FORCES THE ARRAY OFF THE UPPER END OF A  VK
)@@G@@@D@@@@ COMMON BLOCK, THEN THE COMMON BLOCK WILL BE EXPANDED.@[@@@@      VL
)@@G@@@F@@@@       IF DOUBLE-PRECISION OR COMPLEX VARIABLES ARE BEING EQUIVA- VM
)@@G@@@F@@@@ LENCED, NOTE THAT TWO WORDS ARE ALLOCATED FOR EACH VARIABLE OF   VN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THESE MODES.  THUS, IF 'A' IS DOUBLE PRECISION, THEN EQUIVALENCINVO
)@@G@@G     @F@@@@ B(3) AND A(4) WILL BRING INTO EQUIVALENCE B(5) AND A(5), B(VP
)@@G@@7) AND@]@@@@ A(6), ETC. @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 1. 3.   COMMON-STORAGE DEVQ
)@@G@@CLARATION   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEN SUBROUTINES ARE USED TO ANY LAVR
)@@G@@RGE EXTENT, IT OFTEN IS @F@@@@ DESIRED TO TRANSMIT BLOCKS OF DATA BETWEEVS
)@@G@@N SUBROUTINES.  COMMON  @G@@@@ STORAGE PROVIDES A METHOD OF HAVING STORAVT
)@@G@@GE SHARED BY SUBROUTINES.     @A@@@@ THE DECLARATION TAKES THE FORM     VU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @E@@@@       COMMON/<NAME>/<VAR1>,<VAR2>,.VV
)@@G@@../<NAME1>/<VARK>,...   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHERE <NAME> IS THE POSVW
)@@G@@SIBLY-BLANK NAME OF THE COMMON BLOCK.     @F@@@@ ANY SYMBOL WHICH WOULD VX
)@@G@@BE LEGAL AS A VARIABLE NAME IS LEGAL AS A @G@@@@ COMMON-BLOCK NAME.  IT VY
)@@G@@IS QUITE LEGAL TO HAVE A COMMON BLOCK AND A     @ @@@@ VARIABLE WITH THEVZ
)@@G@@ SAME NAME. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE <VARI> ARE VARIABLES, POSSIBLY WA
)@@G@@WITH DIMENSION INFORMA- @F@@@@ TION, TO BE STORED IN THE COMMON BLOCK.  WB
)@@G@@IF <NAME>, THE NAME OF  @F@@@@ THE BLOCK, IS OMITTED OR IS BLANK, THE NAWC
)@@G@@ME 'BLANK$COMMON' IS    @E@@@@ FILLED IN FOR BOOKKEEPING PURPOSES BY THEWD
)@@G@@ COLLECTOR.  IT IS@C@@@@ OBVIOUSLY ILLEGAL TO USE THIS NAME DIRECTLY.   WE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEN AN OBJECT PROGRAM IS COLLECTED, ALL BLOCKSWF
)@@G@@ WITH THE   @G@@@@ SAME NAME ARE ASSIGNED THE SAME STORAGE, THE TOTAL AMWG
)@@G@@OUNT ASSIGNED     @F@@@@ WILL BE THE MAXIMUM OF THE BLOCK SIZES.  THERE WH
)@@G@@ARE NO SPECIAL    @F@@@@ CONSIDERATIONS FOR DOUBLE-PRECISION OR COMPLEX WI
)@@G@@VARIABLES OTHER   @F@@@@ THAN REMEMBERING THAT EACH IS ASSIGNED TWO WORDWJ
)@@G@@S OF CORE STORAGE.@G@@@@ SOME COMPUTERS REQUIRE THAT THE CORE ADDRESS OFWK
)@@G@@ A DOUBLE-PRECISION     @F@@@@ OR COMPLEX OPERAND BE AN EVEN NUMBER; NO WL
)@@G@@SUCH RESTRICTION EXISTS @#@@@@ ON THE 1108.     @[@@@@      @^@@@@      WM
)@@G@@         EXAMPLES:@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DWN
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      WO
)@@G@@@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @#@@@@      WP
)@@G@@ PROGRAM 1--@B@@@@               COMMON /ABC/BLOCK(25),X(75)@#@@@@      WQ
)@@G@@ PROGRAM 2--@B@@@@               DIMENSION PP(75),RAIL(25)  @A@@@@      WR
)@@G@@         COMMON /ABC/ PP,RAIL @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @#@@@@      WS
)@@G@@ PROGRAM 1--@D@@@@               PROGRAM COMMON /ABC/BLOCK(25),X(75)    WT
)@@G@@@#@@@@       PROGRAM 2--@B@@@@               PROGRAM COMMON /ABC/PP,RAILWU
)@@G@@@B@@@@               DIMENSION PP(75),RAIL(25)  @[@@@@      @F@@@@      WV
)@@G@@ THIS CONSTRUCTION WILL CAUSE A COMMON BLOCK NAMED 'ABC' TO @F@@@@ BE GEWW
)@@G@@NERATED.  IF THE 'Z' OPTION IS IN EFFECT, THE BLOCK WILL    @F@@@@ CONTAWX
)@@G@@IN 102 WORDS, IF THE 'Z' OPTION IS NOT IN EFFECT, IT WILL   @F@@@@ CONTAWY
)@@G@@IN 100 WORDS.  AN EFFECTIVE EQUIVALENCE IS SET UP BETWEEN   @F@@@@ PP(1)WZ
)@@G@@ AND BLOCK(1), AND BETWEEN X(1) AND PP(26).  NOTICE THAT    @C@@@@ NAMESXA
)@@G@@ AND EVEN LENGTHS DO NOT HAVE TO MATCH.   @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 1. 4.  XB
)@@G@@ THE 'EXTERNAL' STATEMENT (FORTRAN) @[@@@@      @F@@@@       OCCASIONALLXC
)@@G@@Y IT IS DESIRED TO REFERENCE A FUNCTION NAME,   @E@@@@ RATHER THAN THE FXD
)@@G@@UNCTION ITSELF, AS PER SECTION 3.2.1.6,   @F@@@@ 'FUNCTION-NAME CONSTANTXE
)@@G@@S'.  A FORTRAN FUNCTION NAME IS DISTIN-   @F@@@@ GUISHED FROM AN ORDINARXF
)@@G@@Y VARIABLE VIA THE 'EXTERNAL' STATEMENT:  @[@@@@      @C@@@@       EXTERXG
)@@G@@NAL <NAME1>,<NAME2>,...,<NAMEN>     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL DECLARE <NAMXH
)@@G@@E1>,<NAME2>, ETC., TO BE EXTERNAL.  THE COMPILER@A@@@@ ACTION ON EACH LIXI
)@@G@@ST ITEM <NAME> IS @[@@@@      @F@@@@       1)  SUPPRESS LOCAL ASSIGNMENTXJ
)@@G@@ OF STORAGE TO <NAME>.  (I.E. @A@@@@           STORAGE IS 'EXTERNAL')   XK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       2)  DECLARE <NAME> TO BE OF FUNCTION-NAME MODE.XL
)@@G@@  AS AN     @D@@@@           OPERAND, <NAME> IS EFFECTIVELY A CONSTANT. XM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE 'EXTERNAL' STATEMENT, IF APPLIED TO A GENERXN
)@@G@@IC OR INTRIN-     @E@@@@ SIC FUNCTION, WILL BE TREATED AS AN 'ABNORMAL' XO
)@@G@@DECLARATION @G@@@@ (SECTION 8.6.4.1).  IN MAD, THERE IS NO NEED FOR THE XP
)@@G@@EXTERNAL DECLARA- @F@@@@ TION:  THE PRESENCE OF THE SUFFIXED PERIOD ON FXQ
)@@G@@UNCTION NAMES IS  @F@@@@ SUFFICIENT TO DISTINGUISH A FUNCTION NAME FROM XR
)@@G@@A VARIABLE NAME.  @F@@@@ THIS CONSTRUCTION IS ALSO LEGAL IN FORTRAN; UPOXS
)@@G@@N RECOGNITION OF A@F@@@@ NAME FOLLOWED BY A PERIOD, THE SYNTAX SCANNER DXT
)@@G@@OES NOT BOTHER TO @E@@@@ CHECK WHETHER IT IS COMPILING A MAD OR FORTRAN XU
)@@G@@PROGRAM.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEXV
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          9-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@XW
)@@G@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @ @@@@XX
)@@G@@       EXTERNAL SIN,COS,TAN   @ @@@@       EXTERNAL FOFX,FOFX^X   @^@@@@XY
)@@G@@       EXTERNAL A,B     @^@@@@       EXTERNAL MMM     @[@@@@      @[@@@@XZ
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   YA
)@@G@@       9-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      YB
)@@G@@@ @@@@  9. 2.   MODE DECLARATIONS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      YC
)@@G@@ MODE-DECLARATION STATEMENTS SET MODES OF ALL OPERANDS EXCEPT     @F@@@@YD
)@@G@@ CONSTANTS.  THERE ARE TWO TYPES OF MODE DECLARATIONS:  GLOBAL AND@]@@@@YE
)@@G@@ ITEMIZED.  @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 2. 1.   GLOBAL MODE DECLARATIONS     YF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       ALL OPERANDS MUST HAVE AN ASSIGNED MODE.  THOSEYG
)@@G@@ OPERANDS NOT     @F@@@@ MENTIONED EXPLICITLY IN AN ITEMIZED MODE DECLARYH
)@@G@@ATION ARE ASSIGNED@F@@@@ AN IMPLICIT MODE BASED UPON GLOBAL MODE DECLARAYI
)@@G@@TIONS CUMULATIVELY@B@@@@ IN EFFECT AT THE END OF THE PROGRAM.     @[@@@@YJ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       IN MAD, ALL MODE-DECLARABLE OPERANDS (VARIABLES, FUNCYK
)@@G@@TION  @G@@@@ PARAMETERS, AND FUNCTION REFERENCES) ARE ASSUMED TO BE IN FYL
)@@G@@LOATING     @F@@@@ POINT UNLESS OTHERWISE DECLARED.  IN FORTRAN, THOSE OYM
)@@G@@PERANDS     @F@@@@ BEGINNING WITH THE LETTERS I,J,K,L,M, OR N ARE ASSUMEYN
)@@G@@D TO BE OF  @E@@@@ INTEGER MODE; ALL OTHERS ARE ASSUMED TO BE FLOATING PYO
)@@G@@OINT. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE GLOBAL MODE ASSUMPTIONS CAN BE CHANGEYP
)@@G@@D:  THE GENERAL   @]@@@@ FORM IS    @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @F@@@@YQ
)@@G@@       IMPLICIT <MODE-NAME>(<F1>-<L1>,<F2>-<L2>)<MODE-NAME>(...)  @[@@@@YR
)@@G@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @A@@@@       NORMAL MODE IS <MODE-NAME>   @[@@@@YS
)@@G@@      @B@@@@       WHERE <MODE-NAME> IS ONE OF THE SET@[@@@@      @A@@@@YT
)@@G@@       INTEGER               REAL   @C@@@@       FLOATING POINT        DYU
)@@G@@OUBLE PRECISION   @A@@@@       COMPLEX               BOOLEAN@C@@@@      YV
)@@G@@ LOGICAL               STATEMENT LABEL    @^@@@@       FUNCTION NAME    YW
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@ <F1> <L1>, ETC. ARE LETTERS DENOTING IMPLICIT RANGE. YX
)@@G@@ THUS @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (FORTRAN): @F@@@@       IMPLICIT REAL (A-H,S-Z)YY
)@@G@@,INTEGER(I-O),DOUBLE PRECISION(P-R) @[@@@@      @G@@@@       WILL SPECIFYZ
)@@G@@Y THAT ANY UNDECLARED OPERANDS BEGINNING WITH THE     @F@@@@ LETTERS A TZA
)@@G@@HROUGH H OR S THROUGH Z WILL BE AUTOMATICALLY TYPED   @G@@@@ REAL, THOSEZB
)@@G@@ BEGINNING WITH I THROUGH O WILL BE AUTOMATICALLY TYPED     @F@@@@ INTEGZC
)@@G@@ER, AND THOSE BEGINNING WITH THE LETTERS P THROUGH R WILL BE@^@@@@ TYPEDZD
)@@G@@ DOUBLE PRECISION.@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WZE
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@      ZF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       IN MAD, THERE IS NO WAY TO SET A PARTIAL GLOBALZG
)@@G@@ MODE (AS   @F@@@@ ABOVE), ALL LETTERS A TO Z ARE ASSIGNED THE SAME IMPLZH
)@@G@@ICIT MODE.  @#@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE:     @[@@@@      @]@@@@ (MAD):     @ @@@@ZI
)@@G@@       NORMAL MODE IS INTEGER @[@@@@      @F@@@@       WILL CAUSE ALL UNZJ
)@@G@@DECLARED OPERANDS TO BE TYPED INTEGER.    @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 2. 2.  ZK
)@@G@@ ITEMIZED MODE DECLARATIONS   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       SPECIFIC OPERANDSZL
)@@G@@ CAN BE DECLARED INDEPENDENTLY OF ANY     @B@@@@ GLOBAL MODE DECLARATIONZM
)@@G@@S.  THE FORM IS   @[@@@@      @D@@@@       <MODE-NAME> <VAR1>,<VAR2>,<VAZN
)@@G@@R3>,...,<VARN>    @[@@@@      @B@@@@       IN THIS CASE, <MODE-NAME> MAYZO
)@@G@@ BE   @B@@@@       FORTRAN                         MAD@B@@@@       =====ZP
)@@G@@==                         ===@[@@@@      @C@@@@       INTEGER          ZQ
)@@G@@               INTEGER  @D@@@@       REAL                            FLOZR
)@@G@@ATING POINT @E@@@@       DOUBLE PRECISION                DOUBLE PRECISIOZS
)@@G@@N     @C@@@@       COMPLEX                         COMPLEX  @C@@@@      ZT
)@@G@@ LOGICAL                         BOOLEAN  @D@@@@                        ZU
)@@G@@               FUNCTION NAME  @D@@@@                                    ZV
)@@G@@   STATEMENT LABEL@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       <VAR-I> IS A VARIZW
)@@G@@ABLE, POSSIBLY WITH DIMENSION INFORMATION,@F@@@@ A FUNCTION PARAMETER, PZX
)@@G@@OSSIBLY WITH DIMENSION INFORMATION, OR A  @G@@@@ FUNCTION NAME.  AN ITEMZY
)@@G@@IZED MODE DECLARATION CAN TAKE THE PLACE OF     @F@@@@ A DIMENSION STATEZZ
)@@G@@MENT.  SPECIFYING A FUNCTION NAME IN A MODE     @F@@@@ DECLARATION SPECIAA
)@@G@@FIES THE MODE OF THE VALUE RETURNED BY THE FUNC-@G@@@@ TION.  A MODE DECAB
)@@G@@LARATION IS MEANINGLESS FOR A FUNCTION WHICH DOES     @F@@@@ IF A MODE DAC
)@@G@@ECLARATION REFERENCES AN IMPLICIT OR GENERIC FUNCTION @F@@@@ NAME, THEN AD
)@@G@@THAT NAME IS REMOVED FROM THE TABLE; IT IS NO LONGER  @F@@@@ TREATED AS AE
)@@G@@A GENERIC OR INTRINSIC FUNCTION.  THE NAME CAN ALSO BE@F@@@@ REMOVED FROAF
)@@G@@M THE TABLE VIA THE 'EXTERNAL' OR 'ABNORMAL' DECLARA- @G@@@@ TIONS, OR BAG
)@@G@@Y NAMING AN INTERNAL SUBROUTINE ENTRY POINT THE SAME AS     @F@@@@ THAT AH
)@@G@@OF AN INTRINSIC OR GENERIC FUNCTION.  IN ANY CASE, THE DEC- @D@@@@ LARATAI
)@@G@@ION MUST PRECEDE THE FIRST USE OF THE FUNCTION. @[@@@@      @A@@@@  9. 2AJ
)@@G@@. 3.   MODE CORRESPONDENCE    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE RALPH COMPILEAK
)@@G@@R CAREFULLY KEEPS TRACK OF ALL OPERAND    @F@@@@ MODES WITHIN A GIVEN COAL
)@@G@@MPILATION AND PERFORMS ALL NECESSARY CON- @F@@@@ VERSIONS IF MIXED MODESAM
)@@G@@ ARE USED.  IT CANNOT, HOWEVER, REMEMBER  @F@@@@ MODES FROM ONE SUBROUTIAN
)@@G@@NE TO THE NEXT; THE PROGRAMMER MUST BE    @F@@@@ CAREFUL TO ENSURE THAT AO
)@@G@@MODES OF FUNCTION PARAMETERS CORRESPOND TO@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PAP
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 10@[@@@@      AQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE MODES OF THE CALLING ARGUMENTS; THAT AR
)@@G@@THE MODE DECLARED FOR A @F@@@@ FUNCTION IS THE SAME AS THE MODE DECLAREDAS
)@@G@@ WITHIN THAT FUNCTION,  @F@@@@ AND THAT THE MODES OF VARIABLES IN A COMMAT
)@@G@@ON BLOCK ARE CONSISTENT.@F@@@@ UNPREDICTABLY HIDEOUS THINGS WILL HAPPEN AU
)@@G@@TO COMPUTED VALUES IF   @A@@@@ MODES DO NOT CORRESPOND EXACTLY.   @[@@@@AV
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   AW
)@@G@@       9- 11@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      AX
)@@G@@@ @@@@  9. 3.   DATA INTRODUCTION   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@      AY
)@@G@@ NORMALLY, WHEN A PROGRAM BEGINS EXECUTION, THE VALUE OF ALL@G@@@@ VARIAAZ
)@@G@@BLES WILL BE ZERO.  IT IS OFTEN USEFUL TO PRESET THE VALUE OF     @F@@@@BA
)@@G@@ A VARIABLE TO SOME NON-ZERO VALUE.  FOR EXAMPLE, AN ENTIRE ARRAY @G@@@@BB
)@@G@@ COULD BE PRESET TO CONTAIN MOLECULAR WEIGHTS, OR A TABLE, A RACING     BC
)@@G@@@F@@@@ FORM, OR ANYTHING ELSE.  IN MAD, BECAUSE INPUT-OUTPUT FORMATS AREBD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ALWAYS VARIABLES, THE MAD DATA-INTRODUCTION STATEMENT MUST BE USEBE
)@@G@@D     @D@@@@ UNLESS FORMATS ARE TO BE READ IN AT EXECUTION TIME.  @[@@@@BF
)@@G@@      @C@@@@  9. 3. 1.   THE 'DATA' STATEMENT (FORTRAN)     @[@@@@      BG
)@@G@@@G@@@@       THE 'DATA' STATEMENT IS USED TO SPECIFY THE INITIAL VALUE(SBH
)@@G@@)     @F@@@@ OF A VARIABLE OR VARIABLES.  THE BASIC NON-ITERATIVE FORM IBI
)@@G@@S:    @[@@@@      @E@@@@       DATA <VAR1>/<VAL1>/,<VAR2>,<VAR3>/<VAL2>,BJ
)@@G@@<VAL3>/,... @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE VARIABLE <VAR1> WILL BE ASSIGNEBK
)@@G@@D THE INITIAL VALUE     @F@@@@ <VALUE-1>.  THE VARIABLE <VAR-2> WILL BE BL
)@@G@@ASSIGNED THE INITIAL    @^@@@@ VALUE <VAL2>, ETC.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@BM
)@@G@@       A STRING OF THE FORM  <VAR1>,<VAR2>,...,<VARN> IS CALLED A @E@@@@BN
)@@G@@ 'VARIABLE GROUP', OR 'VARIABLE LIST'; A STRING OF THE FORM @F@@@@ <VAL1BO
)@@G@@>,<VAL2>,...,<VALN> IS CALLED A 'LITERAL GROUP' OR 'LITERAL @F@@@@ LIST'BP
)@@G@@, AND THE INDIVIDUAL <VALUE-I> ARE CALLED 'DATA LITERALS'.  @F@@@@ ALL DBQ
)@@G@@ATA LITERALS MUST BE CONSTANTS OR CONSTANT PARAMETERS (SEE  @F@@@@ SECTIBR
)@@G@@ON 8.4).  THERE MUST BE A 1-TO-1 CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN     @G@@@@ ELEMEBS
)@@G@@NTS IN A VARIABLE GROUP AND THE ELEMENTS IN THE CORRESPONDING     @F@@@@BT
)@@G@@ LITERAL GROUP.  THE LITERAL GROUP REFERRING TO A GIVEN VARIABLE  @F@@@@BU
)@@G@@ GROUP IS ENCLOSED IN SLASHES (/) AND PLACED IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE@B@@@@BV
)@@G@@ VARIABLE, WITH NO SEPARATING PUNCTUATION:@[@@@@      @D@@@@       DATA BW
)@@G@@<VARIABLE GROUP>/<LITERAL GROUP>/, ETC.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       NOTICBX
)@@G@@E THE COMMA, OFTEN FORGOTTEN, SEPARATING THE FIRST    @C@@@@ LITERAL GROBY
)@@G@@UP FROM THE SECOND VARIABLE GROUP.  @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 3. 1. 1.   REBZ
)@@G@@PETITION OF DATA LITERALS     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF IT IS DESIRED CA
)@@G@@TO INCLUDE SEVERAL CONSECUTIVE DATA LI-   @F@@@@ TERALS WITH THE SAME VACB
)@@G@@LUE, THEN A CONSTANT MULTIPLIER CAN BE    @F@@@@ PLACED IN FRONT OF ONE,CC
)@@G@@ CAUSING IT TO BE REPEATED:  THE CONSTRUC-@[@@@@ TION @[@@@@      @^@@@@CD
)@@G@@               N*<VALUE>@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEN USED IN A LITERAL CE
)@@G@@GROUP IS EQUIVALENT TO THE CONSTRUC-@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMCF
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@CG
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@ TION @[@@@@      @D@@@@               <VALUE>,<CH
)@@G@@VALUE>,...,<VALUE>  (N TERMS) @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF N IS AN INTEGECI
)@@G@@R CONSTANT OR PARAMETER WITH INTEGER CON- @#@@@@ STANT VALUE.     @[@@@@CJ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               ===CK
)@@G@@======@[@@@@      @A@@@@       DATA X/0.0/, Y/1.0/, Z/2.0/  @[@@@@      CL
)@@G@@@B@@@@       DATA A,B,GRX,PPP/2.0,4.1,4.1,4.1/  @[@@@@      @C@@@@      CM
)@@G@@ DATA AX,BX,CX/3*4.8/, P,Q,R,S/4*2.0/     @[@@@@      @C@@@@       DATA CN
)@@G@@ IH/'ABC'/, JP,LP,MP/2HJP,2HLP,2HMP/@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@  9. 3CO
)@@G@@. 1. 2.   MODE CORRESPONDENCE IN 'DATA' STATEMENTS    @[@@@@      @G@@@@CP
)@@G@@       THE MODE OF A DATA LITERAL MUST MATCH THE MODE OF THE CORRES-    CQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PONDING VARIABLE.  IF A MODE DOES NOT MATCH, NO CONVERSION WILL BCR
)@@G@@E     @^@@@@ MADE:  THE STATEMENT   @[@@@@      @ @@@@               DATCS
)@@G@@A I/2.0/    @[@@@@      @E@@@@       WILL CAUSE THE INTEGER VARIABLE I TCT
)@@G@@O BE ASSIGNED THE @G@@@@ FLOATING-POINT VALUE 2.0, WITH POSSIBLY DISASTRCU
)@@G@@OUS RESULTS.  RALPH     @F@@@@ PERMITS MISMATCHED MODES IN DATA STATEMENCV
)@@G@@TS, BUT ISSUES A WARNING@]@@@@ MESSAGE.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@CW
)@@G@@  9. 3. 1. 3.   ITERATED VARIABLE LISTS   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEN CX
)@@G@@INTRODUCING DATA INTO AN ARRAY, IT IS CONVENIENT TO BE@F@@@@ ABLE TO SPECY
)@@G@@CIFY ITERATION.  THE FORMAT OF THE FORTRAN 'DO' STATE-@E@@@@ MENT IS USECZ
)@@G@@D, ALTHOUGH IT MUST BE ENCLOSED IN PARENTHESES: @[@@@@      @E@@@@      DA
)@@G@@ (<VARIABLE LIST>,<INDEX>=<START>,<STOP>,<INCREMENT>) @[@@@@      @F@@@@DB
)@@G@@       THE VALUES <START>, <STOP>, AND <INCREMENT> MUST BE EXPRES-@G@@@@DC
)@@G@@ SIONS INVOLVING ONLY INTEGER CONSTANTS OR INTEGER CONSTANT PARAME-     DD
)@@G@@@F@@@@ TERS.  <INDEX> MUST BE AN UNSUBSCRIPTED INTEGER VARIABLE, WHICH  DE
)@@G@@@F@@@@ WILL BE TEMPORARILY (FOR THE PURPOSES OF THE CURRENT STATEMENT)  DF
)@@G@@@F@@@@ TREATED AS A PARAMETER OF INTEGER VALUE.  THE <VARIABLE LIST>,   DG
)@@G@@@E@@@@ WHICH MAY ITSELF BE AN ITERATED VARIABLE LIST (PROVIDED, OF@G@@@@DH
)@@G@@ COURSE, THAT IT USES A DIFFERENT VARIABLE FOR ITS <INDEX> THAN THE     DI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ONE USED IN THE OUTER LOOP) MAY CONTAIN VARIABLES WITH A SUBSCRIPDJ
)@@G@@T     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971DK
)@@G@@ VERSION)          9- 13@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ INCLUDL
)@@G@@DING <INDEX>.  THE ENTIRE VARIABLE LIST WILL BE EFFECTIVELY @]@@@@ REPEADM
)@@G@@TED   @[@@@@      @B@@@@       (<STOP> - <START>)/<INCREMENT> + 1 @[@@@@DN
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       TIMES, VARYING <INDEX> AS INDICATED, FROM <START> TO DO
)@@G@@<STOP>@ @@@@ IN STEPS OF <INCREMENT>.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@DP
)@@G@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@      @A@@@@DQ
)@@G@@       DATA (X(I),I=1,100)/100*0.0/ @[@@@@      @F@@@@       DATA ((A(I,DR
)@@G@@J),B(I,J),J=1,3),I=1,20)/20*1.,20*2.,20*3./     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      DS
)@@G@@@B@@@@  9. 3. 1. 4.   IMPLIED-ITERATIVE LISTS   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      DT
)@@G@@ IF THE NAME OF A DIMENSIONED ARRAY OCCURS IN A VARIABLE    @F@@@@ GROUPDU
)@@G@@, FREE-STANDING, WITH NO SUBSCRIPT, THEN IT IS ASSUMED TO BE@G@@@@ A SHODV
)@@G@@RT-FORM NOTATION FOR AN ITERATION INVOLVING THE ENTIRE ARRAY:     @#@@@@DW
)@@G@@ THE SEQUENCE     @[@@@@      @^@@@@       DIMENSION B(30)  @^@@@@      DX
)@@G@@ DATA B/30*4./    @[@@@@      @ @@@@ IS EQUIVALENT TO THE SEQUENCE@[@@@@DY
)@@G@@      @^@@@@       DIMENSION B(30)  @A@@@@       DATA (B(I),I=1,30)/30*4DZ
)@@G@@./    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 3. 1. 5.   HOLLERITH-STRING DATEA
)@@G@@A     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IF IT IS DESIRED TO ENTER A CHARACTER STREB
)@@G@@ING INTO SUCCESSIVE     @F@@@@ POSITIONS IN AN ARRAY, THE STRING WILL BEEC
)@@G@@ GROUPED TO 6 CHARACTERS@]@@@@ PER WORD:  @[@@@@      @E@@@@       DATA ED
)@@G@@(ST(I),I=1,5)/'THIS IS A CHARACTER STRING'/     @[@@@@      @E@@@@ IS EQEE
)@@G@@UIVALENT TO ALL THREE OF THE FOLLOWING CONSTRUCTIONS: @[@@@@      @G@@@@EF
)@@G@@       DATA (ST(I),I=1,5)/'THIS I','S A CH','ARACTE','R STRI','NG'/     EG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@       DATA ST/26HTHIS IS A CHARACTER STRING/   @[@@@@EH
)@@G@@      @E@@@@       DATA ST/6HTHIS I,6HS A CH,6HARACTE,6HR STRI,2HNG/    EI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 3. 2.   THE 'VECTOR VALUES' STATEMENT (MAD)@[@@@@EJ
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   EK
)@@G@@       9- 14@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@      EL
)@@G@@ IN MAD, THE 'VECTOR VALUES' STATEMENT IS USED TO ASSIGN AN @G@@@@ INITIEM
)@@G@@AL VALUE TO THE ELEMENTS OF A VECTOR, OR ARRAY.  (SEE SECTION     @F@@@@EN
)@@G@@ 3.2.2 FOR A DISCUSSION OF THE TERMS 'VECTOR' AND 'ARRAY', ETC.). @F@@@@EO
)@@G@@ THE 'VECTOR VALUES' STATEMENT WILL AUTOMATICALLY DIMENSION THE   @G@@@@EP
)@@G@@ VARIABLE INVOLVED, IF NECESSARY.  THERE ARE TWO BASIC FORMS OF THE     EQ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ 'VECTOR VALUES' STATEMENT:  BLOCK FORM AND SEQUENTIAL FORM.  BOTHER
)@@G@@@F@@@@ FORMS AUTOMATICALLY ASSIGN THE MODE OF THE REFERENCED VARIABLE TOES
)@@G@@@A@@@@ MATCH THE MODE OF THE PRESET VALUE.@[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 3. 2. 1ET
)@@G@@.   BLOCK-FORM VECTOR VALUES  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE BLOCK-FORM VEEU
)@@G@@CTOR VALUES STATEMENT IS USED TO ASSIGN A @F@@@@ SINGLE VALUE TO A BLOCKEV
)@@G@@ OF CONSECUTIVE VARIABLES:  THE GENERAL   @]@@@@ FORM IS    @[@@@@      EW
)@@G@@@F@@@@       VECTOR VALUES <VARIABLE(SUB1)>...<VARIABLE(SUB2)>=<VALUE>  EX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@ THIS STATEMENT WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIONS:   EY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@       1)  DIMENSION <VARIABLE> AT SIZE 'SUB2'  @[@@@@EZ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       2)  DECLARE <VARIABLE> TO BE OF THE SAME MODE AS <VALFA
)@@G@@UE>   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       3)  ASSIGN THE INITIAL VALUE <VALUE> TO EFB
)@@G@@ACH OF THE CELLS IN     @^@@@@            THE BLOCK.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@FC
)@@G@@       THE '...' NOTATION IS A 'BLOCK OPERATOR', AND MAY ALSO BE  @F@@@@FD
)@@G@@ PUNCHED AS ',...,'.  IT MEANS 'EVERYTHING BETWEEN' AND ASSUMES A @F@@@@FE
)@@G@@ STEP OF 1.  <VALUE> MUST BE A CONSTANT OR CONSTANT PARAMETER.    @[@@@@FF
)@@G@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@FG
)@@G@@      @B@@@@       VECTOR VALUES X(0)...X(1000) = 1.0 @[@@@@      @C@@@@FH
)@@G@@       VECTOR VALUES P(0)...P(50) = (2.,5.)     @[@@@@      @D@@@@      FI
)@@G@@ VECTOR VALUES LINE(20)...LINE(60) = $. . . $   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      FJ
)@@G@@@C@@@@  9. 3. 2. 2.   SEQUENTIAL-FORM VECTOR VALUES   @[@@@@      @F@@@@FK
)@@G@@       THE SEQUENTIAL-FORM VECTOR VALUES STATEMENT IS USED TO     @G@@@@FL
)@@G@@ ASSIGN DIFFERENT VALUES TO SEQUENTIAL CORE CELLS IN AN ARRAY.  THE     FM
)@@G@@@#@@@@ GENERAL FORM IS  @[@@@@      @F@@@@  VECTOR VALUES <VARIABLE(SUB)FN
)@@G@@> = <VAL-1>,<VAL-2>,...,<VAL-N>     @[@@@@      @E@@@@       THIS STATEMFO
)@@G@@ENT WILL PERFORM THE FOLLOWING ACTIONS.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PFP
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 15@[@@@@      FQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@       1)  DIMENSION <VARIABLEFR
)@@G@@> AT SIZE SUB+N-1 @[@@@@      @F@@@@       2)  DECLARE <VARIABLE> TO BE FS
)@@G@@OF THE SAME MODE AS <VALUE>.  @[@@@@      @C@@@@       3)  ASSIGN INITIAFT
)@@G@@L VALUES AS FOLLOWS:    @B@@@@               <VAL-1> TO <VARIABLE(SUB)> FU
)@@G@@@C@@@@               <VAL-2> TO <VARIABLE(SUB+1)>     @#@@@@            FV
)@@G@@   .  @#@@@@               .  @#@@@@               .  @C@@@@            FW
)@@G@@   <VAL-N> TO <VARIABLE(SUB+N-1)>   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       FOR THE PURFX
)@@G@@POSES OF THE SEQUENTIAL-FORM VECTOR VALUES STATE-     @F@@@@ MENT, AN ALFY
)@@G@@PHABETIC CONSTANT IS CONSIDERED TO BE A STRING OF     @E@@@@ 6-CHARACTERFZ
)@@G@@ ALPHABETIC CONSTANTS SEPARATED BY COMMAS:  FOR @^@@@@ EXAMPLE, THE STATGA
)@@G@@EMENT @[@@@@      @D@@@@       VECTOR VALUES LINE = $H,,,THIS IS A HEADIGB
)@@G@@NG$   @[@@@@      @A@@@@ IS EQUIVALENT TO THE STATEMENT     @E@@@@      GC
)@@G@@ VECTOR VALUES LINE = $H,,,TH$,$IS IS $,$A HEAD$,$ING$@[@@@@      @F@@@@GD
)@@G@@       AN ALPHABETIC CONSTANT IS CONSIDERED TO BE OF TYPE INTEGER @B@@@@GE
)@@G@@ WHEN USED IN A VECTOR VALUES STATEMENT.  @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 3. 2. 3GF
)@@G@@.   THE UNDIMENSIONED DIMINUTIVE    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHEN PRESETGG
)@@G@@TING UNDIMENSIONED VARIABLES WITH A VECTOR VALUES     @A@@@@ STATEMENT, GH
)@@G@@ONE SIMPLY PUNCHES:     @[@@@@      @B@@@@       VECTOR VALUES <VARIABLEGI
)@@G@@> = <VALUE> @[@@@@      @G@@@@       <VARIABLE> WILL NOT BE DIMENSIONED.GJ
)@@G@@  IT WILL BE ASSIGNED THE     @D@@@@ MODE OF <VALUE> AND GIVEN THE INITIGK
)@@G@@AL VALUE <VALUE>. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DGL
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 16@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      GM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  9. 4.   THE 'PARAMETER' STATEMENT @[@@@@GN
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE 'PARAMETER' STATEMENT IS USED TO REDEGO
)@@G@@FINE THE MEANING OF     @F@@@@ A SYMBOL.  THIS REDEFINITION TAKES PLACE GP
)@@G@@AT COMPILATION TIME, AND@F@@@@ THE REDEFINITION IS KEPT UNTIL NULLIFIED.GQ
)@@G@@  THE SYMBOL IS VALID IN@F@@@@ ANY CONTEXT WHERE THE VALUE TO WHICH IT IGR
)@@G@@S PARAMETERIZED WOULD BE@]@@@@ VALID.     @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 4. 1.  GS
)@@G@@ OPERAND SUBSTITUTION PARAMETERS    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE OPERANDGT
)@@G@@ SUBSTITUTION PARAMETER STATEMENT HAS THE FORM  @[@@@@      @A@@@@      GU
)@@G@@ PARAMETER <NAME>(<OPERAND>)  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THIS CONSTRUCTIONGV
)@@G@@ WILL DEFINE THE SYMBOL <NAME> TO BE THE  @G@@@@ <OPERAND>, PROVIDED THAGW
)@@G@@T <NAME> IS AN UNSUBSCRIPTED VARIABLE NAME,     @F@@@@ AND <OPERAND> IS GX
)@@G@@A CONSTANT, FUNCTION NAME, OR VARIABLE WITH A   @A@@@@ POSSIBLE CONSTANTGY
)@@G@@ SUBSCRIPT.  THUS,@[@@@@      @ @@@@       PARAMETER PI(3.14159)  @[@@@@GZ
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ DEFINES THE SYMBOL 'PI' TO BE THE CONSTANT  3.14159.  THEREHA
)@@G@@ IS NO@F@@@@ VARIABLE NAMED 'PI'; IT IS NOW A CONSTANT AS FAR AS THE COMHB
)@@G@@PILER @C@@@@ IS CONCERNED.  PARAMETERS MAY BE OF ANY MODE.  @[@@@@      HC
)@@G@@@F@@@@       AS AN EXAMPLE OF THE POWER OF A SIMPLE PARAMETER STATEMENT,HD
)@@G@@@#@@@@ THE CONSTRUCTION @[@@@@      @ @@@@       PARAMETER NDIM(500)    HE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@ PERMITS THE DIMENSION CONSTRUCTION @[@@@@      @A@@@@HF
)@@G@@       DIMENSION X(NDIM),Y(NDIM)    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ AND SO FORTH.  THHG
)@@G@@IS WAY, IF ALL DIMENSION STATEMENTS USE PARAME- @G@@@@ TERS, THE SIZE OFHH
)@@G@@ THE PROGRAM CAN BE ADJUSTED BY CHANGING ONLY THE     @#@@@@ PARAMETER CHI
)@@G@@ARDS. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ANOTHER USE OF A SIMPLE OPERAHJ
)@@G@@ND SUBSTITUTION PARAMETER     @F@@@@ STATEMENT IS TO CHANGE THE NAME OF HK
)@@G@@A FUNCTION REFERENCED THROU-  @F@@@@ GHOUT A PROGRAM.  SUPPOSE THAT A FOHL
)@@G@@RTRAN PROGRAM HAS BEEN BROUGHT@F@@@@ FROM ANOTHER INSTALLATION, WHERE THHM
)@@G@@E ARCCOSINE ROUTINE IS NAMED  @F@@@@ ARCCOS.  ON THE 1108 UNDER EXEC8 THHN
)@@G@@IS FUNCTION IS NAMED 'ACOS'.  @#@@@@ THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      @ @@@@HO
)@@G@@       PARAMETER ARCCOS(ACOS) @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WHP
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 18@[@@@@      @[@@@@      HQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL CAUSE THE COMPILER TO COMPILE A REFEHR
)@@G@@RENCE TO 'ACOS' WHEREVER@^@@@@ 'ARCCOS' IS REFERENCED.@[@@@@      @C@@@@HS
)@@G@@  9. 4. 2.   EXPRESSION-ARITHMETIC PARAMETERS   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      HT
)@@G@@ A VASTLY MORE POWERFUL FORM OF THE PARAMETER STATEMENT IS  @]@@@@ ALLOWHU
)@@G@@ED:   @[@@@@      @E@@@@       PARAMETER <NAME> = <EXPRESSION INVOLVING HV
)@@G@@CONSTANTS>  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHERE <NAME> IS DEFINED AS ABOVE.  <EXPREHW
)@@G@@SSION> MAY BE ANY EXPRES-     @F@@@@ SION IN ANY MODE OR COMBINATION OF HX
)@@G@@MODES WHICH INVOLVES ONLY     @G@@@@ CONSTANTS, CONSTANT PARAMETERS, ANDHY
)@@G@@ THE LEGAL OPERATORS.  THERE IS     @D@@@@ NO LIMIT OF COMPLEXITY OR PARHZ
)@@G@@ENTHESIS STRUCTURE.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE OIA
)@@G@@PERATORS WHICH ARE LEGAL IN 'PARAMETER' STATEMENTS ARE:     @[@@@@      IB
)@@G@@@^@@@@       +       *       -@ @@@@       /       //      **     @ @@@@IC
)@@G@@       .P.     .LS.    .RS.   @ @@@@       .V.     .A.     .EV.   @ @@@@ID
)@@G@@       .N.     .MIN.   .MAX.  @ @@@@       .MOD.   FLD     .LSC.  @ @@@@IE
)@@G@@       .RSC.   .FLOAT. .FIX.  @ @@@@       .DBLE.  .CONJ.  .CMPLX.@ @@@@IF
)@@G@@       .ABS.   .NABS.  .SIGN. @]@@@@       .DIM.@[@@@@      @G@@@@      IG
)@@G@@ THE DIVISION OPERATOR (/) MAY NOT BE USED WITH AN OPERAND OF     @G@@@@IH
)@@G@@ COMPLEX MODE.  THE EXPONENTIATION OPERATORS (.P.) AND (**) MAY NOT     II
)@@G@@@F@@@@ BE USED WITH AN EXPONENT OF OTHER THAN INTEGER MODE.  ANY OTHER  IJ
)@@G@@@E@@@@ OPERATOR MAY BE USED WITH ANY MODE FOR WHICH IT IS DEFINED.@[@@@@IK
)@@G@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@               =========@[@@@@IL
)@@G@@      @^@@@@       PARAMETER A(20)  @^@@@@       PARAMETER B=3.0D5@^@@@@IM
)@@G@@       PARAMETER C=A+B  @ @@@@       PARAMETER D=MIN(A,B,C) @ @@@@      IN
)@@G@@ PARAMETER E=A+(3.LS.7) @^@@@@       PARAMETER F=(2,5)@A@@@@       PARAMIO
)@@G@@ETER G=(F+E)*MOD(A,3)   @A@@@@       PARAMETER H=FLD(0,6,'*')     @ @@@@IP
)@@G@@       PARAMETER ACOS(ARCCOS) @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 4. 3.   NULLIFYING IQ
)@@G@@A PARAMETER STATEMENT   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RAIR
)@@G@@LPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 19@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@IS
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       A PARAMETER STATEMENT CAN BE 'TURNED OFF'IT
)@@G@@ VIA THE STATEMENT@[@@@@      @B@@@@               PARAMETER <NAME>(<NAMIU
)@@G@@E>)   @[@@@@      @E@@@@ WHICH REMOVES ANY PREVIOUS PARAMETER DEFINITIONIV
)@@G@@ FOR <NAME> @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEIW
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          9- 20@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@IX
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 5.   THE 'DEFINE' STATEMENT.  MACROEXPRESSIIY
)@@G@@ONS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       A MACROEXPRESSION IS A SKELETIZ
)@@G@@AL EXPRESSION WHICH WILL BE   @E@@@@ FILLED IN PLACE OF ITS NAME WHEREVEJA
)@@G@@R THE NAME APPEARS.  FOR@G@@@@ EXAMPLE, SUPPOSE THAT A MACROEXPRESSION NJB
)@@G@@AMED 'SUBS' IS DEFINED AS     @]@@@@ FOLLOWS:   @[@@@@      @A@@@@      JC
)@@G@@         DEFINE SUBS = A,B,C,D@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THEN ANY OCCURRENJD
)@@G@@CE OF THE SYMBOL 'SUBS' WILL BE REPLACED BY     @ @@@@ THE STRING 'A,B,CJE
)@@G@@,D'.  THUS, @[@@@@      @D@@@@       XA(SUBS)    WILL BE EXPANDED TO    JF
)@@G@@XA(A,B,C,D) @[@@@@      @A@@@@  9. 5. 1.   SIMPLE MACROEXPRESSIONS@[@@@@JG
)@@G@@      @E@@@@       THE BASIC FORM OF A MACROEXPRESSION DEFINITION IS    JH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@               DEFINE <NAME> = <EXPRESSION>     @[@@@@JI
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       WHERE <NAME> IS ANY LEGAL VARIABLE NAME, AND <EXPRESSJJ
)@@G@@ION> IS     @F@@@@ NEARLY ANY CHARACTER COMBINATION.  <EXPRESSION> HAS TJK
)@@G@@HE FOLLOWING@#@@@@ CONSTRAINTS.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@      JL
)@@G@@ 1)  IT MUST CONTAIN ONLY LEGAL OPERANDS AND OPERATORS@[@@@@      @F@@@@JM
)@@G@@       2)  IT MUST CONTAIN BALANCED PARENTHESES, BRACKETS, AND    @D@@@@JN
)@@G@@           ALPHABETIC DELIMITERS IF IT CONTAINS ANY.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@JO
)@@G@@       3)  IF IT REFERENCES ANOTHER MACROEXPRESSION, THE REFERENCED     JP
)@@G@@@G@@@@           MACROEXPRESSION DEFINITION MUST PRECEDE THIS DEFINITIONJQ
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@JR
)@@G@@  9. 5. 2.   PARAMETRIC MACROEXPRESSIONS  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       A MORJS
)@@G@@E GENERAL FORM OF THE MACRO-EXPRESSION DEFINITION     @^@@@@ INVOLVES PAJT
)@@G@@RAMETERS:   @[@@@@      @F@@@@       DEFINE <NAME>(<PAR-1>,<PAR-2>,...,<JU
)@@G@@PAR-N>)=<EXPRESSION>    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE PAR-I MUST BE UNSUBJV
)@@G@@SCRIPTED VARIABLE NAMES.  <NAME> AND@F@@@@ <EXPRESSION> ARE DEFINED AS AJW
)@@G@@BOVE.  THE EXPANSION OF THIS FORM OF@B@@@@ MACROEXPRESSION PROCEEDS AS FJX
)@@G@@OLLOWS:     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBEJY
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          9- 21@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@JZ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       1)  THE <EXPRESSION> IS SUBSTITUTED FOR <KA
)@@G@@NAME> IN THE CARD @B@@@@           IMAGE BEING EXPANDED, AS ABOVE.@[@@@@KB
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       2)  EACH <PAR-I> IS TREATED AS A TEMPORARY MACRO-EXPRKC
)@@G@@ESSION@F@@@@           FOR THE CALLING EXPRESSION, AND IS EXPANDED IN THKD
)@@G@@E     @A@@@@           EXPANSION OF <NAME>.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      KE
)@@G@@@A@@@@       THUS, SUPPOSE THE DEFINITION @[@@@@      @C@@@@       DEFINKF
)@@G@@E P(A,B,C) = SIN(3.0*B)-A/B+C(A,3)  @[@@@@      @F@@@@ HAS BEEN PROCESSEKG
)@@G@@D.  WHEN THE COMPILER ENCOUNTERS THE EXPRESSION @[@@@@      @ @@@@      KH
)@@G@@ P(2,24.0*SQRT(X+Y),R)  @[@@@@      @E@@@@ IT WILL REPLACE THIS EXPRESSIKI
)@@G@@ON AS A MACROEXPRESSION WITH  @[@@@@      @E@@@@       SIN(3.0*(24.0*SQRKJ
)@@G@@T(X+Y))-2/(24.0*SQRT(X+Y)+R(2,3)    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF 'R' HAS KK
)@@G@@BEEN DIMENSIONED, R(2,3) WILL BE TREATED AS A   @E@@@@ SUBSCRIPTED VARIAKL
)@@G@@BLE; OTHERWISE IT WILL BE A FUNCTION CALL.@F@@@@ NOTICE THAT IN EXPANDINKM
)@@G@@G EACH PARAMETER AS A TEMPORARY MACROEX-  @F@@@@ PRESSION IN ITS OWN RIGKN
)@@G@@HT, THE COMPILER WILL FILL IN PARENTHESES @F@@@@ IF NECESSARY TO PRESERVKO
)@@G@@E THE ARITHMETIC PRECEDENCES.  IF THE     @F@@@@ ENTIRE MACROEXPRESSION KP
)@@G@@IS INVOLVED IN AN EXPRESSION, THE COMPILER@B@@@@ WILL FILL IN PARENTHESEKQ
)@@G@@S IF NECESSARY.   @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 5. 3.   RULES FOR MACROEXPRESSIKR
)@@G@@ON EXPANSION@[@@@@      @F@@@@       WHEN A MACROEXPRESSION IS EXPANDED KS
)@@G@@AND INSERTED INTO THE   @F@@@@ SOURCE STATEMENT, CERTAIN RULES INVOLVINGKT
)@@G@@ PUNCTUATION APPLY.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       1)  IF THE SUBSTITUTIONKU
)@@G@@ BEING MADE IS A TEMPORARY PARAMETER@F@@@@           MACROEXPRESSION EXPKV
)@@G@@ANSION, AND THE ITEM BEING SUBSTITU-@F@@@@           TED IS A SINGLE ITEKW
)@@G@@M, NO CHECKING IS DONE:  THE ITEM IS@ @@@@           INSERTED DIRECTLY. KX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       2)  IF THE MACROEXPRESSION-CALLING NAME IS BOUNKY
)@@G@@DED ON BOTH @G@@@@           SIDES BY SEPARATOR CHARACTERS, THEN THE EXPKZ
)@@G@@ANDED MACROEX-    @F@@@@           PRESSION IS INSERTED WITHOUT ALTERATILA
)@@G@@ON.  SEPARATOR    @ @@@@           CHARACTERS ARE:    @A@@@@            LB
)@@G@@   ()    PARENTHESES    @ @@@@               []    BRACKETS @ @@@@      LC
)@@G@@         ,     COMMA    @A@@@@               ...   BLOCK OPERATOR @C@@@@LD
)@@G@@               /     SLASH (DATA STATEMENT ONLY)@A@@@@               =  LE
)@@G@@   EQUALS SIGN    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DLF
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 22@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      LG
)@@G@@@C@@@@                     (END OR BEGINNING OF CARD) @[@@@@      @F@@@@LH
)@@G@@       3)  IF NEITHER CONDITION 1) OR 2) IS MET, THEN THE MACROEX-@F@@@@LI
)@@G@@           PRESSION EXPANSION IS ENCLOSED IN PARENTHESES BEFORE   @ @@@@LJ
)@@G@@           BEING INSERTED.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WLK
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 23@[@@@@      @[@@@@      LL
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@  9. 5. 4.   SUGGESTED APPLICATIONS OF MACLM
)@@G@@ROEXPRESSIONS     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE MACROEXPRESSION IS AN IMMLN
)@@G@@ENSELY POWERFUL FEATURE OF THE@F@@@@ RALPH COMPILER, AND CAN BE USED FORLO
)@@G@@ LIMITLESS APPLICATIONS.  HERE@B@@@@ ARE A FEW WHICH ONE MIGHT FIND USEFLP
)@@G@@UL.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@LQ
)@@G@@  9. 5. 4. 1.   SYMMETRIC-MATRIX SUBSCRIPT DEFINITION @[@@@@      @[@@@@LR
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       A SYMMETRIC MATRIX IS A 2-DIMENSIONAL SQUARE MATRIX ALS
)@@G@@(I,J) @F@@@@ WITH THE PROPERTY THAT  A(I,J) = A(J,I) EVERYWHERE.  THUS, LT
)@@G@@FOR A @F@@@@ 100 BY 100 SYMMETRIC MATRIX, 10000 WORDS OF MEMORY ARE REQULU
)@@G@@IRED. @F@@@@ WITH THE USE OF A MACROEXPRESSION TO DEFINE THE ACCESS SUBSLV
)@@G@@CRIPT,@F@@@@ THIS REQUIREMENT CAN BE REDUCED TO 5150 WORDS, A SAVING OF LW
)@@G@@4850! @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@       NORMALLY A MATRIX WOULD BE SELX
)@@G@@T UP AS FOLLOWS   @[@@@@      @D@@@@       DIMENSION X(100,100)     REFELY
)@@G@@RENCING X(I,J)    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@ REPLACE THIS WITH@[@@@@LZ
)@@G@@      @C@@@@       PARAMETER XDIM = (100*100-100)/2+100     @ @@@@      MA
)@@G@@ DIMENSION XX(XDIM)     @^@@@@       DEFINE X(I,J)=   @F@@@@        X(MAMB
)@@G@@X(I,J)-MIN(I,J)+((2*(100+1)-MIN(I,J))*(MIN(I,J)-1)/2) @[@@@@      @[@@@@MC
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ A REFERENCE TO X(I,J) WILL PRODUCE THE PROPER LINEAR SUBSCRMD
)@@G@@IPT FOR     @^@@@@ THE SYMMETRIC MATRIX.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@ME
)@@G@@  9. 5. 4. 2.   LIST DEFINITIONS FOR INPUT/OUTPUT     @[@@@@      @[@@@@MF
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       IT IS VERY COMMON IN A PROGRAMMING PROBLEM TO HAVE NEMG
)@@G@@ED TO @A@@@@ MAKE MANY STATEMENTS OF THE FORM   @[@@@@      @B@@@@      MH
)@@G@@ WRITE(4) (A(I),I=1,N),(B(I),I=1,N) @[@@@@      @E@@@@ THIS CAN BE SHORTMI
)@@G@@ENED CONSIDERABLY VIA A MACROEXPRESSION:  @[@@@@      @A@@@@       DEFINMJ
)@@G@@E LIST1=(A(I),I=1,N)    @A@@@@       DEFINE LIST2=(B(I),I=1,N)    @[@@@@MK
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   ML
)@@G@@       9- 24@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WITH MM
)@@G@@THESE DEFINITIONS AT HAND, THEN THE ABOVE WRITE STATEMENT CAN     @#@@@@MN
)@@G@@ BE SHORTENED TO  @[@@@@      @A@@@@               WRITE(4) LIST1,LIST2 MO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@ A FURTHER IMPROVEMENT MIGHT BE     @[@@@@      @B@@@@MP
)@@G@@       DEFINE LIST(BB) = (BB(I),I=1,N)    @[@@@@      @]@@@@ PERMITTING MQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@               WRITE(4) LIST(A),LIST(B)   @[@@@@      MR
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 5. 4. 3.   PARTWORD STORAGE ALLOCATIOMS
)@@G@@N     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       VERY OFTEN A LARGE-SCALE PROGRAMMING APPLMT
)@@G@@ICATION WILL DEAL @F@@@@ WITH QUANTITIES THAT DO NOT NEED AN ENTIRE 36-BMU
)@@G@@IT COMPUTER WORD  @F@@@@ FOR STORAGE, AND WHICH WOULD NOT FIT INTO AVAILMV
)@@G@@ABLE MEMORY UNLESS@F@@@@ SOME SORT OF 'PACKING', OR COMPRESSING SEVERAL MW
)@@G@@ITEMS INTO ONE    @F@@@@ WORD, IS DONE.  A MACROEXPRESSION PROVIDES A PAMX
)@@G@@INLESS METHOD OF  @F@@@@ DEFINING A 'VARIABLE' TO OCCUPY LESS THAN A FULMY
)@@G@@L WORD OF STORAGE.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       AS A SIMPLE EXAMPLE, SUPPOSE MZ
)@@G@@THAT A BIT PLANE, SUCH AS IS  @F@@@@ USED IN A 'PICTURE' PROCESSING PROGNA
)@@G@@RAM, IS BEING MANIPULATED.  A @F@@@@ CONSERVATIVE SIZE FOR A BIT PLANE MNB
)@@G@@IGHT BE 144 BY 144 BITS, OR A @F@@@@ TOTAL OF 20736.  IF A REGULAR DIMENNC
)@@G@@SION STATEMENT IS USED, THIS  @F@@@@ PLANE WILL REQUIRE 20736 WORDS OF CND
)@@G@@ORE.  BY PARTWORD STORAGE     @G@@@@ MACROEXPRESSION USAGE, THIS CAN BE NE
)@@G@@REDUCED TO 576 WORDS BY PACKING     @^@@@@ 36 BITS TO A WORD!     @[@@@@NF
)@@G@@      @ @@@@       NORMALLY, ONE WOULD PUT@[@@@@      @A@@@@       DIMENNG
)@@G@@SION IPLANE(144,144)    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ AND REFERENCE IPLANE(I,J) AS NH
)@@G@@A BIT.  INSTEAD, INSERT THE STATE-  @]@@@@ MENTS:     @[@@@@      @A@@@@NI
)@@G@@       PARAMETER NDIM = 144*144/36  @ @@@@       DIMENSION BUF(NDIM)    NJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@       DEFINE IPLANE(I,J)=FLD(MOD(J-1,36),1,BUF(4*(I-1)+J//36))   NK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ IPLANE(I,J) NOW REFERENCES ONLY A SINGLE BIT!   SUBSCNL
)@@G@@RIPTION IS BY     @F@@@@ ROWS OF 144 BITS EACH, IN 4 CONSECUTIVE COMPUTENM
)@@G@@R WORDS.  IN THIS @F@@@@ INSTANCE A 'STACK' OF PLANES MAY BE EFFECTED BYNN
)@@G@@ ADDING ANOTHER   @^@@@@ DIMENSION TO 'BUF'     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      NO
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSINP
)@@G@@ON)          9- 25@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       ASSIGNQ
)@@G@@NING STORAGE TO 6-BIT, 12-BIT, OR 18-BIT ITEMS WILL   @F@@@@ CAUSE THE ONR
)@@G@@PTIMIZER TO INSERT THE APPROPRIATE PARTWORD OPERATORS,@ @@@@ CAUSING NO NS
)@@G@@DECREASE IN SPEED.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       TO ASSIGN AN ARRANT
)@@G@@Y WITH 6 BITS PER ITEM (CHARACTER ARRAY), @C@@@@ USE THE FOLLOWING MACRONU
)@@G@@EXPRESSION DEFINITION:  @[@@@@      @ @@@@       PARAMETER NCARD=80//6  NV
)@@G@@@ @@@@       DIMENSION CARD(NCARD)  @D@@@@       DEFINE COLUMN(J)=FLD(6*NW
)@@G@@MOD(J-1,6),6,CARD(J//6))@[@@@@      @F@@@@ A REFERENCE TO COLUMN(12) WILNX
)@@G@@L REFERENCE THE 12'TH COLUMN OF THE @F@@@@ CARD IMAGE IN THE ARRAY 'CARDNY
)@@G@@', WHICH IS THE 6TH CHARACTER OF THE@#@@@@ SECOND WORD.     @[@@@@      NZ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  9. 5. 4. 4.   VARIABLE TRACE@[@@@@      OA
)@@G@@@F@@@@       A GIVEN VARIABLE MAY BE 'TRACED' FOR DIAGNOSTIC PURPOSES   OB
)@@G@@@F@@@@ USING A DEFINED FUNCTION:  SUPPOSE IT IS DESIRED TO TRACE ALL    OC
)@@G@@@D@@@@ OCCURRENCES OF THE VARIABLE 'X'.  DEFINE A TRACER:   @[@@@@      OD
)@@G@@@A@@@@       DEFINE X = IND(VTRACE(X))    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WHERE 'VTRAOE
)@@G@@CE' IS A FUNCTION WHICH PRINTS THE ARGUMENT AND RE-   @F@@@@ TURNS.  IF OF
)@@G@@VTRACE DOES NOT WISH TO TAKE THE TIME TO EXTRACT THE  @F@@@@ NAME AND MOOG
)@@G@@DE OF THE CALLING ARGUMENT, A SECOND ARGUMENT MAY BE  @A@@@@ ADDED, AND OH
)@@G@@ANOTHER ENTRY CALLED:   @[@@@@      @A@@@@       DEFINE X = IND(XTRACE(XOI
)@@G@@,'X'))@[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE 'IND' PSEUDOFUNCTION IS USED IN BOTH CASES OJ
)@@G@@BECAUSE IT MAY    @B@@@@ OCCUR ON EITHER SIDE ON AN EQUALS SIGN.  @[@@@@OK
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       A SLIGHTLY MORE SOPHISTICATED DEFINITION MAY BE USED OL
)@@G@@TO    @F@@@@ TRACE A SINGLE ELEMENT OF AN ARRAY VARIABLE:  THE DEFINITIOOM
)@@G@@N     @[@@@@      @E@@@@       DEFINE R(I) = IND([I.EQ.7,LOC(R(I)),VTRACON
)@@G@@E(R(I))])   @[@@@@      @E@@@@ WILL TRACE R(7) WITHOUT TRACING ANY OTHEROO
)@@G@@ ELEMENT OF R.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO POP
)@@G@@ROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 26@[@@@@      OQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 6.   COMPILEROR
)@@G@@-CONTROL STATEMENTS     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       COMPILER-COOS
)@@G@@NTROL STATEMENTS ARE USED TO MODIFY STANDARD    @G@@@@ COMPILER UTILITY OT
)@@G@@ACTIONS, SUCH AS PRINTING OF THE PROGRAM, COLLEC-     @ @@@@ TION OF REFOU
)@@G@@ERENCES, ETC.     @[@@@@      @ @@@@  9. 6. 1.   LISTING CONTROL  @[@@@@OV
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       LISTING-CONTROL STATEMENTS CONTROL THE PRINTING OF SOOW
)@@G@@URCE  @^@@@@ CARDS AND OBJECT CODE. @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 6. 1. 1.   SOOX
)@@G@@URCE LISTING CONTROL    @[@@@@      @C@@@@       TO START A LISTING OF TOY
)@@G@@HE SOURCE PROGRAM:@[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @A@@@@            OZ
)@@G@@   START EDIT SOURCE    @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @ @@@@      PA
)@@G@@         LISTING ON     @A@@@@               START EDIT SOURCE    @[@@@@PB
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@       TO TURN OFF THE SOURCE-PROGRAM LISTING:  PC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @A@@@@               STOP EDIT SOURCPD
)@@G@@E     @[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @ @@@@               LISTING OPE
)@@G@@FF    @A@@@@               STOP EDIT SOURCE     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE 'STOP EDIT SOURCE' OR 'LISTING OFF' CARD WILL BE THE LAST CARPG
)@@G@@D     @F@@@@ PRINTED UNTIL THE CARD AFTER THE NEXT 'START EDIT SOURCE' OPH
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ 'LISTING ON' CARD, IF ANY.  IF NO CARD TO TURN THE LISTING PI
)@@G@@BACK ON     @D@@@@ APPEARS, THEN THE STORAGE MAP WILL NOT BE PRINTED.   PJ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 6. 1. 2.   OBJECT LISTING CONTROL    @[@@@@      PK
)@@G@@@D@@@@       TO START LISTING OF OBJECT CODE GENERATED:     @[@@@@      PL
)@@G@@@ @@@@       (FORTRAN AND MAD):     @ @@@@               START EDIT CODEPM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       TO TERMINATE THE LISTING OF GENERATED OBJECT COPN
)@@G@@DE, THE     @]@@@@ STATEMENT: @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WPO
)@@G@@ITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 27@[@@@@      @[@@@@      PP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@       (FORTRAN AND MAD):     @ @@@@      PQ
)@@G@@         STOP EDIT CODE @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL START OR STOPR
)@@G@@P OBJECT LISTING EFFECTIVE AS OF THE CARD AFTER @^@@@@ THE STATEMENT ITSPS
)@@G@@ELF.  @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 6. 2.   CROSS-REFERENCE COLLECTION   @[@@@@PT
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       RALPH CAN GENERATE A TABLE OF CROSS-REFERENCES TO ALLPU
)@@G@@ SYM- @G@@@@ BOLS BY STATEMENT NUMBER.  TO INITIATE THE CROSS-REFERENCE PV
)@@G@@COLLEC-     @[@@@@ TION,@[@@@@      @ @@@@       (FORTRAN AND MAD):     PW
)@@G@@@ @@@@               REFERENCES ON  @[@@@@      @C@@@@       TO TURN OFFPX
)@@G@@ CROSS-REFERENCE COLLECTION:  @[@@@@      @ @@@@       (FORTRAN AND MAD)PY
)@@G@@:     @ @@@@               REFERENCES OFF @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@PZ
)@@G@@       THE TABLE OF CROSS REFERENCES WILL BE PRINTED AT THE END OF@E@@@@QA
)@@G@@ PHASE 1, AFTER THE LAST SOURCE CARD PRINTED, BUT BEFORE THE@#@@@@ STORAQB
)@@G@@GE MAP.     @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 6. 3.   CHANGE-OF-LANGUAGE CONTROL   QC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@       RALPH CAN COMPILE BOTH FORTRAN AND MAD PROGRAMSQD
)@@G@@.  IF IT IS @G@@@@ DESIRED TO SWITCH LANGUAGES IN THE MIDDLE, THERE ARE QE
)@@G@@STATEMENTS TO     @F@@@@ CAUSE RALPH TO SWITCH COMPILATION MODES IN THE QF
)@@G@@MIDDLE OF A PRO-  @[@@@@ GRAM.@[@@@@      @#@@@@       (FORTRAN): @^@@@@QG
)@@G@@               ENTER MAD@[@@@@      @#@@@@       (MAD):     @ @@@@      QH
)@@G@@         ENTER FORTRAN  @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THESE STATEMENTS CAUSE QI
)@@G@@THE COMPILER TO BEGIN ACCEPTING     @F@@@@ SOURCE STATEMENTS WRITTEN IN QJ
)@@G@@THE INDICATED LANGUAGE WITH THE NEXT@[@@@@ CARD.@[@@@@      @F@@@@      QK
)@@G@@ BECAUSE OF DIFFERENT CONVENTIONS FOR CONTINUATION STATE-   @F@@@@ MENTSQL
)@@G@@, THE CHANGE-OF-LANGUAGE CARD SHOULD ALWAYS BE FOLLOWED BY A@F@@@@ NULL QM
)@@G@@'CONTINUE' CARD, WITHOUT A STATEMENT LABEL, WITH THE 'C' IN @]@@@@ COLUMQN
)@@G@@N 12: @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDQO
)@@G@@E TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 28@[@@@@QP
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@               ======== @[@@@@      QQ
)@@G@@@^@@@@               ENTER MAD@ @@@@                    CONTINUE  @A@@@@QR
)@@G@@                    (MAD STATEMENTS)@A@@@@                    ENTER FORTQS
)@@G@@RAN   @ @@@@                    CONTINUE  @A@@@@               (FORTRAN QT
)@@G@@STATEMENTS) @[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 6. 4.   GENERIC AND INTRINSIC FUNCTIOQU
)@@G@@N CONTROL   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF A USER HAS CODED HISQV
)@@G@@ OWN FUNCTION WHOSE NAME MATCHES    @F@@@@ THE NAME OF A GENERIC OR INTRQW
)@@G@@INSIC FUNCTION, OR WHICH IS APT     @F@@@@ TO CAUSE DIFFICULTY WITH THE QX
)@@G@@OPTIMIZER, HE MAY WARN THE COMPILER @F@@@@ THAT THIS FUNCTION IS NOT THEQY
)@@G@@ NORMALLY EXPECTED VARIETY VIA THE  @^@@@@ 'ABNORMAL' STATEMENT.  @[@@@@QZ
)@@G@@      @B@@@@  9. 6. 4. 1.   THE 'ABNORMAL' STATEMENT  @[@@@@      @F@@@@RA
)@@G@@       THE 'ABNORMAL' STATEMENT ENABLES THE USER TO REMOVE A FUNC-@F@@@@RB
)@@G@@ TION FROM THE TABLE OF GENERIC OR INTRINSIC FUNCTIONS.  THUS, THE@]@@@@RC
)@@G@@ STATEMENT  @[@@@@      @#@@@@       Y = LOG(X) @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL RD
)@@G@@NORMALLY COMPILE A REFERENCE TO 'ALOG', 'DLOG', OR 'CLOG',  @F@@@@ DEPENRE
)@@G@@DING UPON THE MODE OF X.  FURTHER, THE OPTIMIZER WILL CON-  @F@@@@ DENSERF
)@@G@@ REFERENCES TO THIS FUNCTION, IF NECESSARY, AND CAN OPTIMIZE@F@@@@ AROUNRG
)@@G@@D THE FUNCTION CALL, TRUSTING THAT NO MATHEMATICAL LIBRARY  @F@@@@ FUNCTRH
)@@G@@ION WILL CHANGE ITS ARGUMENT(S) OR CHANGE ANY COMMON-STORAGE@]@@@@ VARIARI
)@@G@@BLES. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF, FOR SOME REASON, THE PROGRAMMER WISHERJ
)@@G@@S TO USE THE FUNC-@F@@@@ TION 'LOG' FOR SOME OTHER PURPOSE, IT MAY BE DERK
)@@G@@ACTIVATED AS A    @F@@@@ GENERIC FUNCTION VIA THE 'ABNORMAL' STATEMENT. RL
)@@G@@ THE GENERAL FORM @[@@@@ IS   @[@@@@      @C@@@@       ABNORMAL <NAME1>,RM
)@@G@@<NAME2>,...,<NAMEN>     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       <NAME1>, ETC., ARE THE RN
)@@G@@FUNCTIONS TO BE DECLARED ABNORMAL.  @F@@@@ THIS DECLARATION IS NOT RETRORO
)@@G@@ACTIVE; IT MUST OCCUR BEFORE THE    @F@@@@ FUNCTION-CALL WHOSE MEANING IRP
)@@G@@S TO BE ALTERED.  IF <NAME> IS NOT A@F@@@@ GENERIC OR INTRINSIC FUNCTIONRQ
)@@G@@, THEN THE 'ABNORMAL' DECLARATION   @G@@@@ WILL BE TREATED AS 'EXTERNAL'RR
)@@G@@ BY THE COMPILER.  (SEE SECTION 8.1.4     @C@@@@ FOR A DISCUSSION OF THERS
)@@G@@ 'EXTERNAL' STATEMENT). @[@@@@      @F@@@@       AS A PRECAUTIONARY MEASRT
)@@G@@URE, THE 'EXTERNAL' STATEMENT, THE  @F@@@@ 'DIMENSION' STATEMENT, OR ANYRU
)@@G@@ MODE DECLARATION WILL ALSO REMOVE A@F@@@@ REFERENCED FUNCTION FROM THE RV
)@@G@@GENERAL OR IMPLICIT FUNCTION TABLE. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMRW
)@@G@@MING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 29@[@@@@      @[@@@@RX
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@               EXAMPLES:@^@@@@      RY
)@@G@@         =========@ @@@@       ABNORMAL SIN,FLOAT,SQRT@#@@@@       ABNORRZ
)@@G@@MAL X @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 6. 4. 2.   CONTROL VIA DECLARATSA
)@@G@@ION STATEMENTS.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IF A GENERIC OR ISB
)@@G@@NTRINSIC FUNCTION IS REFERENCED IN A DECLARATION@G@@@@ STATEMENT, THEN ISC
)@@G@@T IS CONSIDERED ABNORMAL FOR OPTIMIZATION PURPOSES.   @E@@@@ FOR A COMPLSD
)@@G@@ETE DISCUSSION OF THIS ACTION, SEE SECTION 8.2.2@ @@@@ (ITEMIZED MODE DESE
)@@G@@CLARATIONS) @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBESF
)@@G@@R 1971 VERSION)          9- 30@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@SG
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  9. 7.   SOURCE STATEMENT CONTROL  @[@@@@      SH
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 7. 1.   THE 'INCLUDE' STATEMENT (FORTSI
)@@G@@RAN AND MAD)@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE 'INCLUDE' STATEMENTSJ
)@@G@@ PROVIDES THE PROGRAMMER WITH A MEANS     @F@@@@ OF ADDING PRE-CODED STASK
)@@G@@TEMENTS, EITHER FROM THE SYSTEM LIBRARY OR@F@@@@ HIS OWN LIBRARY, TO HISSL
)@@G@@ PROGRAM.  IN SIMPLEST FORM, THE INCLUDE  @#@@@@ STATEMENT IS     @[@@@@SM
)@@G@@      @A@@@@       INCLUDE <PROCEDURE-NAME>     @[@@@@      @A@@@@ OR   SN
)@@G@@ INCLUDE <PROCEDURE-NAME>,LIST@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE SECOND FORM WSO
)@@G@@ILL PROVIDE A LISTING OF THE INCLUDED     @F@@@@ STATEMENTS.  THE INCLUDSP
)@@G@@E WILL CAUSE THE COMPILER TO TRY TO FIND A@F@@@@ FORTRAN PROCEDURE NAMEDSQ
)@@G@@ <PROCEDURE-NAME>.  IT WILL FIRST SEARCH  @F@@@@ THE SOURCE INPUT FILE, SR
)@@G@@THEN THE TEMPORARY PROGRAM FILE TPF$, AND @F@@@@ FINALLY THE SYSTEM LIBRSS
)@@G@@ARY RLIB$.  IF A PROCEDURE WITH THE SPECI-@G@@@@ FIED NAME IS NOT FOUND,ST
)@@G@@ THE INCLUDE STATEMENT IS DECLARED TO BE IN     @]@@@@ ERROR.     @[@@@@SU
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       WHEN THE SPECIFIED PROCEDURE HAS BEEN FOUND, THE CARDSV
)@@G@@S ARE @F@@@@ ADDED TO THE TOMPILATION IMMEDIATELY AFTER THE INCLUDE STATSW
)@@G@@EMENT.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       AN ALTERNATE FORM OF 'INCLUDE' IS PROVIDESX
)@@G@@D, WHICH PERMITS  @D@@@@ THE INCLUSTION OF A PROCEDURE FROM AN ARBITRARYSY
)@@G@@ FILE:@[@@@@      @B@@@@       INCLUDE <FILE>(<PROCEDURE-NAME>)   @C@@@@SZ
)@@G@@ OR    INCLUDE <FILE>(PROCEDURE-NAME>),LIST     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL TA
)@@G@@CAUSE THE COMPILER TO SEARCH ONLY THE SPECIFIED FILE INSTEAD@F@@@@ OF THTB
)@@G@@E NORMAL SEQUENCE.  THE LIMITATIONS OF THE SYNTAX SCANNER   @E@@@@ FORBITC
)@@G@@D FILE NAMES OF MORE THAN 6 CHARACTERS, OR THOSE WHICH@^@@@@ INCLUDE A DTD
)@@G@@OLLAR SIGN. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       IF THE FILE NAME 'FOR$PF' IS ASSIGNTE
)@@G@@ED, EITHER AS A FILE    @F@@@@ IN ITS OWN RIGHT OR AS A '@USE' ASSOCIATITF
)@@G@@ON TO ANOTHER FILE,     @F@@@@ THEN THIS FILE WILL BE SEARCHED INSTEAD OTG
)@@G@@F THE SOURCE INPUT FILE @A@@@@ WHEN LOOKING FOR THE PROCEDURE.    @[@@@@TH
)@@G@@      @D@@@@  9. 7. 2.   THE 'DELETE' STATEMENT (FORTRAN AND MAD) @[@@@@TI
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       THE 'DELETE' STATEMENT PROVIDES THE PROGRAMMER WITH ATJ
)@@G@@ MEANS@G@@@@ OF CONDITIONALLY SKIPPING SECTIONS OF THE SOURCE STATEMENTSTK
)@@G@@ DEPEN-     @D@@@@ DING UPON COMPILATION PARAMETERS.  IT TAKES THE FORM TL
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSITM
)@@G@@ON)          9- 31@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@TN
)@@G@@       DELETE <LABEL>,<VALUE> @[@@@@      @F@@@@       <LABEL> IS A STATTO
)@@G@@EMENT LABEL, AND <VALUE> IS A CONSTANT OR @F@@@@ CONSTANT PARAMETER.  IFTP
)@@G@@ <VALUE> IS ZERO, THE COMPILER IGNORES THE@F@@@@ 'DELETE' STATEMENT.  IFTQ
)@@G@@ <VALUE> IS NON-ZERO, THE COMPILER WILL   @F@@@@ IGNORE ALL SOURCE STATETR
)@@G@@MENTS UNTIL IT ENCOUNTERS ONE WITH THE    @G@@@@ STATEMENT LABEL <LABEL>TS
)@@G@@.  IT IS IMPERATIVE THAT <LABEL> BE PUNCHED     @G@@@@ STARTING IN COLUMTT
)@@G@@N 1 OF THE TERMINATION CARD.  THE CARD WITH LABEL     @E@@@@ <LABEL> IS TU
)@@G@@THE FIRST CARD WHICH WILL BE PROCESSED AFTER THE@#@@@@ 'DELETE' ITSELF. TV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       IF A 'DELETE' STATEMENT OCCURS INSIDE AN INCLUDTW
)@@G@@ED PROCEDURE,     @D@@@@ IT MAY NOT REFER TO A LABEL OUTSIDE THAT PROCEDTX
)@@G@@URE.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DTY
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 32@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      TZ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @D@@@@  9. 7. 3.   CODING A PROCEDURE FOR USE WITH 'INCLUDE'UA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE PROCEDURE DEFINITION PROCESSOR (PDP) IS USEUB
)@@G@@D TO SET UP A     @F@@@@ PROCEDURE FOR USE WITH THE 'INCLUDE' STATEMENT.UC
)@@G@@  FOR A COMPLETE  @F@@@@ DISCUSSION OF THE PROCEDURE DEFINITION PROCESSOUD
)@@G@@R, SEE UNIVAC     @E@@@@ MANUAL UP-4144 (PROGRAMMERS' REFERENCE MANUAL),UE
)@@G@@ SECTION    @[@@@@ 15.2.@[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE STANDARD PROCESSOR-UF
)@@G@@CALL OPTIONS 'I','U','W', AND 'L'   @F@@@@ APPLY TO THE PROCEDURE DEFINIUG
)@@G@@TION PROCESSOR, 'N' IS ASSUMED.  SEE@F@@@@ SECTION 10.3 FOR A DISCUSSIONUH
)@@G@@ OF OPTIONS.  FOR THE PURPOSES OF   @G@@@@ THIS EXAMPLE, ASSUME THAT ONEUI
)@@G@@ IS INSERTING A NEW PROCEDURE ELEMENT     @#@@@@ ('I' OPTION):    @[@@@@UJ
)@@G@@      @B@@@@ @PDP,<OPTIONS>  <ELEMENT DESCRIPTOR>     @#@@@@ <NAME>  PROUK
)@@G@@C     @B@@@@       (                               )  @B@@@@       (    UL
)@@G@@                           )  @B@@@@       (   BODY OF PROCEDURE        UM
)@@G@@   )  @B@@@@       (                               )  @B@@@@       (    UN
)@@G@@                           )  @[@@@@  END @#@@@@ <NAME1>   PROC   @ @@@@UO
)@@G@@       (                )     @ @@@@       (   ETC          )     @ @@@@UP
)@@G@@       (                )     @[@@@@  END @[@@@@      @F@@@@       <OPTIUQ
)@@G@@ONS> IS THE SET OF CALLING OPTIONS, WHICH MUST INCLUDE@F@@@@ 'F' (FOR FOUR
)@@G@@RTRAN).  <ELEMENT DESCRIPTOR> CONTAINS FILE, ELEMENT, @F@@@@ VERSION, ETUS
)@@G@@C., AS IN SECTION 10.1.9.  <NAME> IS THE NAME OF THE  @G@@@@ PROCEDURE, UT
)@@G@@WHICH MUST BEGIN IN COLUMN 1, AND BE SEPARATED FROM THE     @F@@@@ WORD UU
)@@G@@'PROC' BY AT LEAST ONE BLANK.  THE STATEMENTS WHICH FORM THE@F@@@@ BODY UV
)@@G@@OF THE PROCEDURE FOLLOW, AND ARE TERMINATED BY THE 'END'    @F@@@@ CARD.UW
)@@G@@  THE 'END' CARD  *MUST*  HAVE THE 'E' IN COLUMN 2, AND NO  @F@@@@ OTHERUX
)@@G@@ CHARACTERS IN THE FIRST 6 COLUMNS SAVE THE LETTERS 'E',    @F@@@@ 'N','UY
)@@G@@D' IN COLUMNS 2,3,4.  AS MANY PROCEDURES AS DESIRED MAY BE  @E@@@@ PUT IUZ
)@@G@@NTO ONE CALL TO THE PROCEDURE DEFINITION PROCESSOR.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@VA
)@@G@@       WHEN CODING PROCEDURES FOR THE ASSEMBLER, IT IS NECESSARY TO     VB
)@@G@@@F@@@@ SUFFIX EACH ENTRY NAME <NAME> WITH AN ASTERISK.  FOR THIS READON,VC
)@@G@@@E@@@@ THE FORTRAN PROCEDURE SCANNER WILL ACCEPT FORTRAN PROCEDURE@E@@@@VD
)@@G@@ ENTRY NAMES WITH ASTERISKS AFTER THE NAME, BUT THEY ARE NOT@]@@@@ REQUIVE
)@@G@@RED.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971VF
)@@G@@ VERSION)          9- 33@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      VG
)@@G@@@B@@@@  9. 7. 4.   AVAILABLE LIBRARY PROCEDURES @[@@@@      @F@@@@      VH
)@@G@@ SOME OFTEN-USED PROCEDURES HAVE BEEN PLACED IN THE SYSTEM  @D@@@@ LIBRAVI
)@@G@@RY RLIB$ FOR REFERENCE BY THE USER.  A SIMPLE   @[@@@@      @^@@@@      VJ
)@@G@@ INCLUDE  <NAME>  @[@@@@      @C@@@@ WILL INCLUDE THE LIBRARY PROCEDURE VK
)@@G@@<NAME>.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  9. 7. 4. 1.   MATHEMATICAL CVL
)@@G@@ONSTANTS    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       'PI' IS THE NAME OF A PROCEDURE WHIVM
)@@G@@CH WILL DEFINE THE SYMBOL     @F@@@@               PI TO THE BEST DOUBLEVN
)@@G@@-PRECISION VALUE OF PI AVAI-  @^@@@@               LABLE.   @[@@@@      VO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@       'CONST' IS THE NAME OF A PROCEDURE VP
)@@G@@WHICH WILL DEFINE A     @F@@@@               NUMBER OF DOUBLE-PRECISION VQ
)@@G@@MATHEMATICAL CONSTANTS: @[@@@@      @A@@@@               NAME     MEANINVR
)@@G@@G     @A@@@@               ====     =======     @[@@@@      @B@@@@      VS
)@@G@@         SQRT2    SQUARE ROOT OF 2  @B@@@@               SQRT3    SQUAREVT
)@@G@@ ROOT OF 3  @D@@@@               E        BASE OF NATURAL LOGARITHMS    VU
)@@G@@@C@@@@               LN10     NATURAL LOGARITHM OF TEN@D@@@@            VV
)@@G@@   DEGREE   NUMBER OF RADIANS PER DEGREE  @D@@@@               RADIAN   VW
)@@G@@NUMBER OF DEGREES PER RADIAN  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@VX
)@@G@@      @A@@@@  9. 7. 4. 2.   PHYSICAL CONSTANTS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      VY
)@@G@@@G@@@@       A NUMBER OF OFTEN-USED PHYSICAL CONSTANTS HAVE BEEN PROVIDEVZ
)@@G@@D     @D@@@@ IN THEIR MKS AND CGS VALUES.  THESE CONSTANTS ARE:   @[@@@@WA
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@               NAME     MEANING     @A@@@@      WB
)@@G@@         ====     =======     @[@@@@      @D@@@@               C        WC
)@@G@@VELOCITY OF LIGHT IN A VACUUM @C@@@@               EQ       CHARGE ON ANWD
)@@G@@ ELECTRON   @C@@@@               ME       MASS OF AN ELECTRON     @B@@@@WE
)@@G@@               MP       MASS OF A PROTON  @B@@@@               H        WF
)@@G@@PLANCK'S CONSTANT @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DWG
)@@G@@ECEMBER 1971 VERSION)          9- 34@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      WH
)@@G@@@ @@@@               HBAR     H/2PI @B@@@@               NZERO    AVOGADWI
)@@G@@RO'S NUMBER @C@@@@               K        BOLTZMANN'S CONSTANT    @A@@@@WJ
)@@G@@               R        GAS CONSTANT@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@      WK
)@@G@@ THE NAMES OF THE 'INCLUDE' PROCEDURES FOR DEFINING THESE   @G@@@@ QUANTWL
)@@G@@ITIES IN CGS AND MKS UNITS ARE 'CGS' AND 'MKS', RESPECTIVELY.     @[@@@@WM
)@@G@@ THUS,@[@@@@      @#@@@@       INCLUDE MKS@[@@@@      @F@@@@ WILL INCLUDWN
)@@G@@E THE DEFINITIONS OF THE CONSTANTS AS DESCRIBED ABOVE,@#@@@@ IN MKS UNITWO
)@@G@@S.    @[@@@@      @H@@@@       THE VALUES OF THESE PHYSICAL CONSTANTS HAWP
)@@G@@VE NOT EVER BEEN MEASURED     @F@@@@ TO A PRECISION GREATER THAN (AT BESWQ
)@@G@@T) 8 DECIMAL PLACES.  FOR THIS@F@@@@ REASON, IT WOULD BE IDIOTIC TO INCLWR
)@@G@@UDE THEIR VALUES IN DOUBLE    @G@@@@ PRECISION--AN ACT SOMEWHAT AKIN TO WS
)@@G@@SURVEYING A FOOTBALL FIELD WITH     @^@@@@ AN INTERFEROMETER.     @[@@@@WT
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   WU
)@@G@@       9- 35@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 7. 4. 3.   NOWV
)@@G@@NSTANDARD MATRIX SUBSCRIPTION @[@@@@      @F@@@@       'SYMMTX' IS A PROWW
)@@G@@CEDURE CONTAINING TWO MACROEXPRESSION     @F@@@@               DEFINITIOWX
)@@G@@NS WHICH WILL ALLOW THE USER TO DEFINE A  @G@@@@               SYMMETRICWY
)@@G@@ MATRIX, AS IN SECTION 8.5.4.1.  THE MACROEX-   @ @@@@               PREWZ
)@@G@@SSIONS:     @[@@@@      @B@@@@               'SYMM' DEFINES THE ARRAY   XA
)@@G@@@B@@@@               'SYMDIM' DIMENSIONS IT.    @[@@@@      @A@@@@      XB
)@@G@@         THUS, THE SEQUENCE   @[@@@@      @ @@@@               INCLUDE SXC
)@@G@@YMMTX @B@@@@               DIMENSION X(SYMDIM(100))   @C@@@@            XD
)@@G@@   DEFINE X(A,B) = SYMM(X,A,B,100)  @[@@@@      @F@@@@               WILXE
)@@G@@L DEFINE 'X' EXACTLY AS IN SECTION 8.5.4.3.  THE@ @@@@               GENXF
)@@G@@ERAL FORM IS@[@@@@      @F@@@@               SYMDIM(<SIZE>) TO PRODUCE CXG
)@@G@@ORRECT ARRAY DIMENSION. @C@@@@               SYMM(<BASE>,<SUB1>,<SUB2>,<XH
)@@G@@SIZE>)@[@@@@      @F@@@@               TO DEFINE THE MATRIX.  <BASE> IS XI
)@@G@@THE ARRAY DIMEN-  @F@@@@               SIONED WITH 'SYMDIM', <SUB1> AND XJ
)@@G@@<SUB2> ARE THE TWO@G@@@@               SUBSCRIPTS USED IN THE DEFINITIONXK
)@@G@@, AND <SIZE> IS THE     @D@@@@               ROW OR COLUMN OF THE SQUAREXL
)@@G@@ MATRIX.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  9. 7. 4. 4.   PARTWORD STORAXM
)@@G@@GE DEFINITION     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       'PARTWD' IS A PROCEDURE CONTAXN
)@@G@@INING TWO MACROEXPRESSION     @F@@@@               DEFINITIONS WHICH ALLXO
)@@G@@OW THE USER TO DEFINE PARTWORD@F@@@@               STORAGE ALLOCATION, AXP
)@@G@@S IN SECTION 8.5.4.3.  THE    @^@@@@               MACROEX- @ @@@@      XQ
)@@G@@         PRESSIONS ARE  @[@@@@      @G@@@@               'PARTSZ' TO DIMXR
)@@G@@ENSION THE ARRAY 'PART' TO DEFINE THE     @^@@@@               ARRAY.   XS
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@               THUS, THE SEQUENCE:  @[@@@@      @ @@@@XT
)@@G@@               INCLUDE PARTWD @B@@@@               DIMENSION B(PARTSZ(80XU
)@@G@@,6))  @C@@@@               DEFINE COLUMN(K)=PART(B,K,6)     @[@@@@      XV
)@@G@@@F@@@@               WILL DEFINE 'COLUMN' EXACTLY AS IN SECTION 8.5.4.3.XW
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@               THE GENERAL FORM IS  @[@@@@      @F@@@@XX
)@@G@@               PARTSZ(<SIZE>,<BITS>)   TO DIMENSION THE BASE.     @[@@@@XY
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A GUIDE TO PROGRAMMING WITH RALPH (DECEMBER 1971 VERSION)   XZ
)@@G@@       9- 36@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@                  YA
)@@G@@ <SIZE> IS THE NUMBER OF 'CELLS' WITH <BITS>    @B@@@@                  YB
