)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@  1. 2.   DIVISIONAL CONTROL STATEMENTS   @[@@@@      ZB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ DIVISIONAL CONTROL REFERS TO THE BREAKDOWN OF A DOCUMZC
)@@G@@ENT ACCORDING     @F@@@@ TO CHAPTERS, PARAGRAPHS ETC., AND THE CREATION ZD
)@@G@@OF A TABLE OF     @]@@@@ CONTENTS.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@ CHAPTER AND PARAGZE
)@@G@@RAPH NUMBERING IS AUTOMATICALLY CONTROLLED BY   @F@@@@ DOC.  ALSO TEXT CZF
)@@G@@OMPOSITION AND SENTENCE ALIGNMENT IS PERFORMED. @G@@@@ THESE FUNCTIONS AZG
)@@G@@RE REQUESTED BY PLACING A NUMERIC DIGIT (4,3,2,1,     @A@@@@ OR 0) IN COZH
)@@G@@LUMN 1 OF THE TEXT.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ FOUR COUNTERS ARE MAINTAINED ZI
)@@G@@BY DOC.  THEY ARE CHAPTER, SECTION, @F@@@@ SUBSECTION, AND PARAGRAPH COUZJ
)@@G@@NTERS (4,3,2, AND 1) WHICH CONTROL  @E@@@@ THEIR RESPECTIVE NUMBERING ANZK
)@@G@@D TABLE OF CONTENTS ENTRY.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE ACTION TAKEN UPON EZL
)@@G@@NCOUNTERING TEXT WITH A NUMERIC DIGIT IN  @^@@@@ COLUMN 1 IS AS FOLLOWS:ZM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@         4  -  CHAPTER CONTROL.  THE CHAPTER COUNTER IZN
)@@G@@S INCREASED @F@@@@               BY ONE, AND THE OTHER THREE COUNTERS ARZO
)@@G@@E ZEROED.   @F@@@@               THE CHAPTER NUMBER IS EDITED, FOLLOWED ZP
)@@G@@BY A PERIOD,@F@@@@               FOLLOWED BY THE LINE OF TEXT.  THE LINEZQ
)@@G@@ IS PRINTED @F@@@@               AND INSERTED IN THE TABLE OF CONTENTS, ZR
)@@G@@WHERE IT IS @F@@@@               FOLLOWED BY THE PAGE NUMBER FIELD FROM ZS
)@@G@@THE PAGE    @G@@@@               HEADING.  A PAGE EJECT ALWAYS OCCURS BEZT
)@@G@@FORE THE LINE     @ @@@@               IS PRINTED.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ZU
)@@G@@         3  -  SECTION CONTROL.  IF THE CHAPTER COUNTER IS ZERO, IT     ZV
)@@G@@@G@@@@               IS SET TO ONE.  THE SECTION COUNTER IS SET TO 1, ANZW
)@@G@@D     @F@@@@               THE OTHER TWO COUNTERS ARE ZEROED.  THE CHAPTZX
)@@G@@ER AND@G@@@@               SECTION NUMBERS ARE EDITED, THE LINE IS PRINTZY
)@@G@@ED, AND     @E@@@@               IT IS INSERTED IN THE TABLE OF CONTENTSZZ
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@         2  -  SUBSECTION CONTROL.  IF CHAPTER OAA
)@@G@@R SECTION COUNTER @G@@@@               IS ZERO, IT IS SET TO ONE.  PARAGAB
)@@G@@RAPH COUNTER SET TO     @G@@@@               ZERO.  THE THREE COUNTERS AAC
)@@G@@RE EDITED AND THE LINE IS     @E@@@@               PRINTED AND PLACED INAD
)@@G@@ THE TABLE OF CONTENTS. @[@@@@      @F@@@@         1  -  PARAGRAPH CONTRAE
)@@G@@OL.  SIMILAR TO ABOVE, EXCEPT THAT  @G@@@@               INSERTION INTO AF
)@@G@@THE TABLE OF CONTENTS IS MADE ONLY IF     @B@@@@               THE F OPTAG
)@@G@@ION WAS PRESENT.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@         0  -  TEXT COMPOSITION CONTAH
)@@G@@ROL.  NO COUNTER IS INVOLVED  @F@@@@               HERE AND NO ENTRY IS AI
)@@G@@MADE IN THE TABLE OF CONTENTS.@F@@@@               THE ZERO IN COLUMN 1 AJ
)@@G@@IS REPLACED BY A BLANK AND THE@F@@@@               TEXT IS PRECEDED BY AAK
)@@G@@ 'SPACE 0' CONTROL STATEMENT  @^@@@@               IMAGE.   @[@@@@*****^AL
)@@G@@@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCUMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                                AM
)@@G@@ 1-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ FOR EACH COUNTER CONTROAN
)@@G@@L (4,3,2, AND 1), APPROPRIATE SPACING IS  @C@@@@ PERFORMED BEFORE AND AFAO
)@@G@@TER PRINTING AS FOLLOWS:@[@@@@      @D@@@@         4     BEFORE - NEW PAAP
)@@G@@GE     AFTER - 3 LINES  @D@@@@         3            - 2 LINES           AQ
)@@G@@ - 2 LINES  @D@@@@         2            - 1 LINE             - 1 LINE   AR
)@@G@@@D@@@@         1            - 0 LINES            - 0 LINES  @[@@@@      AS
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THE IMAGE INSERTED INTO THE OUTPUT ELEMENT IS THE ORIGINAL IMAGE AT
)@@G@@@F@@@@ WITH A DIGIT IN COLUMN 1, NOT THE IMAGE AS IT APPEARS ON THE     AU
)@@G@@@G@@@@ LISTING.  IN THE TABLE OF CONTENTS, WHICH IS PRINTED AT THE END OAV
)@@G@@F     @E@@@@ THE LISTING, SECTION, SUBSECTION, AND PARAGRAPH TITLES ARE AW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ INDENTED TO THE RIGHT TO IMPROVE THE VISIBILITY OF CHAPTER TITLESAX
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE CHAPTER, SECTION, ETC. TITLE MUST NOT EXTENAY
)@@G@@D TOO FAR TO THE  @G@@@@ RIGHT ON THE CARD, AS THE NUMBERS ARE INSERTED AZ
)@@G@@AT THE LEFT AND THE     @F@@@@ TEXT OF THE TITLE IS SHIFTED TO THE RIGHTBA
)@@G@@ TO MAKE ROOM.  IF THIS @E@@@@ CONSTRAINT IS VIOLATED, THE IMAGE ON THE BB
)@@G@@LISTING WILL BE   @G@@@@ TRUNCATED.   THE CARD IMAGE IN THE OUTPUT ELEMEBC
)@@G@@NT IS UNAFFECTED BY     @F@@@@ THIS CONSIDERATION.   GENERALLY 45 CHARACBD
)@@G@@TERS IS A REASONABLE    @]@@@@ MAXIMUM.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@BE
)@@G@@      @B@@@@  1. 3.   LISTING CONTROL STATEMENTS.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@BF
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ THESE CARDS CONTROL THE GENERAL APPEARANCE OF THE LISTING. BG
)@@G@@ THEIR@G@@@@ FORMAT IS THAT OF A COMMAND WORD, BEGINNING IN COLUMN 1, EXBH
)@@G@@TENDING     @F@@@@ AT MOST TO COLUMN 6.  IN SOME CASES, A SPECIFICATION BI
)@@G@@FIELD MAY   @F@@@@ FOLLOW.  THE AVAILABLE COMMANDS AND THEIR DESCRIPTIONBJ
)@@G@@S FOLLOW.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@ LIST       -  TURN ON THE LISTING.  THIS BK
)@@G@@COMMAND OVERRIDES THE N @F@@@@               OPTION, IF IT WAS PRESENT OBL
)@@G@@N THE PROCESSOR CALL    @^@@@@               CARD.    @[@@@@      @A@@@@BM
)@@G@@ UNLIST     -  TURN OFF THE LISTING.@[@@@@      @D@@@@ EJECT      -  EJEBN
)@@G@@CT PAPER TO BEGIN PRINTING NEW PAGE.@[@@@@      @B@@@@ DOUBLE     -  ENTBO
)@@G@@ER DOUBLE SPACE MODE.   @[@@@@      @B@@@@ SINGLE     -  ENTER SINGLE SPBP
)@@G@@ACE MODE.   @[@@@@      @E@@@@ INSERT     -  66 CHARACTERS, BEGINNING INBQ
)@@G@@ COLUMN 13 OF THE @F@@@@               'INSERT' CARD IMAGE, ARE INSERTEDBR
)@@G@@ INTO THE TABLE OF@^@@@@               CONTENTS.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 11BS
)@@G@@08 DOCUMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1-  5@[@@@@BT
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ SPACE N    -  SPACE PAPER DOWN N LIBU
)@@G@@NES, WHERE N IS AN UNSIGNED   @F@@@@               DECIMAL INTEGER PLACEBV
)@@G@@D IN COLUMNS 7-8.  THIS CAUSES@F@@@@               A PAPER EJECT IF FEWEBW
)@@G@@R THAN N LINES REMAIN ON THE  @G@@@@               PAGE.  IF N IS OMITTEBX
)@@G@@D, A VALUE OF 1 IS ASSUMED.  IF     @G@@@@               A BLANK CARD OCBY
)@@G@@CURS IN THE INPUT, IT IS CONVERTED TO     @F@@@@               A SPACE CBZ
)@@G@@ARD WITH N OMITTED.  IF N IS ZERO, NO     @E@@@@               SPACING ICA
)@@G@@S PERFORMED.  A 'SPACE 0' CARD HAS A@D@@@@               SPECIAL FUNCTIOCB
)@@G@@N AS DESCRIBED LATER.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@ REMAIN N   -  N IS AN UNSIGNECC
)@@G@@D INTEGER IN COLUMNS 8-9.  IF FEWER @F@@@@               THAN N LINES RECD
)@@G@@MAIN ON THE PAGE, A PAPER EJECT     @F@@@@               OCCURS; OTHERWICE
)@@G@@SE THERE IS NO EFFECT.  IF N IS     @G@@@@               OMITTED, ZERO ICF
)@@G@@S ASSUMED.  WHEN THE SPECIFICATION IS     @C@@@@               ZERO, THECG
)@@G@@ PAPER IS NEVER EJECTED.@[@@@@      @F@@@@ UNHYPH S   -  TURN THE HYPHENCH
)@@G@@ATION REMOVAL (G OPTION) ON OR OFF, @F@@@@               WHERE S IS EITHCI
)@@G@@ER 'ON' OR 'OFF' BEGINNING IN COLUMN@#@@@@               8. @[@@@@      CJ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ HYPHEN S   -  TURN THE AUTOMATIC HYPHENATOR ON OR OFF, WHERE S ISCK
)@@G@@@E@@@@               EITHER 'ON' OR 'OFF' BEGINNING IN COLUMN 8.  @[@@@@CL
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ RIGHTM S   -  TURN THE RIGHT MARGIN ALIGNMENT ON OR OFF, WHCM
)@@G@@ERE S @F@@@@               IS EITHER 'ON' OR 'OFF' BEGINNING IN COLUMN 8CN
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @E@@@@ COLUMN N   -  N IS AN UNSIGNED INTEGER IN COLUMCO
)@@G@@NS 8-9.  IF @F@@@@               OMITTED, THE VALUE 2 IS ASSUMED.  UNTILCP
)@@G@@ THE FIRST  @F@@@@               COLUMN CARD APPEARS, COLUMN 2 IS IN EFFCQ
)@@G@@ECT.  N MUST@F@@@@               BE GREATER THAN 1 AND LESS THAN 61.  N CR
)@@G@@DESIGNATES  @F@@@@               THE COLUMN WHICH IS THE NORMAL LEFT MARCS
)@@G@@GIN FOR THE @F@@@@               TEXT.  SUBSEQUENTLY, THE TERM 'COLUMN NCT
)@@G@@' WILL REFER@F@@@@               TO THE CURRENT LEFT MARGIN AS SPECIFIEDCU
)@@G@@ ON THE MOST@G@@@@               RECENT 'COLUMN' STATEMENT.  IF NO 'COLUCV
)@@G@@MN' STATEMENT     @E@@@@               HAVE APPEARED THEN IT WILL REFER CW
)@@G@@TO COLUMN 2.@[@@@@      @E@@@@ WHEN IN THE UNLIST MODE, THE EJECT, SPACECX
)@@G@@, AND REMAIN CARDS@F@@@@ PRODUCE NO EFFECT, EXCEPT THAT THEY ARE RECOGNICY
)@@G@@ZED AS CONTROL    @]@@@@ CARDS.     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCUMENT CZ
)@@G@@PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@DA
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  1. 4.   DOCUMENT TEXT DB
)@@G@@COMPOSITION.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE DOC PROCESSOR FORMS LINESDC
)@@G@@ OF TEXT THAT APPEAR ON THE LISTING @F@@@@ (AND IN THE OUTPUT ELEMENT) WDD
)@@G@@ITH A PROPER LEFT MARGIN AND MAXIMUM@F@@@@ EXTENSION TO THE RIGHT MARGINDE
)@@G@@.  THIS IS ACCOMPLISHED BY MOVING   @F@@@@ WORDS AND BLANK STRINGS FROM DF
)@@G@@THE INPUT LINE TO AN OUTPUT AREA,   @F@@@@ UNTIL THE OUTPUT LINE IS FILLDG
)@@G@@ED.  IT IS THEN PRINTED AND WRITTEN @^@@@@ TO THE OUTPUT ELEMENT. @[@@@@DH
)@@G@@      @A@@@@  1. 4. 1.   RIGHT MARGIN ALIGNMENT.@[@@@@      @F@@@@ DOCUMDI
)@@G@@ENTS BEING PREPARED FOR PUBLICATION SHOULD BE PRINTED USING @F@@@@ THE RDJ
)@@G@@IGHT MARGIN ALIGNMENT OPTION.  THE ROUTINE PERFORMING THIS  @F@@@@ FUNCTDK
)@@G@@ION ALIGNS ONLY THE PRINTED OUTPUT TO THE RIGHT MARGIN.  THE@F@@@@ IMAGEDL
)@@G@@ INSERTED INTO THE OUTPUT ELEMENT IS THE ORIGINAL IMAGE     @F@@@@ BEFORDM
)@@G@@E RIGHT ALIGNMENT.  THUS ANY SUBSEQUENT UPDATING OR TEXT    @F@@@@ EDITIDN
)@@G@@NG SHOULD BE DONE USING A LISTING WITHOUT RIGHT ALIGNMENT.  @[@@@@      DO
)@@G@@@ @@@@  1. 4. 2.   HYPHENATION.     @[@@@@      @E@@@@ AN AUTOMATIC HYPHDP
)@@G@@ENATION ROUTINE IS INCORPORATED IN THE DOC@E@@@@ PROCESSOR.  THE DESIGN DQ
)@@G@@OF THIS ROUTINE IS BASED ON A PAPER,@G@@@@ 'METHOD FOR HYPHENATING AT THDR
)@@G@@E END OF A PRINTED LINE', BY RICH AND     @G@@@@ STONE; COMMUNICATIONS ODS
)@@G@@F THE ACM, AUGUST, 1965, PAGE 444.  BECAUSE     @F@@@@ OF THE NATURE OF DT
)@@G@@THIS HYPHENATION ROUTINE, GRAMMATICALLY CORRECT @G@@@@ RESULTS ARE NOT GDU
)@@G@@UARANTEED, AND SHOULD NOT BE EXPECTED.  DOCUMENTS     @F@@@@ BEING PREPADV
)@@G@@RED FOR PUBLICATION SHOULD NOT, THEREFORE, BE PRINTED @A@@@@ USING THE ADW
)@@G@@UTOMATIC HYPHENATOR.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE HYPHENATOR MAY BE ACTIVATDX
)@@G@@ED AND DEACTIVATED BY THE H OPTION  @E@@@@ AND THE 'HYPHEN' CONTROL CARDDY
)@@G@@ AS DESCRIBED ABOVE.  SHOULD  @E@@@@ ALTERATIONS TO THE TEXT REQUIRE REFDZ
)@@G@@ORMATTING OF THE TEXT,  @F@@@@ HYPHENATED WORDS WILL BE JOINED TOGETHER EA
)@@G@@AS NECESSARY.  THIS     @F@@@@ FEATURE ALSO ALLOWS TEXT ON INPUT CARDS TEB
)@@G@@O BE HYPHENATED AT THE  @E@@@@ END OF A CARD AS DESIRED.  THIS MEANS THAEC
)@@G@@T A WORD WHICH IS @F@@@@ NORMALLY HYPHENATED, SUCH AS 'RIGHT-HANDED', MUED
)@@G@@ST NOT BE SPLIT AT@F@@@@ THE END OF A CARD IN SUCH A WAY THAT THE DESIREEE
)@@G@@D HYPHEN IS THE   @ @@@@ LAST CHARACTER ON THE CARD.  @[@@@@      @A@@@@EF
)@@G@@  1. 4. 3.   HYPHENATION REMOVAL.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ ONCE A DOCUMENT HEG
)@@G@@AS BEEN UPDATED USING THE HYPHENATION ROUTINE THE     @F@@@@ HYPHENS REMEH
)@@G@@AIN FIXED.  IF A SUBSEQUENT LISTING IS RUN WITHOUT THE@F@@@@ 'H' OPTION,EI
)@@G@@ OR WITH THE 'HYPHEN OFF' CONTROL STATEMENT, THESE    @F@@@@ HYPHENS WILEJ
)@@G@@L STILL APPEAR.  IN ORDER TO REMOVE THESE HYPHENS FROM@F@@@@ THE INPUT EEK
)@@G@@LEMENT A NEW UPDATE MUST BE RUN USING THE 'G' OPTION. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@EL
)@@G@@THE 178 DOCUMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1- 10 EM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@ IF THERE IS A WORD ON THE RIGEN
)@@G@@HT MARGIN WHICH IS NORMALLY A @G@@@@ HYPHENATED WORD, SUCH AS 'RIGHT-HANEO
)@@G@@DED', IT MAY BE RETAINED IN THE     @G@@@@ FOLLOWING MANNER.  A 'HYPHEN EP
)@@G@@ON' CARD MUST BE INSERTED IMMEDIATELY     @F@@@@ PRECEDING THE LINE, ANDEQ
)@@G@@ A 'HYPHEN OFF' CARD IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING@F@@@@ IT.  THESE TWO 'HYPHEN'ER
)@@G@@ CONTROL STATEMENTS SHOULD THEN BE REMOVED@^@@@@ DURING THE NEXT UPDATE.ES
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@ IF THE PREVIOUS LINE WAS ALSO HYPHENATED IT WILL BE JET
)@@G@@OINED @F@@@@ CORRECTLY.  ONLY THE HYPHENATED WORD ON THE LINE BETWEEN THEU
)@@G@@E     @D@@@@ 'HYPHEN' CONTROL STATEMENTS WILL REMAIN UNCHANGED.   @[@@@@EV
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ IF THE HYPHENATION REMOVAL OPTION IS IN EFFECT IT SHOULD NOEW
)@@G@@T BE  @F@@@@ USED ON TABULAR OR FLOWCHART SECTIONS.  IT MAY BE TEMPORARIEX
)@@G@@LY    @E@@@@ INHIBITED BY USING THE 'UNHYPH OFF' AND'UNHYPH ON' CONTROL EY
)@@G@@@E@@@@ STATEMENTS.  THE 'UNHYPH ON' CONTROL STATEMENT RESTORES THE@C@@@@EZ
)@@G@@ ORIGINAL G OPTION RATHER THAN TURNING IT ON.   @[@@@@      @C@@@@  1. 4FA
)@@G@@. 4.   INHIBITION OF TEXT COMPOSITION.    @[@@@@      @E@@@@ THE MOVEMENFB
)@@G@@T OF TEXT TO FORM COMPLETE LINES IS HALTED UPON @E@@@@ RECOGNITION OF A FC
)@@G@@CONTROL CARD, AND AT THE START OF A NEW   @F@@@@ PARAGRAPH.  ANY PARTIALFD
)@@G@@ LINE ALREADY CREATED IS PRINTED, AND     @A@@@@ FORMATION OF A NEW LINEFE
)@@G@@ IS BEGUN.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE START OF A NEW PARAGRAPH IS RECOGNIZEFF
)@@G@@D BY THE OCCURRENCE OF A@E@@@@ CARD OF TEXT (I.E., NOT A CONTROL CARD) OFG
)@@G@@N WHICH THE FIRST @F@@@@ NON-BLANK CHARACTER IS NOT IN COLUMN N.  THIS IFH
)@@G@@NCLUDES BOTH THE  @F@@@@ CASE OF INDENTATION TO THE RIGHT AND THAT OF EXFI
)@@G@@TENSION TO THE    @F@@@@ LEFT.   FOR THIS REASON, ALL LINES OF TEXT WHICFJ
)@@G@@H ARE TO BE MOVED @F@@@@ AS NECESSARY MUST BEGIN IN COLUMN N.  MOREOVER,FK
)@@G@@ THE 'COLUMN'     @E@@@@ CONTROL CARD MUST BE USED WHENEVER TEXT IS TO BFL
)@@G@@E INDENTED. @[@@@@      @F@@@@ IN ADDITION TO THE CONTROL CARDS DESCRIBEFM
)@@G@@D ABOVE, TWO SPECIAL    @F@@@@ CONTROLS ARE AVAILABLE TO HALT TEXT MOVEMFN
)@@G@@ENT.  THE FIRST OF THESE@F@@@@ IS A SPACE CARD WITH ZERO LINES SPECIFIEDFO
)@@G@@ FOR SPACING.  A 'SPACE @G@@@@ 0' CARD CAUSES NO SPACING TO BE PERFORMEDFP
)@@G@@; HENCE THE FORMAT OF THE     @E@@@@ LISTING IS UNAFFECTED.  ITS ONLY FUFQ
)@@G@@NCTION IS TO STOP TEXT  @F@@@@ COMPOSITION AND BEGIN A NEW LINE.  SECONDFR
)@@G@@LY, THE IDENTICAL EFFECT@F@@@@ MAY BE OBTAINED BY PLACING A ZERO IN COLUFS
)@@G@@MN 1 OF A CARD, THE TEXT@F@@@@ OF WHICH IS TO BEGIN A NEW LINE.  ON THE FT
)@@G@@OUTPUT, THE 0 WILL BE   @F@@@@ REPLACED BY A BLANK AND THE CARD WILL BE FU
)@@G@@PRECEDED BY A 'SPACE 0' @]@@@@ IMAGE.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHEN CREATIFV
)@@G@@NG TABLES AS PART OF A DOCUMENT, IT IS ADVISABLE TO USE     @F@@@@ 'SPACFW
)@@G@@E 0' CARDS WHERE NEEDED.  TO INSURE PROPER FORMATTING OF    @F@@@@ TABLEFX
)@@G@@S, TABULAR INFORMATION SHOULD NOT EXCEED COLUMN 66.  IN     @F@@@@ ADDITFY
)@@G@@ION, THE RIGHT MARGIN AND HYPHENATION REMOVAL OPTIONS SHOULD@C@@@@ BE TUFZ
)@@G@@RNED OFF ('RIGHTM OFF' AND 'UNHYPH OFF'). @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCGA
)@@G@@UMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1- 8 @[@@@@      GB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@  1. 5.   EDITING GC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE DOC PROCESSOR PROVIDES BOTH CARD IMAGGD
)@@G@@E AND CHARACTER-STRING  @F@@@@ EDITING.  CORRECTION AND UPDATING OF DOCUGE
)@@G@@MENTS IS FLEXIBLE AND   @G@@@@ EASY TO USE.  DURING AN UPDATE, HOWEVER, GF
)@@G@@THE PRINTED IMAGE AND ITS     @F@@@@ CORRESPONDING LINE NUMBER MAY DIFFEGG
)@@G@@R FROM THE IMAGE STORED IN THE@G@@@@ UPDATED ELEMENT.  THIS PRESENTS A PGH
)@@G@@ROBLEM IN UPDATING.  A POSSIBLE     @F@@@@ SOLUTION IS TO TURN THE N (NOGI
)@@G@@ LIST) OPTION ON WHEN MAKING AN     @E@@@@ UPDATE.  THEN IN THE SAME OR GJ
)@@G@@SUBSEQUENT RUN, CALL THE DOC  @F@@@@ PROCESSOR WITH THE 'N' OPTION ON WIGK
)@@G@@THOUT EDITING, AND USE THE    @F@@@@ PREVIOUS OUTPUT ELEMENT AS THE NEW GL
)@@G@@INPUT ELEMENT.  THE RESULTANT @E@@@@ LISTING WILL REFLECT EACH IMAGE AS GM
)@@G@@IT APPEARS IN THE STORED@D@@@@ ELEMENT WITH ITS RESPECTIVE CORRECT LINE GN
)@@G@@NUMBER.     @[@@@@      @A@@@@  1. 5. 1.   CARD IMAGE EDITING     @[@@@@GO
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ THE DOC PROCESSOR LISTS THE SOURCE LANGUAGE INPUT ON WHICH GP
)@@G@@IT IS @F@@@@ OPERATING.  ON THIS LISTING, SUCCESSIVE LINES ARE LABELED BGQ
)@@G@@Y     @F@@@@ SUCCESSIVE INTEGRAL NUMBERS.  WHEN ALTERING A SOURCE-LANGUAGR
)@@G@@GE    @F@@@@ ELEMENT IN A PROGRAM FILE, THESE NUMBERS ARE USED TO INDICAGS
)@@G@@TE    @E@@@@ WHERE CORRECTIONS ARE TO BE INSERTED.  A LINE OF THE FORM: GT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@         -N,M     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WITH THE '-' IN TGU
)@@G@@HE FIRST COLUMN INDICATES THAT SOURCE LINES 'N' @F@@@@ THROUGH 'M' ARE TGV
)@@G@@O BE REPLACED BY ALL SUCCEEDING LINES IN THE    @F@@@@ CONTROL STREAM UPGW
)@@G@@ TO THE NEXT LINE WITH A '-' IN COLUMN ONE, OR  @ @@@@ THE NEXT CONTROL GX
)@@G@@STATEMENT.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@ A LINE OF THE FORM:    @[@@@@      @]@@@@GY
)@@G@@         -K @[@@@@      @F@@@@ INDICATES THAT SUCCEEDING CORRECTIONS AREGZ
)@@G@@ TO BE INSERTED INTO THE@B@@@@ SOURCE LANGUAGE ELEMENT FOLLOWING LINE K.HA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE, THE CONTROL STREAM:   @[@@@@      @#@@@@HB
)@@G@@         -30,31   @ @@@@         CORRECTION LINE A    @#@@@@         -10HC
)@@G@@0,115 @#@@@@         -120     @ @@@@         CORRECTION LINE B    @ @@@@HD
)@@G@@         CORRECTION LINE C    @ @@@@         CORRECTION LINE D    @[@@@@HE
)@@G@@      @F@@@@ WILL REPLACE LINES 30 AND 31 BY THE CORRECTION LINE A, DELEHF
)@@G@@TE    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCUMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).              HG
)@@G@@                   1- 9 @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@ LINESHH
)@@G@@ 100 THROUGH 115, AND INSERT CORRECTION LINES B, C AND D    @^@@@@ FOLLOHI
)@@G@@WING LINE 120.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@ IF THE USER WISHES TO INSERT CORRECHJ
)@@G@@TIONS BEFORE THE FIRST LINE   @G@@@@ ITEM OF HIS OLD SOURCE INPUT, HE MUHK
)@@G@@ST PLACE THEM IMMEDIATELY AFTER     @G@@@@ THE PROCESSOR CALL STATEMENT HL
)@@G@@WITHOUT SPECIFYING A CORRECTION LINE.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ WHEN CORRECHM
)@@G@@TIONS FOLLOW A PROCESSOR CALL STATEMENT IN A CONTROL  @G@@@@ STREAM, THEHN
)@@G@@ SOURCE INPUT ROUTINE (SIR) INTERPRETS A MINUS SIGN '-'     @F@@@@ IN THHO
)@@G@@E FIRST COLUMN OF A LINE AS A CORRECTION LINE.  IN CERTAIN  @F@@@@ SITUAHP
)@@G@@TIONS THE DATA MAY HAVE '-' IN COLUMN ONE.  THIS IS NOT     @F@@@@ DESIRHQ
)@@G@@ABLE, BUT MIGHT HAPPEN WHEN MAKING CORRECTIONS TO A @RUN OR @F@@@@ @ADD HR
)@@G@@STREAM WITH THE @DATA OR @ELT PROCESSORS.  THE USER MAY WISH@G@@@@ TO INHS
)@@G@@SERT A SET OF CORRECTIONS THAT ARE ACTUALLY CORRECTIONS FOR A     @F@@@@HT
)@@G@@ PROCESSOR CALL IN THE @RUN OR @ADD STREAM.  THESE CORRECTIONS ARE@G@@@@HU
)@@G@@ NOT TO BE INTERPRETED UNTIL THE @RUN OR @ADD IS PROCESSED.  TO GET     HV
)@@G@@@F@@@@ AROUND THIS PROBLEM, SIR IS PREPARED TO HANDLE THE FOLLOWING     HW
)@@G@@@#@@@@ CORRECTION LINE: @[@@@@      @]@@@@         -=X@[@@@@      @F@@@@HX
)@@G@@ WHICH MEANS THAT FROM HERE ON, SIR IS TO USE 'X' TO IDENTIFY     @F@@@@HY
)@@G@@ CORRECTION LINES.  'X' MAY BE 1,2, OR 3 CHARACTERS IN LENGTH BUT @F@@@@HZ
)@@G@@ MUST NOT CONTAIN A SPACE OR NUMERIC CHARACTER.  THE USER MAY     @F@@@@IA
)@@G@@ CHANGE CORRECTION LINE IDENTIFIERS AS OFTEN AS HE WISHES BUT SIR @F@@@@IB
)@@G@@ WILL RECOGNIZE ONLY ONE IDENTIFIER AT A TIME.  INITIALLY SIR IS  @E@@@@IC
)@@G@@ SET TO RECOGNIZE '-' AS THE CORRECTION LINE IDENTIFIER.    @[@@@@      ID
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THE FOLLOWING EXAMPLE ILLUSTRATES THE USE OF IDENTIFIER CHANGES. IE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@         -2             FOLLOW LINE 2     @B@@@@      IF
)@@G@@   CORRECTIONS    WITH CORRECTIONS. @C@@@@         -=*            CHANGEIG
)@@G@@ IDENTIFIER TO *. @D@@@@         *11,13         DELETE LINES 11,12, AND IH
)@@G@@13    @C@@@@         CORRECTIONS    AND INSERT CORRECTIONS. @D@@@@      II
)@@G@@   *=+++          CHANGE IDENTIFIER TO +++.     @B@@@@         +++22    IJ
)@@G@@      FOLLOW LINE 22    @B@@@@         CORRECTIONS    WITH CORRECTIONS  IK
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCUMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                    IL
)@@G@@             1- 10@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@IM
)@@G@@  1. 5. 2.   CHARACTER-STRING EDITING.    @[@@@@      @E@@@@ CAPABILITIEIN
)@@G@@S ARE PROVIDED FOR THE MANIPULATION OF CHARACTER@F@@@@ STRINGS ON ANY PAIO
)@@G@@RTICULAR CARD IMAGE OF THE INPUT, EIGHER TEXT OR@E@@@@ CONTROL, WHETHER IP
)@@G@@IN THE RUN STREAM OR THE INPUT ELEMENT.   @G@@@@ CHARACTER EDITING CARDSIQ
)@@G@@ HAVE AN AMPERSAND (&) IN COLUMN 1, AND ARE     @F@@@@ OTHERWISE FREE-FOIR
)@@G@@RM.  THEY FOLLOW THE LINE THAT IS TO BE ALTERED.@[@@@@      @B@@@@ TO COIS
)@@G@@RRECT LINE K OF THE INPUT ELEMENT   @[@@@@      @]@@@@         -K @#@@@@IT
)@@G@@         & ....   @[@@@@      @A@@@@ TO CORRECT A CARD IN THE RUN STREAMIU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@         <BAD CARD>     @#@@@@         & ....   @[@@@@IV
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ THE CHARACTER CORRECTION CARDS HAVE SEVERAL FORMS DEPENDINGIW
)@@G@@ ON THE     @F@@@@ PARTICULAR FUNCTION INTENDED.  EACH FORM WILL BE DESCIX
)@@G@@RIBED BELOW.@E@@@@ IN THE DESCRIPTIONS, THE SLASH (/) IS USED AS A DELIMIY
)@@G@@ITER. @F@@@@ HOWEVER, ANY NON-BLANK CHARACTER WHICH DOES NOT APPEAR IN AIZ
)@@G@@NY    @G@@@@ SPECIFICATION ON THE CARD MAY BE USED INSTEAD.  ONLY ONE CHJA
)@@G@@ARACTER     @F@@@@ MAY BE USED AS THE DELIMITER ON ANY PARTICULAR CARD. JB
)@@G@@ THE FIRST  @F@@@@ NON-BLANK CHARACTER ON THE CARD (AFTER THE AMPERSAND JC
)@@G@@IN COLUMN 1)@F@@@@ IS TAKEN TO BE THE DELIMITER CHARACTER FOR THAT CARD.JD
)@@G@@  IN THE    @G@@@@ FOLLOWING DESCRIPTIONS, CORNER BRACKETS (<,>) ARE USEJE
)@@G@@D TO INDICATE     @F@@@@ METASYNTACTIC VARIABLES.  ANY NUMBER OF BLANKS JF
)@@G@@MAY PRECEDE THE   @#@@@@ FIRST DELIMITER. @[@@@@      @]@@@@ FORM 1     JG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@         &  /<SPEC1> / <SPEC2> /    @[@@@@      @F@@@@JH
)@@G@@ THE CARD BEING CORRECTED IS SEARCHED FOR THE FIRST OCCURRENCE OF @G@@@@JI
)@@G@@ THE CHARACTER STRING <SPEC1>.  THAT STRING IS THEN REPLACED BY THE     JJ
)@@G@@@ @@@@ CHARACTER STRING <SPEC2>.    @[@@@@      @]@@@@ FORM 2     @[@@@@JK
)@@G@@      @A@@@@         &  /<SPEC1> / <SPEC2> /*   @[@@@@      @E@@@@ THIS JL
)@@G@@CARD IS HANDLED JUST LIKE FORM 1, EXCEPT THAT EVERY   @F@@@@ OCCURRENCE JM
)@@G@@OF <SPEC1> IS REPLACED BY <SPEC2>.  THE ASTERISK MUST @F@@@@ IMMEDIATELYJN
)@@G@@ FOLLOW THE THIRD DELIMITER.  (THIS DOES NOT PRECLUDE @C@@@@ THE USE OF JO
)@@G@@THE ASTERISK AS THE DELIMITER).     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCUMENT JP
)@@G@@PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1- 11@[@@@@      @[@@@@JQ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @]@@@@ FORM 3     @[@@@@      @A@@@@         &  //<SPEJR
)@@G@@C1> / <SPEC2> /   @[@@@@      @F@@@@ NOTE THAT THE FIRST TWO NON-BLANK CJS
)@@G@@HARACTERS AFTER THE AMPERSAND @F@@@@ ARE CONSECUTIVE DELIMITERS.  NO CHAJT
)@@G@@RACTERS MAY SEPARATE THEM, OR @F@@@@ THIS CARD WILL BE ASSUMED TO BE OF JU
)@@G@@FORM 1 OR 2.  <SPEC1> MAY     @F@@@@ CONTAIN DIGITS AND BLANKS ONLY, OR JV
)@@G@@MAY BE EMPTY.  IT SPECIFIES A @F@@@@ COLUMN NUMBER.  IF SPEC1 CONTAINS AJW
)@@G@@N ILLEGAL CHARACTER, OR IS    @F@@@@ BLANK OR EMPTY, THE VALUE ASSUMED IJX
)@@G@@S THAT WHICH APPEARED ON THE  @G@@@@ MOST RECENT VALID COLUMN CARD.  THEJY
)@@G@@ EFFECT OF THIS CORRECTION CARD     @F@@@@ IS TO INSERT THE CHARACTER STJZ
)@@G@@RING <SPEC2> BEGINNING AT THE COLUMN@E@@@@ SPECIFIED BY <SPEC1> OVERLAYIKA
)@@G@@NG ANY PREVIOUSLY EXISTING    @]@@@@ CHARACTERS.@[@@@@      @]@@@@ FORM KB
)@@G@@4     @[@@@@      @^@@@@         &  //<SPEC1> / @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THIS KC
)@@G@@CARD IS SIMILAR TO THAT FOR FORM 3, EXCEPT THAT THERE MUST BE     @F@@@@KD
)@@G@@ EXACTLY THREE DELIMITERS ON THE CARD.  <SPEC1> IS INTERPRETED IN @G@@@@KE
)@@G@@ THE SAME WAY AS FOR FORM 3.  THE FUNCTION OF THIS CARD IS TO CAUSE     KF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE CARD BEING ALTERED TO HAVE ITS FIRST NON-BLANK CHARACTER AFTEKG
)@@G@@R     @F@@@@ COLUMN 1 OCCUR IN THE COLUMN SPECIFIED BY <SPEC1>.  THE CHAKH
)@@G@@RACTER@E@@@@ STRING BEGINNING WITH THE FIRST NON-BLANK IS SHIFTED IN ITSKI
)@@G@@@B@@@@ ENTIRETY TO SATISFY THIS REQUIREMENT.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      KJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE USE OF CHARACTER INSERTION CARDS IS LIKELY TO ALTER THE LENGTKK
)@@G@@H     @F@@@@ OF THE CARD IMAGE.  IF IT IS SHORTENED, THE UNUSED AREA IS KL
)@@G@@FILLED@F@@@@ WITH BLANKS.  IF IT IS LENGTHENED, THE EXCESS IS FIRST CHECKM
)@@G@@KED TO@F@@@@ SEE IF IT IS ENTIRELY BLANK.  IF SO, IT IS IGNORED.  OTHERWKN
)@@G@@ISE,  @F@@@@ THE CARD IS CONTINUED IN SUCH A WAY THAT A WORD (A STRING OKO
)@@G@@F     @F@@@@ CONSECUTIVE NON-BLANK CHARACTERS) IS NOT BROKEN BETWEEN CARKP
)@@G@@D     @F@@@@ IMAGES, WHICH MEANS EACH CARD IMAGE ENDS WITH A STRING OF BKQ
)@@G@@LANKS,@F@@@@ AND THE FIRST WORD OF EACH CONTINUATION CARD BEGINS IN COLUKR
)@@G@@MN N, @E@@@@ WITH COLUMNS 1 THROUGH N-1 BLANKED OUT.  THIS INDICATES THEKS
)@@G@@@E@@@@ IMPORTANCE OF THE PROPER USE OF COLUMN CONTROL CARDS.  THIS@F@@@@KT
)@@G@@ CONTINUATION PROCESS WILL FAIL IF A SUFFICIENTLY LONG STRING OF  @E@@@@KU
)@@G@@ CONSECUTIVE NON-BLANK CHARACTERS SHOULD BE ENCOUNTERED.    @[@@@@      KV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE LENGTH OF SUCH A STRING SHOULD NOT EXCEED 67-N, WHERE N IS THKW
)@@G@@E     @F@@@@ SPECIFICATION OF THE CURRENTLY EFFECTIVE 'COLUMN N' CARD.  KX
)@@G@@THE   @F@@@@ MAXIMUM LENGTH TO WHICH A CARD MAY EXPAND IS OVER 600 CHARAKY
)@@G@@CTERS.@F@@@@ THUS MORE THAN ONE CHARACTER CORRECTION MAY BE MADE; THE CAKZ
)@@G@@RD TO @G@@@@ BE CHANGED IS MERELY FOLLOWED WITH AS MANY CHARACTER EDITINLA
)@@G@@G CARDS     @F@@@@ AS ARE NECESSARY.  THE CHANGES ARE MADE IN THE SAME OLB
)@@G@@RDER AS THE @^@@@@ CARDS ARE ENCOUNTERED. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE 1108 DOCLC
)@@G@@UMENT PROCESSOR (DOC).                                 1- 12@[@@@@      LD
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @]@@@@ EXAMPLES:  @[@@@@      @D@@@@ SUPPOSE THELE
)@@G@@ FOLLOWING IS A PORTION OF A DOCUMENT:    @[@@@@      @G@@@@         43 LF
)@@G@@   ...  UNARMED AND UNPREPARED TO BEET THEM BACK.  'TIS     @G@@@@      LG
)@@G@@   44    SAID THAT RICHMOND IS THEIR ADMIRAL.  AND THERE THEY     @G@@@@LH
)@@G@@         45    HULL,   AWAITING   BUT  EHT  AID  OF  BUCKINGHAM  TO     LI
)@@G@@@B@@@@         46    TO WELCOME THME ASHOR....  @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THERELJ
)@@G@@ ARE SEVERAL TYPOGRAPHICAL ERRORS IN THE ABOVE.  THEY CAN BE@^@@@@ CORRELK
)@@G@@CTED AS FOLLOWS:  @[@@@@      @C@@@@         @DOC,SMLFD     RICHARD/III,LL
)@@G@@RICHARD/III @]@@@@         -43@^@@@@         &/BEET/BEAT/   @]@@@@      LM

)@@G@@HME/THEM/   @^@@@@         &/SHOR/SHORE/  @#@@@@         &//2/    @C@@@@LO
)@@G@@                        (WILLIAM SHAKESPEAR)    @^@@@@         &/WILLIAMLP
)@@G@@/WM./ @[@@@@      @E@@@@ RESULTING IN THE FOLLOWING OUTPUT, ASSUMING NO LQ
)@@G@@LINE NUMBER @]@@@@ CHANGES:   @[@@@@      @G@@@@         43*   ...  UNARLR
)@@G@@MED AND UNPREPARED TO BEAT THEM BACK.  'TIS     @G@@@@         44    SAILS
)@@G@@D THAT RICHMOND IS THEIR ADMIRAL.  AND THERE THEY     @G@@@@         45*LT
)@@G@@   HULL,  AWAITING BUT THE AID OF BUCKINGHAM TO WELCOME     @ @@@@      LU
)@@G@@   46*   THEM ASHORE....@D@@@@         47                     (WM. SHAKELV
)@@G@@SPEARE)     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ SIMILARLY, THE FOLLOWING ILLUSTRATES AN ALW
)@@G@@PPROPRIATE USE OF THE   @F@@@@ 'COLUMN' CARD, IN A LISTING THAT MIGHT HALX
)@@G@@VE BEEN PRODUCED WITH   @[@@@@ @PRT:@[@@@@      @B@@@@         14    OPTLY
)@@G@@IONS AVAILABLE ARE:     @^@@@@         15    COLUMN 11@G@@@@         16 LZ
)@@G@@         S - THIS  OPTION  IS USED TO INDICATE THAT THE     @G@@@@      MA
)@@G@@   17              FILE  IS  TO BE SENT TO A SPECIFIC DEVICE.     @^@@@@MB

)@@G@@ PUNCH FILE @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  PROPER  USE  OF  'COLUMN'  CARDS  CAMD

)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  1. 7NB
)@@G@@.   SUGGESTIONS FOR DOCUMENT PREPARATION. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@NC
)@@G@@ IN THE PREPARATION OF A DOCUMENT THE FOLLOWING SUGGESTIONS MAY BE@#@@@@ND
)@@G@@ USED AS A GUIDE. @[@@@@      @F@@@@         1.    KEYPUNCH CHAPTER, SECNE
)@@G@@TION, SUBSECTION AND PARAGRAPH@E@@@@               TITLE CARDS WITH A 4,NF
)@@G@@ 3, 2, OR 1 IN COLUMN 1.@[@@@@      @F@@@@         2.    KEYPUNCH ALL OTNG
)@@G@@HER CARDS STARTING IN COLUMN 2.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@         3.    STANH
)@@G@@RT EACH SENTENCE IN COLUMN 2 OF A NEW CARD.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      NI
)@@G@@   4.    SENTENCES MAY BE COMBINED INTO PARAGRAPHS BY PLACING     @F@@@@NJ
)@@G@@               A 'NEW PARAGRAPH CARD' AT THE START OF EACH NEW    @G@@@@NK
)@@G@@               PARAGRAPH.  A NEW PARAGRAPH CARD HAS COLUMNS 1 AND 2     NL
)@@G@@@F@@@@               BLANK.  THE DOC PROCESSOR WILL RUN THE SENTENCES   NM
)@@G@@@G@@@@               WITHIN EACH PARAGRAPH TOGETHER WITH TWO BLANKS AFTENN
)@@G@@R     @ @@@@               EACH PERIOD.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@         5. NO
)@@G@@   WORDS SHOULD NOT BE SPLIT FROM ONE CARD TO THE NEXT@F@@@@            NP
)@@G@@   WITH A HYPHEN.  IF A WORD WILL NOT FIT IN THE SPACE@F@@@@            NQ
)@@G@@   REMAINING IT SHOULD BE STARTED ON THE NEXT CARD IN @F@@@@            NR
)@@G@@   COLUMN 2.  THE DOC PROCESSOR WILL IGNORE THE BLANKS@G@@@@            NS
)@@G@@   TO THE RIGHT OF THE LAST NON-BLANK.  THE WORD ON THE     @F@@@@      NT
)@@G@@         NEXT CARD WILL BE STARTED WITH ONE BLANK BETWEEN   @^@@@@      NU
)@@G@@         THEM.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@         6.    PRECEDE ALL TABLES ANNV
)@@G@@D FLOWCHARTS WITH 'RIGHTM OFF'@D@@@@               AND 'UNHYPH OFF' CONTNW
)@@G@@ROL STATEMENTS.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@         7.    IF TEXT CONTINUES AFTNX
)@@G@@ER THE TABLES OR FLOWCHARTS,  @G@@@@               RESTORE THE OPTIONS WNY
)@@G@@ITH 'RIGHTM ON' AND 'UNHYPH ON'     @A@@@@               CONTROL STATEMENZ
)@@G@@NTS.  @[@@@@      @F@@@@         8.    IN UPDATING CHANGES TO A FILE, DOOA
)@@G@@ SO WITH THE N    @F@@@@               OPTION ON, TO PRODUCE NO LISTING.OB
)@@G@@  THEN PRODUCE A  @F@@@@               LISTING OF THE NEWLY UPDATED FILEOC
)@@G@@ USING AN '@ELT,L'@E@@@@               OR A '@LIST,S' STATEMENT.  THIS WOD
)@@G@@ILL SHOW THE@F@@@@               ELEMENT AS IT IS FOR FUTURE UPDATING.  OE
)@@G@@FOLLOWING   @F@@@@               THIS UPDATING, THE DOC PROCESSOR SHOULDOF
)@@G@@ BE USED TO @G@@@@               PRODUCE A FORMATTED LISTING WITH THE DEOG
)@@G@@SIRED LISTING     @A@@@@               OPTIONS SPECIFIED.   @[@@@@      OH
)@@G@@@F@@@@         9.    IN FLOWCHARTING, DO NOT PLACE A HYPHEN IN THE SAME OI
)@@G@@@F@@@@               COLUMN SPECIFIED BY THE PREVIOUS 'COLUMN' CARD.    OJ
)@@G@@___LE1,TPF$.FILE2 @ @@@@         @ELT,L  TPF$.FILE2   @#@@@@         @FIOK

)@@G@@      @^@@@@  1.   INTRODUCTION     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      UH
)@@G@@@G@@@@       APL\1100  IS  A CONVERSATIONAL PROCESSOR FOR THE UNIVAC 110UI
)@@G@@0     @G@@@@ SERIES  OF  COMPUTERS WHICH COMPILES AND EXECUTES PROGRAMS UJ
)@@G@@WRITTEN     @G@@@@ IN  THE  IVERSON  APL  LANGUAGE.    THIS  LANGUAGE  WUK
)@@G@@AS ORIGINALLY     @F@@@@ DESCRIBED   BY  K.   E.   IVERSON  IN  HIS  BOOUL
)@@G@@K  'A  PROGRAMMING@G@@@@ LANGUAGE'[1].   IN THIS WORK,  DR. IVERSON NOTEUM
)@@G@@D THAT CONVENTIONAL     @G@@@@ MATHEMATICAL  SYMBOLS  DID  NOT  ENCOMPASUN
)@@G@@S  MANY OF THE OPERATIONS     @G@@@@ WHICH  ARE  USED IN STATING ALGORITUO
)@@G@@HMS,  AND PROCEEDED TO DEFINE A     @G@@@@ NOTATIONAL SYSTEM WHICH LACKEUP
)@@G@@D THESE DEFICIENCIES.   THE SYSTEM HE     @G@@@@ DEFINED WAS CONCISE,  SUQ
)@@G@@ELF CONSISTENT, AND SUFFICIENTLY GENERAL TO     @C@@@@ BE ABLE TO DESCRIUR
)@@G@@BE A WIDE CLASS OF PROBLEMS.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      IN THE TIME SINCE US
)@@G@@THIS WORK WAS ORIGINALLY PUBLISHED, SEVERAL     @G@@@@ COMPUTER  SYSTEMSUT
)@@G@@  WHICH  WOULD  PROCESS  THE  APL  LANGUAGE  WERE     @G@@@@ DEVELOPED [UU
)@@G@@2] [3],  AND SOME EVOLUTION IN THE LANGUAGE ITSELF TOOK     @G@@@@ PLACEUV
)@@G@@;  FEATURES  NEEDED  FOR  COMPUTER IMPLEMENTATION WERE ADDED,     @G@@@@UW
)@@G@@ OTHER FEATURES WERE DELETED, AND THE INTERPRETATION OF SOME OF THE     UX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SYMBOLS  WAS  CHANGED.    ALTHOUGH  A  FORMAL  DEFINITION  OF  THUY
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RESULTING  COMPUTER LANGUAGE HAS NOT YET BEEN PUBLISHED,  TUZ
)@@G@@HE MOST     @F@@@@ EXTENSIVE  DESCRIPTION  OF  THE  LANGUAGE  AND  ITS  VA
)@@G@@FEATURES  IS@G@@@@ CONTAINED IN PAKIN [4].   IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT A FVB
)@@G@@EW EXTENSIONS     @G@@@@ HAVE  BEEN  MADE TO APL SINCE THE PUBLICATION OVC
)@@G@@F [4],  AND SOME OF     @G@@@@ THE  FEATURES DESCRIBED IN IT ARE NOT YETVD
)@@G@@ OPERATIONAL IN APL\1100.     @G@@@@ THESE  DIFFERENCES ARE NOTED AT APPVE
)@@G@@ROPRIATE PLACES IN THIS MANUAL.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS MANUAL VF
)@@G@@IS INTENDED AS A REFERENCE TO THE APL\1100 SYSTEM     @G@@@@ FOR USERS, VG
)@@G@@ AND CORRESPONDS TO LEVEL 4.0 OF THE PROGRAM.  INFORMA-     @G@@@@ TION VH
)@@G@@ ABOUT  PARTICULAR CHANGES AND NEW FEATURES MAY ALSO BE FOUND     @G@@@@VI
)@@G@@ IN  THE  APL  WORKSPACE   1   APL1100.    INFORMATION REQUIRED FOR     VJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ INSTALLATION  MANAGEMENT  AND  SYSTEM  PROGRAMMERS MAY BE FOUND IVK
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ COMPANION  DOCUMENTS.   THIS VERSION OF THE MANUAL IS PRELIVL
)@@G@@MINARY,     @G@@@@ AND  IN  SOME CASES INCOMPLETE.   WE ARE RELEASING ITVM
)@@G@@ AT THIS TIME     @G@@@@ BECAUSE  OF  A  SIGNIFICANT  DEMAND  FROM  USERVN
)@@G@@S TO HAVE AVAILABLE     @D@@@@ INFORMATION SPECIFICALLY ABOUT THIS IMPLEVO
)@@G@@MENTATION.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      APL\1100 HAS BEEN DEVELOPED AT THE CVP
)@@G@@OMPUTER SCIENCE CENTER OF     @G@@@@ THE  UNIVERSITY  OF  MARYLAND (COLLVQ
)@@G@@EGE PARK CAMPUS),  WITH PARTIAL     @G@@@@ SUPPORT  FROM NSF GRANT #GU-2VR
)@@G@@061,  AND HAS BEEN OPERATIONAL IN ONE     @G@@@@ FORM  OR ANOTHER SINCE VS
)@@G@@JANUARY,  1971.   A GREAT DEAL OF CREDIT IS     @G@@@@ DUE  TO  THE  MANVT
)@@G@@Y  STUDENTS WHO WORKED ON THIS PROJECT AT VARIOUS     @G@@@@ TIMES:   GEVU
)@@G@@ORGE MC HUGH,  DAN MINTZ,  JOE MAKSIN,  RAY COOK,  JOHN     @G@@@@ ROUNTVV
)@@G@@REE,   AND  MIKE  MC  AMIS.   ESPECIAL THANKS TO THE CENTER'S     @F@@@@VW
)@@G@@ ASSOCIATE  DIRECTOR,   MR.    JOHN  P.   MENARD,   WITHOUT  WHOSE@E@@@@VX
)@@G@@ ENCOURAGEMENT WE WOULD NEVER HAVE GOTTEN OFF THE GROUND.   @[@@@@      VY
)@@G@@@D@@@@                                          PEH 9/20/71 @E@@@@      VZ
)@@G@@                                    COLLEGE PARK, MD. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@WA
)@@G@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           1-  2WB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  1.   DESK CALCULATOR USAGE  WC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  1. 1WD
)@@G@@.   SIGNING ON    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          APL\1100  RUNSWE
)@@G@@  AS  A  NORMAL  PROCESSOR UNDER THE EXEC 8     @G@@@@ SYSTEM; IT CAN BEWF
)@@G@@ RUN FROM DEMAND (TELETYPE) OR IN THE BATCH MODE,     @G@@@@ ALTHOUGH  IWG
)@@G@@T  IS  PRIMARILY DEMAND-ORIENTED.   AFTER FOLLOWING THE     @G@@@@ NORMAWH
)@@G@@L  EXEC  8  PROCEDURES  TO  MAKE YOURSELF KNOWN TO THE SYSTEM     @G@@@@WI
)@@G@@ (I.E.  TYPING A SITEID AND A @RUN CARD),  THE APL PROCESSOR MAY BE     WJ
)@@G@@@A@@@@ INVOKED BY THE SINGLE CARD IMAGE   @[@@@@      @^@@@@            WK
)@@G@@       @APL @[@@@@      @E@@@@ OR, IF YOU HAVE LOCKED YOUR LIBRARY NUMBEWL
)@@G@@R (SEE CHAPTER 4):@[@@@@      @A@@@@                   @APL   /<KEY>    WM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHERE  <KEY> IS THE PREVIOUSLY DEFINED PASSWORD.   THWN
)@@G@@E SYSTEM WILL     @G@@@@ RESPOND WITH A SIGN-ON LINE, FOLLOWED BY ONE OFWO
)@@G@@ TWO SIGNALS EITHER     @[@@@@      @A@@@@                   CLEAR  WS, WP
)@@G@@   OR @[@@@@      @B@@@@                   SAVED  MM/DD/YY - HH:MM@[@@@@WQ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ THE 'CLEAR WS' MESSAGE IS THE NORMAL ONE;  'SAVED' ETC.  INWR
)@@G@@DICATES     @G@@@@ THAT  A WORKSPACE YOU SAVED USING ')CONTINUE' (CHAPTEWS
)@@G@@R 4) HAS BEEN     @G@@@@ RESTORED FOR YOU,  ENABLING YOU TO CONTINUE YOUWT
)@@G@@R PREVIOUS TERMINAL     @G@@@@ SESSION FROM THE POINT YOU LEFT OFF.  IN WU
)@@G@@EITHER CASE, YOU HAVE NOW     @G@@@@ ESTABLISHED  YOURSELF  IN  THE  DESWV
)@@G@@K CALCULATOR MODE AND MAY START     @^@@@@ ENTERING STATEMENTS.   @[@@@@WW
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  1. 2.   ENTERING STATEMENTS @[@@@@      @[@@@@WX
)@@G@@      @G@@@@          IN  THE  DESK CALCULATOR MODE,  ANY STATEMENT TYPEWY
)@@G@@D IN IS     @G@@@@ IMMEDIATELY  EVALUATED  AND  (NORMALLY) THE RESULTS AWZ
)@@G@@RE DISPLAYED.     @A@@@@ THUS, TYPING IN THE EXPRESSION     @[@@@@      XA
)@@G@@@^@@@@                   3 + 4@[@@@@      @G@@@@ (FOLLOWED,   OF  COURSEXB
)@@G@@,   BY  A CARRIAGE RETURN) WILL RESULT IN A     @^@@@@ DISPLAY OF THE VAXC
)@@G@@LUE 7.@[@@@@      @G@@@@         THE SIMPLE STATEMENT ABOVE IS AN EXAMPLXD
)@@G@@E OF THE USE OF THE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRXE
)@@G@@ELIMINARY)                           1-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@XF
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ OPERATOR '+',  THE DYADIC ADDITION OPERATOR.  SO-CALLED 'PRXG
)@@G@@IMITIVE     @G@@@@ OPERATORS'  ARE PROVIDED FOR ALL OF THE NORMAL MATHEMXH
)@@G@@ATICAL OPERA-     @G@@@@ TIONS,  SUCH AS ADDITION,  SUBTRACTION,  MULTIPXI
)@@G@@LICATION,  ETC.  IN     @G@@@@ ADDITION,   THE  LANGUAGE  CONTAINS PRIMIXJ
)@@G@@TIVES FOR MANY OPERATIONS     @G@@@@ NEEDED  SPECIFICALLY  TO  DESCRIBE XK
)@@G@@ALGORITHMS.   IT IS THESE OTHER     @G@@@@ OPERATORS  WHICH  SERVE  PRIMXL
)@@G@@ARILY  TO  DISTINGUISH APL FROM OTHER     @F@@@@ PROGRAMMING   LANGUAGESXM
)@@G@@;   THEY  MAKE  IT  UNNECESSARY  (IN  MOST@G@@@@ INSTANCES) TO PROGRAM LXN
)@@G@@OOPS,  AND ENABLE THE PROGRAMMER TO SPECIFY     @G@@@@ WHAT  IS TO BE DOXO
)@@G@@NE (HIS ALGORITHM) RATHER THAN THE DETAILS OF HOW     @^@@@@ TO DO IT (AXP
)@@G@@ PROGRAM).  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  1. 3.   THE APL CHARACTER SEXQ
)@@G@@T.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          BECAUSE OF THE WIDE RANGE XR
)@@G@@OF OPERATIONS WHICH CAN BE DES-     @G@@@@ CRIBED BY THE LANGUAGE,  A GRXS
)@@G@@EAT MANY DIFFERENT SYMBOLS ARE NEEDED     @G@@@@ TO  SPECIFY  THEM.    IXT
)@@G@@NDEED ONE OF THE CRITICISMS OF APL HAS BEEN     @G@@@@ THAT  THERE  ARE XU
)@@G@@TOO MANY CHARACTERS REQUIRED.   THIS OBJECTION IS     @G@@@@ EASILY ANSWXV
)@@G@@ERED,  HOWEVER,  BY EXAMPLE.  IN APL, THERE IS A SINGLE     @G@@@@ CHARAXW
)@@G@@CTER  WHICH  MAY  BE  USED  TO  SORT.    ADMITTEDLY  IT LOOKS     @G@@@@XX
)@@G@@ PECULIAR,   AND MAY BE DIFFICULT TO REMEMBER AT FIRST.   IN ALMOST     XY
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ANY  OTHER  LANGUAGE,  HOWEVER,  A PROGRAMMER WOULD BE REQUIRED TXZ
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ WRITE  AN  ENTIRE SUBROUTINE TO DO WHAT APL DOES FOR HIM WIYA
)@@G@@TH THIS     @G@@@@ SINGLE  SYMBOL.    ANY  APL USER IS FREE TO RESTRICT YB
)@@G@@HIMSELF TO TO     @G@@@@ USING  THE  SUBSET OF CHARACTERS WHICH IS FOUNDYC
)@@G@@ IN OTHER LANGUAGES     @G@@@@ BUT  THE UNNECESSARY EXTRA PROGRAMMING INYD
)@@G@@VOLVED SEEMS HARDLY WORTH     @]@@@@ THE PRICE. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      YE
)@@G@@A  NOTE TO THE NEOPHYTE APL PROGRAMMER (ESPECIALLY APPLICABLE     @G@@@@YF
)@@G@@ IF  YOU  ARE  AN 'EXPERT' IN SOME OTHER LANGUAGE):   ONCE YOU HAVE     YG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FAMILIARIZED YOURSELF WITH THE BASIC ELEMENTS OF THE LANGUAGE, YOYH
)@@G@@U     @G@@@@ SHOULD  IMMEDIATELY INVEST SOME TIME IN LEARNING THE PROPERYI
)@@G@@ USE OF     @G@@@@ THE  MORE  ADVANCED TECHNIQUES.   THIS RELATIVELY SMAYJ
)@@G@@LL INVESTMENT     @G@@@@ WILL  PAY  BIG  DIVIDENDS  IN  ENABLING YOU TO YK
)@@G@@WRITE YOUR PROGRAMS     @G@@@@ QUICKLY  AND  EFFORTLESSLY.    MANY  FORTYL
)@@G@@RAN AND BASIC PROGRAMMERS     @G@@@@ EXPEND  A  GREAT  DEAL OF WASTED EFYM
)@@G@@FORT BY MERELY TRANSLATING WHAT     @G@@@@ THEY WOULD HAVE WRITTEN IN THYN
)@@G@@ESE LANGUAGES TO APL.   SUCH A TRANS-     @G@@@@ LATION IS POSSIBLE,  OFYO
)@@G@@ COURSE, BUT IT ENTAILS MUCH MORE WORK THAN     @C@@@@ NEEDED IF THE UNIYP
)@@G@@QUE FEATURES OF APL ARE USED. @[@@@@      @G@@@@         THE CHARACTER SYQ
)@@G@@ET NEEDED TO DESCRIBE ALL OF THE APL OPERA-     @G@@@@ TIONS  FAR  EXCEEYR
)@@G@@DS  THE NORMAL 64-CHARACTER SET AVAILABLE ON MOST     @G@@@@ COMPUTERS. YS
)@@G@@   A SPECIAL CHARACTER SET HAS BEEN DEFINED,  AND IT IS     @G@@@@ THE  YT
)@@G@@SET USED IN ALL OF THE STANDARD APL LITERATURE.   A TYPE BALL     @G@@@@YU
)@@G@@ FOR  THIS  CHARACTER SET IS AVAILABLE FOR IBM TYPEWRITERS AS INPUT     YV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DEVICES, MAKING THE ENTIRE SET AVAILABLE TO THE PROGRAMMER WHO HAYW
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ ACCESS  TO  SUCH A DEVICE.   FOR PURPOSES OF THIS MANUAL,  YX
)@@G@@WE WILL     @D@@@@ REFER TO THIS SET AS THE 'REFERENCE' CHARACTER SET.  YY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  YZ
)@@G@@                         1-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ZA
)@@G@@          AS  OF  THIS WRITING,  UNIVAC DOES NOT SUPPORT INPUT OF A     ZB
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CHARACTER SET WHICH EXCEEDS 64 CHARACTERS, ALTHOUGH ASCII INPUT IZC
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ UNDER DEVELOPMENT.   BECAUSE OF THIS,  A SPECIAL CHARACTER ZD
)@@G@@SET HAS     @G@@@@ BEEN  DEFINED  FOR  1100  SERIES  USAGE.   IN THIS SEZE
)@@G@@T,  THOSE APL     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS  WHICH  ALSO  EXIST  IN  THE  FIELDAZF
)@@G@@TA  AND/OR TELETYPE     @G@@@@ CHARACTER SETS REMAIN UNCHANGED.  THE ADDZG
)@@G@@ITIONAL CHARACTERS NEEDED     @G@@@@ ARE  DEFINED AS DIGRAPHS,  I.E.  TWZH
)@@G@@O FIELDATA OR TTY CHARACTERS IN     @G@@@@ COMBINATION  ARE  USED  TO REZI
)@@G@@PRESENT A SINGLE APL CHARACTER.   THE     @G@@@@ FIRST CHARACTER OF MOSTZJ
)@@G@@ DIGRAPHS IS THE DOLLAR SIGN,  $.   IN SOME     @G@@@@ CASES, THE MASTERZK
)@@G@@ SPACE @ IS USED.  THE PUNCHED CARD CODE FOR THIS     @G@@@@ SET IS THE ZL
)@@G@@NORMAL UNIVAC FIELDATA CODE.   FROM TELETYPES, THE SAME     @G@@@@ GRAPHZM
)@@G@@ICS  ARE USED,  IF THEY EXIST.   IN DISTRIBUTED UNIVAC EXEC 8     @F@@@@ZN
)@@G@@ SYSTEMS,    SEVERAL  CHARACTERS  WHICH  EXIST  ON  TELETYPES  ARE@G@@@@ZO
)@@G@@ NONETHELESS  IGNORED BY EXEC 8 -- FOR THESE,  ALTERNATE CHARACTERS     ZP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ARE  DEFINED  (THESE  CHARACTERS CAN BE USED ON THE 1108 SYSTEM AZQ
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ MARYLAND,  HOWEVER).  THROUGHOUT THE REMAINDER OF THIS MANUZR
)@@G@@AL, THE     @G@@@@ FIELDATA  CHARACTER SET WILL BE USED.   A TRANSLATIONZS
)@@G@@ TABLE TO THE     @F@@@@ REFERENCE SET (DEFINED IN PAKIN [4]) IS INCLUDEZT
)@@G@@D IN APPENDIX A.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  1. 4.   DATA TYPES    ZU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          APL  IS  PRIMARILY AN ARRAY-ORIEZV
)@@G@@NTED LANGUAGE -- A SINGLE     @G@@@@ OPERATION MAY BE PERFORMED ON SEVERZW
)@@G@@AL ELEMENTS OF AN ARRAY AT ONCE     @G@@@@ (HENCE  A  REDUCTION  IN  THEZX
)@@G@@  NEED TO PROGRAM LOOPS).   SINCE THE     @G@@@@ LANGUAGE  ALLOWS ARRAYSZY
)@@G@@ OF DIFFERENT SIZES,  ONE OF THE PROPERTIES     @G@@@@ OF  AN APL VARIABZZ
)@@G@@LE IS ITS SHAPE,  WHICH CAN BE FULLY SPECIFIED BY     @G@@@@ TWO QUANTITAA
)@@G@@IES,  THE RANK AND THE DIMENSIONS.   THE RANK OF AN APL     @G@@@@ ARRAYAB
)@@G@@  IS THE NUMBER OF SUBSCRIPT EXPRESSIONS NEEDED TO SPECIFY AN     @G@@@@AC
)@@G@@ ELEMENT  OR  ELEMENTS OF IT.   THE DIMENSIONS SPECIFY THE RANGE OF     AD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VALUES  THAT LEGAL SUBSCRIPT VALUES MAY TAKE ON.   IN ADDITION,  AE
)@@G@@A     @G@@@@ VARIABLE MAY BE A SET OF NUMBERS OR CHARACTERS -- WE WILL CAF
)@@G@@ALL THE     @E@@@@ CHARACTER/NUMERIC PROPERTY OF AN APL VARIABLE ITS 'MOAG
)@@G@@DE'.  @[@@@@      @ @@@@  1. 4. 1.    NUMERIC DATA    @[@@@@      @G@@@@AH
)@@G@@       AN  APL  NUMBER  MAY  BE  ANY  COMBINATION OF DIGITS WITHOUT     AI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ INTERVENING  BLANKS.   THUS,  3  AND  500  ARE  VALID APL NUMBERSAJ
)@@G@@.     @G@@@@ APL\1100  WILL  RETAIN  UP  TO  18 SIGNIFICANT DIGITS IN A AK
)@@G@@NUMBER;     @G@@@@ POSITIONS  AFTER  THE  18TH  ARE IGNORED.   NORMALLY,AL
)@@G@@  NUMBERS ARE     @G@@@@ PRINTED  OUT  WITH ONLY 10 DIGITS, EVEN IF MOREAM
)@@G@@ HAVE BEEN ENTERED.     @G@@@@ THE  ADDITIONAL  DIGITS  CAN  BE PRINTED AN
)@@G@@USING THE )DIGITS COMMAND     @#@@@@ (CHAPTER 4).     @[@@@@      @G@@@@AO
)@@G@@     A  SINGLE  DECIMAL POINT IS ALLOWED IN AN APL NUMBER.   AN APL     AP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NUMBER  FOLLOWED  BY  EXX  (WHERE XX IS ANOTHER APL NUMBER) AND NAQ
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ INTERVENING  SPACES  INDICATES THAT THE NUMBER IS TO BE MULAR
)@@G@@TIPLIED     @C@@@@ BY THE POWER OF TEN SPECIFIED BY XX.  HENCE    @[@@@@AS
)@@G@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        AT
)@@G@@                   1-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@      AU
)@@G@@        3E2    3.0E1   AND      300 @[@@@@      @D@@@@ ARE ALL VALID WAYAV
)@@G@@S TO TYPE THE NUMBER THREE HUNDRED. @G@@@@     APL  USES A SPECIAL CHARAAW
)@@G@@CTER TO INDICATE A NEGATIVE CONSTANT;     @G@@@@ IN  APL\1100,   IT IS TAX
)@@G@@HE AMPERSAND (&).   USING THIS,  THE NUMBER     @A@@@@ 'MINUS THREE' IS AY
)@@G@@REPRESENTED BY    @[@@@@      @#@@@@           &3     @[@@@@      @G@@@@AZ
)@@G@@ ONE  SHOULD KEEP IN MIND THAT THERE IS A SUBTLE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN     BA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THIS AND TYPING -3.   THE FIRST REPRESENTATION TELLS APL TO CREATBB
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ A  NUMBER WHOSE VALUE IS MINUS THREE;  THE SECOND CREATES ABC
)@@G@@ NUMBER     @G@@@@ WHOSE  VALUE  IS PLUS THREE AND SUBSEQUENTLY TAKES THBD
)@@G@@E NEGATIVE OF     @ @@@@ IT.  CONSEQUENTLY, TYPING IN @[@@@@      @#@@@@BE
)@@G@@           -&3    @[@@@@      @D@@@@ WILL RESULT IN A DISPLAY OF THE NUMBF
)@@G@@BER THREE, BUT    @[@@@@      @#@@@@           &-3    @[@@@@      @G@@@@BG
)@@G@@ WILL  RESULT  IN  A  'LEXICAL ERROR' REPORT (BECAUSE THE & WAS NOT     BH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FOLLOWED  IMMEDIATELY BY A DIGIT).   IT SHOULD BE NOTED THAT THE BI
)@@G@@&     @G@@@@ SIGN IS ACTUALLY PART OF THE NUMBER ITSELF.  THIS DISTINCTIBJ
)@@G@@ON WILL     @B@@@@ BECOME CLEARER WHEN WE DISCUSS VECTORS.  @[@@@@      BK
)@@G@@@G@@@@      THE & SIGN MUST BE USED TO SPECIFY NEGATIVE EXPONENTS -- E.GBL
)@@G@@.     @C@@@@ ANOTHER WAY TO TYPE THE NUMBER THREE HUNDRED IS@[@@@@      BM
)@@G@@@^@@@@           30000.0E&2   @[@@@@      @G@@@@     NO  DECIMAL  POINTSBN
)@@G@@  ARE  ALLOWED IN EXPONENTS.   THE RANGE OF     @G@@@@ EXPONENTS  ALLOWEBO
)@@G@@D  IN APL/1108 IS APPROXIMATELY PLUS OR MINUS 307     @G@@@@ (DEPENDING BP
)@@G@@UPON THE PART OF THE NUMBER TO THE LEFT OF THE E).   AN     @G@@@@ ATTEMBQ
)@@G@@PT TO SPECIFY A NUMBER OUT OF THIS RANGE (EXCEPT FOR ZERO, OF     @B@@@@BR
)@@G@@ COURSE) WILL RESULT IN A 'LEXICAL ERROR'.@[@@@@      @ @@@@  1. 4. 2.  BS
)@@G@@  CHARACTER DATA  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      CHARACTER  DATA  IS  INPUT TO BT
)@@G@@APL BY ENCLOSING IT IN (SINGLE)     @G@@@@ QUOTES  -- THUS 'A' OR 'ABC' BU
)@@G@@ARE VALID CHARACTER DATA.   IT SHOULD     @G@@@@ BE  NOTED  THAT  ALTHOUBV
)@@G@@GH  SOME  APL CHARACTERS MUST BE ENTERED BY     @G@@@@ TYPING TWO FIELDABW
)@@G@@TA CHARACTERS (E.G.  $S OR $R), SUCH DIGRAPHS ARE     @G@@@@ CONSIDERED BX
)@@G@@TO BE SINGLE CHARACTERS BY APL.   A SINGLE QUOTE MAY BE     @G@@@@ INCLUBY
)@@G@@DED  IN  A  CHARACTER  STRING  BY TYPING TWO ADJACENT QUOTES.     @]@@@@BZ
)@@G@@ THUS TYPING@[@@@@      @#@@@@           'A''B' @[@@@@      @G@@@@ RESULCA
)@@G@@TS IN THE INPUT OF THE THREE CHARACTERS A,  ', AND B.  UNLIKE     @[@@@@CB
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    CC
)@@G@@       1-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ OTHER  APL SYSTEMCD
)@@G@@S,  APL\1100 DOES NOT PERMIT YOU TO LEAVE OFF THE     @G@@@@ TRAILING  QCE
)@@G@@UOTE  OF   A  LINE  AND  CONTINUE ON THE NEXT LINE -- A     @ @@@@ 'LEXICF
)@@G@@CAL ERROR' WILL RESULT. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  1. 5.   THE SHAPCG
)@@G@@E PROPERTIES OF APL DATA@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@     AS NOTED ABOVCH
)@@G@@E,  APL IS ESSENTIALLY AN ARRAY LANGUAGE;  AN APL     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  GCI
)@@G@@ENERALLY CONSISTS OF A COLLECTION OF SEVERAL NUMBERS OR     @G@@@@ CHARACJ
)@@G@@CTERS  WHICH ARE MANIPULATED AS A UNIT.   SINCE THE REMAINING     @G@@@@CK
)@@G@@ DISCUSSION IS APPLICABLE TO DATA OF ANY MODE, WE WILL REFER TO THE     CL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ INDIVIDUAL PIECES OF DATA IN AN APL VARIABLE AS 'ELEMENTS',  WHICCM
)@@G@@H     @B@@@@ MAY BE EITHER NUMBERS OR CHARACTERS.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@CN
)@@G@@     THE SIMPLEST KIND OF APL VARIABLE IS THE SCALAR -- IT HAS ZERO     CO
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RANK (NO DIMENSIONS) AND HAS ONE ELEMENT.  EXAMPLES OF SCALARS ARCP
)@@G@@E     @[@@@@      @D@@@@              12.6             AND         'X'  CQ
)@@G@@ .    @[@@@@      @G@@@@     THE  NEXT  MOST  COMPLEX  DATA  SHAPE IS THCR
)@@G@@E VECTOR.   VECTORS     @G@@@@ CONSIST  OF  A  SET  OF  ELEMENTS WHICH ACS
)@@G@@RE ORDERED ALONG A SINGLE     @G@@@@ COORDINATE -- THEY HAVE RANK 1,  ANCT
)@@G@@D THEIR LENGTH IS THE NUMBER OF     @^@@@@ ELEMENTS IN THE VECTOR.@[@@@@CU
)@@G@@      @G@@@@    NUMERIC VECTORS ARE ENTERED BY TYPING A LIST OF SEVERAL CV
)@@G@@NUMBERS     @B@@@@ SEPARATED BY AT LEAST ONE BLANK.  THUS   @[@@@@      CW
)@@G@@@^@@@@           2   3   5E12 @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS A THREE-ELEMENT VECTCX
)@@G@@OR.  AT THIS POINT, THE NEED FOR THE & SIGN     @B@@@@ SHOULD BECOME APPCY
)@@G@@ARENT -- THE VECTOR     @[@@@@      @#@@@@           &2   3 @[@@@@      CZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IS  A  SINGLE  ENTITY  CONTAINING  TWO VALUES,  MINUS TWO AND PLUDA
)@@G@@S     @^@@@@ THREE.  THE EXPRESSION @[@@@@      @#@@@@           -2  3 ,DB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ HOWEVER,  CAUSES APL TO NEGATE THE ENTIRE VECTOR,  WIDC
)@@G@@TH THE RESULT     @A@@@@ BEING MINUS TWO AND MINUS THREE.   @[@@@@      DD
)@@G@@@G@@@@     CHARACTER  VECTORS  ARE  ENTERED  AS  A  STRING  OF CHARACTERDE
)@@G@@S     @ @@@@ ENCLOSED IN QUOTES, THUS     @[@@@@      @^@@@@           'DF
)@@G@@ABCDEF'     @[@@@@      @A@@@@ IS A SIX-ELEMENT CHARACTER VECTOR. @[@@@@DG
)@@G@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        DH
)@@G@@                   1-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@     WDI
)@@G@@E  NOTE  THAT IT IS POSSIBLE TO HAVE A VECTOR CONTAINING ONLY     @G@@@@DJ
)@@G@@ ONE  ELEMENT.    EVEN  THOUGH  SCALARS  ALSO  HAVE ONE ELEMENT,  A     DK
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ONE-ELEMENT  VECTOR  IS  A DIFFERENT QUANTITY,  AS ITS RANK IS ONDL
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RATHER THAN ZERO AS FOR A SCALAR.  ONE-ELEMENT VECTORS ARE DM
)@@G@@CREATED     @G@@@@ BY  APL  AS  THE  RESULT OF SOME OPERATION AND CANNOTDN
)@@G@@ BE LITERALLY     @G@@@@ TYPED  IN.  IT IS ALSO POSSIBLE TO HAVE A VECTODO
)@@G@@R OF ZERO ELEMENTS.     @G@@@@ ALTHOUGH  SUCH  A  NUMERIC 'NULL VECTOR' DP
)@@G@@CANNOT BE LITERALLY TYPED     @G@@@@ IN,   THE  CHARACTER  'NULL  VECTORDQ
)@@G@@'  CAN BE CREATED BY TYPING TWO     @G@@@@ ADJACENT  QUOTES (WITH NOTHINDR
)@@G@@G BETWEEN THEM).   NULL VECTORS PRINT     @#@@@@ AS BLANK LINES.  @[@@@@DS
)@@G@@      @G@@@@      MATRICES ARE RANK 2 ARRAYS.   APL\1100 WILL PRINT MATRDT
)@@G@@ICES IN     @G@@@@ A  COLUMNAR FORMAT.   THE SECOND (COLUMN) SUBSCRIPT RDU
)@@G@@UNS FROM LEFT     @G@@@@ TO  RIGHT  ON  THE PAGE,  THE FIRST (ROW) INDEXDV
)@@G@@ VARIES FROM TOP TO     @G@@@@ BOTTOM.    NUMERIC ARRAYS WILL BE PRINTEDDW
)@@G@@ WITH AT LEAST TWO BLANKS     @G@@@@ BETWEEN ELEMENTS IN EACH ROW, AND WDX
)@@G@@ITH THE DECIMAL POINTS (IF ANY)     @G@@@@ ALIGNED.  CHARACTER ARRAYS ARDY
)@@G@@E PRINTED WITHOUT INTERVENING BLANKS.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       APL\1DZ
)@@G@@100  ALLOWS  THE  CREATION  OF VARIABLES UP TO RANK 63.     @G@@@@ WHEN EA
)@@G@@AN ARRAY OF GREATER THAN RANK 2 IS PRINTED,  IT IS PRINTED AS     @G@@@@EB
)@@G@@ A  SET  OF MATRICES ONE PER PLANE.   THE PLANES ARE SEPARATED FROM     EC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ EACH  OTHER  BY  BLANK  LINES.    ARRAYS OF MATRIX OR GREATER RANED
)@@G@@K     @G@@@@ CANNOT BE LITERALLY TYPED IN AS CAN VECTORS AND SCALARS.  TEE
)@@G@@HEY ARE     @G@@@@ INSTEAD CREATED BY APL AS THE RESULT OF A SPECIFIC OPEF
)@@G@@ERATION (SUCH     @G@@@@ AS  RESHAPE).    WE  WILL DEFER THE DISCUSSION EG
)@@G@@OF THESE QUANTITIES     @C@@@@ UNTIL WE COVER THE SO-CALLED 'MIXED' OPEREH
)@@G@@ATORS.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  1. 6.   APL OPERATORS @[@@@@      EI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ NOW  THAT  WE  KNOW  HOW  TO ENTER DATA INTO APL,  WEEJ
)@@G@@ CAN BEGIN TO     @F@@@@ DISCUSS   HOW   WE  CAN  INSTRUCT  APL  TO  PEREK
)@@G@@FORM  SOME  USEFUL@G@@@@ COMPUTATIONS  ON THE DATA.   AN APL PRIMITIVE OEL
)@@G@@PERATOR IS A SYMBOL     @G@@@@ WHICH  INDICATES  WHAT  KIND  OF COMPUTATEM
)@@G@@ION IS TO BE DONE ON DATA     @G@@@@ (OPERANDS).    WE  HAVE  ALREADY  SEN
)@@G@@EEN AN EXAMPLE OF THE USE OF AN     @ @@@@ OPERATOR -- THE APL STATEMENTEO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@                   3 + 2@[@@@@      @G@@@@ INSTRUCTS  EP
)@@G@@THE SYSTEM TO TAKE THE SUM OF 3 AND 2;  THE OPERATOR IN     @G@@@@ THIS EQ
)@@G@@ CASE  IS  THE '+' SIGN, AND ITS OBVIOUS MEANING IS ADDITION.     @G@@@@ER
)@@G@@ NOTICE  THAT IN THIS EXAMPLE,  THE '+' SIGN SPECIFIES THAT THE TWO     ES
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OPERANDS  (THREE  AND  TWO)  ARE  TO  BE  ADDED  TO  EACH  OTHER.ET
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OBVIOUSLY,   IF  ONE  IS  GOING TO DO ADDITION,  THERE MUST BE TWEU
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ NUMBERS TO ADD -- IT MAKES NO SENSE TO SAY 'ADD 5', SINCE OEV
)@@G@@NE MUST     @G@@@@ BE ABLE TO  ADD 5 TO SOMETHING ELSE.   OPERATORS WHICEW
)@@G@@H REQUIRE TWO     @G@@@@ OPERANDS  ARE CALLED 'DYADIC' OPERATORS,  THOSEEX
)@@G@@ WHICH REQUIRE ONLY     @G@@@@ ONE  OPERAND  ARE 'MONADIC',  AND THOSE WEY
)@@G@@HICH HAVE NO OPERANDS ARE     @G@@@@ 'NILADIC'  (THERE  IS  ONLY  ONE  NEZ
)@@G@@ILADIC  PRIMITIVE,  THE 'GO TO'     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO FA
)@@G@@APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           1-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@FB
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@ OPERATOR WHICH WILL BE DISCUSSED LATER.) @[@@@@FC
)@@G@@      @G@@@@          IN  ADDITION  TO  THEIR  MONADIC/DYADIC  PROPERTIEFD
)@@G@@S,  APL     @G@@@@ OPERATORS  MAY BE FURTHER CLASSIFIED AS BEING 'SCALARFE
)@@G@@' OR 'MIXED'.     @G@@@@ THIS CLASSIFICATION IS BASED UPON THE MANNER INFF
)@@G@@ WHICH THE OPERATOR     @G@@@@ IS  APPLIED  TO  THE  INDIVIDUAL  ELEMENTFG
)@@G@@S OF AN OPERAND.   SCALAR     @G@@@@ OPERATORS  ARE  APPLIED  TO EACH INFH
)@@G@@DIVIDUAL ELEMENT OF AN OPERAND,     @G@@@@ AND  THE  SHAPE  OF  THE  RESFI
)@@G@@ULT  IS  RELATED  TO THE SHAPE OF THE     @G@@@@ OPERANDS IN A RELATIVELFJ
)@@G@@Y STRAIGHTFORWARD FASHION.   THE RESULTS OF     @G@@@@ MIXED OPERATORS, FK
)@@G@@ HOWEVER, ARE NOT SO SIMPLE.  MIXED OPERATORS ARE     @G@@@@ USED TO IN FL
)@@G@@SOME FASHION MANIPULATE THE SHAPE OF DATA.  THEY MAY BE     @G@@@@ USED,FM
)@@G@@  FOR  EXAMPLE, TO SELECT CERTAIN ELEMENTS OUT OF AN OPERAND,     @G@@@@FN
)@@G@@ TO  COMBINE  TWO  OPERANDS  INTO  ONE,  TO SORT AN OPERAND IN SOME     FO
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SEQUENCE,  ETC.   WHILE THE RULES FOR DETERMINING THE SHAPE OF THFP
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RESULT  OF A SCALAR OPERATOR ARE THE SAME REGARDLESS OF THEFQ
)@@G@@ SCALAR     @G@@@@ OPERATOR  USED,   THE  RESULTS OF A MIXED OPERATOR DEFR
)@@G@@PEND UPON THE     @#@@@@ OPERATOR ITSELF. @[@@@@      @G@@@@          FOFS
)@@G@@R  EACH  APL OPERATOR,  THERE ARE SPECIFIC REQUIREMENTS     @G@@@@ ABOUTFT
)@@G@@  THE RANK AND DIMENSIONS OF THE OPERANDS -- THESE ARE CALLED     @G@@@@FU
)@@G@@ 'CONFORMABILITY'  REQUIREMENTS.    IF  TWO OPERANDS MEET THE SHAPE     FV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ REQUIREMENTS  FOR  A PARTICULAR OPERATION TO BE PERFORMED ON THEMFW
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ THEY  ARE  SAID  TO  BE  'CONFORMABLE'.   AN ATTEMPT TO PERFX
)@@G@@FORM AN     @G@@@@ OPERATION ON TWO OPERANDS WHICH ARE NOT CONFORMABLE WFY
)@@G@@ILL RESULT IN     @F@@@@ AN ERROR MESSAGE, USUALLY EITHER 'LENGTH ERROR'FZ
)@@G@@ OR 'RANK ERROR'. @[@@@@      @B@@@@  1. 6. 1.    DYADIC SCALAR OPERATORGA
)@@G@@S     @[@@@@      @G@@@@         DYADIC SCALAR OPERATORS ARE USED FOR THGB
)@@G@@E NORMAL ARITHMETIC     @G@@@@ OPERATIONS  IN THE LANGUAGE.   SOME OF THGC
)@@G@@EM ARE ADD (+),  SUBTRACT     @G@@@@ (-),  MULTIPLY (#),  DIVIDE (%),  EGD
)@@G@@XPONENTIATE (*),  AND LOGARITHM     @G@@@@ ($*).    A  GREAT MANY OTHERSGE
)@@G@@ ARE PROVIDED;  THEY ARE DISCUSSED IN     @^@@@@ DETAIL IN CHAPTER 5.   GF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@         THE TWO OPERANDS OF A DYADIC SCALAR OPERATOR GG
)@@G@@MUST HAVE THE     @G@@@@ SAME  RANK  AND  DIMENSIONS,   UNLESS ONE OF THGH
)@@G@@EM IS A SCALAR OR A     @G@@@@ 1-ELEMENT  VECTOR.    THE  PARTICULAR  OPGI
)@@G@@ERATOR IS THEN APPLIED BY     @G@@@@ COMBINING THE ELEMENTS OF EACH OPERGJ
)@@G@@AND ONE BY ONE.  AS AN EXAMPLE,     @^@@@@ THE APL STATEMENT:     @[@@@@GK
)@@G@@      @B@@@@                   3 4 5 6 + 0 &2 3 4     @[@@@@      @#@@@@GL
)@@G@@ HAS THE RESULT   @[@@@@      @ @@@@                   3 2 8 10   @[@@@@GM
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ WHICH IS OBTAINED BY ADDING 3 + 0,  4 + &2, 5 + 3 AND 6 + 4GN
)@@G@@.  WHEN     @G@@@@ ONE  OF  THE  OPERANDS  IS  A  SCALAR  OR ONE-ELEMENTGO
)@@G@@ VECTOR IT IS     @G@@@@ 'EXTENDED',  I.E. IT IS TREATED AS IF IT HAD THGP
)@@G@@E SAME SHAPE AS THE     @ @@@@ OTHER OPERAND.  THE STATEMENT@[@@@@*****^GQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          GR
)@@G@@ 1-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@            GS
)@@G@@       6# 4 1 0 2 @[@@@@      @^@@@@ THUS GIVES THE RESULT  @[@@@@      GT
)@@G@@@ @@@@                   24 6 0 12  @[@@@@      @G@@@@          THE  SAMGU
)@@G@@E  ELEMENT  BY ELEMENT COMBINATION RULES WHEN THE     @B@@@@ OPERANDS ARGV
)@@G@@E MATRICES OR HIGHER RANK.    @[@@@@      @B@@@@  1. 6. 2.    MONADIC SCGW
)@@G@@ALAR OPERATORS    @[@@@@      @G@@@@          MONADIC  SCALAR OPERATORS GX
)@@G@@ALSO OPERATE ELEMENT-BY-ELEMENT     @G@@@@ ON THEIR OPERANDS.  A MONADICGY
)@@G@@ OPERATOR HAS ONLY ONE OPERAND, WHICH     @G@@@@ IS  WRITTEN TO ITS RIGHGZ
)@@G@@T.   ALTHOUGH THE SAME SYMBOLS ARE USED FOR     @G@@@@ BOTH MONADIC AND HA
)@@G@@DYADIC OPERATORS,  THEY ARE NONETHELESS DIFFERENT     @G@@@@ OPERATORS. HB
)@@G@@   ONE  CAN  TELL  WHETHER  A GIVEN SYMBOL REPRESENTS A     @G@@@@ DYADIHC
)@@G@@C  OR  MONADIC  OPERATOR BY THE PRESENCE OR ABSENCE OF A LEFT     @^@@@@HD
)@@G@@ OPERAND.  THE STATEMENT@[@@@@      @ @@@@                   3 4 - 1 2  HE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS  AN  INSTANCE OF THE DYADIC OPERATOR 'SUBTRACT',  HF
)@@G@@AND GIVES THE     @]@@@@ RESULT     @[@@@@      @ @@@@                  HG
)@@G@@ 2   2.     @[@@@@      @#@@@@ THE STATEMENT    @[@@@@      @ @@@@      HH
)@@G@@             -4   5     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS  AN  INSTANCE OF THE MONADHI
)@@G@@IC OPERATOR NEGATE (TAKE THE NEGATIVE     @^@@@@ OF), AND THE RESULT IS HJ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@                   &4  &5     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ MONADHK
)@@G@@IC OPERATORS ARE PROVIDED TO NEGATE (-),  EXTRACT THE SIGN OF     @G@@@@HL
)@@G@@ A  NUMBER (#), GET THE ABSOLUTE VALUE ($!), AND MANY OTHER THINGS.     HM
)@@G@@@B@@@@ FOR A DETAILED DISCUSSION, SEE CHAPTER 5.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      HN
)@@G@@@E@@@@  1. 7.   NAMED VARIABLES; THE SPECIFICATION ($S) OPERATOR  @[@@@@HO
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@         THE BEST METHOD OF LEARNING HOW TO USE HP
)@@G@@APL IS TO PLAY WITH     @G@@@@ IT.   YOU CAN NOW TYPE IN VARIOUS KINDS OHQ
)@@G@@F SIMPLE STATEMENTS,  AND     @G@@@@ EXAMINE  THE ANSWERS IMMEDIATELY.  HR
)@@G@@ THIS SHOULD GIVE YOU A FEELING     @G@@@@ FOR WHAT EACH OF THE OPERATORHS
)@@G@@S DOES.  WHEN YOU GET TO THE POINT OF     @E@@@@ DOING SOME SERIOUS WORKHT
)@@G@@, HOWEVER, SOMETHING MORE IS NEEDED.@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USERHU
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           1- 10@[@@@@HV
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@         WHEN ONE IS USING A DESK CAHW
)@@G@@LCULATOR,  IT IS OFTEN THE CASE     @G@@@@ THAT  INTERMEDIATE  RESULTS NHX
)@@G@@EED TO BE SAVED AND LATER USED AGAIN;     @G@@@@ THE  PAPER  AND  PENCILHY
)@@G@@  BECOME  EXTREMELY HANDY FOR THIS PURPOSE.     @G@@@@ MOST  PROGRAMMINGHZ
)@@G@@  LANGUAGES  PROVIDE  A  MECHANISM  BY WHICH SUCH     @F@@@@ RESULTS   MIA
)@@G@@AY  BE  GIVEN  A  NAME  AND  SAVED  --  IN  SUBSEQUENT@G@@@@ CALCULATIONIB
)@@G@@S,   ONE  NEED  ONLY  TO  REFER  TO  THE  NAME  AND THE     @G@@@@ APPROIC
)@@G@@PRIATE  DATA IS USED.   APL IS NO EXCEPTION TO THIS,  AND THE     @G@@@@ID
)@@G@@ 'SPECIFICATION'  OR  'REPLACEMENT'  OPERATOR ($S) IS USED FOR THIS     IE
)@@G@@@]@@@@ PURPOSE.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@         APL NAMES MAY BE ANY COMBINIF
)@@G@@ATION OF LETTERS AND DIGITS (NO     @G@@@@ INTERVENING SPACES).   THE FIIG
)@@G@@RST CHARACTER MUST BE  A LETTER,  AND     @G@@@@ THE NAME CAN BE FROM 1 IH
)@@G@@TO 72 CHARACTERS IN LENGTH.   APL NAMES MAY     @G@@@@ BE  USED  FOR OTHII
)@@G@@ER THINGS THAN DATA,  BUT WE WILL DEFER THIS TO A     @]@@@@ LATER TIME.IJ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@          APL  DATA DESCRIBED BY NAME ARE CALLED 'NAMEIK
)@@G@@D VARIABLES'.     @G@@@@ ALTHOUGH  IT  WAS  IMPLIED ABOVE THAT A NAME ISIL
)@@G@@ ATTACHED BY APL TO     @G@@@@ DATA,  IN REALITY, THE SPECIFICATION OPERIM
)@@G@@ATOR ATTACHES THE DATA TO     @G@@@@ THE NAME.   THE SPECIFICATION OPERAIN
)@@G@@TOR IS DYADIC, AND TAKES A NAME     @G@@@@ ON  THE  LEFT  AND  AN  APL  IO
)@@G@@EXPRESSION  ON  THE RIGHT.   THUS THE     @]@@@@ STATEMENT  @[@@@@      IP
)@@G@@@ @@@@                    A$S 3 4 5 @[@@@@      @G@@@@ SPECIFIES  THE  VIQ
)@@G@@ECTOR  QUANTITY  3  4 5 AS THE VALUE OF THE NAMED     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  'IR
)@@G@@A'.    SUBSEQUENTLY,  THE NAME MAY BE USED WHENEVER THE     @ @@@@ DATA IS
)@@G@@IS WANTED -- TYPING IN  @[@@@@      @^@@@@                   3 # A@[@@@@IT
)@@G@@      @ @@@@ RESULTS IN  A RESPONSE OF    @[@@@@      @ @@@@            IU
)@@G@@       9 12 15    @[@@@@      @ @@@@ JUST AS IF ONE HAD TYPED     @[@@@@IV
)@@G@@      @ @@@@                   3# 3 4 5   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@IW
)@@G@@         THE NAME 'REPLACEMENT' IS SOMETIMES USED FOR THIS OPERATOR     IX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TO POINT UP THE FACT THAT THE DATA TO THE RIGHT OF THE $S OPERATOIY
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ 'REPLACES'  ANY DATA WHICH HAD PREVIOUSLY BEEN ASSOCIATED WIZ
)@@G@@ITH THE     @G@@@@ SAME  NAME.    IF  ONE  HAD SPECIFIED 3 4 5 AS THE VAJA
)@@G@@LUE OF 'A' AS     @A@@@@ ABOVE, AND THEN SUBSEQUENTLY TYPED @[@@@@      JB
)@@G@@@ @@@@                   A$S 'XYZ'  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THEN  OLD  VALUE JC
)@@G@@OF A (3 4 5) WOULD BE 'REPLACED' BY THE NEW VALUE     @G@@@@ (THE CHARACJD
)@@G@@TER VECTOR 'XYZ').  IF ONE THEN ATTEMPTED THE STATEMENT     @[@@@@*****^JE
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          JF
)@@G@@ 1- 11@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@            JG
)@@G@@       3 # A@[@@@@      @G@@@@ APL  WOULD  RESPOND  WITH A 'DOMAIN ERRORJH
)@@G@@' MESSAGE -- THIS RESULTS     @G@@@@ BECAUSE  A  IS NOW A CHARACTER VECTJI
)@@G@@OR,  AND AN ATTEMPT TO MULTIPLY     @C@@@@ CHARACTERS BY A NUMBER IS CLEJJ
)@@G@@ARLY MEANINGLESS. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      AN ATTEMPT TO REFERENCE A NAMEJK
)@@G@@ WHICH HAD NO VALUE ASSIGNED TO     @G@@@@ IT  (I.E.  HAS NEVER BEEN ON JL
)@@G@@THE LEFT OF A SPECIFICATION OPERATOR)     @A@@@@ WILL RESULT IN A 'VALUEJM
)@@G@@ ERROR'.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  1. 8.   SIMPLE APL STATEMENTJN
)@@G@@S     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@     AN  APL  STATEMENT  IS  A ONE-LJO
)@@G@@INE COLLECTION OF OPERATORS AND     @G@@@@ OPERANDS WHICH INSTRUCT APL TJP
)@@G@@O COMPUTE SOMETHING.   OF COURSE,  AN     @G@@@@ ARBIRTARY  COLLECTION OJQ
)@@G@@F OPERATORS AND OPERANDS IS NOT SUFFICIENT,     @G@@@@ THERE  ARE A FEW JR
)@@G@@RULES AS TO HOW THEY MUST APPEAR IN ORDER FOR APL     @G@@@@ TO  UNDERSTJS
)@@G@@AND THEM.   THIS SET OF RULES COMPRISES THE 'SYNTAX' OF     @G@@@@ THE  JT
)@@G@@APL  LANGUAGE,  AND IF YOU TYPE IN A STATEMENT WHICH VIOLATES     @G@@@@JU
)@@G@@ THESE  RULES,   APL WILL CHASTISE YOU APPROPRIATELY WITH THE ERROR     JV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ MESSAGE  'SYNTAX  ERROR'.   MOST ERROR MESSAGES ALSO RESULT IN THJW
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OFFENDING STATEMENT'S BEING TYPED BACK AT YOU WITH THE POSIJX
)@@G@@TION OF     @G@@@@ THE  ERROR  APPROPRIATELY MARKED.   AT THE PRESENT TIJY
)@@G@@ME,  APL\1100     @G@@@@ DOES  THIS FOR MOST,  BUT NOT ALL,  ERRORS.   IJZ
)@@G@@N A FEW CASES,  THE     @G@@@@ EXACT  POSITION  OF  THE  ERROR IS NOT MAKA
)@@G@@RKED,  FUTURE VERSIONS OF     @E@@@@ APL\1100 WILL MARK THE POSITION OF KB
)@@G@@THE ERROR IN ALL CASES. @[@@@@      @G@@@@    THERE IS NO LIMIT TO THE NKC
)@@G@@UMBER OF OPERATIONS WHICH CAN BE DONE     @G@@@@ ON  A  LINE  SAVE  THE KD
)@@G@@NUMBER OF CHARACTERS YOU CAN TYPE.   UNLIKE     @G@@@@ FORTRAN  AND  OTHKE
)@@G@@ER  LANGUAGES,   THERE IS NO PREFERENCE FOR DOING     @G@@@@ (SAY) MULTIKF
)@@G@@PLICATIONS BEFORE ADDITIONS.   INSTEAD,  THE OPERATIONS     @G@@@@ ARE  KG
)@@G@@DONE IN ORDER FROM RIGHT TO LEFT.   THIS STRICT RIGHT-TO-LEFT     @G@@@@KH
)@@G@@ SEQUENCE  MAY  BE  ALTERED  BY  THE  USE  OF  PARENTHESES  --  THE     KI
)@@G@@@B@@@@ FOLLOWING EXAMPLES DEMONSTRATE THIS:     @[@@@@      @ @@@@      KJ
)@@G@@     5 # (4 + 8) % 2 4  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ GIVES  THE  RESULT 30  15.   KK
)@@G@@THE QUANTITY 4 + 8 IS FIRST EVALUATED     @G@@@@ GIVING  THE  SCALAR  12KL
)@@G@@.    THIS  IS  THEN EXTENDED TO A 2-ELEMENT     @G@@@@ VECTOR,   AND  DIKM
)@@G@@VIDED  BY THE TWO-ELEMENT VECTOR 2 4,  GIVING THE     @G@@@@ VECTOR RESUKN
)@@G@@LT   6 3    .  MULTIPLICATION BY 5 THEN GIVES THE FINAL     @]@@@@ ANSWEKO
)@@G@@R.    @[@@@@      @D@@@@    IF ONE HAD LEFT OUT THE PARENTHESES, AND TYPKP
)@@G@@ED    @[@@@@      @ @@@@           5 # 4 + 8 % 2 4    @[@@@@      @G@@@@KQ
)@@G@@ THE RESULT WOULD BE 40 30;  8 % 2 4 IS 4 2; 4 + 4 2 IS 8 6 AND 5 #     KR
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)              KS
)@@G@@             1- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@ 8 6 GIVES 4KT
)@@G@@0 30. @[@@@@      @G@@@@     THE  SPECIFICATION  OPERATOR  MAY  BE  USEDKU
)@@G@@ FREELY AS OFTEN AS     @A@@@@ DESIRED ON A LINE.  THE STATEMENT  @[@@@@KV
)@@G@@      @ @@@@           2 + B $S 1 + A $S 3@[@@@@      @G@@@@ CAUSES  THRKW
)@@G@@EE  THINGS  TO HAPPEN -- THE VALUE 3 IS ASSIGNED TO THE     @G@@@@ VARIAKX
)@@G@@BLE A, THE VALUE 4 (1 + A) IS ASSIGNED TO B, AND THE RESULT 6     @ @@@@KY
)@@G@@ (2 + B) IS FINALLY PRINTED.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@     WE  NOTE AT THIS POKZ
)@@G@@INT THAT THE RESULT OF A STATEMENT NEED NOT     @G@@@@ ALWAYS  BE IMMEDILA
)@@G@@ATELY PRINTED.   IF THE LAST (LEFTMOST) OPERATION     @G@@@@ DONE  IN  ALB
)@@G@@ STATEMENT IS A SPECIFICATION, THE RESULT IS NOT TYPED.     @^@@@@ THUS LC
)@@G@@THE STATEMENT     @[@@@@      @A@@@@           C $S 2 + B $S 1 + A $S 3 LD
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WILL RESULT IN THE VALUE 6 BEING ASSIGNED TO C, BUT ILE
)@@G@@T WILL NOT BE     @G@@@@ PRINTED.   IF  YOU WISH TO REASSURE YOURSELF THLF
)@@G@@AT C IS INDEED SIX,     @#@@@@ YOU CAN TYPE     @[@@@@      @]@@@@      LG
)@@G@@     C@[@@@@      @B@@@@ BY ITSELF, AND APL WILL RESPOND WITH 6.  @[@@@@LH
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       ALTHOUGH  THE  SPECIFICATION  OPERATOR  MAY  BE  USEDLI
)@@G@@ WITHIN     @G@@@@ PARENTHESES  EXTREME CAUTION SHOULD BE EXERCISED AS TLJ
)@@G@@HE RESULT CAN     @G@@@@ BE UNPREDICTABLE.  THE EFFECTS OF SPECIFICATIONLK
)@@G@@ WITHIN PARENTHESES     @F@@@@ ARE DISCUSSED IN DETAIL BELOW IN THE SECTLL
)@@G@@ION ON 'SIDE EFFECTS'.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  1. 9.   SUBSCRIPLM
)@@G@@TING  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@     ALTHOUGH AT THIS POINT IT IS TOLN
)@@G@@O EARLY TO DELVE INTO THE FINER     @G@@@@ POINTS OF MIXED OPERATORS, THLO
)@@G@@E SUBSCRIPTING OPERATOR IS RELATIVELY     @F@@@@ EASY TO UNDERSTAND AND LP
)@@G@@CAN BE OF USE EVEN AT THIS EARLY STAGE.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@     WE  HAVLQ
)@@G@@E  NOTED  THAT  VECTORS  AND  ARRAYS MAY BE CREATED AND     @G@@@@ COMPULR
)@@G@@TATIONS  PERFORMED  ON ALL ELEMENTS OF SUCH A VARIABLE AT ONE     @G@@@@LS
)@@G@@ TIME.   THERE ARE TIMES, HOWEVER, WHEN WE WOULD LIKE TO REFER TO A     LT
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SPECIFIC  ELEMENT  OR  GROUP  OF  ELEMENTS  RATHER  THAN AN ENTIRLU
)@@G@@E     @]@@@@ OPERAND.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@     THE  ELEMENTS OF A VECTORLV
)@@G@@ MAY BE CONSIDERED TO ALL BE NUMBERED     @G@@@@ -- AT THE PRESENT TIME,LW
)@@G@@  WE WILL ASSUME THAT THIS NUMBERING ALWAYS     @G@@@@ STARTS  WITH  1 (LX
)@@G@@ORIGIN-1 INDEXING) -- IF THERE ARE THREE ELEMENTS     @G@@@@ IN A VECTORLY
)@@G@@,  THEY ARE THEN OBVIOUSLY THE FIRST,  THE SECOND,  AND     @G@@@@ THE TLZ
)@@G@@HIRD.   A PARTICULAR ONE OF THEM IS REFERENCED BY PUTTING ITS     @[@@@@MA
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    MB
)@@G@@       1- 13@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ SUBSCRIPT  NUMBERMC
)@@G@@  (ITS  'INDEX') IN SQUARE BRACKETS -- THUS IF WE     @^@@@@ HAVE PREVIOMD
)@@G@@USLY TYPED  @[@@@@      @^@@@@           A $S 6 5 12, @[@@@@      @^@@@@ME
)@@G@@ THE RESULT OF TYPING   @[@@@@      @#@@@@           A[2]   @[@@@@      MF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IS 5,  SINCE 5 IS THE SECOND ELEMENT OF A.  ELEMENTS OF A MAY ALSMG
)@@G@@O     @C@@@@ BE CHANGED IN THIS MANNER -- IF WE WERE TO TYPE@[@@@@      MH
)@@G@@@^@@@@           A[1] $S 3    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ AND THEN EXAMINE A, IT MI
)@@G@@WOULD NO LONGER BE 6 5 12, BUT WOULD BE 3 5     @G@@@@ 12 INSTEAD.   TYPMJ
)@@G@@ING A[4] WOULD RESULT IN AN 'INDEX ERROR' SINCE A     @ @@@@ HAS ONLY THMK
)@@G@@REE ELEMENTS.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@    THE QUANTITY WITHIN THE SUBSCRIPML
)@@G@@T BRACKETS NEED NOT BE A SINGLE     @G@@@@ NUMBER AS GIVEN ABOVE.   IT MMM
)@@G@@AY BE ANY VALID APL EXPRESSION, WHICH     @G@@@@ WHEN  EVALUATED,  RESULMN
)@@G@@TS IN A VALUE (OR SET OF VALUES) WHICH IS A     @G@@@@ LEGAL  SUBSCRIPT.MO
)@@G@@   THUS,  INSTEAD OF WRITING A[2],  WE COULD HAVE     @A@@@@ DONE IT THEMP
)@@G@@ HARD WAY, BY WRITING:  @[@@@@      @^@@@@           A[A[3] - 10].@[@@@@MQ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ SINCE  THE  VALUE  OF  A[3] IS 12,  A[3] - 10 IS 2,  AND THMR
)@@G@@E FINAL     @ @@@@ RESULT IS AGAIN A[2] OR 5.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@    IFMS
)@@G@@ THE QUANTITY WITHIN THE BRACKETS IS NOT A SCALAR,  BUT (SAY)     @G@@@@MT
)@@G@@ A VECTOR,  THEN THE RESULT IS A VECTOR.   THE SUBSCRIPTING IS DONE     MU
)@@G@@@D@@@@ FOR EACH SUBSCRIPT VALUE.  AN EXAMPLE OF THIS IS     @[@@@@      MV
)@@G@@@A@@@@           ('ABCDEFG') [6 1 4 5]    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHICH RESULMW
)@@G@@TS IN THE RESPONSE      FADE      .   VECTORS HAVE ONLY     @G@@@@ ONE  MX
)@@G@@SUBSCRIPT  EXPRESSION,   MATRICES HAVE TWO,  ETC.   SUBSCRIPT     @G@@@@MY
)@@G@@ EXPRESSIONS  ARE  SEPARATED  FROM ONE ANOTHER BY SEMICOLONS.   THE     MZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NUMBER  OF  SUBSCRIPT  EXPRESSIONS  WHICH  ARE  NEEDED TO CHOOSE NA
)@@G@@A     @G@@@@ SINGLE ELEMENT FROM AN ARRAY IS THE RANK OF THE ARRAY.  ONENB
)@@G@@ OF THE     @G@@@@ DIFFERENCES  BETWEEN  A  SCALAR  (RANK 0) AND A ONE-ENC
)@@G@@LEMENT VECTOR     @G@@@@ (RANK1)  CAN NOW BE SEEN.  IF B SAY, IS A ONE-END
)@@G@@LEMENT VECTOR, THEN     @G@@@@ WE  CAN WRITE B[1], AND WE WILL GET THE (NE
)@@G@@SINGLE) VALUE SAVED IN B.     @G@@@@ IF B WERE A SCALAR,  HOWEVER,  TYPINF
)@@G@@NG B[1] WOULD RESULT IN A 'RANK     @E@@@@ ERROR', SINCE SCALARS, BEING NG
)@@G@@RANK ZERO, HAVE NO SUBSCRIPTS.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  1.10.   SINH
)@@G@@GNING OFF   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO NI
)@@G@@APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           1- 14@[@@@@      @[@@@@NJ

)@@G@@YOU SIGN ON (WITH AN @APL CARD),  THE     @G@@@@ SYSTEM WILL REMEMBER YONX
)@@G@@U,  AND RETRIEVE YOUR CONTINUE WORKSPACE SO     @G@@@@ THAT  YOU  CAN  RNY
)@@G@@ESUME  FROM  THE POINT AT WHICH YOU STOPPED.   IT     @G@@@@ SHOULD  BE NZ
)@@G@@ NOTED  THAT YOUR WORKSPACES (YOU MAY SAVE OTHERS, TOO,     @G@@@@ SEE COA
)@@G@@HAPTER 4) ARE UNIQUELY YOUR OWN,  EVEN THOUGH SOME OTHER USER     @G@@@@OB
)@@G@@ MAY  HAVE  A  WORKSPACE WITH THE SAME NAME.  APL DISTINGUISHES YOU     OC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FROM  EVERYONE  ELSE  BY  REMEMBERING  BOTH THE ACCOUNT NUMBER ANOD
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ PROJECT  ID  FIELDS FROM YOUR @RUN CARD.   THUS,  IF YOU RUOE
)@@G@@N LATER     @G@@@@ WITH  A CHANGE IN EITHER OF THESE FIELDS,  APL WILL NOF
)@@G@@OT BE ABLE TO     @G@@@@ IDENTIFY  YOU, AND YOU WILL NOT BE ABLE TO GET OG
)@@G@@AT YOUR WORKSPACES.     @F@@@@ (CHAPTER 4 CONTAINS INFORMATION ON OVERRIOH
)@@G@@DING THIS, HOWEVER.)    @[@@@@      @G@@@@     UNLIKE  OTHER  APL  IMPLEOI
)@@G@@MENTATIONS,   THE  USE OF THE )OFF OR     @G@@@@ )CONTINUE  COMMANDS  DOOJ
)@@G@@ES  NOT  TERMINATE  YOUR  DIALOG  WITH  THE     @G@@@@ COMPUTER, IT ONLYOK
)@@G@@ TERMINATES YOUR APL SESSION, AND RETURNS CONTROL     @G@@@@ TO  EXEC  8OL
)@@G@@.   YOU MAY THEN USE ANY OF THE OTHER EXEC 8 PROCESSORS     @G@@@@ (SUCHOM
)@@G@@  AS  BASIC OR THE TEXT EDITOR).   WHEN YOU FINALLY DECIDE TO     @G@@@@ON

)@@G@@  1.11.   TUTORIALS     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@     TO  HELP  YOUOQ

)@@G@@INS FUNCTIONS WHICH WILL DRILL YOU IN THE USE OF SELECTED APL     @F@@@@OT

)@@G@@ EXPRESSIONS.  TO ACCESS THIS WORKSPACE, TYPE   @[@@@@      @ @@@@      OV
)@@G@@     )LOAD 1 APLCOURSE  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  SYSTEM  WILL RESPOND WITOW
)@@G@@H A TIME AND DATE MESSAGE TELLING YOU     @G@@@@ WHEN  THIS  WORKSPACE WOX
)@@G@@AS LAST CHANGED.   WHEN THE SYSTEM IS AGAIN     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USEROY
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           1- 15@[@@@@OZ
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ READY  TO  ACCEPT  INPUT  FROM  YOUPA
)@@G@@  (THE CARRIAGE WILL INDENT SIX     @#@@@@ SPACES) TYPE     @[@@@@      PB
)@@G@@@^@@@@           DESCRIBE     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ YOU WILL THEN BE GIVEN PC
