)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@ AND THE SYSTEM WILL GIVE YOU A LIST OF THEM.   @[@@@@PK
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    PL
)@@G@@       2-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  2.   FUNCTION DEPM
)@@G@@FINITION    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PN
)@@G@@@#@@@@  2. 1.   GENERAL @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@         ALTHOUGH PO
)@@G@@APL IS QUITE USEFUL AS A DESK CALCULATOR,  ONLY A     @G@@@@ FRACTION  OPP
)@@G@@F  ITS  CAPABILITIES  ARE  USED  IN  THIS MANNER.   THE     @G@@@@ PRIMIPQ
)@@G@@TIVE  OPERATORS  WHICH  ARE  PROVIDED  ARE GENERAL IN NATURE.     @G@@@@PR
)@@G@@ WHEN  SOLVING  A SPECIFIC PROBLEM,  THE CASE OFTEN OCCURS THAT ONE     PS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DOES  A  PARTICULAR  SEQUENCE OF OPERATIONS REPEATEDLY,  AND COULPT
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ MAKE  GOOD  USE  OF  A  SINGLE OPERATOR WHICH DID THIS SEQUPU
)@@G@@ENCE OF     @G@@@@ OPERATIONS WITHOUT HAVING TO RETYPE THEM EACH TIME THPV
)@@G@@EY WERE USED.     @G@@@@ APL  PROVIDES  THE  CAPABILITY TO CREATE SPECIAPW
)@@G@@LIZED OPERATORS FOR     @G@@@@ THIS  PURPOSE;   THEY  ARE  CALLED  'FUNCPX
)@@G@@TIONS'  AND  ARE  ROUGHLY     @C@@@@ ANALAGOUS TO SUBROUTINES IN OTHER LPY
)@@G@@ANGUAGES.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@          IN  DISCUSSING APL NAMES IN CHAPPZ
)@@G@@TER 2,  WE MENTIONED THAT     @G@@@@ NAMES  COULD BE USED FOR OTHER THINQA
)@@G@@GS BESIDES DATA;  FUNCTIONS ARE     @G@@@@ OBJECTS  WHICH ARE ALSO REFERQB
)@@G@@RED TO BY NAME.   JUST LIKE PRIMITIVE     @G@@@@ OPERATORS,   FUNCTIONS QC
)@@G@@ MAY  BE  DYADIC,  MONADIC OR NILADIC.   IN     @G@@@@ ADDITION,   A  FUQD
)@@G@@NCTION  MAY  OR  MAY  NOT  HAVE  A VALUE.   THESE     @E@@@@ PROPERTIES QE
)@@G@@ARE DETERMINED WHEN THE FUNCTION IS DEFINED.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      QF
)@@G@@   WHENEVER WE REFER TO A NAMED VARIABLE, APL TREATS IT AS IF     @G@@@@QG
)@@G@@ WE  HAD  ACTUALLY  RE-TYPED THE DATA AT THAT POINT.   IN A SIMILAR     QH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FASHION,  WHENEVER WE REFERENCE A FUNCTION NAME,  APL REACTS AS IQI
)@@G@@F     @G@@@@ WE  HAD  TYPED THE INDIVIDUAL LINES OF THE FUNCTION AT THATQJ
)@@G@@ POINT.     @G@@@@ THUS,   WE  CAN  CONSIDER  VARIABLES  AS  NAMES FOR OQK
)@@G@@PERANDS,  AND     @A@@@@ FUNCTIONS AS NAMES FOR OPERATORS.  @[@@@@      QL
)@@G@@@G@@@@         A FUNCTION IS DEFINED BY ENTERING THE 'FUNCTION DEFINITIOQM
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ MODE',   TYPING IN THE LINES OF INSTRUCTIONS WHICH DEFINE WQN
)@@G@@HAT THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  IS  TO  DO,   AND  THEN LEAVING FUNCTION DEQO
)@@G@@FINITION MODE     @G@@@@ (RETURNING  TO  DESK  CALCULATOR  MODE).  WHILEQP
)@@G@@ WE ARE IN FUNCTION     @G@@@@ DEFINITION  MODE  WE  ARE  DEFINING  WHATQQ
)@@G@@  SHOULD  BE DONE WHEN WE     @G@@@@ REFERENCE  THE  NAME  OF  THE  FUNCQR
)@@G@@TION.    CONSEQUENTLY,  THE APL     @G@@@@ STATEMENTS  TYPED  IN  ARE  NQS
)@@G@@OT  IMMEDIATELY  EXECUTED (AS IN DESK     @G@@@@ CALCULATOR MODE).  INSTQT
)@@G@@EAD, THEY ARE SAVED UNTIL WE RETURN TO DESK     @C@@@@ CALCULATOR MODE AQU
)@@G@@ND ATTEMPT TO USE THE FUNCTION@[@@@@      @G@@@@          THE  APL  STATQV
)@@G@@EMENTS  IN  A  FUNCTION  ARE NUMBERED,  AND     @G@@@@ EXECUTED IN NUMERQW
)@@G@@ICAL ORDER.  ANY APL NUMBER GREATER THAN ZERO MAY     @G@@@@ BE  USED  AQX
)@@G@@S A LINE NUMBER IN THE FUNCTION DEFINITION MODE.   LINE     @G@@@@ NUMBEQY
)@@G@@R  ZERO IS RESERVED FOR THE FUNCTION HEADER LINE (SEE BELOW).     @G@@@@QZ
)@@G@@ LINE  1.5,   FOR  EXAMPLE,   COMES BETWEEN LINES 1 AND 2.   IN THE     RA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FUNCTION  DEFINITION MODE,  IT IS NOT REQUIRED THAT LINES BE TYPERB
)@@G@@D     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        RC
)@@G@@                   2-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IN  IRD
)@@G@@N  ORDER,  OR THAT ALL POSSIBLE LINE NUMBERS BE USED.   IT IS     @G@@@@RE
)@@G@@ PERFECTLY  ACCEPTABLE  TO  HAVE  A LINE 999 WITHOUT HAVING LINES 1     RF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THROUGH  998.    WHEN  A  FUNCTION  IS CLOSED,  HOWEVER,  APL WILRG
)@@G@@L     @G@@@@ RENUMBER  ALL  OF  THE STATEMENTS IN IT,  AND GIVE THEM SEQRH
)@@G@@UENTIAL     @G@@@@ INTEGER  LINE  NUMBERS.    CONSEQUENTLY,   WHEN  THE RI
)@@G@@ FUNCTION  IS     @G@@@@ RE-OPENED,   THE  LINE  NUMBERS MAY HAVE CHANGERJ
)@@G@@D FROM THEIR VALUES     @G@@@@ WHEN  IT  WAS ORIGINALLY DEFINED.   THEY RK
)@@G@@WILL REMAIN IN THE PROPER     @ @@@@ NUMERICAL SEQUENCE, HOWEVER. @[@@@@RL
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       SINCE  A  DEFINED  FUNCTION  IS  EQUIVALENT  TO  A PRRM
)@@G@@IMITIVE     @G@@@@ OPERATOR,  IT MAY BE USED FREELY JUST AS IF IT WERE PRN
)@@G@@RIMITIVE.  IN     @G@@@@ PARTICULAR,   A  FUNCTION  MAY  BE  USED  IN  TRO
)@@G@@HE  BODY OF ANOTHER     @G@@@@ FUNCTION, OR EVEN IN ITS OWN BODY.  APL FRP
)@@G@@UNCTIONS ARE RECURSIVE TO     @D@@@@ A DEPTH LIMITED ONLY BY THE SIZE OFRQ
)@@G@@ A WORKSPACE.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @D@@@@  2. 2.   DEFINING A NEWRR
)@@G@@ FUNCTION: THE HEADER LINE    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@         TO RS
)@@G@@DEFINE A NEW FUNCTION, YOU FIRST TYPE THE APL SYMBOL $F     @G@@@@ (WHICRT
)@@G@@H  OPENS  FUNCTION  DEFINITION),   AND THEN TYPE (ON THE SAME     @G@@@@RU
)@@G@@ LINE) THE 'FUNCTION HEADER'.  THE 'FUNCTION HEADER' TELLS APL WHAT     RV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION IS TO BE,  WHETHER OR NOT IT IS TO HAVE RW
)@@G@@A     @G@@@@ RESULT,  WHETHER IT IS NILADIC,  MONADIC OR DYADIC, AND WHERX
)@@G@@THER IT     @A@@@@ IS TO HAVE ANY 'LOCAL VARIABLES'.  @[@@@@      @D@@@@RY
)@@G@@         THE GENERAL FORM OF A FUNCTION HEADER IS:    @[@@@@      @G@@@@RZ
)@@G@@      $F <RESULT> $S <LEFTARG> <FUNCNAME> <RIGHTARG> ; <LV1> ; ETC.     SA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @]@@@@ WHERE:     @[@@@@      @F@@@@     $F              CAUSB
)@@G@@SES THE SYSTEM TO ENTER FUNCTION DEFINI-  @A@@@@                     TIOSC
)@@G@@N MODE.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@     <RESULT>        IS THE NAME TO BE USESD
)@@G@@D FOR THE RESULT OF     @F@@@@                     THE FUNCTION, IF IT HSE
)@@G@@AS ONE.  IF THE FUNC-   @F@@@@                     TION HAS NO RESULT, TSF
)@@G@@HEN <RESULT> AND THE    @E@@@@                     $S WHICH FOLLOWS IT SSG
)@@G@@HOULD BE OMITTED. @[@@@@      @E@@@@     <LEFTARG>       IS A NAME USED SH
)@@G@@TO REPRESENT THE LEFT   @F@@@@                     ARGUMENT (IF THE FUNCSI
)@@G@@TION IS DYADIC).  IF    @F@@@@                     THE FUNCTION HAS NO LSJ
)@@G@@EFT ARGUMENT (I.E. IT   @E@@@@                     IS NILADIC OR MONADICSK
)@@G@@), THEN THIS IS   @ @@@@                     OMITTED. @[@@@@      @D@@@@SL
)@@G@@     <FUNCNAME>      IS THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@SM
)@@G@@     <RIGHTARG>      IS THE NAME OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT.  IF THE   @E@@@@SN
)@@G@@                     FUNCTION HAS NONE (I.E. IT IS NILADIC),@[@@@@*****^SO
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          SP
)@@G@@ 2-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@                     THESQ
)@@G@@N THIS IS OMITTED.@[@@@@      @G@@@@     <LV1>;<LV2> ETC.    ARE NAMES TSR
)@@G@@O BE USED FOR 'LOCAL VARIABLES'     @E@@@@                     OF THE FUSS
)@@G@@NCTION (SEE BELOW).  YOU MAY  @E@@@@                     DECLARE AS MANYST
)@@G@@ LOCAL VARIABLES AS YOU @E@@@@                     WISH, OR NONE AT ALL.SU
)@@G@@  THE NAME TO BE  @E@@@@                     USED FOR EACH LOCAL VARIABLSV
)@@G@@E MUST BE   @F@@@@                     SEPARATED FROM WHATEVER APPEARS TSW
)@@G@@O ITS LEFT  @C@@@@                     ON THE LINE BY A SEMICOLON.@[@@@@SX
)@@G@@      @G@@@@    TO AVOID CONFUSING TWO NAMES WITH A SINGLE VERY LONG NAMSY
)@@G@@E,  THE     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  AND  FUNCTION NAMES MUST BE SEPARATED FROM SZ
)@@G@@EACH OTHER BY     @^@@@@ AT LEAST ONE BLANK.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      TA
)@@G@@@A@@@@  2. 3.   THE BODY OF A FUNCTION    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@TB
)@@G@@          WHEN YOU HAVE TYPED IN YOUR FUNCTION HEADER LINE (AND HIT     TC
)@@G@@@C@@@@ CARRIAGE RETURN), THE SYSTEM WILL RESPOND WITH @[@@@@      @^@@@@TD
)@@G@@                   [1]  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ AND  WAIT  FOR  YOU  TO TYPE TE
)@@G@@THE FIRST LINE.   THIS (AND ANY OTHER     @G@@@@ LINES  YOU TYPE IN) MAKTF
)@@G@@E UP THE 'BODY' OF THE FUNCTION.   THEY ARE     @G@@@@ THE  MEANS  BY  WTG
)@@G@@HICH  YOU TELL APL WHAT IT SHOULD DO WHENEVER THE     @ @@@@ FUNCTION ISTH
)@@G@@ REFERRED TO.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@          A  MINIMAL  AMOUNT OF CHECTI
)@@G@@KING FOR CORRECTNESS IS DONE AS     @G@@@@ LINES  ARE TYPED IN,  AND IF TJ
)@@G@@AN ERROR IS DETECTED,  AN APPROPRIATE     @G@@@@ MESSAGE  WILL  BE  DISPTK
)@@G@@LAYED.   THE SYSTEM WILL THEN PROMPT YOU BY     @G@@@@ PRINTING  THE LINTL
)@@G@@E NUMBER FOR THE NEXT LINE IT EXPECTS TO READ (IF     @G@@@@ YOU HAD AN TM
)@@G@@ERROR OR DIDN'T TYPE ANYTHING,  IT MAY ASK FOR THE SAME     @G@@@@ LINE TN
)@@G@@ AGAIN).   YOU ARE NOT REQUIRED TO GIVE IT THE LINE IT WANTS,     @G@@@@TO
)@@G@@ THE  PROMPTING  IS  MERELY  TO  SAVE  YOU  THE  TROUBLE  OF TYPING     TP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SEQUENTIAL  LINE NUMBERS.  TO TYPE IN A DIFFERENTLY NUMBERED LINETQ
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ YOU NEED ONLY TYPE THE LINE NUMBER ENCLOSED IN BRACKETS BEFTR
)@@G@@ORE YOU     @G@@@@ TYPE  IN  THE TEXT OF THE LINE.  IN FACT, IF YOU CHANTS
)@@G@@GE YOUR MIND,     @G@@@@ YOU COULD TYPE IN SEVERAL LINE NUMBERS (EACH ENTT
)@@G@@CLOSED IN BRACKETS)     @G@@@@ ON  THE  SAME  LINE  BEFORE  YOU ACTUALLYTU
)@@G@@ TYPE THE THE TEXT OF THE     @G@@@@ STATEMENT.  APL WILL ACCEPT THE LASTV
)@@G@@T (RIGHTMOST) LINE NUMBER TYPED     @^@@@@ AS THE DESIRED ONE.    @[@@@@TW
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  2. 4.   LINE DELETION, INSERTION AND RETYPING TX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          WHENEVER  A  LINE  NUMBER  IS  TTY
)@@G@@YPED  BEFORE  ENTERING  A     @G@@@@ STATEMENT,   THEN  THAT  IS THE LINTZ
)@@G@@E NUMBER WHICH IS USED FOR THAT     @G@@@@ STATEMENT.    IF  IT IS THE SUA
)@@G@@AME AS THE LINE NUMBER OF A STATEMENT     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIUB
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           2-  4@[@@@@      UC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHICH  ALREADY  EXISTS,  THE OLD STATEMENUD
)@@G@@T EFFECTIVELY DISAPPEARS,     @G@@@@ AND  THE  NEW ONE IS USED INSTEAD. UE
)@@G@@  LINES MAY BE INSERTED BETWEEN     @G@@@@ OTHER LINES MERELY BY TYPING UF
)@@G@@A LINE NUMBER WHICH IS IN BETWEEN THE     @G@@@@ LINE NUMBERS DESIRED.  UG
)@@G@@IT IS NOT POSSIBLE TO DELETE A LINE BY ONLY     @G@@@@ TYPING  ITS  LINEUH
)@@G@@ NUMBER AND HITTING CARRIAGE RETURN.   INSTEAD OF     @G@@@@ ACCEPTING  UI
)@@G@@SUCH AN EMPTY LINE,  APL WILL PROMPT YOU AGAIN WITH THE     @F@@@@ SAME UJ
)@@G@@  LINE  NUMBER.    THIS  FEATURE  IS  TO  PROTECT  YOU  FROM@G@@@@ ACCIDUK
)@@G@@ENTALLY DELETING A LINE.   TO DELETE A LINE IN APL\1100,  YOU     @G@@@@UL
)@@G@@ MUST  ENTER  THE  LAMP (COMMENT) SYMBOL $:,  AND THEN HIT CARRIAGE     UM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RETURN.    A  LINE  WHICH CONTAINS THIS SYMBOL AND NOTHING ELSE IUN
)@@G@@S     @B@@@@ CONSIDERED VACUOUS, AND WILL BE DELETED. @[@@@@      @[@@@@UO
)@@G@@      @C@@@@  2. 5.   CLOSING THE DEFINITION OF A FUNCTION  @[@@@@      UP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@          ONCE  YOU  HAVE  COMPLETED  TYPING THE DEFINUQ
)@@G@@ITION OF YOUR     @G@@@@ FUNCTION, YOU CLOSE IT AND RETURN TO DESK CALCUUR
)@@G@@LATOR MODE BY AGAIN     @G@@@@ TYPING  THE FUNCTION DEFINITION CHARACTERUS
)@@G@@ $F.   THIS CHARACTER MAY     @G@@@@ APPEAR  ON THE SAME LINE AS TEXT WHUT
)@@G@@ICH HAS BEEN TYPED IN,  OR ON A     @G@@@@ LINE  BY  ITSELF.    ANYTHINGUU
)@@G@@ TYPED TO THE RIGHT OF THE $F WILL BE     @]@@@@ IGNORED.   @[@@@@      UV
)@@G@@@G@@@@          IF  A  $F  APPEARS  AS A CHARACTER CONSTANT (I.E.  WITHIUW
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ QUOTES),   IT  WILL  NOT  CAUSE  THE  FUNCTION  TO BE CLOSEUX
)@@G@@D.   IN     @G@@@@ ADDITION, A $F TYPED AFTER A LAMP $: WILL BE CONSIDERUY
)@@G@@ED AS PART OF     @E@@@@ THE COMMENT, AND THE FUNCTION DEFINITION WILL RUZ
)@@G@@EMAIN OPEN. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  2. 6.   REOPENING THE DEFINIVA
)@@G@@TION OF A FUNCTION@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          IT  OFTEN OCCUVB
)@@G@@RS THAT ONE WISHES TO CHANGE SOMETHING IN A     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  AFTER  VC
)@@G@@HAVING  PREVIOUSLY  DEFINED  IT;  THIS IS DONE BY     @G@@@@ TYPING THE VD
)@@G@@FUNCTION DEFINITION CHARACTER ($F) FOLLOWED BY THE NAME     @G@@@@ OF  TVE
)@@G@@HE  FUNCTION  ITSELF  (SINCE  THE  FUNCTION  HAS ALREADY BEEN     @G@@@@VF
)@@G@@ DEFINED,   ITS  HEADER LINE SHOULD NOT BE RETYPED).   IN THE USUAL     VG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FASHION,   THE  SYSTEM WILL PROMPT YOU WITH THE NUMBER OF THE NEXVH
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ LINE  IT  EXPECTS  YOU  TO  TYPE;  SINCE YOU ARE RE-OPENINGVI
)@@G@@ AN OLD     @G@@@@ FUNCTION,   IT INITIALLY ASSUMES THAT YOU WISH TO ADDVJ
)@@G@@ NEW LINES TO     @G@@@@ THE END OF WHAT IS ALREADY THERE.   THE LINE NUVK
)@@G@@MBER TYPED OUT WILL     @F@@@@ BE ONE GREATER THAN THE NUMBER OF LINES AVL
)@@G@@LREADY IN THE FUNCTION. @[@@@@      @G@@@@          IT  IS  POSSIBLE  TOVM
)@@G@@  RE-OPEN  AN  OLD FUNCTION,  DO SOME     @G@@@@ EDITING,  AND CLOSE IT VN
)@@G@@AGAIN ALL IN ONE LINE.  TO DO THIS, RE-OPEN     @G@@@@ THE  FUNCTION  INVO
)@@G@@  THE NORMAL FASHION ($F FOLLOWED BY THE FUNCTION     @G@@@@ NAME), TYPEVP
)@@G@@ THE EDITING INFORMATION ON THE SAME LINE (WHICH MAY BE     @G@@@@ A  LIVQ
)@@G@@NE NUMBER FOLLOWED BY THE TEXT OF A STATEMENT) AND THEN CLOSE     @G@@@@VR
)@@G@@ THE DEFINITION BY TYPING THE $F.   ANY EDITING COMMAND (SEE BELOW)     VS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ MAY  BE  TYPED AFTER THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION.   APL WILL SCAN THVT
)@@G@@E     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        VU
)@@G@@                   2-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ LINE,VV
)@@G@@   AND WHEN AN EDITING COMMAND IS DETECTED,  PERFORM IT.   IT     @G@@@@VW
)@@G@@ WILL  THEN  RETURN TO THE ORIGINAL LINE (IF POSSIBLE) AND CONTINUE     VX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SCANNING FOR ANOTHER EDITING COMMAND (WHICH WILL BE DONE),  OR THVY
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ CLOSING $F,  OR THE END OF THE STATEMENT.  IF THE $F IS NOTVZ
)@@G@@ ON THE     @G@@@@ LINE,   APL WILL REMAIN IN THE FUNCTION DEFINITION MOWA
)@@G@@DE AND PROMPT     @E@@@@ YOU WITH THE LINE NUMBER OF THE NEXT STATEMENT WB
)@@G@@IT EXPECTS. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  2. 7.   FUNCTION EDITING COMWC
)@@G@@MANDS @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@          APL  PROVIDES  SEVERAL  COWD
)@@G@@MMANDS TO MAKE FUNCTION EDITING     @G@@@@ EASIER.   FUNCTION EDITING COWE
)@@G@@MMANDS ARE ENCLOSED IN BRACKETS.  APL     @G@@@@ DISTINGUISHES THEM FROMWF
)@@G@@ SUBSCRIPTS BECAUSE THEY MUST APPEAR AT THE     @G@@@@ BEGINNING  (LEFT WG
)@@G@@SIDE) OF A TYPED LINE.   A FUNCTION COMMAND WHICH     @G@@@@ APPEARS  ANWH
)@@G@@YWHERE  AFTER  APL  TEXT  HAS BEEN TYPED ON A LINE WILL     @C@@@@ USUALWI
)@@G@@LY RESULT IN THE MESSAGE 'DEFN ERROR'.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@          THWJ
)@@G@@E  SIMPLEST  OF  THE  FUNCTION  EDITING COMMANDS,  LEFT     @G@@@@ BRACKWK
)@@G@@ET,  LINE NUMBER, RIGHT BRACKET HAS ALREADY BEEN  INTRODUCED.     @G@@@@WL
)@@G@@ IT  MEANS  'ASSIGN THE SPECIFIED STATEMENT NUMBER TO THE FOLLOWING     WM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ STATEMENT'.    THE  OTHERS  ARE LISTED BELOW.   NOTE THAT ALTHOUGWN
)@@G@@H     @G@@@@ THESE  EDITING  COMMANDS  HAVE  THE  SAME  FORMAT  AS  THE WO
)@@G@@EDITING     @G@@@@ COMMANDS ON OTHER APL SYSTEMS, THE MEANING OF SOME OFWP
)@@G@@ THEM DIFFERS     @]@@@@ SLIGHTLY.  @[@@@@      @D@@@@         ["]      WQ
)@@G@@      DISPLAY THE ENTIRE FUNCTION.  @E@@@@         [N"]           DISPLAWR
)@@G@@Y LINE 'N' OF THE FUNCTION.   @G@@@@          [N"M]          DISPLAY 'M'WS
)@@G@@ LINES, STARTING FROM LINE 'N'.     @G@@@@         ["N]           PREPARWT
)@@G@@E TO CHANGE SELECTED PORTIONS OF LINE     @F@@@@                        WU
)@@G@@'N'.  LINE CHANGING IS COVERED BELOW.     @[@@@@      @D@@@@  2. 7. 1.  WV
)@@G@@  EDITING A LINE: THE LINE CHANGE MODE    @[@@@@      @G@@@@          THWW
)@@G@@E  EDITING  COMMAND  ["N]  CAUSES APL TO ENTER THE LINE     @G@@@@ CHANGWX
)@@G@@E  MODE  FOR  LINE  'N'.   IN THIS MODE,  SMALL PORTIONS OF A     @G@@@@WY
)@@G@@ STATEMENT  MAY  BE  CHANGED  WITHOUT  HAVING  TO RETYPE THE ENTIRE     WZ
)@@G@@@]@@@@ STATEMENT. @[@@@@      @G@@@@          WHEN  THE FUNCTION EDITINGXA
)@@G@@ COMMAND ["N] IS DETECTED,  THE     @G@@@@ LINE  IS  DISPLAYED,   AND THXB
)@@G@@E SYSTEM THEN WAITS FOR A LINE CHANGE     @^@@@@ COMMAND OF THE FORM.   XC
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@         A)  /<STRING 1>/<STRING 2>/        OR  @C@@@@XD
)@@G@@         B)  /<STRING 1>/<STRING 2>         OR  @B@@@@         C)  /<STRXE
)@@G@@ING 1>/<STRING 2>/ G    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  FIRST  NON-BLANK  XF
)@@G@@APL  CHARACTER ON THE LINE ( / IN THE     @G@@@@ EXAMPLES  ABOVE)  IS USXG
)@@G@@ED AS A DELIMITER TO SEPARATE STRING 1 FROM     @G@@@@ STRING  2  AND  (XH
)@@G@@POSSIBLY) TO MARK THE END OF STRING 2.   APL WILL     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@XI
)@@G@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           2-  6XJ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ SCAN  THE  DISPLAYED  STATEMEXK
)@@G@@NT FOR AN OCCURENCE OF THE CHARACTERS     @G@@@@ WHICH MAKE UP STRING 1.XL
)@@G@@  WHEN THE MATCH IS DETECTED, THE OCCURENCE     @G@@@@ OF STRING 1 IN THXM
)@@G@@E STATEMENT IS CHANGED TO STRING 2.   IF FORM 'A'     @G@@@@ ABOVE  IS UXN
)@@G@@SED,  THE REMAINDER OF THE STATEMENT IS UNCHANGED.   IF     @G@@@@ FORM XO
)@@G@@'B' IS USED,  THE REMAINDER OF THE STATEMENT (AFTER STRING 2)     @G@@@@XP
)@@G@@ IS  BLANKED.    IF  ANY  NON-BLANK  CHARACTER  FOLLOWS  THE  THIRD     XQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DELIMITER, THEN ALL OCCURENCES OF STRING 1 IN THE LINE ARE CHANGEXR
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ TO  STRING 2 (INSTEAD OF JUST THE FIRST).  AFTER EDITING THXS
)@@G@@E LINE,     @G@@@@ THE  NEW  VERSION  OF  THE  LINE  IS  AGAIN DISPLAYEDXT
)@@G@@,  AND APL IS     @G@@@@ PREPARED  TO  ACCEPT  ANOTHER  CHANGE COMMAND FXU
)@@G@@OR THAT LINE.   ANY     @G@@@@ NUMBER OF SUCH CHANGES MAY BE MADE TO A LXV
)@@G@@INE -- EACH TIME A CHANGE     @G@@@@ IS  MADE,   THE  NEW  LINE  WILL  BXW
)@@G@@E  RE-DISPLAYED.   A BLANK LINE     @F@@@@ (CARRIAGE  RETURN)  SIGNALS  XX
)@@G@@APL  TO  ACCEPT  THE  MOST  RECENTLY@G@@@@ DISPLAYED  VERSION  OF  THE LXY
)@@G@@INE AND RETURN TO THE NORMAL FUNCTION     @#@@@@ DEFINITION MODE. @[@@@@XZ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@          IN  THE  LINE CHANGE MODE, ANY PORTION OF THE TYPEYA
)@@G@@D LINE,     @G@@@@ INCLUDING THE LINE NUMBER,  MAY BE CHANGED.  SINCE THYB
)@@G@@E LINE IS NOT     @G@@@@ INSERTED  INTO THE FUNCTION UNTIL ONE LEAVES THYC
)@@G@@E LINE CHANGE MODE,     @G@@@@ THIS  FEATURE  MAY  BE  USED  TO  PRODUCEYD
)@@G@@  A  COPY OF A PARTICULAR     @G@@@@ STATEMENT  WITH  A  CHANGED  LINE  YE
)@@G@@NUMBER,  WITHOUT DESTROYING THE     @G@@@@ ORIGINAL  STATEMENT.    STRINYF
)@@G@@GS  1 AND 2 MAY CONTAIN ANY NUMBER OF     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS (EXCEPT THATYG
)@@G@@ STRING 1 MUST HAVE AT LEAST ONE).   A LINE     @G@@@@ MAY  BE  LENGTHENYH
)@@G@@ED  BY  A  CHANGE  COMMAND  TO  A  MAXIMUM OF 132     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS;YI
)@@G@@  AN ATTEMPT TO LENGTHEN A LINE BEYOND THIS WILL RESULT     @^@@@@ IN A YJ
)@@G@@'LENGTH ERROR'.   @[@@@@      @ @@@@  2. 7. 2.    LOCKED FUNCTIONS@[@@@@YK
)@@G@@      @G@@@@          IT  IS  SOMETIMES  DESIRABLE  TO  KEEP  SECRET  THYL
)@@G@@E EXACT     @G@@@@ STATEMENTS WHICH COMPRISE A FUNCTION.  THIS IS DONE BYM
)@@G@@Y LOCKING THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  DEFINITION.    A LOCKED FUNCTION MAY YN
)@@G@@BE USED IN THE SAME     @G@@@@ MANNER AS ANY OTHER FUNCTION,  HOWEVER,  YO
)@@G@@ANY ATTEMPT TO RE-OPEN IT     @G@@@@ WILL RESULT IN A 'DEFN ERROR'.   INYP
)@@G@@ ADDITION, WHEN AN ERROR OCCURS     @G@@@@ IN THE EXECUTION OF A LOCKED YQ
)@@G@@FUNCTION,  THE STATEMENT WHICH CAUSED     @G@@@@ THE   ERROR WILL NOT BEYR
)@@G@@ DISPLAYED,  ALTHOUGH THE FUNCTION NAME AND     @G@@@@ LINE NUMBER WILL.YS
)@@G@@   AS A CONSEQUENCE,  IT IS IMPOSSIBLE TO DISPLAY     @A@@@@ THE CONTENTYT
)@@G@@S OF A LOCKED FUNCTION. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      A FUNCTION IS LOCKED BY YU
)@@G@@USING THE LOCK SYMBOL,  $K INSTEAD OF     @G@@@@ THE  NORMAL  FUNCTION  YV
)@@G@@DEFINITION  SYMBOL $F.   THE $K MAY BE USED     @G@@@@ EITHER  TO  OPEN YW
)@@G@@OR CLOSE THE DEFINITION (OR BOTH).   A PREVIOUSLY     @F@@@@ DEFINED  UNYX
)@@G@@LOCKED  FUNCTION  MAY  BE  LOCKED  BY  RE-OPENING  ITS@G@@@@ DEFINITION YY
)@@G@@ USING $K IN PLACE OF $F.   SINCE A LOCKED FUNCTION MAY     @G@@@@ NEVERYZ
)@@G@@  BE  DISPLAYED  OR  CHANGED  AGAIN,   ONE  SHOULD NOT LOCK A     @G@@@@ZA
)@@G@@ FUNCTION  UNLESS  AN  UNLOCKED  COPY  OR  PRINTOUT  OF  IT  EXISTS     ZB
)@@G@@@]@@@@ ELSEWHERE. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  2. 8.   CORRECTING ERRZC
)@@G@@ORS   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        ZD
)@@G@@                   2-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      ZE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@      WHEN THE FUNCTION DEFINITION MODE IS ENTERED, A ZF
)@@G@@COMPLETE COPY     @G@@@@ OF THE FUNCTION IS MADE.   THE ORIGINAL COPY ISZG
)@@G@@ KEPT ALSO,  AND IT     @G@@@@ IS  NOT  REPLACED BY THE EDITED COPY UNTIZH
)@@G@@L THE FUNCTION DEFINITION     @G@@@@ MODE IS CLOSED.  WHEN THE DEFINITIOZI
)@@G@@N MODE IS OPEN, ANY LINE MAY BE     @G@@@@ CHANGED,  INCLUDING THE FUNCTZJ
)@@G@@ION HEADER LINE.   SINCE THE ORIGINAL     @G@@@@ COPY OF A FUNCTION IS NZK
)@@G@@OT DISTURBED, IT IS POSSIBLE TO MAKE A COPY     @G@@@@ OF  A  FUNCTION  ZL
)@@G@@BY  OPENING IT,  CHANGING ITS NAME (ON THE HEADER     @G@@@@ LINE),   ANZM
)@@G@@D CLOSING.   BY CHANGING THE NAME,  YOU HAVE DEFINED AN     @G@@@@ ENTIRZN
)@@G@@ELY  NEW FUNCTION,  AND THE ORIGINAL COPY (WITH THE OLD NAME)     @ @@@@ZO
)@@G@@ WILL REMAIN UNDISTURBED.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  FEATURE  CAZP
)@@G@@N  BE USED WHEN ERRORS HAVE BEEN MADE WHILE     @G@@@@ EDITING  WHICH  AZQ
)@@G@@RE  SO SEVERE AS TO MAKE IT WORTHWHILE TO DISCARD     @G@@@@ THE  EDITEDZR
)@@G@@  FUNCTION  COMPLETELY AND REVERT TO THE ORIGINAL COPY.     @G@@@@ ONE CZS
)@@G@@AN CHANGE THE NAME OF THE FUNCTION BEING EDITED AND LEAVE THE     @G@@@@ZT
)@@G@@ DEFINITION  MODE.    THE  RESULT  WILL  BE  THAT BOTH THE ORIGINAL     ZU
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FUNCTION  AND  THE  RENAMED ONE WILL EXIST IN THE WORKSPACE.   THZV
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RENAMED  ONE  MAY  THEN  BE  DISCARDED USING  )ERASE,  AND ZW
)@@G@@ANOTHER     @C@@@@ ATTEMPT MADE TO EDIT THE ORIGINAL FUNCTION.    @[@@@@ZX
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       A SIMILAR FEATURE EXISTS WHILE IN THE LINE CHANGE MODZY
)@@G@@E.   IN     @G@@@@ THE  LINE  CHANGE  MODE,   ANYTHING  ON  THE  LINE  MZZ
)@@G@@AY BE CHANGED     @G@@@@ INCLUDING  THE  LINE  NUMBER.   THE TEXT OF THEAA
)@@G@@ EDITED LINE IS NOT     @G@@@@ INCORPORATED  INTO  THE  BODY OF THE FUNCAB
)@@G@@TION UNTIL ONE LEAVES THE     @G@@@@ LINE  CHANGE MODE (BY ENTERING A BLAC
)@@G@@ANK LINE).   CONSEQUENTLY,  ONE     @G@@@@ CAN  DISCARD  THE  RESULTS  OAD
)@@G@@F A BADLY EDITED LINE BY CHANGING ITS     @#@@@@ LINE NUMBER.     @[@@@@AE
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  2. 9.   ARGUMENTS AND LOCAL VARIABAF
)@@G@@LES   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       SINCE  A DEFINED FUNCTION WILAG
)@@G@@L ACT LIKE A PRIMITIVE OPERATOR     @G@@@@ WHEN REFERENCED, IT IS CLEAR AH
)@@G@@THAT IT MUST HAVE DATA TO OPERATE ON.     @G@@@@ WHEN  A  DYADIC  FUNCTIAI
)@@G@@ON IS USED,  FOR EXAMPLE,  WE TYPE THE LEFT     @G@@@@ OPERAND,   THE  FAJ
)@@G@@UNCTION NAME,  AND THE RIGHT OPERAND,  JUST AS WE     @G@@@@ WOULD FOR AAK
)@@G@@ PRIMITIVE.  SINCE THE FUNCTION MUST BE ABLE TO OPERATE     @G@@@@ ON THAL
)@@G@@ESE OPERANDS (WHICH ARE CALLED ITS ARGUMENTS) THERE MUST BE A     @G@@@@AM
)@@G@@ WAY  TO  REFER TO THEM WITHIN THE BODY OF THE FUNCTION.   THE LEFT     AN
)@@G@@@D@@@@ AND RIGHT ARGUMENT NAMES ARE USED FOR THIS PURPOSE.  @[@@@@      AO
)@@G@@@G@@@@       WHENEVER  IT IS NECESSARY IN THE BODY OF A FUNCTION TO REFEAP
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ TO  THE VALUE OF AN ARGUMENT,  WE USE THE NAME WE HAVE DEFIAQ
)@@G@@NED FOR     @G@@@@ THIS  PURPOSE  ON THE FUNCTION HEADER LINE.   WHEN THAR
)@@G@@E FUNCTION IS     @G@@@@ ENTERED, APL WILL AUTOMATICALLY CREATE VARIABLEAS
)@@G@@S WITH THESE NAMES,     @G@@@@ AND  ASSIGN  TO  THEM  THE  VALUES OF THEAT
)@@G@@ LEFT AND RIGHT OPERANDS.     @G@@@@ THESE  NAMES  MAY  THEN  BE   USED AU
)@@G@@ IN THE BODY OF THE FUNCTION TO     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO AV
)@@G@@APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           2-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@AW
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ REFERENCE  THE DATA.   NAMED VARIABLES CREATED AX
)@@G@@IN THIS MANNER HAVE     @G@@@@ NO  SIGNIFICANCE EXCEPT WHEN THE FUNCTIONAY
)@@G@@ IS BEING EXECUTED;  THEY     @E@@@@ ARE CREATED WHEN IT STARTS AND DISCAZ
)@@G@@ARDED WHEN IT FINISHES. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE VARIABLES CREATED FOBA
)@@G@@R THE ARGUMENTS OF A FUNCTION ARE NOT     @G@@@@ THE SAME AS THE OPERANDBB
)@@G@@S USED ON THE LINE IN WHICH THE FUNCTION IS     @G@@@@ CALLED,   THEY  ABC
)@@G@@RE  COPIES  OF  THESE OPERANDS.   A SPECIFICATION     @G@@@@ OPERATOR  IBD
)@@G@@N  THE FUNCTION BODY MAY HAVE ONE OF THESE NAMES AS ITS     @G@@@@ LEFT BE
)@@G@@ARGUMENT, BUT THE VALUES OF THE ORIGINAL OPERANDS WILL NOT BE     @#@@@@BF
)@@G@@ AFFECTED BY THIS.@[@@@@      @G@@@@      JUST AS WE MUST HAVE SOME METHBG
)@@G@@OD OF REFERENCING THE ARGUMENTS     @G@@@@ OF A FUNCTION,  WE MUST ALSO BH
)@@G@@BE ABLE TO SPECIFY WHAT ITS RESULT IS     @G@@@@ TO BE, AND THE RESULT NBI
)@@G@@AME IS USED FOR THIS PURPOSE.  IF THE FUNC-     @G@@@@ TION HAS A RESULTBJ
)@@G@@,  THEN SOMEWHERE IN THE BODY OF A FUNCTION,  THE     @G@@@@ VALUE MUST BK
)@@G@@BE SPECIFIED BY STORING THE DESIRED VALUE IN THE RESULT     @G@@@@ VARIABL
)@@G@@BLE.  AS FOR ARGUMENT NAMES, THE NAME USED FOR THE RESULT HAS     @E@@@@BM
)@@G@@ NO SIGNIFICANCE UNLESS THE FUNCTION IS BEING EXECUTED.     @[@@@@      BN
)@@G@@@G@@@@       VARIABLES  LIKE THE ARGUMENTS AND RESULT,  WHICH ARE CREATEBO
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ AND DESTROYED AS WE ENTER AND LEAVE A FUNCTION,  ARE CALLEDBP
)@@G@@ 'LOCAL     @G@@@@ VARIABLES'.    IT  SOMETIMES  HAPPENS  THAT  A  REASOBQ
)@@G@@NABLY COMPLEX     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  MAY HAVE NEED TO SAVE SEVERAL INTERMEBR
)@@G@@DIATE RESULTS,  AND     @G@@@@ NATURALLY  THE  SPECIFICATION  OPERATOR IBS
)@@G@@S USED FOR THIS.   WE ARE     @G@@@@ FREE  TO  USE  ANY NAMED VARIABLE (BT
)@@G@@INCLUDING RESULT AND ARGUMENTS)     @G@@@@ FOR THIS PURPOSE, BUT IF THESBU
)@@G@@E RESULTS HAVE NO SIGNIFICANCE EXCEPT     @G@@@@ INTERNALLY TO THE FUNCTBV
)@@G@@ION,  WE USUALLY DECLARE THE VARIABLE NAMES     @G@@@@ TO BE USED AS LOCBW
)@@G@@AL VARIABLES ON THE FUNCTION HEADER LINE.   THESE     @F@@@@ VARIABLES WBX
)@@G@@ILL THEN BE DISCARDED WHEN THE FUNCTION TERMINATES.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@BY
)@@G@@      @A@@@@  2.10.   MASKING OF VARIABLE NAMES @[@@@@      @[@@@@      BZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@       SINCE  A FUNCTION IS USED IN THE SAME FASHION AS A PRIMITIVCA
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OPERATOR,  AND SINCE WE MAY USE PRIMITIVE OPERATORS IN THE CB
)@@G@@BODY OF     @G@@@@ A  FUNCTION IT IS CLEAR THAT WE MAY REFER TO FUNCTIONCC
)@@G@@S IN THE BODY     @G@@@@ OF OTHER FUNCTIONS.   WE CAN,  IN FACT EVEN REFCD
)@@G@@ER TO A FUNCTION IN     @G@@@@ ITS  OWN BODY,  BUT WE MUST BE CAREFUL THCE
)@@G@@AT THERE IS SOME WAY THAT     @E@@@@ IT WILL EVENTAULLY FINISH, AND NOT CF
)@@G@@CALL ITSELF FOREVER.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       EACH  TIME  A  FUNCTIONCG
)@@G@@  IS CALLED,  ITS LOCAL VARIABLES ARE     @G@@@@ CREATED.   IF  A  FUNCTCH
)@@G@@ION THEN PROCEEDS TO CALL ANOTHER FUNCTION,     @G@@@@ THE  LOCAL  VARIACI
)@@G@@BLES  FOR  THE  SECOND FUNCTION ARE ALSO CREATED.     @G@@@@ SINCE  THE CJ
)@@G@@ FIRST  FUNCTION HAS NOT FINISHED,  HOWEVER,  ITS LOCAL     @G@@@@ VARIACK
)@@G@@BLES  STILL  EXIST,  AND MAY BE REFERRED TO BY THEIR NAMES IN     @G@@@@CL
)@@G@@ THE SECOND FUNCTION.  IF SOME OF THE LOCAL VARIABLES OF THE SECOND     CM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FUNCTION  HAVE  NAMES  WHICH ARE THE SAME AS NAMES USED ELSEWHERECN
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ THE  MOST  RECENT  DEFINITION  (I.E.   THAT  OF THE FUNCTIOCO
)@@G@@N BEING     @G@@@@ IMMEDIATELY  EXECUTED)  OF  THE  NAME IS USED,  AND TCP
)@@G@@HE OTHERS ARE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINCQ
)@@G@@ARY)                           2-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      CR
)@@G@@@G@@@@ 'MASKED'.    THIS WILL BE TREATED IN MORE DETAIL WHEN WE COVER THCS
)@@G@@E     @D@@@@ EXECUTION OF APL PROGRAMS AND )SI AND )SIV COMMANDS. @[@@@@CT
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    CU
)@@G@@       3-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  3.   SYSTEM COMMCV
)@@G@@ANDS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IN  ADDITION  TO CW
)@@G@@ THE  COMPUTATIONAL  FACILITIES  OF THE APL     @G@@@@ LANGUAGE  ITSELF,CX
)@@G@@   APL\1100  PROVIDES  A NUMBER OF FACILITIES FOR     @G@@@@ SAVING  ANDCY
)@@G@@  COPYING  FUNCTIONS  AND DATA,  COMMUNICATING WITH THE     @F@@@@ COMPUCZ
)@@G@@TER  OPERATOR,   AND  MISCELLANEOUS  OTHER  THINGS.    THESE@G@@@@ FACILDA
)@@G@@ITIES ARE ACCESSED THROUGH THE  USE OF APL 'SYSTEM COMMANDS'.     @G@@@@DB
)@@G@@ AN APL SYSTEM COMMAND STARTS WITH A RIGHT PARENTHESIS, FOLLOWED BY     DC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE NAME OF THE COMMAND,  AND ANY OTHER INFORMATION WHICH MIGHT BDD
)@@G@@E     @B@@@@ REQUIRED BY THE SPECIFIC COMMAND USED.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@DE
)@@G@@      @A@@@@  3. 1.   WORKSPACES AND LIBRARIES  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      DF
)@@G@@@G@@@@       WHILE  AN APL TERMINAL SESSION IS UNDERWAY,  NAMED VARIABLEDG
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ AND  FUNCTIONS  ARE  STORED  IN YOUR 'ACTIVE WORKSPACE',  WDH
)@@G@@HICH IS     @G@@@@ ESTABLISHED WHEN YOUR @APL CARD IS PROCESSED.   THE NDI
)@@G@@ORMAL SIZE OF     @G@@@@ A  WORKSPACE IS APPROXIMATELY 32K CHARACTERS,  DJ
)@@G@@ENOUGH TO CONTAIN A     @G@@@@ GREAT  MANY  FUNCTIONS  AND VARIABLES.   DK
)@@G@@IN ADDITION TO THE ACTIVE     @G@@@@ WORKSPACE,  APL ESTABLISHES A 'LIBRDL
)@@G@@ARY' OF WORKSPACES ON DRUM, AND     @G@@@@ YOU  MAY  SAVE  MANY  DIFFEREDM
)@@G@@NT  WORKSPACES  IN  THIS  LIBRARY AND     @G@@@@ RETRIEVE  THEM  FOR  USDN
)@@G@@E  AT  ANY  TIME.    MANY OF THE APL SYSTEM     @G@@@@ COMMANDS  ARE  CODO
)@@G@@NCERNED  WITH  THE  MAINTENANCE  OF  LIBRARIES OF     @]@@@@ WORKSPACES.DP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 1. 1.   LIBRARY NUMBERS  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      DQ
)@@G@@ AN  INDIVIDUAL  LIBRARY OF WORKSPACES IS MAINTAINED FOR EACH     @G@@@@DR
)@@G@@ DIFFERENT  APL\1100  USER,   AND THESE ARE DISTINGUISHED FROM EACH     DS
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OTHER   BY  'LIBRARY  NUMBERS'.    UNLESS  EXPLICITLY  INSTRUCTEDDT
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OTHERWISE, APL COMPUTES YOUR LIBRARY NUMBER AUTOMATICALLY FROM THDU
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ ACCOUNT NUMBER AND PROJECT FIELDS OF YOUR @RUN CARD.  UNDERDV
)@@G@@ NORMAL     @G@@@@ CIRCUMSTANCES, YOU WILL NEVER NEED TO KNOW OR USE YOUDW
)@@G@@R OWN LIBRARY     @G@@@@ NUMBER,  BUT A SYSTEM FUNCTION (CHAPTER 6) IS ADX
)@@G@@VAILABLE WHICH WILL     @G@@@@ GIVE  IT  TO  YOU.    A LIBRARY NUMBER MUDY
)@@G@@ST BE USED IF YOU WISH TO     @G@@@@ ACCESS  WORKSPACES  IN  LIBRARIES  DZ
)@@G@@OTHER  THAN YOUR OWN.   LIBRARY     @G@@@@ NUMBERS  FOR  INDIVIDUAL  APLEA
)@@G@@  USERS  START  FROM 1000;  NUMBERS 1     @G@@@@ THROUGH  999  ARE USED EB
)@@G@@FOR PUBLIC LIBRARIES IN WHICH WORKSPACES OF     @D@@@@ GENERAL INTEREST EC
)@@G@@(SUCH AS THE TUTORIALS) ARE SAVED.  @[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 1. 2.   WORKSED
)@@G@@PACE NAMES  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      EACH WORKSPACE SAVED IN A LIBRARY MUEE
)@@G@@ST BE NAMED, AND THE NAME     @G@@@@ IS  ASSIGNED WHEN THE WORKSPACE IS EF
)@@G@@ORIGINALLY SAVED.   A WORKSPACE     @G@@@@ NAME IS ANY COMBINATION OF APEG
)@@G@@L LETTERS AND DIGITS, STARTING WITH A     @G@@@@ LETTER.   A  MAXIMUM  OEH
)@@G@@F 12 CHARACTERS IS PERMITTED IN A WORKSPACE     @F@@@@ NAME; CHARACTERS EI
)@@G@@AFTER THE TWELFTH WILL BE ACCEPTED BUT IGNORED. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USEREJ
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           3-  2@[@@@@EK

)@@G@@ORD  ON  EVERY  )SAVE.   THE LOCK MAY BE REMOVED BY )SAVE ING     @G@@@@FK

)@@G@@ TO CERTAIN DEFAULT     @G@@@@ VALUES  WHEN  )CLEAR  IS  DONE.   THEY MAHN
)@@G@@Y BE SUBSEQUENTLY CHANGED     @F@@@@ EITHER  BY  SYSTEM  COMMANDS  OR  BHO
)@@G@@Y  THE  EXECUTION  OF  CERTAIN@G@@@@ FUNCTIONS.    THE FUNCTIONS WHICH CHP
)@@G@@ORRESPOND TO THESE COMMANDS ARE     @C@@@@ FOUND IN THE WORKSPACE WSFNS HQ
)@@G@@IN LIBRARY 1.     @[@@@@      @^@@@@  3. 3. 1.   )ORIGIN <N>@[@@@@      HR
)@@G@@@G@@@@        SETS  THE  INDEX  ORIGIN FOR SUBSCRIPTING AND CERTAIN OTHEHS
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ OPERATORS.   <N> MAY BE ZERO OR ONE.   THE NORMAL DEFAULT VHT
)@@G@@ALUE IS     @G@@@@ 1,  I.E. THE SUBSCRIPT FOR THE FIRST ELEMENT IN AN ARHU
)@@G@@RAY IS UNITY.     @D@@@@ IN ORIGIN 0, SUBSCRIPT VALUES RANGE UPWARD FROMHV
)@@G@@ ZERO.@[@@@@      @^@@@@  3. 3. 2.   )WIDTH <N> @[@@@@      @G@@@@      HW
)@@G@@ SETS THE MAXIMUM NUMBER OF APL CHARACTERS TO BE PRINTED ON A     @G@@@@HX
)@@G@@ SINGLE  LINE.    IF AN OUTPUT LINE EXCEEDS THIS VALUE,  IT WILL BE     HY
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CONTINUED  ON  AS MANY ADDITIONAL LINES AS ARE NEEDED.   CONTINUEHZ
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ LINES  WILL BE INDENTED BY FOUR SPACES.   THE DEFAULT VALUEIA
)@@G@@S FOR A     @G@@@@ CLEAR  WORKSPACE  ARE  72  FOR DEMAND RUNS AND 132 FOIB
)@@G@@R BATCH RUNS.     @G@@@@ ONCE  A  WORKSPACE IS )SAVE'D, ITS WIDTH REMAINIC
)@@G@@S WITH IT, HOWEVER,     @G@@@@ AND  WILL  NOT  BE  AFFECTED  BY THE BATCID
)@@G@@H/DEMAND STATUS OF A @RUN     @ @@@@ WHICH MAY LATER )LOAD IT.    @[@@@@IE
)@@G@@      @G@@@@        THE  SPECIFIED  WIDTH  IS  MEASURED IN APL CHARACTERIF
)@@G@@S,  NOT     @G@@@@ FIELDATA  CHARACTERS.   SINCE IT IS POSSIBLE FOR A LIIG
)@@G@@NE CONTAINING     @G@@@@ (SAY)  72  APL CHARACTERS TO CONTAIN MORE THAN IH
)@@G@@72 FIELDATA CHARAC-     @G@@@@ TERS  (BECAUSE  OF DIGRAPHS),  IT IS POSSII
)@@G@@IBLE THAT SOME LINES NEAR     @E@@@@ THE SPECIFIED WIDTH IN LENGTH MIGHTIJ
)@@G@@ BE DOUBLY INDENTED.    @[@@@@      @^@@@@  3. 3. 3.   )DIGITS <N>@[@@@@IK
)@@G@@      @G@@@@        THIS  CONTROLS THE NUMBER OF SIGNIFICANT DIGITS OF AIL
)@@G@@ NUMBER     @G@@@@ WHICH APL WILL NORMALLY PRINT.  THE DEFAULT VALUE IS IM
)@@G@@10.  INTERNAL     @G@@@@ CALCULATIONS IN APL ARE ALWAYS DONE WITH AS MANIN
)@@G@@Y (UP TO 18) DIGITS     @G@@@@ AS  EXIST  IN  THE  NUMBER;  THE WIDTH PAIO
)@@G@@RAMETER ONLY CONTROLS THE     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF DIGITS WHICH ARE PRINTED.IP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  3. 3. 4.   )FUZZ <N>  @[@@@@      @G@@@@IQ
)@@G@@       THIS  COMMAND  CONTROLS  THE  AMOUNT OF 'FUZZING' APPLIED TO     IR
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CERTAIN OPERATIONS SUCH AS CEILING AND COMPARISONS.   THE VALUE IIS

)@@G@@6.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 3. 5.   )SYMBOLS <N>     @[@@@@IW
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    IX
)@@G@@       3-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      IY
)@@G@@ THIS  CONTROLS  THE  NUMBER  OF DIFFERENT SYMBOLIC NAMES FOR     @G@@@@IZ
)@@G@@ VARIABLES  AND FUNCTIONS WHICH MAY BE USED.   IN A CLEAR WS,  THIS     JA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VALUE  IS  256,   MEANING  THAT 256 DISTINCT SYMBOLS OF 4 OR FEWEJB
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS  (OR A LESSER NUMBER OF LONGER NAMES) MAY BE REFJC
)@@G@@ERENCED     @G@@@@ IN  THE  WORKSPACE.    THE SPACE USED BY THE SYMBOL TJD

)@@G@@E SYMBOL TABLE.   IF MORE     @G@@@@ NAMES  ARE TO BE REFERENCED,  THE SJG

)@@G@@SE  OF THE ACTIVE WS).   THE )SYMBOLS     @C@@@@ COMMAND MAY NOT BE USEDJI
)@@G@@ EXCEPT IN A CLEAR WS.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  3. 4JJ
)@@G@@.   INFORMATIONAL COMMANDS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  INFORMJK
)@@G@@ATIONAL  SYSTEM  COMMANDS SERVE MAINLY TO INFORM YOU OF     @B@@@@ THE SJL
)@@G@@TATUS OF OBJECTS IN YOUR WORKSPACE. @[@@@@      @#@@@@  3. 4. 1.   )FNS JM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS COMMAND PRODUCES A LIST OF THE NAMES OF ALLJN
)@@G@@ FUNCTIONS IN     @^@@@@ THE ACTIVE WORKSPACE.  @[@@@@      @#@@@@  3. 4JO
)@@G@@. 2.   )VARS@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  COMMAND  PRODUCES  A  LIST  OJP
)@@G@@F  THE  NAMES  OF ALL THE     @A@@@@ VARIABLES IN THE ACTIVE WORKSPACE. JQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 4. 3.   )SI AND )SIV     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      JR
)@@G@@ THESE  COMMANDS BOTH PRODUCE A DISPLAY OF THE CURRENT 'STATE     @G@@@@JS
)@@G@@ INDICATOR'.    THE STATE INDICATOR IS USED BY APL TO KEEP TRACK OF     JT
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CALLS  UPON FUNCTIONS FROM OTHER FUNCTIONS.   EACH TIME A FUNCTIOJU
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ IS  CALLED,   THE NAME AND LINE NUMBER OF THE CALLING FUNCTJV
)@@G@@ION ARE     @G@@@@ RECORDED.  IT IS SOMETIMES THE CASE THAT SOMETHING (FJW
)@@G@@OR EXAMPLE AN     @G@@@@ ERROR)  CAUSES  APL  TO BE UNABLE TO PROCEED ATJX
)@@G@@ SOME POINT.   WHEN     @G@@@@ THIS  HAPPENS,  EXECUTION OF THE FUNCTIONJY
)@@G@@ IN WHICH THE STOP OCCURS     @G@@@@ IS  SUSPENDED,  AND  CONTROL  RETURJZ
)@@G@@NS TO THE DESK CALCULATOR MODE.     @G@@@@ SINCE FUNCTIONS MAY CALL OTHEKA
)@@G@@R FUNCTIONS,  THERE MAY BE A CHAIN OF     @G@@@@ FUNCTIONS WHICH HAVE PAKB
)@@G@@RTIALLY COMPLETED THEIR EXECUTION,  EACH OF     @G@@@@ WHICH  WAS  TEMPOKC
)@@G@@RARILY  HALTED WHILE ANOTHER FUNCTION WAS CALLED.     @G@@@@ THIS  CHAINKD
)@@G@@ OF FUNCTION NAMES AND LINE NUMBERS COMPRISES THE STATE     @G@@@@ INDICKE
)@@G@@ATOR.    THE  MOST  RECENTLY  HALTED  FUNCTION  IS SAID TO BE     @G@@@@KF
)@@G@@ 'SUSPENDED',   OTHERS  IN  THE  CHAIN (BACK TO THE DESK CALCULATOR     KG
)@@G@@@^@@@@ MODE) ARE 'PENDANT'.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       SINCE  EACH  HALTKH
)@@G@@  IN A FUNCTION CAUSES A RETURN TO THE DESK     @G@@@@ CALCULATOR MODE, KI
)@@G@@ IT IS POSSIBLE TO GENERATE AN ENTIRELY NEW CHAIN     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@KJ
)@@G@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           3-  6KK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ OF  PENDANT/SUSPENDED  FUNCTIKL
)@@G@@ONS ON TOP OF AN OLD ONE.   EACH SUCH     @G@@@@ CHAIN  STARTS  FROM  THKM
)@@G@@E  DESK CALCULATOR MODE AND TERMINATES IN A     @G@@@@ SUSPENDED  FUNCTIKN
)@@G@@ON.   TO DISTINGUISH THESE CHAINS,  THE SUSPENDED     @G@@@@ (MOST  RECEKO
)@@G@@NT) FUNCTION IN A CHAIN HAS AN ASTERISK APPENDED TO ITS     @A@@@@ NAME KP
)@@G@@IN THE DISPLAY OF THE SI.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE )SIV COMMAND KQ
)@@G@@DIFFERS FROM )SI IN THAT IN ADDITION TO THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION NAMES ANKR
)@@G@@D LINE NUMBERS, )SIV ALSO PRINTS THE NAMES OF THE     @G@@@@ LOCAL  VARIKS
)@@G@@ABLES  ACTIVATED  AT  EACH  FUNCTION  CALL.    THE MOST     @G@@@@ RECENKT
)@@G@@TLY  SUSPENDED  FUNCTION  APPEARS  ON  THE  TOP  LINE  OF THE     @G@@@@KU
)@@G@@ DISPLAY,   SUCCESSIVELY OLDER FUNCTION CALLS ARE IN ORDER DOWN THE     KV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PAGE.    IF  THE STATE INDICATOR IS EMPTY,  BOTH )SI AND )SIV WILKW
)@@G@@L     @ @@@@ RESPOND WITH A BLANK LINE.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@KX
)@@G@@  3. 5.   COMMUNICATIONS COMMANDS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      KY
)@@G@@ APL\1100  PROVIDES SEVERAL COMMANDS WHICH ENABLE YOU TO CON-     @G@@@@KZ
)@@G@@ VERSE WITH THE CENTRAL SITE COMPUTER OPERATOR,  AND WITH OTHER APL     LA
)@@G@@@D@@@@ USERS WHO ARE SIGNED ON AT THE SAME TIME YOU ARE.    @[@@@@      LB
)@@G@@@^@@@@  3. 5. 1.   )OPR <TEXT>@[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS COMMAND DISPLLC
)@@G@@AYS THE <TEXT> YOU TYPE IN ON THE OPERATORS     @G@@@@ CONSOLE,  AND THELD
)@@G@@N WAITS FOR HIM TO REPLY TO YOU.  APL IS NOT PRE-     @G@@@@ PARED  TO  LE
)@@G@@ACCEPT  MORE  INPUT  FROM  YOU  WHILE  THE  OPERATOR IS     @G@@@@ REPLYLF
)@@G@@ING.   THE TELETYPE CARRIER WILL REMAIN AT THE FAR LEFT UNTIL     @^@@@@LG
)@@G@@ THE OPERATOR RESPONDS. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      IF YOU BECOME IMPATIENT,LH
)@@G@@ YOU CAN CONTINUE YOUR APL SESSION BY     @G@@@@ HITTING BREAK-CARRIAGE LI
)@@G@@RETURN.   YOU WILL NOT, HOWEVER, BE ABLE TO     @G@@@@ SEND  THE  OPERATLJ
)@@G@@OR  ANOTHER  SUCH MESSAGE UNTIL HE REPLIES TO THE     @G@@@@ FIRST  ONE.LK
)@@G@@   IN ADDITION,  ALTHOUGH YOU CAN CONTINUE IN APL,  YOU     @G@@@@ WILL LL
)@@G@@ NOT  BE ABLE TO EXECUTE ANY OTHER EXEC 8 PROCESSOR UNTIL THE     @G@@@@LM
)@@G@@ OPERATOR  REPLIES.    TYPING  )OFF  OR )CONTINUE WHILE AN OPERATOR     LN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ REQUEST  IS  OUTSTANDING  WILL RESULT IN A GRACEFUL EXIT FROM APLLO
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ BUT  THE  INABILITY  TO  PROCESS ANY FURTHER EXEC 8 CONTROLLP
)@@G@@ CARDS.     @G@@@@ FOR  THIS REASON,  YOU SHOULD RESTRICT YOUR USAGE OF LQ
)@@G@@)OPR TO CASES     @G@@@@ IN  WHICH  YOU ARE RELATIVELY SURE THAT THE MACLR
)@@G@@HINE IS NOT RUNNING     @]@@@@ UNATTENDED.@[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 5. 2.  LS
)@@G@@ )OPRN <TEXT>     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS COMMAND DISPLAYS THE SPELT
)@@G@@CIFIED <TEXT> ON THE OPERATOR'S     @D@@@@ CONSOLE, BUT DOES NOT CAUSE ALU
)@@G@@PL TO WAIT FOR A REPLY. @[@@@@      @^@@@@  3. 5. 3.   )PORTS     @[@@@@LV
)@@G@@      @G@@@@      THIS COMMAND WILL PRODUCE A LIST OF THE RUNID'S AND @RLW
)@@G@@UN CARD     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  LX
)@@G@@                         3-  7@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@LY
)@@G@@ PROJECT  FIELDS  FOR  ALL  TERMINAL  USERS  USING APL AT THE TIME.     LZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RUNID'S  THUS  OBTAINED  MAY  BE  USED IN )MSG COMMANDS TO ADDRESMA
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ MESSAGES TO OTHER USERS.   AT THE PRESENT TIME, THE )PORTS MB
)@@G@@COMMAND     @C@@@@ IS UNDER DEVELOPMENT AND IS NOT OPERATIONAL.   @[@@@@MC
)@@G@@      @A@@@@  3. 5. 4.   )MSG <RUNID> <TEXT>    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      MD
)@@G@@ THE  SPECIFIED TEXT IS TRANSMITTED TO THE TERMINAL USER WITH     @G@@@@ME
)@@G@@ THE GIVEN RUNID, AND APL PAUSES TO AWAIT A REPLY.  THIS COMMAND IS     MF
)@@G@@@^@@@@ NOT YET OPERATIONAL.   @[@@@@      @A@@@@  3. 5. 5.   )MSGN <RUNIMG
)@@G@@D> <TEXT>   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  COMMAND  SENDS THE TEXT TO THMH
)@@G@@E SPECIFIED USER AND DOES     @D@@@@ NOT WAIT FOR A REPLY.  IT IS NOT YEMI
)@@G@@T OPERATIONAL.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  3. 6.   MISCELLANEOUS MJ
)@@G@@COMMANDS    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  3. 6. 1.   )OFF:MK
)@@G@@<PASSWORD>  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  COMMAND IS USED TO TERMINATE ML
)@@G@@AN APL WORK SESSION,  AND     @G@@@@ THE  ACTIVE  WORKSPACE IS DISCARDEDMM
)@@G@@.   IF A PASSWORD (INDICATED BY     @G@@@@ THE  COLON)  IS  PROVIDED,   MN
)@@G@@THEN THE LIBRARY NUMBER USED FOR THIS     @G@@@@ SESSION IS LOCKED,  I.EMO
)@@G@@. APL WILL NOT ALLOW THIS LIBRARY NUMBER TO     @G@@@@ BE  USED  AGAIN  MP
)@@G@@UNLESS  THE  IDENTICAL  PASSWORD  IS  USED ON THE     @ @@@@ PROCESSOR CMQ
)@@G@@ALL CARD -- E.G.  @[@@@@      @B@@@@                       @APL  /<PASSWMR
)@@G@@ORD>  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ AN  ATTEMPT TO USE A LOCKED LIBRARY NUMBER WITHMS
)@@G@@OUT THE PASSWORD OR     @G@@@@ WITH  THE WRONG PASSWORD WILL RESULT IN TMT
)@@G@@HE MESSAGE 'NUMBER NOT IN     @G@@@@ SYSTEM'.    ONCE  A  PASSWORD HAS BMU
)@@G@@EEN ESTABLISHED,  IT REMAINS IN     @G@@@@ FORCE  UNTIL  CHANGED  BY  ANMV
)@@G@@ )OFF (OR )CONTINUE) WITH A DIFFERENT     @G@@@@ PASSWORD;   IT IS NOT NMW
)@@G@@ECESSARY TO RE-SPECIFY THE PASSWORD AT EACH     @F@@@@ )OFF.  A PASSWORDMX
)@@G@@ MAY BE REMOVED BY CHANGING IT TO BLANKS, I.E.  @[@@@@      @ @@@@      MY
)@@G@@                )OFF :  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  COLON  IS  NOT  USED  EXMZ
)@@G@@CEPT  WHEN SPECIFYING (OR CLEARING) A     @]@@@@ PASSWORD.  @[@@@@      NA
)@@G@@@A@@@@  3. 6. 2.   )CONTINUE:<PASSWORD>   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS CNB
)@@G@@OMMAND, LIKE )OFF, ALSO TERMINATES AN APL WORK SESSION,     @G@@@@ BUT  NC
)@@G@@THE ACTIVE WORKSPACE IS NOT DESTROYED.   THE ACTIVE WORKSPACE     @G@@@@ND
)@@G@@ IS  SAVED  IN A SPECIAL WORKSPACE RESERVED FOR YOU,  WHOSE NAME IS     NE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CONTINUE.   WHEN  AN APL SESSION HAS BEEN TERMINATED BY )CONTINUENF
)@@G@@,     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        NG
)@@G@@                   3-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ APL WNH
)@@G@@ILL AUTOMATICALLY RE-)LOAD THE CONTINUE WORKSPACE AT THE NEXT     @#@@@@NI
)@@G@@ APL SESSION.     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINNJ
)@@G@@ARY)                           4-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      NK
)@@G@@@A@@@@  4.   THE APL PRIMITIVE OPERATORS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@NL
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 1.   PRIMITIVE SCALAR OPERATORSNM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AS MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY,  THE PRIMINN
)@@G@@TIVE SCALAR OPERATORS ACT     @G@@@@ ELEMENT  BY ELEMENT ON THEIR OPERANNO
)@@G@@DS.   IN THE CASE OF THE DYADIC     @G@@@@ SCALARS,  BOTH  OPERANDS  MUSNP
)@@G@@T  HAVE THE SAME RANK AND DIMENSIONS,     @G@@@@ UNLESS  ONE  OF  THEM INQ
)@@G@@S A SCALAR OR ONE-ELEMENT VECTOR,  IN WHICH     @G@@@@ CASE  IT IS EXTENNR
)@@G@@DED TO MATCH THE DIMENSIONS OF THE OTHER OPERAND.     @G@@@@ IN  MOST  CNS
)@@G@@ASES,  THE MONADIC AND DYADIC OPERATORS WHICH SHARE THE     @E@@@@ SAME NT
)@@G@@SYMBOL ARE CLOSELY RELATED (FOR EXAMPLE, + AND -).    @[@@@@      @G@@@@NU
)@@G@@      A SCALAR OPERATOR MAY,  IN GENERAL,  HAVE ONLY A SPECIFIC SET     NV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OF  VALUES FOR ITS OPERANDS;  THIS IS CALLED ITS 'DOMAIN',  AND ANW
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ ATTEMPT  TO  VIOLATE  THESE RULES WILL RESULT IN A 'DOMAIN NX
)@@G@@ERROR'.     @G@@@@ AS  AN  EXAMPLE, ADDITION IS AN UNDEFINED OPERATION ONY
)@@G@@N CHARACTERS,     @G@@@@ HENCE  THE DOMAIN OF THE ADDITION OPERATOR IS TNZ
)@@G@@HE SET OF VALID APL     @]@@@@ NUMBERS.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AN  AOA
)@@G@@DDITIONAL  PROPERTY  OF  DYADIC OPERATORS IS A QUANTITY     @G@@@@ CALLEOB
)@@G@@D  THEIR  'IDENTITY'  ELEMENT.    WHEN  AN  OPERATOR  HAS ITS     @G@@@@OC
)@@G@@ IDENTITY  AS  THE APPROPRIATE OPERAND,  THE VALUE OF THE RESULT IS     OD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  SAME  AS  THAT  OF  THE OTHER OPERAND,  I.E.  IT IS AS IF THOE
)@@G@@E     @F@@@@ OPERATOR  DID  NOTHING.    EXAMPLES  OF  IDENTITY  OPERATOROF
)@@G@@S  ARE@G@@@@ MULTIPLICATION  BY  ONE,   AND THE ADDITION OF ZERO.   AN IOG
)@@G@@DENTITY     @G@@@@ ELEMENT MAY BE A LEFT IDENTITY,  A RIGHT IDENTITY,  OOH
)@@G@@R BOTH.   FOR     @G@@@@ EXAMPLE,   ZERO  IS THE IDENTITY ELEMENT FOR ADOI
)@@G@@DITION.   SINCE THE     @]@@@@ EXPRESSIONS@[@@@@      @B@@@@            OJ
)@@G@@        0 + X          AND    @[@@@@      @ @@@@                    X + OK
)@@G@@0     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ BOTH GIVE X AS A RESULT,  IT IS CLEAR THAT THE OL
)@@G@@ZERO IS BOTH A LEFT     @G@@@@ AND  A RIGHT IDENTITY.   ON THE OTHER HANOM
)@@G@@D,  ALTHOUGH ZERO IS ALSO     @G@@@@ THE IDENTITY ELEMENT FOR SUBTRACTIOON
)@@G@@N, IT IS A RIGHT IDENTITY ONLY,     @^@@@@ E.G.  IN THE EXPRESSION@[@@@@OO
)@@G@@      @ @@@@                    X - 0     @[@@@@      @F@@@@ THE RESULT OP
)@@G@@IS X, AND WE SEE THAT ZERO IS A RIGHT IDENTITY, BUT   @[@@@@      @ @@@@OQ
)@@G@@                    0 - X     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS NOT X,  IT IS MINUS OR
)@@G@@X;  THUS ZERO IS NOT A LEFT IDENTITY.   THE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USEROS
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4-  2@[@@@@OT
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IDENTITY  ELEMENTS  OF THE SCALAR DOU
)@@G@@YADS CAN BE PRODUCED BY CERTAIN     @F@@@@ USES OF THE REDUCTION AND INNOV
)@@G@@ER PRODUCT OPERATORS (SEE BELOW).   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  PROPEROW
)@@G@@TIES  OF  THE  SCALAR OPERATORS ARE SUMMARIZED IN     @G@@@@ TABLES 5.1 OX
)@@G@@AND 5.2.  IN THESE TABLES, THE DOMAINS FOR THE OPERANDS     @G@@@@ AND  OY
)@@G@@OF  THE RESULT ARE GIVEN IN THE COLUMNS HEADED O AND R.   THE     @C@@@@OZ
)@@G@@ ENTRIES IN THESE COLUMNS ARE CODED AS FOLLOWS: @[@@@@      @B@@@@      PA
)@@G@@    N     NUMERIC; ANY APL NUMBER   @[@@@@      @^@@@@          I     INPB
)@@G@@TEGER @[@@@@      @F@@@@          L     LOGICAL; AN APL INTEGER RESTRICTPC
)@@G@@ED TO THE VALUES  @B@@@@                0 (FALSE) AND 1 (TRUE)    @[@@@@PD
)@@G@@      @ @@@@          C     CHARACTER     @[@@@@      @C@@@@        (N) PE
)@@G@@    REFER TO FOOTNOTE N OF THE TABLE@[@@@@      @G@@@@      IT SHOULD BEPF
)@@G@@ NOTED THAT SINCE THE BOOLEAN TRUTH VARIABLES ARE     @G@@@@ REPRESENTEDPG
)@@G@@  BY  NUMBERS,  THEY MAY BE USED IN CALCULATIONS IN THE     @B@@@@ SAME PH
)@@G@@FASHION AS ANY OTHER APL NUMBER.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USERPI
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4-  3@[@@@@PJ

)@@G@@ FOR TABLE 5.1    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ (1)   IF  THE  LEFT  OPERAND  OF  TSO
)@@G@@HE POWER (*) IS NEGATIVE,  THEN     @G@@@@ APL\1100 WILL ATTEMPT TO GIVESP
)@@G@@ A REAL-VALUED RESULT;  IF THE RESULT     @G@@@@ IS  A COMPLEX NUMBER,  SQ
)@@G@@A DOMAIN ERROR WILL RESULT.   HENCE &27*1%3     @G@@@@ WILL YIELD THE CUSR
)@@G@@BE ROOT OF &27,  I.E. &3, BUT &27*0.5 WILL GIVE A     @D@@@@ DOMAIN ERROSS
)@@G@@R, AS THE SQUARE ROOT OF &27 IS IMAGINARY.@[@@@@      @G@@@@ (2)   THE  ST
)@@G@@GENERAL DEFINITION OF THE RESIDUE FUNCTION FOR LEFT AND     @A@@@@ RIGHTSU
)@@G@@ OPERANDS L AND R IS GIVEN BY @[@@@@      @C@@@@          L   NON-ZERO  SV
)@@G@@        R-($!L)#$LR%$!L @[@@@@      @A@@@@          L   ZERO,R$>0       SW
)@@G@@  R   @[@@@@      @C@@@@          L   ZERO,R<0          DOMAIN ERROR    SX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ (3)   PERMISSIBLE  VALUES FOR THE LEFT ARGUMENT OF THSY
)@@G@@E GENERALIZED     @G@@@@ CIRCULAR FUNCTION OPERATOR $T ARE THE INTEGERS SZ
)@@G@@&7 TO 7,  WHERE THE     @G@@@@ NEGATIVE VALUES CORRESPOND TO THE INVERSETA

)@@G@@ES FOR THE HYPERBOLIC FUNCTIONS     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO TC

)@@G@@                     :                                :     @G@@@@ :   1TM

)@@G@@RCTANH R    :     @F@@@@ :..............................................TS
)@@G@@.................:@[@@@@      @G@@@@ (4)   THE  REDUCTION  IDENTITIES  FTT
)@@G@@OR THE RELATIONAL OPERATORS ARE     @G@@@@ MEANINGFUL  ONLY  WHEN  THESETU
)@@G@@  OPERATORS  ARE  APPLIED  TO LOGICAL     @G@@@@ OPERANDS (I.E.  0 AND 1TV
)@@G@@).   IN THESE CASES, THEY ARE EQUIVALENT TO     @G@@@@ BOOLEAN FUNCTIONSTW
)@@G@@ OF TWO OPERANDS, FOR EXAMPLE $= IS EQUIVALENT TO     @ @@@@ THE EXCLUSITX
)@@G@@VE OR FUNCTION.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ (5)   THE  DYADIC  PRIMITIVE  OPERATY
)@@G@@TORS  =  AND  $= ARE SUBJECT TO     @E@@@@ FUZZING WHEN APPLIED TO NUMERTZ
)@@G@@IC ARGUMENTS (SEE CHAPTER 6). @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIUA
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4-  6@[@@@@      UB

)@@G@@DIC SCALARS @[@@@@      @F@@@@ .........................................UD

)@@G@@     :   ADDING ZERO TO THE OPERAND,      :     @G@@@@ :           :    UJ
)@@G@@           :   I.E. +R IS EQUIVALENT TO 0+R     :     @G@@@@ :          UK
)@@G@@ :               :                                    :     @G@@@@ :    UL
)@@G@@ -     :   N      N    :   NEGATE.  CHANGES THE SIGN OF THE :     @G@@@@UM
)@@G@@ :           :               :   OPERAND.  -R IS EQUIVALENT TO    :     UN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ :           :               :   0-R                              UO
)@@G@@:     @G@@@@ :           :               :                              UP
)@@G@@      :     @G@@@@ :     #     :   N      N    :   SIGN.  1, 0 OR &1 DEPUQ
)@@G@@ENDING ON   :     @G@@@@ :           :               :   WHETHER THE OPEUR
)@@G@@RAND IS POSITIVE, :     @G@@@@ :           :               :   ZERO OR NUS
)@@G@@EGATIVE                 :     @G@@@@ :           :               :      UT
)@@G@@                              :     @G@@@@ :     %     :   N      N    :UU
)@@G@@   RECIPROCAL.  %R IS EQUIVALENT    :     @G@@@@ :           :          UV
)@@G@@     :   TO 1%R                           :     @G@@@@ :           :    UW
)@@G@@           :                                    :     @G@@@@ :    $C    UX
)@@G@@ :   N      I    :   CEILING.  THE SMALLEST INTEGER   :     @G@@@@ :    UY
)@@G@@       :               :   GREATER THAN THE OPERAND.  THIS  :     @G@@@@UZ
)@@G@@ :           :               :   OPERATOR IS SUBJECT TO FUZZING   :     VA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ :           :               :   (CHAPTER 6)                      VB
)@@G@@:     @G@@@@ :           :               :                              VC
)@@G@@      :     @G@@@@ :    $L     :   N      I    :   FLOOR.  THE LARGEST IVD
)@@G@@NTEGER      :     @G@@@@ :           :               :   NOT GREATER THAVE
)@@G@@N THE OPERAND.    :     @G@@@@ :           :               :   FOR POSITVF
)@@G@@IVE OPERANDS, THIS      :     @G@@@@ :           :               :   AMOVG
)@@G@@UNTS TO TRUNCATION.  THIS     :     @G@@@@ :           :               :VH
)@@G@@   OPERATOR IS ALSO AFFECTED BY     :     @G@@@@ :           :          VI
)@@G@@     :   FUZZING                          :     @G@@@@ :           :    VJ
)@@G@@           :                                    :     @G@@@@ :     *    VK
)@@G@@ :   N      N    :   EXPONENTION.  THE NUMBER 'E'     :     @G@@@@ :    VL
)@@G@@       :               :   (BASE OF NATURAL LOGARITHMS)     :     @G@@@@VM
)@@G@@ :           :               :   RAISED TO THE SPECIFIED POWER    :     VN

)@@G@@ERAND :     @G@@@@ :           :               :                        VQ

)@@G@@@ @@@@  4. 2.   COMPOUND OPERATORS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      WU
)@@G@@APL\1100 PROVIDES THREE GENERALIZED PRIMITIVE OPERATORS WHICH     @G@@@@WV
)@@G@@ ARE  USED  IN  CONJUNCTION  WITH  DYADIC SCALAR OPERATORS.   THESE     WW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OPERATORS  APPLY  THE  SPECIFIED  DYADIC  SCALAR  OPERATORS TO THWX
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OPERANDS  IN  A  MANNER OTHER THAN THE STRICTLY ELEMENT-BY-WY
)@@G@@ELEMENT     @G@@@@ APPLICATION  OF  THE  DYADS THEMSELVES,  AND PRODUCE WZ
)@@G@@RESULTS WHOSE     @G@@@@ RANK  AND  DIMENSIONS  DIFFER  FROM THOSE OF THXA
)@@G@@E OPERANDS.   THESE     @G@@@@ OPERATORS  ARE REDUCTION (A GENERALIZATIOXB
)@@G@@N OF THE MATHEMATICAL SUM     @E@@@@ AND PRODUCT OPERATORS), INNER PRODUXC
)@@G@@CT, AND OUTER PRODUCT.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@  4. 2. 1.   REDUCTION  @[@@@@XD
)@@G@@      @F@@@@       REDUCTION  IS  A  MONADIC  OPERATION  INDICATED  BY  XE
)@@G@@THE  /@G@@@@ CHARACTER.    IT  IS  ALWAYS  DONE IN CONJUNCTION WITH A PRXF
)@@G@@IMITIVE     @G@@@@ DYADIC  SCALAR OPERATOR,  WHICH IS WRITTEN IMMEDIATELXG
)@@G@@Y TO THE LEFT     @G@@@@ OF THE /.   THUS,  A REDUCTION WITH RESPECT TO XH
)@@G@@ADDITION IS WRITTEN     @G@@@@ AS  +/.   A REDUCTION WITH RESPECT TO THEXI
)@@G@@ CEILING WOULD BE WRITTEN     @[@@@@ $C/. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE MOXJ
)@@G@@ST OBVIOUS EXAMPLE OF REDUCTION IS ITS APPLICATION TO A     @G@@@@ VECTOXK
)@@G@@R.    A REDUCTION WITH RESPECT TO SOME OPERATOR IS EQUIVALENT     @G@@@@XL
)@@G@@ TO HAVING WRITTEN THE OPERATOR BETWEEN EACH ELEMENT OF THE VECTOR.     XM
)@@G@@@#@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE,     @[@@@@      @ @@@@                    +/ 2 3 4  XN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  XO
)@@G@@                         4-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@XP
)@@G@@ IS EQUIVALENT TO WRITING     @[@@@@      @ @@@@                    2 + XQ
)@@G@@3 + 4 @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THUS,   +/  APPLIED  TO A VECTOR IS THE SUM OF XR
)@@G@@ALL ELEMENTS OF THE     @G@@@@ VECTOR.   THE APPLICATION OF THE SPECIFIEXS
)@@G@@D OPERATOR TAKES PLACE IN     @G@@@@ THE  NORMAL APL ORDER OF RIGHT-TO-LXT
)@@G@@EFT.   TO DEMONSTRATE THIS,  WE     @]@@@@ NOTE THAT  @[@@@@      @D@@@@XU
)@@G@@                    %/ 3 5     IS THREE FIFTHS, BUT   @[@@@@      @B@@@@XV
)@@G@@                    %/ 3 3 5   IS FIVE.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IT  IXW
)@@G@@S  AT THIS POINT THAT THE REDUCTION IDENTITY ELEMENT OF     @G@@@@ THE DXX
)@@G@@YADIC SCALAR OPERATORS PLAYS A ROLE.  SINCE THE DEFINITION OF     @G@@@@XY
)@@G@@ THE  IDENTITY  ELEMENT  IS THAT IT DOES ESSENTIALLY NOTHING TO THE     XZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RESULT,  WE CAN CONSIDER THAT THE PRESENCE OF THE IDENTITY ELEMENYA
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ IS  IMPLIED  IN A REDUCTION.   USING THE (NON-APL) CONVENTIYB
)@@G@@ON THAT     @G@@@@ THE IDENTITY IS IN PARENTHESES (BECAUSE IT IS NOT 'REYC
)@@G@@ALLY' THERE),     @C@@@@ THE TWO EXAMPLES ABOVE COULD BE REWRITTEN AS:  YD
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@          +/ 2 3 4 (0)    AND    %/ 3 3 5 (1)   @[@@@@YE
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ NOW  CONSIDER THE CASE THAT THE OPERANDS WERE TWO-ELEMENT VYF
)@@G@@ECTORS;     @^@@@@ WE WOULD THEN HAVE     @[@@@@      @B@@@@          +/YG
)@@G@@ 2 3          AND    %/ 3 3   @[@@@@      @ @@@@ OR ADDING THE IDENTITIEYH
)@@G@@S:    @[@@@@      @C@@@@          +/ 2 3 (0)             %/ 3 3 (1)     YI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@ WHICH IS EQUIVALENT TO @[@@@@      @C@@@@          2 YJ
)@@G@@+ 3 (+0)      AND    3 % 3 (%1)     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ CONTINUING THIS PYK
)@@G@@ROCESS THE FOLLOWING DEFINITIONS SHOULD BE CLEAR.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@YL
)@@G@@ (A)  THE RESULT OF REDUCING A ONE-ELEMENT OPERAND HAS THE VALUE OF     YM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE OPERAND ITSELF (REGARDLESS OF THE DYAD USED IN THE REDUCTION)YN
)@@G@@,     @[@@@@ AND  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ (B)  THE  RESULT  OF REDUCING A NULYO
)@@G@@L (ZERO-ELEMENT) OPERAND IS THE     @G@@@@ REDUCTION IDENTITY OF THE SPEYP
)@@G@@CIFIED DYAD IF IT EXISTS (OR A DOMAIN     @^@@@@ ERROR IF IT DOES NOT). YQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE NAME REDUCTION ARISES BECAUSE THE RANK OF TYR
)@@G@@HE OPERAND IS     @G@@@@ REDUCED  BY  ONE  TO  GIVE  THE  RANK  OF THE RYS
)@@G@@ESULT.   THUS,  THE     @G@@@@ REDUCTION OF A VECTOR IS A SCALAR,  THE RYT
)@@G@@EDUCTION OF A MATRIX IS A     @G@@@@ VECTOR,   ETC.    (IN  THIS CONTEXTYU
)@@G@@,  A SCALAR OPERAND ACTS LIKE A     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO YV
)@@G@@APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@YW
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ VECTOR, I.E. THE REDUCTION OF A SCALAR IS A SCAYX
)@@G@@LAR).  REDUCTION IS     @G@@@@ NORMALLY  ALONG  THE  LAST  COORDINATE  OYY
)@@G@@F  AN  ARRAY (CLEARLY FOR     @G@@@@ VECTORS THE LAST COORDINATE IS THE YZ
)@@G@@ONLY COORDINATE),  AND 'REDUCES     @B@@@@ IT AWAY'.  IF WE HAD A MATRIXZA
)@@G@@ M OF VALUES@[@@@@      @#@@@@           1 2 3  @#@@@@           4 5 6  ZB
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@ THEN THE REDUCTION +/M WOULD BE EQUIVALENT TO  @[@@@@ZC
)@@G@@      @^@@@@           1 + 2 + 3    @[@@@@      @^@@@@           4 + 5 +ZD
)@@G@@ 6    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ GIVING  THE  VECTOR  RESULT  6 15.   REDUCTION ZE
)@@G@@MAY BE SPECIFICALLY     @G@@@@ APPLIED  ALONG  ANY  COORDINATE OF AN ARRZF
)@@G@@AY.   IF THE SYMBOL $/ IS     @G@@@@ USED  INSTEAD  OF  /,   THEN REDUCTZG
)@@G@@ION TAKES PLACE ALONG THE FIRST     @G@@@@ COORDINATE  OF  AN  ARRAY.   ZH
)@@G@@ IN OUR EXAMPLE ABOVE,  +$/M WOULD BE     @#@@@@ EQUIVALENT TO    @[@@@@ZI
)@@G@@      @#@@@@           1 2 3  @#@@@@           + + +  @#@@@@           4ZJ
)@@G@@ 6 6 ,@[@@@@      @C@@@@ YIELDING THE VECTOR RESULT 5 7 9          .    ZK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       REDUCTION  ALONG AN ARBITRARY COORDINATE MAY BEZL
)@@G@@ SPECIFIED BY     @G@@@@ PUTTING  THE  COORDINATE  SUBSCRIPT  NUMBER  INZM
)@@G@@ BRACKETS AFTER THE     @G@@@@ REDUCTION OPERATOR,  E.G.    +/[1]   SIGNZN
)@@G@@IFIES REDUCTION ALONG THE     @G@@@@ FIRST COORDINATE.  THE QUANTITY WITZO
)@@G@@HIN THE BRACKETS MAY BE ANY APL     @G@@@@ EXPRESSION WHICH EVALUATES TOZP
)@@G@@ AN INTEGER.   IF THIS VALUE DOES NOT     @G@@@@ SPECIFY ONE OF THE COORZQ
)@@G@@DINATES OF THE RIGHT OPERAND (I.E. IS NOT A     @G@@@@ DIGIT  IN  THE SEZR
)@@G@@T $I$R$RY,  FOR RIGHT OPERAND Y),  AN INDEX ERROR     @#@@@@ WILL RESULTZS
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @ @@@@  4. 2. 2.   INNER PRODUCT    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ZT
)@@G@@       THE  APL  INNER PRODUCT IS A DYADIC OPERATION,  AND REQUIRES     ZU
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THAT TWO SCALAR DYADIC OPERATORS BE SPECIFIED.   THE DECIMAL POINZV
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ IS USED TO INDICATE AN INNER PRODUCT, AND THE TWO DYADIC OPZW
)@@G@@ERATORS     @G@@@@ MUST  APPEAR  DIRECTLY TO THE LEFT AND RIGHT OF THE PZX
)@@G@@OINT (WITHOUT     @G@@@@ INTERVENING BLANKS).   THE ORDINARY MATRIX INNEZY
)@@G@@R OR DOT PRODUCT OF     @G@@@@ MATHEMATICS  IS A SPECIAL CASE OF THE USEZZ
)@@G@@ OF THE APL INNER PRODUCT     @A@@@@ OPERATOR, AND WOULD BE WRITTEN AS  AA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@                    +.# @[@@@@      @G@@@@       FOR  AB
)@@G@@CONFORMABILITY,   THE  RIGHTMOST  DIMENSION OF THE LEFT     @G@@@@ OPERAAC
)@@G@@ND MUST EQUAL THE LEFTMOST DIMENSION OF THE RIGHT OPERAND; IN     @G@@@@AD
)@@G@@ EFFECT,  A  REDUCTION TAKES PLACE ALONG THIS INNERMOST COORDINATE.     AE
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)              AF
)@@G@@             4- 10@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE DIMENSIAG
)@@G@@ONS OF THE RESULT ARE OBTAINED BY CATENATING THE DIMEN-     @G@@@@ SIONSAH
)@@G@@  OF THE LEFT AND RIGHT OPERANDS,  STRIKING OUT THE INNERMOST     @G@@@@AI
)@@G@@ DIMENSIONS OF EACH.   FOR EXAMPLE,  FOR LEFT AND RIGHT OPERANDS OF     AJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DIMENSIONS   7 2 5  AND  5 3  RESPECTIVELY,  THE DIMENSIONS OF THAK
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RESULT WOULD BE  7 2 3  .   IF ONE OF THE OPERANDS IS A SCAAL
)@@G@@LAR, IT     @G@@@@ IS EXTENDED IN THE USUAL FASHION.   IF ONE OF THE INNAM
)@@G@@ER DIMENSIONS     @G@@@@ OF AN OPERAND IS ONE,  IT WILL BE EXTENDED (IF AN
)@@G@@NECESSARY) TO MATCH     @G@@@@ THE  INNER  DIMENSION  OF THE OTHER OPERAAO
)@@G@@ND (THIS EXTENSION IS NOT     @#@@@@ YET OPERATIONAL).@[@@@@      @G@@@@AP
)@@G@@      IN THE INNER PRODUCT OPERATION, SELECTED ELEMENTS OF THE LEFT     AQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AND  RIGHT OPERAND ARE COMBINED PAIRWISE USING THE DYADIC OPERATOAR
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED  ON  THE RIGHT TO FORM VECTORS.   THESE VECTORS AAS
)@@G@@RE THEN     @G@@@@ REDUCED USING THE OPERATOR SPECIFIED ON THE LEFT OF TAT
)@@G@@HE INNER PRO-     @G@@@@ DUCT.  FORMALLY STATED, IF A AND B ARE THE LEFTAU
)@@G@@ AND RIGHT OPERANDS     @F@@@@ OF +.# AND C IS THE RESULT, THEN THE DIMEAV
)@@G@@NSION OF C IS GIVEN BY  @[@@@@      @A@@@@                    (&1$^$RA),AW
)@@G@@1$^$RB@[@@@@      @G@@@@ IF  WE SAY THAT A HAS RANK N (I.E. N SUBSCRIPTSAX
)@@G@@) AND B HAS RANK M,     @B@@@@ THEN THE VALUE OF THE SPECIFIC ELEMENT   AY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@          C[A1;A2;...AN-1;B2;B3...BM]     @[@@@@      AZ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ (NOTICE THAT COORDINATES AN AND B1 ARE REDUCED OUT) IS EQUAL TO  BA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@          +/A[A1;A2...AN-1;]#B[;B2;B3...BM]     @[@@@@BB
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       IF  THE  LENGTH  OF  THE COORDINATE OVER WHICH THE REBC
)@@G@@DUCTION     @G@@@@ TAKES  PLACE  (THE  INNERMOST COORDINATE OF THE OPERABD
)@@G@@NDS) IS ZERO,     @G@@@@ THE  RESULT  IS AN ARRAY OF VALUES EQUAL TO THEBE
)@@G@@ REDUCTION IDENTITY     @B@@@@ OF THE LEFT OPERATOR (IF IT EXISTS).     BF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  4. 2. 3.   OUTER PRODUCT    @[@@@@      BG
)@@G@@@G@@@@      THE APL OUTER PRODUCT OPERATION IS ALSO DYADIC,  AND REQUIREBH
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ THAT  A  SINGLE DYADIC SCALAR OPERATOR BE SPECIFIED WITH ITBI
)@@G@@.   THE     @ @@@@ OUTER PRODUCT IS SPECIFIED BY@[@@@@      @^@@@@      BJ
)@@G@@              $..X@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHERE X IS ANY DYADIC SCALAR OPERATBK
)@@G@@OR.   NOTE THAT THIS IS SIMILAR     @G@@@@ TO  THE  SPECIFICATION  FOR  BL
)@@G@@INNER  PRODUCT  EXCEPT  THAT THE LEFT     @ @@@@ OPERATOR IS THE DIGRAPHBM
)@@G@@ $.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  RESULT  OF AN OUTER PRODUCT OPERATIOBN
)@@G@@N ON THE OPERANDS A     @A@@@@ AND B IS AN ARRAY OF DIMENSIONS    @[@@@@BO
)@@G@@      @ @@@@                    ($RA),$RB @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIBP
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 11@[@@@@      BQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WHICH  IS  OBTAINED  BY APPLYBR
)@@G@@ING THE SPECIFIED DYADIC OPERATION TO     @G@@@@ EVERY PAIR OF ELEMENTS BS
)@@G@@OF A AND B.   IN ADDITION TO OBVIOUS APPLI-     @G@@@@ CATIONS  USING ARBT
)@@G@@ITHMETIC OPERATIONS,  THIS OPERATION IS EXTREMELY     @G@@@@ USEFUL  IN BU
)@@G@@ GENERATING MASKS OF VARIOUS TYPES.   FOR EXAMPLE,  THE     @]@@@@ EXPREBV
)@@G@@SSION @[@@@@      @A@@@@                    ($IN)$..=$IN    @[@@@@      BW
)@@G@@@E@@@@ WILL GENERATE AN N BY N IDENTITY MATRIX, AND THE EXPRESSION@[@@@@BX
)@@G@@      @A@@@@                    ($IN)$..< $IM   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ RESULBY
)@@G@@TS  IN  AN  N BY M MATRIX WITH 1'S ON AND ABOVE THE PRINCIPAL     @ @@@@BZ
)@@G@@ DIAGONAL AND ZEROS BELOW IT. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  4. 3.   MICA
)@@G@@XED OPERATORS     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3. 1.  CB
)@@G@@ RESHAPE $R (DYADIC RHO)@[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS OPERATOR IS USED TOCC
)@@G@@ CREATE VARIABLES OF A SPECIFIC SHAPE     @G@@@@ AND INITIALIZE THEIR VACD
)@@G@@LUES.   THE LEFT ARGUMENT MUST BE A NUMERIC     @G@@@@ VECTOR  OR SCALARCE
)@@G@@.   THE RANK OF THE RESULT IS EQUAL TO THE NUMBER     @G@@@@ OF ELEMENTSCF
)@@G@@ OF THE LEFT ARGUMENT, AND THE DIMENSIONS OF THE RESULT     @G@@@@ ARE  CG
)@@G@@GIVEN  BY  ITS  VALUES.   THE VALUES OF THE RESULT ARE SET BY     @G@@@@CH
)@@G@@ TAKING  THE  VALUES  OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT CYCLICALLY IN ROW-MAJOR     CI
)@@G@@@]@@@@ ORDER.     @[@@@@      @#@@@@      EXAMPLES:   @E@@@@           3CJ
)@@G@@  2  $R  'ABCDEF'  YIELDS THE 3 BY 2 MATRIX     @[@@@@      @ @@@@      CK
)@@G@@                   ABC  @ @@@@                         DEF  @[@@@@      CL
)@@G@@@D@@@@ THE EXPRESSION 5 $R 6 1 GIVES THE 5-ELEMENT VECTOR   @[@@@@      CM
)@@G@@@^@@@@           6  1  6  1  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3. 2.  CN
)@@G@@ SIZE $R (MONADIC RHO)  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  OPERATOR  CAN BE CO
)@@G@@CONSIDERED THE INVERSE OF THE RESHAPE     @G@@@@ (DYADIC  $R)  OPERATOR.CP
)@@G@@    IT RETURNS A VECTOR WHOSE LENGTH IS THE     @G@@@@ RANK OF THE RIGHTCQ
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT, AND WHOSE VALUES ARE THE CORRESPONDING     @]@@@@ DIMENSIONS.CR
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@      EXAMPLE:  IF  C  IS SPECIFIED BY    @[@@@@*****^CS
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          CT
)@@G@@ 4- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@           C  $S  3  2  CU
)@@G@@$R  'ABCDEF'@[@@@@ THEN @ @@@@           $RC IS  3  2  .    @[@@@@      CV
)@@G@@@G@@@@      SINCE A SCALAR HAS ZERO RANK,  MONADIC $R APPLIED TO A SCALACW
)@@G@@R     @D@@@@ YIELDS A VECTOR OF ZERO LENGTH, I.E. A 'NULL VECTOR'.@[@@@@CX
)@@G@@      @C@@@@  4. 3. 3.   INDEX GENERATOR $I (MONADIC IOTA)  @[@@@@      CY
)@@G@@@G@@@@      THIS OPERATOR GENERATES A VECTOR OF SEQUENTIAL INTEGERS.  THCZ
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OPERAND MUST BE A ONE-ELEMENT NUMERIC QUANTITY, (SCALAR OR DA
)@@G@@VECTOR)     @G@@@@ AND  THE  LENGTH  OF  THE RESULT WILL BE EQUAL TO THEDB
)@@G@@ VALUE OF THE     @G@@@@ OPERAND.  THE VALUES OF THE RESULT INCREASE BY DC
)@@G@@UNITY STARTING FROM     @#@@@@ THE INDEX ORIGIN.@[@@@@      @E@@@@      DD
)@@G@@EXAMPLES:  IN ORIGIN 1,  $I6 IS 1  2  3  4  5  6 .    @A@@@@ IN ORIGIN ZDE
)@@G@@ERO, $I3 IS 0  1  2 .   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3. 4.   INDEXDF
)@@G@@ OF $I (DYADIC IOTA)    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THIS OPERATOR REQUIRES ADG
)@@G@@ VECTOR LEFT ARGUMENT,  AND THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT MAY BE OF ANY DH
)@@G@@SHAPE.   THE RESULT IS AN ARRAY OF INTEGERS     @G@@@@ WHICH  TELLS THE DI
)@@G@@POSITION OF EACH ELEMENT OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT IN     @G@@@@ THE LEFT.  DJ
)@@G@@ THIS RESULT IS AN ARRAY OF INTEGERS WHICH HAS THE SAME     @G@@@@ SHAPEDK
)@@G@@ AS THE RIGHT ARGUMENT,  AND EACH INTEGER IS THE INDEX OF THE     @G@@@@DL
)@@G@@ FIRST  OCCURRENCE  IN  THE  LEFT  ARGUMENT OF A VALUE EQUAL TO THE     DM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CORRESPONDING  ELEMENT OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT.   IF NO VALUE IN THDN
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ LEFT  ARGUMENT  CORRESPONDS,   THEN THE RESULT IS 1 + $RL FDO
)@@G@@OR LEFT     @]@@@@ ARGUMENT L.@[@@@@      @B@@@@      EXAMPLES:  3  6  2DP
)@@G@@.4  $I  6  IS  2  @[@@@@      @A@@@@ AND IF R IS THE TWO BY THREE MATRIXDQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@                 OLD    @^@@@@                 NEW    DR
)@@G@@@ @@@@ THEN          'ABCDEF' $IC   @[@@@@      @^@@@@ IS THE MATRIX   7DS
)@@G@@ 7 4  @^@@@@                 7 5 7  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE DYADIC IDT
)@@G@@OTA OPERATION MAY BE CONSIDERED AS THE INVERSE OF     @G@@@@ SUBSCRIPTINDU
)@@G@@G.   FOR EXAMPLE,  IF  V  IS A VECTOR CONSISTING OF ALL     @G@@@@ OF  TDV
)@@G@@HE  LETTERS OF THE ALPHABET, AND  A  IS ANY ALPHABETIC ARRAY,     @[@@@@DW
)@@G@@ THEN @[@@@@      @^@@@@                 V[V$IA]@C@@@@ IS  A, REGARDLESSDX
)@@G@@ OF THE ORIGINAL SHAPE OF  A. @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDY
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 13@[@@@@      DZ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3. 5.   RAVEL  ,  (MONADIEA
)@@G@@C)    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  RAVEL  OPERATOR YIELDS A VECTOR RESUEB
)@@G@@LT WHOSE VALUES ARE     @D@@@@ THE VALUES OF THE RIGHT OPERAND IN ROW-MAEC
)@@G@@JOR ORDER.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3. 6.   CATENATE  ,  (DYAED
)@@G@@DIC)  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE CATENATE OPERATOR JOINS ITS TWO ARGUMEEE
)@@G@@NTS ALONG A COORDI-     @G@@@@ NATE.   THE COORDINATE MAY BE AN EXISTINGEF
)@@G@@ ONE (IN WHICH CASE IT IS     @G@@@@ LENGTHENED)  OR  A  NEW  COORDINATEEG
)@@G@@  ADDED FOR THIS PURPOSE.   THE     @G@@@@ SIMPLEST CASE OCCURS IF THE AEH
)@@G@@RGUMENTS ARE SCALARS OR VECTORS;  THE     @G@@@@ RESULT  IS  A  VECTOR  EI
)@@G@@OBTAINED BY JOINING THE TWO OPERANDS END TO     @^@@@@ END.  AS AN EXAMPEJ
)@@G@@LE,   @[@@@@      @^@@@@           'ABC','XYZ'  @[@@@@      @B@@@@ GIVESEK
)@@G@@ THE VECTOR RESULT  'ABCXYZ'  .     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       SIMILARLY, EL
)@@G@@ MATRICES AND ARRAYS OF HIGHER RANK MAY BE JOINED     @G@@@@ ALONG THEIREM
)@@G@@ LAST COORDINATE.  IF WE HAVE 2 BY 3 MATRICES  A  AND B     @[@@@@ WHEREEN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@ A  IS  1  2  3  AND  B  IS   7   8   9   @B@@@@      EO
)@@G@@  4  5  6              10  11  12   @[@@@@      @A@@@@ THEN  A,B  IS THEEP
)@@G@@ 2 BY 6 MATRIX    @[@@@@      @ @@@@           1  2  3   7   8   9@ @@@@EQ
)@@G@@           4  5  6  10  11  12@[@@@@      @G@@@@ TWO  ARRAYS MAY BE JOINER
)@@G@@ED BY CATENATION ALONG ANY COORDINATE.   TO     @G@@@@ CATENATE  ALONG  ES
)@@G@@A COORDINATE OTHER THAN THE LAST,  THE COORDINATE     @G@@@@ MUST  BE  EET
)@@G@@NCLOSED  IN BRACKETS IN THE USUAL FASHION FOLLOWING THE     @G@@@@ OPERAEU
)@@G@@TOR.    THE  MATRICES ABOVE WOULD BE JOINED ALONG THEIR FIRST     @F@@@@EV
)@@G@@ COORDINATE BY  A,[1]B  WHICH WOULD RESULT IN THE 4 BY 3 MATRIX   @[@@@@EW
)@@G@@      @^@@@@           1   2   3    @^@@@@           4   5   6    @^@@@@EX
)@@G@@           7   8   9    @^@@@@          10  11  12    @[@@@@      @E@@@@EY
)@@G@@      CATENATION ALONG AN EXISTING COORDINATE IS ALLOWED IF:@G@@@@      EZ
)@@G@@ (A)  BOTH ARGUMENTS HAVE THE SAME RANK, AND THEIR DIMENSIONS     @E@@@@FA
)@@G@@            ARE EQUAL FOR ALL BUT THE SELECTED COORDINATE   @F@@@@ OR;  FB
)@@G@@ (B)  THE RANK THE ARGUMENTS DIFFERS BY ONE.  IN THIS CASE, @F@@@@      FC
)@@G@@      THE OPERAND OF LOWER RANK IS EXTENDED BY CONSIDERING  @F@@@@      FD
)@@G@@      THAT IT HAS AN EXTRA DIMENSION OF LENGTH 1 WHICH IS   @F@@@@      FE
)@@G@@      THE SELECTED COORDINATE.  ALL OTHER DIMENSIONS OF BOTH@[@@@@*****^FF
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          FG
)@@G@@ 4- 14@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@            OPERANDS MUSFH
)@@G@@T BE EQUAL  @F@@@@ OR;   (C)  ONE OF THE OPERANDS IS A SCALAR.  IN THIS FI
)@@G@@CASE, THE   @F@@@@            SCALAR IS EXTENDED TO HAVE THE SAME DIMENSFJ
)@@G@@IONS AS THE @F@@@@            OTHER ARGUMENT EXCEPT THAT THE SELECTED COFK
)@@G@@ORDINATE HAS@B@@@@            AN ASSUMED DIMENSION OF UNITY.@[@@@@      FL
)@@G@@@G@@@@       THE  CATENATION OF TWO OPERANDS BY CREATING A NEW COORDINATFM
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ IS  CALLED LAMINATION.   LAMINATION IS INDICATED WHEN THE VFN
)@@G@@ALUE OF     @G@@@@ THE  COORDINATE  SELECTING  EXPRESSION  IS A NON-INTEFO
)@@G@@GER;  THE NEW     @G@@@@ COORDINATE  WILL BE INSERTED BETWEEN THE COORDIFP
)@@G@@NATES WHOSE INDICES     @G@@@@ BRACKET  THIS  VALUE.   IT WILL BE OF LENFQ
)@@G@@GTH TWO,  WHERE THE LOWER     @G@@@@ VALUE SELECTS ELEMENTS OF THE LEFT FR
)@@G@@OPERAND.   AS AN EXAMPLE,  IF A     @B@@@@ AND  B  ARE AS ABOVE, THEN (IFS
)@@G@@N ORIGIN 1) @[@@@@      @^@@@@           A,[1.5]B     @[@@@@      @ @@@@FT
)@@G@@ YIELDS THE 2 BY 2 BY 3 ARRAY:@[@@@@      @^@@@@            1   2   3   FU
)@@G@@@^@@@@            7   8   9   @[@@@@      @^@@@@            4   5   6   FV
)@@G@@@^@@@@           10  11  12   @[@@@@      @D@@@@      LAMINATION OF TWO FW
)@@G@@ARRAYS IS ALLOWED IF EITHER   @[@@@@      @E@@@@       (A)  BOTH ARRAYS FX
)@@G@@HAVE IDENTICAL RANK AND DIMENSIONS, @F@@@@ OR;   (B)  ONE OF THE OPERANDFY
)@@G@@S IS A SCALAR, IN WHICH CASE IT IS  @E@@@@            EXTENDED TO THE SAFZ
)@@G@@ME DIMENSIONS AS THE OTHER.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3. 7.  GA
)@@G@@ TAKE  ^  (ALTERNATE: @T)     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE DYADIC OPERATGB
)@@G@@OR  TAKE  BEARS A SIMILARITY TO THE RESHAPE     @G@@@@ (DYADIC  RHO) OPEGC
)@@G@@RATOR IN THAT THE LEFT OPERAND SPECIFIES THE RANK     @G@@@@ AND  DIMENSGD
)@@G@@IONS  OF  THE RESULT,  AND THE VALUES OF THE RESULT ARE     @G@@@@ TAKENGE
)@@G@@  FROM  THE RIGHT OPERAND;  IT DIFFERS IN THE MANNER IN WHICH     @G@@@@GF
)@@G@@ THE  VALUES ARE CHOSEN.   THE LEFT ARGUMENT MUST BE A VECTOR WHOSE     GG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ LENGTH  IS  EQUAL  TO  THE RANK OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT (EXCEPT THAGH
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ SCALARS  AND  ONE-ELEMENT VECTORS ARE EXTENDED).   IN ITS SGI
)@@G@@IMPLEST     @G@@@@ FORM,   THE  RESULT  IS  OBTAINED BY TAKING THE FIRSTGJ
)@@G@@ 'N' ELEMENTS     @G@@@@ ALONG  EACH  COORDINATE  OF  THE  RIGHT OPERANDGK
)@@G@@,  WHERE 'N' IS THE     @G@@@@ ELEMENT OF THE LEFT ARGUMENT WHICH CORRESGL
)@@G@@PONDS TO THAT COORDINATE.     @C@@@@ IN THE SIMPLE CASE OF A VECTOR, FORGM
)@@G@@ INSTANCE,  @[@@@@      @A@@@@           3  ^  'ABCDEF'  IS  'ABC'@[@@@@GN
)@@G@@      @ @@@@ AND IF  C  IS THE MATRIX     @[@@@@      @#@@@@           1GO
)@@G@@  2  3@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        GP
)@@G@@                   4- 15@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@      GQ
)@@G@@     4  5  6@#@@@@           7  8  9@[@@@@      @A@@@@ THEN  2  2  ^  C GR
)@@G@@ IS THE MATRIX    @[@@@@      @#@@@@           1  2   @#@@@@           3GS
)@@G@@  4   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IF THE VALUE OF AN ELEMENT IN THE LEFT ARGUMENTGT
)@@G@@ IS NEGATIVE,  THEN     @G@@@@ THE  RESULT IS OBTAINED BY TAKING THE LASGU
)@@G@@T  N  ELEMENTS INSTEAD OF     @^@@@@ THE FIRST  N .  THUS,  @[@@@@      GV
)@@G@@@B@@@@           &3^ 'ABCDEF'  IS  'DEF'  , AND @[@@@@      @A@@@@      GW
)@@G@@   2 &2^C  IS           2  3  @A@@@@                              5  6  GX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@      IT IS POSSIBLE FOR A VALUE  N  OF THE LEFT ARGUMGY
)@@G@@ENT TO EXCEED     @G@@@@ THE SIZE OF THE CORRESPONDING DIMENSION OF THE GZ
)@@G@@RIGHT ARGUMENT.  IN     @G@@@@ THIS CASE (CALLED 'OVERTAKE'), THE RESULTHA
)@@G@@ IS FILLED WITH ZEROS (IF     @F@@@@ NUMERIC) OR BLANKS (IF CHARACTER). HB
)@@G@@ THUS, WITH  C  AS ABOVE,     @[@@@@      @B@@@@           2  4  ^  C   HC

)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3. 8.   DROP  $^  (ALTERNATE: @D)    @[@@@@      HF
)@@G@@@G@@@@      THE DYADIC OPERATOR  DROP  IS SIMILAR TO  TAKE; THE NUMBER OHG
)@@G@@F     @G@@@@ ELEMENTS  SPECIFIED  IN  THE LEFT ARGUMENTS ARE DROPPED OFFHH
