)@@G@@MPLE, @[@@@@      @A@@@@       3$^  'ABCDEF'  IS  'DEF'.    @[@@@@      HJ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 3. 9.   UPGRADE  $U  AND DOWNGRADE  $D     @[@@@@HK
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       THE  UPGRADE  AND DOWNGRADE OPERATORS ARE MONADIC PRIHL
)@@G@@MITIVES     @G@@@@ WHICH  ARE  USED  FOR  SORTING THEIR VECTOR RIGHT ARGHM
)@@G@@UMENTS.   THE     @G@@@@ RESULT  OF  AN  UPGRADE IS THE PERMUTATION VECTHN
)@@G@@OR OF INDICES WHICH     @G@@@@ WOULD  ORDER  THE RIGHT ARGUMENT IN ASCENHO
)@@G@@DING SEQUENCE;  DOWNGRADE     @ @@@@ SORTS IN DESCENDING SEQUENCE.@[@@@@HP
)@@G@@      @E@@@@      EXAMPLES:  $U  7  2.6  3  3  12  IS  2  3  4  1  5    HQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  UPGRADE  AND  DOWNGRADE OPERATORS CAN BE UHR
)@@G@@SED TO EFFECT     @G@@@@ 'MESHING',  AN OPERATION DEFINED IN DR. IVERSONHS
)@@G@@'S ORIGINAL WORK ON     @G@@@@ APL [1],  BUT NOT INCLUDED AS A PRIMITIVEHT
)@@G@@ IN APL\1100.  IF  A  AND     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\11HU
)@@G@@00 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 16@[@@@@      @[@@@@      HV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ B   ARE  VECTORS  OF  THE  SAME MODE,  AND  P  IS A LHW
)@@G@@OGICAL VECTOR     @ @@@@ (ZEROS AND ONES ONLY), THEN  @[@@@@      @^@@@@HX
)@@G@@           (B,A)[$U$DP] @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS  A  VECTOR  CONSISTING  OFHY
)@@G@@  ELEMENTS OF  A  WHEREVER THERE WERE     @G@@@@ ZEROS  IN  THE MASK  P HZ
)@@G@@ AND ELEMENTS OF  B  WHERE THERE WERE ONES.     @G@@@@ THIS  ASSUMES  THIA
)@@G@@AT THE NUMBERS OF ZEROS AND ONES IN  P  ARE EQUAL     @B@@@@ TO THE NUMBIB
)@@G@@ER OF ELEMENTS IN  A  AND  B. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 3.10.  IC
)@@G@@ COMPRESS  /  AND  $/  (DYADIC)     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  COMPREID
)@@G@@SS  OPERATOR COMPRESSES ITS RIGHT OPERAND ALONG A     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED  IE
)@@G@@COORDINATE BY STRIKING OUT ELEMENTS AS SPECIFIED BY THE     @G@@@@ LEFT IF
)@@G@@ OPERAND.   THE  LEFT  OPERAND MUST BE A LOGICAL VECTOR (I.E.     @G@@@@IG
)@@G@@ ONLY  1'S  OR  0'S)  WHOSE  LENGTH  IS  EQUAL TO THE LENGTH OF THE     IH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SELECTED  COORDINATE.   THE LEFT OPERAND IS USED AS A LOGICAL MASII
)@@G@@K     @G@@@@ AND IS MATCHED AGAINST THE RIGHT ARGUMENT.   WHEREVER THEREIJ
)@@G@@ IS A 1     @G@@@@ IN  THE  LEFT  OPERAND,   THE  CORRESPONDING  ELEMENTIK
)@@G@@ OF THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ OPERAND WILL BE USED;  A 0 IN THE LEFT OPERAND IL
)@@G@@WILL CAUSE THE COR-     @F@@@@ RESPONDING ELEMENT(S) OF THE RIGHT OPERANIM
)@@G@@D TO BE STRICKEN OUT.   @[@@@@      @#@@@@      EXAMPLES    @[@@@@      IN
)@@G@@@A@@@@           1 0 1 / 'ABC'   IS  'AC' @[@@@@      @^@@@@ AND, IF X IIO
)@@G@@S GIVEN BY  @[@@@@      @ @@@@           X $S 3 2 $R $I 6   @[@@@@      IP
)@@G@@@[@@@@ THEN @B@@@@           1 0 / X  IS THE VECTOR 1 3 5  .@[@@@@      IQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@      THE / SYMBOL SPECIFIES COMPRESSION ALONG THE LAST COORDINATEIR
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ AND $/ IS COMPRESSION ALONG THE FIRST.   IN ADDITION, A PARIS
)@@G@@TICULAR     @G@@@@ COORDINATE  MAY  BE  SELECTED  BY  SUBSCRIPTING  THE IT
)@@G@@OPERATOR (SEE     @]@@@@ BELOW).    @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3.11.   EXPANIU
)@@G@@D  \  AND  $\     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  EXPAND  OPERATOR IS A DYIV
)@@G@@ADIC OPERATOR WHICH CAN BE CON-     @G@@@@ SIDERED AS AN INVERSE TO COMPIW
)@@G@@RESS.   IT TOO TAKES A LOGICAL VECTOR     @G@@@@ AS  ITS  LEFT  OPERAND IX
)@@G@@ AND MATCHES THIS OPERAND AGAINST THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ OPERAND.   INSTEAIY
)@@G@@D OF DELETING ELEMENTS AS COMPRESS DOES, HOWEVER,     @G@@@@ EXPAND  INSIZ
)@@G@@ERTS  ELEMENTS;   EVERYWHERE  A ONE APPEARS IN THE LEFT     @G@@@@ OPERAJA
)@@G@@ND,  THE CORRESPONDING ELEMENT OF THE RIGHT OPERAND IS TAKEN,     @G@@@@JB
)@@G@@ WHEREVER  A  ZERO APPEARS,  A FILLER ELEMENT IS INSERTED.   IF THE     JC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RIGHT OPERAND IS NUMERIC,  THE FILLER ELEMENT IS ZERO;  A BLANK IJD
)@@G@@S     @A@@@@ THE FILLER FOR CHARACTER OPERANDS. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USERJE
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 17@[@@@@JF
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      ALTHOUGH NULL DATAJG
)@@G@@ SUCH AS  $IO  OR  ''  HAVE THE PROPERTY OF     @G@@@@ MODE  (NUMERIC ORJH
)@@G@@ CHARACTER),  THE EXPAND OPERATOR IS THE ONLY APL     @G@@@@ OPERATOR  FJI
)@@G@@OR  WHICH  THE  MODE  IS  USED (IN DETERMINING THE FILL     @G@@@@ CHARAJJ
)@@G@@CTER).    ONE  OF  THE USES OF THIS FEATURE IS IN DETERMINING     @G@@@@JK
)@@G@@ WHETHER  A  GIVEN  OPERAND  IS  NUMERIC  OR  CHARACTER - E.G.  THE     JL
)@@G@@@]@@@@ EXPRESSION @[@@@@      @^@@@@           0=0\0$RX     @[@@@@      JM
)@@G@@@E@@@@ WILL BE TRUE IF X IS NUMERIC, FALSE IF X IS CHARACTER.     @[@@@@JN
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       AS FOR COMPRESS,  THE \ SYMBOL SPECIFIES EXPANSION ALJO
)@@G@@ONG THE     @F@@@@ LAST COORDINATE, $\ ALONG THE FIRST, AND \[N] ALONG TJP
)@@G@@HE N'TH.    @[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 3.12.   REVERSE  $V  AND  @V  (MONADIJQ
)@@G@@C)    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE REVERSE OPERATOR CAUSES THE ELEMENTS JR
)@@G@@ALONG THE SPECIFIED     @C@@@@ COORDINATE TO HAVE THEIR ORDER REVERSED, JS

)@@G@@ ROTATE  $V  AND  @V  (DYADIC)@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE RESULT OF A RJX

)@@G@@@G@@@@ CIRCULAR  SHIFT  IS DONE,  A NEGATIVE LEFT OPERAND VALUE INDUCES KD

)@@G@@  A MATRIX RIGHT OPERAND,  EACH ROW ($V) OR     @F@@@@ COLUMN   (@V)   IKI
)@@G@@S   ROTATED  BY  THE  AMOUNT  SPECIFIED  BY  THE@G@@@@ CORRESPONDING ELEKJ
)@@G@@MENT OF THE LEFT OPERAND, E.G. IF X IS THE MATRIX     @[@@@@      @#@@@@KK
)@@G@@           1 2 3  @#@@@@           4 5 6  @[@@@@      @[@@@@ THEN @[@@@@KL
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    KM
)@@G@@       4- 18@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@          &1 1 $V KN
)@@G@@X     @[@@@@      @#@@@@ IS        3 1 2  @#@@@@           5 6 4  @[@@@@KO
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ THE  OPERAND  IS  EXTENDED TO ARRAYS OF HIGHER RANK IN THE KP

)@@G@@E  EXTENDED  WHERE@]@@@@ NECESSARY. @[@@@@      @ @@@@  4. 3.14.   TRANSKS
)@@G@@POSE  $X    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  RESULT  OF  A DYADIC TRANSPOSEKT
)@@G@@ OPERATION IS OBTAINED BY     @G@@@@ INTERCHANGING  THE  SUBSCRIPTS OF TKU
)@@G@@HE RIGHT OPERAND ACCORDING TO A     @G@@@@ PATTERN SPECIFIED BY THE LEFTKV
)@@G@@ OPERAND.   THE LEFT ARGUMENT MUST BE     @G@@@@ A  VECTOR  OF LENGTH EQKW
)@@G@@UAL TO THE RANK OF THE RIGHT ARGUMENT,  AND     @G@@@@ EACH  VALUE  OF  KX
)@@G@@THE  LEFT  OPERAND  MUST  BE AN INTEGER WHICH CAN     @G@@@@ SPECIFY  A KY
)@@G@@ COORDINATE OF THE RIGHT OPERAND.   IF WE CALL THE LEFT     @G@@@@ OPERAKZ
)@@G@@ND  L AND THE RIGHT R,  THEN THE I'TH COORDINATE OF R BECOMES     @G@@@@LA
)@@G@@ THE  L[I]TH  COORDINATE  OF THE RESULT.   AS AN EXAMPLE,  ORDINARY     LB
)@@G@@@C@@@@ MATRIX TRANSPOSITION OF R WOULD BE INDICATED BY@[@@@@      @^@@@@LC
)@@G@@           2 1 $V R     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ I.E.   THE 1ST COORDINATE OF LD
)@@G@@R BECOMES THE 2ND (L[1] IS 2) COORDI-     @G@@@@ NATE  OF  THE  RESULT  LE
)@@G@@AND THE 2ND COORDINATE OF R BECOMES THE 1ST     @ @@@@ (V[2] IS 1) OF THLF
)@@G@@E RESULT.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IT IS NOT NECESSARY FOR THE INDEX OLG
)@@G@@F EVERY COORDINATE OF THE     @F@@@@ RESULT TO BE PRESENT AS A VALUE IN LH
)@@G@@THE LEFT ARGUMENT -FOR EXAMPLE@[@@@@      @^@@@@           1  1 $V R    LI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WOULD  HAVE  AS  ITS  RESULT  THE VECTOR WHICH FORMS LJ
)@@G@@THE PRINCIPAL     @ @@@@ DIAGONAL OF THE MATRIX R.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@LK
)@@G@@      THE MONADIC TRANSPOSE OPERATOR IS SIMILAR IN EFFECT TO DYADIC     LL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TRANSPOSE;   THE  LAST  TWO  COORDINATES  OF THE RIGHT OPERAND ARLM
)@@G@@E     @]@@@@ TRANSPOSED.@[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3.15.   MEMBERSHIP  $E  (LN
)@@G@@DYADIC)     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  MEMBERSHIP OPERATOR RETURNS A LO
)@@G@@LOGICAL VALUE OF TRUE (1)     @G@@@@ FOR EACH ELEMENT OF THE LEFT OPERANLP
)@@G@@D WHICH APPEARS ANYWHERE IN THE     @G@@@@ RIGHT  OPERAND,   AND  FALSE LQ
)@@G@@ (0) FOR ELEMENTS OF THE LEFT OPERAND     @G@@@@ WHICH DO NOT OCCUR IN TLR
)@@G@@HE RIGHT.  OBVIOUSLY, THE OPERANDS MAY HAVE     @G@@@@ ANY SHAPE, AND THLS
)@@G@@E RESULT IS A VARIABLE OF 0'S AND 1'S WHOSE SHAPE     @A@@@@ IS THE SHAPLT
)@@G@@E OF THE LEFT OPERAND.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  COMPARISON  HAS  TLU
)@@G@@HE  PROPERTIES OF THE DYADIC EQUALITY     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUILV
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 19@[@@@@      LW
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ OPERATOR,  I.E.  IF BOTH ARGUMENTS ARE NULX
)@@G@@MERIC,  THE COMPARISON IS     @G@@@@ SUBJECT  TO  FUZZING,   AND CHARACTLY
)@@G@@ERS AND NUMBERS ARE ALWAYS CON-     @^@@@@ SIDERED TO BE UNEQUAL. @[@@@@LZ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       ALTHOUGH  THE  MEMBERSHIP  OPERATOR  $E  IS  SIMILAR MA
)@@G@@IN MANY     @G@@@@ RESPECTS  TO THE DYADIC IOTA ($I) ONE SHOULD NOTE THAMB
)@@G@@T IN ADDITION     @G@@@@ TO  THE  FACT  THAT  $I  RETURNS  AN  INDEX  WHMC
)@@G@@ILE $E RESULTS IN A     @G@@@@ TRUE/FALSE INDICATION, THE RESULT OF $I HMD
)@@G@@AS THE SHAPE OF THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ OPERAND, WHILE THE RESULT OF $E HASME
)@@G@@ THE SHAPE OF ITS LEFT OPERAND.     @[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 3.16.   ENCODMF
)@@G@@E @B AND DECODE $B (DYADIC)   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE DECODE AND ENCMG
)@@G@@ODE ARE UNIQUE AMONG THE MIXED OPERATORS IN     @G@@@@ THAT  THEIR  FUNCMH
)@@G@@TION  IS  PRIMARILY ARITHMETIC,  RATHER THAN ONLY     @G@@@@ SELECTION OMI
)@@G@@R RESHAPING OF THEIR OPERANDS.  THEY ARE USED TO CHANGE     @D@@@@ THE NMJ
)@@G@@UMBER SYSTEM USED TO REPRESENT THEIR OPERANDS.  @[@@@@      @B@@@@  4. 3MK
)@@G@@.16. 1.   ENCODE (REPRESENTATION)   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IN THE SIMPML
)@@G@@LEST CASE,  THE ENCODE (@B) OPERATOR TAKES A ONE-     @G@@@@ ELEMENT  NUMM
)@@G@@MERIC  RIGHT  OPERAND  AND  EXPRESSES  IT IN THE NUMBER     @G@@@@ SYSTEMN
)@@G@@M  SPECIFIED  BY  THE  LEFT  OPERAND.    THE  LEFT OPERAND IS     @G@@@@MO
)@@G@@ NORMALLY  A VECTOR,  AND DEFINES THE POSITIONAL NUMBER SYSTEM USED     MP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TO  REPRESENT  THE  RIGHT  OPERAND  (THE  ENCODE  OPERATOR IS ALSMQ
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ REFERRED  TO AS 'REPRESENTATION').   FOR EXAMPLE,  IF WE WAMR
)@@G@@NTED TO     @G@@@@ REPRESENT  A  NUMBER  WHICH  WAS IN SECONDS AS HOURS,MS
)@@G@@  MINUTES AND     @G@@@@ SECONDS,  THE  APPROPRIATE  LEFT  ARGUMENT WOULMT
)@@G@@D BE   24  60  60 .     @#@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE,     @[@@@@      @A@@@@      MU
)@@G@@     24  60  60  @B  10921    @[@@@@      @^@@@@ IS         3   2   1   MV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ AND  THE  REPRESENTATION  OF  THE  NUMBER  576 IN THEMW
)@@G@@ OCTAL NUMBER     @^@@@@ SYSTEM IS GIVEN BY     @[@@@@      @A@@@@      MX
)@@G@@               8 8 8 8 @B 576 @[@@@@      @B@@@@ WHICH GIVES         1 1MY
)@@G@@ 0 0         .    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      WHEN THE RIGHT OPERAND IS A SCMZ
)@@G@@ALAR, THE RESULT IS A VECTOR OF     @G@@@@ LENGTH EQUAL TO THE LEFT OPERNA
)@@G@@AND.   IN THE GENERAL CASE OF A RIGHT     @G@@@@ OPERAND OF ARBITRARY RANB
)@@G@@NK,  THE DIMENSIONS OF THE RESULT ARE GIVEN     @G@@@@ BY  THE RULES FORNC
)@@G@@ OUTER PRODUCT - THE RANK OF THE RESULT BEING ONE     @C@@@@ GREATER THAND
)@@G@@N THE RANK OF THE RIGHT OPERAND.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AT  THE  PRNE
)@@G@@ESENT  TIME,   APL\1100  WILL ONLY ACCEPT A RIGHT     @G@@@@ OPERAND OF NF
)@@G@@LENGTH 1,  AND THE RESULT IS A VECTOR REGARDLESS OF THE     @F@@@@ RIGHTNG
)@@G@@   OPERAND   RANK.     SINCE   THIS  WILL  CHANGE  WHEN  THE@G@@@@ IMPLENH
)@@G@@MENTATION OF ENCODE IS COMPLETE,  ONE SHOULD NOT AT THIS TIME     @[@@@@NI
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                    NJ
)@@G@@       4- 20@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WRITE FUNCTIONS WNK
)@@G@@HICH DEPEND UPON THE RESULT'S BEING A VECTOR.  IF     @G@@@@ NECESSARY, NL
)@@G@@  ONE  CAN  GUARANTEE  THAT  THE  RESULT IS A VECTOR BY     @]@@@@ EITHENM
)@@G@@R:    @[@@@@      @F@@@@       (A)  FORCING THE RIGHT OPERAND TO BE A SCNN
)@@G@@ALAR BY PRECEDING @ @@@@            IT WITH  ''$R  OR @[@@@@      @D@@@@NO
)@@G@@       (B)  RAVELING (,) THE RESULT BEFORE USING IT.  @[@@@@      @ @@@@NP
)@@G@@  4. 3.16. 2.   DECODE (BASE) @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE DECODE OPERATONQ
)@@G@@R IS THE INVERSE OF ENCODE.  GIVEN A VECTOR     @G@@@@ RIGHT  OPERAND,  NR
)@@G@@IT EVALUATES IT IN THE NUMBER SYSTEM SPECIFIED BY     @G@@@@ THE  (VECTONS
)@@G@@R)  LEFT  OPERAND.   THE RANK OF THE RESULT IS ONE LESS     @G@@@@ THAN NT
)@@G@@ THE RANK OF THE RIGHT OPERAND - I.E.  A VECTOR RIGHT OPERAND     @G@@@@NU
)@@G@@ YIELDS  A SCALAR RESULT.   EACH ELEMENT IN THE LEFT OPERAND CORRE-     NV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SPONDS TO AN ELEMENT IN THE RIGHT OPERAND (I.E.  A POSITION IN THNW
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ NUMBER SYSTEM); ONE-ELEMENT LEFT OPERANDS ARE EXTENDED.  A NX
)@@G@@CONVER-     @F@@@@ SION FROM HOURS, MINUTES AND SECONDS TO SECONDS WOULDNY
)@@G@@ BE GIVEN BY@[@@@@      @ @@@@           24 60 60 $B 3 2 1  @[@@@@      NZ
)@@G@@@^@@@@ RESULTING IN  10921  . @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE VALUE OF THE OA
)@@G@@NUMBER  1 1 0 0  IN THE BASE 8 (OCTAL) NUM-     @^@@@@ BER SYSTEM IS GIVOB
)@@G@@EN BY @[@@@@      @^@@@@           8 $B 1 1 0 0 @[@@@@      @^@@@@ WHOSEOC
)@@G@@ RESULT IS  576  .@[@@@@      @G@@@@       AS OF THIS WRITING,  THE DECOOD
)@@G@@DE OPERATOR ACCEPTS ONLY SCALAR     @G@@@@ OR VECTOR RIGHT OPERANDS, YIEOE
)@@G@@LDING A SCALAR RESULT.  THE EXTENSION     @F@@@@ TO RIGHT OPERANDS OF AROF
)@@G@@BITRARY RANK WILL BE AVAILABLE SHORTLY.   @[@@@@      @A@@@@  4. 3.17.  OG
)@@G@@ DEAL ? OR $Q (DYADIC)  @[@@@@      @^@@@@      THE EXPRESSION    @[@@@@OH
)@@G@@      @#@@@@           I?N    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ YIELDS  A VECTOR OF I IOI
)@@G@@NTEGERS SELECTED RANDOMLY (WITHOUT REPLACE-     @G@@@@ MENT)  FROM THE SOJ
)@@G@@ET $IN .   THE NAME DEAL IS APPROPRIATE SINCE THE     @]@@@@ EXPRESSION OK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@           52?52  @[@@@@      @D@@@@ CORRESPONDS TO THOL
)@@G@@E RANDOM DEAL OF A DECK OF CARDS.   @[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 3.18.   EXECUOM
)@@G@@TE (UNQUOTE) $E (MONADIC)     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\11ON
)@@G@@00 (PRELIMINARY)                           4- 21@[@@@@      @[@@@@      OO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  UNQUOTE  OPERATOR TAKES A CHAROP
)@@G@@ACTER VECTOR OR SCALAR AS     @G@@@@ ITS RIGHT OPERAND.  THIS CHARACTER OQ
)@@G@@STRING IS THEN TREATED AS IF IT     @G@@@@ WERE  AN  APL STATEMENT,  ANDOR
)@@G@@ EXECUTED.   THE VALUE OF THE UNQUOTE     @G@@@@ OPERATOR  IS  THE VALUEOS
)@@G@@ OF THE UNQUOTED STATEMENT.  AS AN EXAMPLE,     @^@@@@ CONSIDER THE FOLLOT
)@@G@@OWING:@[@@@@      @#@@@@           A$S'3+'@^@@@@           C$S$EA,'5'   OU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  CHARACTER  VARIABLE  A  IS  CATENATED WITH THE COV
)@@G@@HARACTER 'S',     @G@@@@ YIELDING  '3+5',  WHICH IS THEN EXECUTED AS A SOW
)@@G@@TATEMENT.   THE RE-     @D@@@@ SULTING VALUE OF C IS THE NUMERIC QUANTITOX
)@@G@@Y EIGHT.    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  4. 4.   SUBSCRIPOY
)@@G@@TING (INDEXING) OF OPERATORS  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@OZ
)@@G@@       THE  COMPOUND  OPERATOR  REDUCTION  AND SEVERAL OF THE MIXED     PA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OPERATORS  ACT ALONG A PARTICULAR COORDINATE OF THE RIGHT OPERANDPB
)@@G@@.     @G@@@@ IN MOST CASES,  UNIQUE CHARACTERS HAVE BEEN DEFINED WHICH IPC
)@@G@@NDICATE     @G@@@@ WHETHER  THESE OPERATIONS ARE TO TAKE PLACE ALONG THEPD
)@@G@@ LAST COORDI-     @B@@@@ NATE (THE USUAL CASE), OR THE FIRST.     @[@@@@PE
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       IN DEALING WITH ARRAYS OF RANK GREATER THAN 2,  ONE MPF
)@@G@@AY WISH     @G@@@@ TO  APPLY ONE OF THESE OPERATORS ALONG ONE OF THE INTPG
)@@G@@ERIOR COORDI-     @G@@@@ NATES.    EVEN  WHEN  WORKING  WITH MATRICES,  PH
)@@G@@IT MAY SOMETIMES BE     @G@@@@ DESIRABLE  TO  WRITE FUNCTIONS WHICH MAY PI
)@@G@@APPLY SUCH AN OPERATOR TO     @G@@@@ EITHER  THE  FIRST  OR  THE SECOND PJ
)@@G@@COORDINATE,  DEPENDING UPON THE     @G@@@@ VALUE OF SOME VARIABLE.   TO PK
)@@G@@ACCOMPLISH THIS PURPOSE,  SUCH OPERA-     @ @@@@ TORS MAY BE SUBSCRIPTEDPL
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@       THE  GENERAL  FORM  FOR  SUBSCRIPTING  ANPM
)@@G@@  OPERATOR  IS  TO@G@@@@ IMMEDIATELY  FOLLOW  THE  SYMBOL  FOR  THE OPERPN
)@@G@@ATOR BY A SUBSCRIPT     @D@@@@ EXPRESSION ENCLOSED IN SQUARE BRACKETS.  PO
)@@G@@FOR EXAMPLE:@[@@@@      @ @@@@           /[3]   OR   $V[I+6]@[@@@@      PP
)@@G@@@F@@@@ THE QUANTITY IN BRACKETS MUST EVALUATE TO AN INTEGER IN THE SET  PQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@           $I $R X@[@@@@      @G@@@@ FOR RIGHT OPERANDPR
)@@G@@  X , THAT IS, IT MUST SPECIFY ONE OF THE COORDI-     @G@@@@ OF  THE  RIPS
)@@G@@GHT  OPERAND; THE ONLY EXCEPTION TO THIS IS LAMINATION,     @G@@@@ DISCUPT
)@@G@@SSED  ABOVE.   SUBSCRIPTING OF OPERATORS IS ORIGIN DEPENDENT;     @E@@@@PU
)@@G@@ AN ILLEGAL SUBSCRIPT VALUE RESULTS IN AN 'INDEX ERROR'.    @[@@@@*****^PV
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          PW

)@@G@@APL PROGRAMS@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PY
)@@G@@@ @@@@  5. 1.   PSEUDO-VARIABLES    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      PZ
)@@G@@ THERE  ARE  SEVERAL QUANTITIES IN APL\1100 WHICH ARE WRITTEN     @G@@@@QA
)@@G@@ AND  USED  AS  IF  THEY  WERE THE NAMES OF VARIABLES, BUT ARE NOT.     QB
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THESE  ARE  THE  INPUT/OUTPUT PSEUDO-VARIABLES QUAD ( " OR $W) ANQC
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ QUOTE  QUAD ($" OR $H) AND DEBUGGING AIDS FOR FUNCTIONS CALQD
)@@G@@LED THE     @ @@@@ STOPVECTOR AND TRACEVECTOR.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      QE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 2.   TERMINAL INPUT/OUTPUT     @[@@@@      @[@@@@QF
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 2. 1.   MIXED OUTPUT     @[@@@@      @G@@@@QG
)@@G@@       AS WE HAVE SEEN,  APL\1100 WILL ALWAYS IMMEDIATELY PRINT THE     QH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FINAL RESULT OF A LINE AS LONG AS THE LAST (LEFTMOST) OPERATION OQI
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ A LINE IS NOT SPECIFICATION.   IT OFTEN HAPPENS,  HOWEVER, QJ
)@@G@@THAT WE     @G@@@@ WOULD  LIKE  TO  PRINT  SEVERAL  DIFFERENT THINGS ON QK
)@@G@@A LINE,  PAR-     @G@@@@ TICULARLY  A  MIXTURE  OF CHARACTERS AND NUMBERQL
)@@G@@S.   IF SEVERAL EX-     @G@@@@ PRESSIONS  ON  A  LINE ARE SEPARATED BY SQM
)@@G@@EMICOLONS,  THEN APL\1100     @G@@@@ WILL  PRINT  EACH  OF  THE  EXPRESSQN
)@@G@@IONS  ON THE SAME LINE.   AS AN     @G@@@@ EXAMPLE,  IF THE VALUES OF  XQO
)@@G@@  AND  Y  ARE THREE AND FIVE, RESPEC-     @ @@@@ TIVELY, THEN THE STATEMQP
)@@G@@ENT   @D@@@@       'THERE WERE ';X;' SUCCESSES IN ';Y;'TRIES'     @B@@@@QQ
)@@G@@ WOULD CAUSE THE PRINTING OF THE LINE     @[@@@@      @B@@@@       THEREQR
)@@G@@ WERE 3 SUCCESSES IN 5 TRIES  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 2. 2.  QS
)@@G@@ EVALUATED OUTPUT @[@@@@      @G@@@@       ALTHOUGH  THE  VALUE OF ANY AQT
)@@G@@PL EXPRESSION CAN BE PRINTED BY     @G@@@@ PUTTING IT ON ITS OWN LINE,  QU
)@@G@@IT SOMETIMES HAPPENS (PARTICULARLY IN     @G@@@@ DEBUGGING)  THAT WE WISQV
)@@G@@H TO EXPLICITLY CAUSE CERTAIN QUANTITIES TO     @G@@@@ BE PRINTED.  THISQW
)@@G@@ IS DONE BY USING THE PSEUDOVARIABLE QUAD (SYMBOL     @]@@@@ " OR $W).  QX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHENEVER THE " SYMBOL APPEARS TO THE LEFT OF A QY
)@@G@@SPECIFICATION     @G@@@@ ($S)  SYMBOL,   THE SPECIFIED VALUE IS IMMEDIATQZ
)@@G@@ELY PRINTED.   THIS     @D@@@@ SYMBOL MAY APPEAR ANYWHERE IN A LINE, FORRA
)@@G@@ EXAMPLE:   @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRRB
)@@G@@ELIMINARY)                           5-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@RC
)@@G@@      @ @@@@           A$S (3 + "$S 5)%2  @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WOULD CAUSERD
)@@G@@ THE VALUE 5 TO BE PRINTED, AND THE VALUE FOUR WOULD BE     @#@@@@ ASSIGRE
)@@G@@NED TO 'A'. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 2. 3.   EVALUATED INPUT  RF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       IT  OFTEN  HAPPENS  THAT ONE DOES NOT KNOW THE RG
)@@G@@VALUES OF ALL     @G@@@@ PARAMETERS  AT THE TIME A FUNCTION IS WRITTEN; RH
)@@G@@ SOME VALUES REMAIN     @G@@@@ TO BE SUPPLIED AT THE TIME THE FUNCTION IRI
)@@G@@S USED.  THE QUAD PSEUDO-     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  (WITHOUT  A  FOLLOWING SPRJ
)@@G@@ECIFICATION SYMBOL) IS USED FOR     @G@@@@ THIS.   SINCE THIS SYMBOL (")RK
)@@G@@ REPRESENTS A PSEUDOVARIABLE,  IT MAY     @G@@@@ BE  PLACED  IN A STATEMRL
)@@G@@ENT AT THE POINT AT WHICH THE UNKNOWN VALUE     @G@@@@ IS  NEEDED,   JUSRM
)@@G@@T  AS A NORMAL VARIABLE WOULD BE.   WHEN APL\1100     @G@@@@ REACHES  THRN
)@@G@@E POINT AT WHICH IT NEEDS THE VALUE,  IT WILL PRINT THE     @G@@@@ QUAD RO
)@@G@@ SYMBOL FOLLOWED BY A COLON,  AND WAIT FOR THE REQUIRED VALUE     @G@@@@RP
)@@G@@ TO  BE TYPED IN.   ONCE THE VALUE IS TYPED IN,  APL\1100 WILL THEN     RQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PROCEED  TO  USE IT JUST AS IF A NORMAL VARIABLE WERE USED INSTEARR
)@@G@@D     @]@@@@ OF  " .    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHEN APL\1100 IS WAITINRS
)@@G@@G FOR EVALUATED INPUT,  ANY VALID APL     @G@@@@ STATEMENT MAY BE TYPED RT
)@@G@@IN;  IT MAY CONTAIN FUNCTION CALLS AND EVEN     @G@@@@ OTHER  QUADS.    RU
)@@G@@THE  STATEMENT TYPED IN WILL BE EVALUATED AND ITS     @C@@@@ FINAL RESULRV
)@@G@@T USED IN THE ORIGINAL STATEMENT.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      THE QUAD-COLRW
)@@G@@ON WHICH IS OUTPUT WHEN APL NEEDS INPUT IS CALLED     @G@@@@ THE  'SIGNARX
)@@G@@L FLAG FOR EVALUATED INPUT'.   THIS FLAG MAY BE CHANGED     @F@@@@ THROURY
)@@G@@GH THE USE OF THE SFEI FUNCTION IN THE WORKSPACE 1 WSFNS.   @[@@@@      RZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@       IF  AN ERROR IS DETECTED AND ONE DOES NOT CARE TO SUPPLY THSA
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ REQUESTED  INPUT,  TYPING A NILADIC GO TO ($G) WILL CAUSE ASB
)@@G@@PL\1100     @G@@@@ TO  SUSPEND  EXECUTION  (SEE  BELOW).   THIS ESCAPE FSC
)@@G@@ROM EVALUATED     @F@@@@ INPUT IS ESPECIALLY USEFUL WHEN A FUNCTION IS ISD
)@@G@@N AN INPUT LOOP.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 2. 4.   STRING OUTPSE
)@@G@@UT    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      WHEN THE QUAD SYMBOL IS USED FOR OUTPUT, TSF
)@@G@@HE SPECIFIED RESULT     @G@@@@ IS  IMMEDIATELY  PRINTED.    TO  DEFER  TSG
)@@G@@HE  OUTPUT  OF PARTICULAR     @G@@@@ INFORMATION,  THE QUOTE-QUAD ($" ORSH
)@@G@@ $H) PSEUDOVARIABLE MAY BE USED     @G@@@@ INSTEAD.    APL\1100  BUILDS SI
)@@G@@ THE  IMAGE  OF  A LINE TO BE PRINTED     @G@@@@ CHARACTER  BY  CHARACTESJ
)@@G@@R  IN  A  SPECIAL  PRINT BUFFER.   WHEN THE     @G@@@@ QUOTE-QUAD  SYMBOSK
)@@G@@L IS USED FOR OUTPUT,  EACH OUTPUT OPERATION ADDS     @G@@@@ NEW  INFORMSL
)@@G@@ATION  TO  THE  END OF THE CURRENT LINE IMAGE,  BUT THE     @G@@@@ IMAGESM
)@@G@@  IS  NOT  PRINTED  UNTIL  IT  IS  FORCED TO BE BY ONE OF THE     @^@@@@SN
)@@G@@ FOLLOWING CONDITIONS:  @[@@@@      @F@@@@      (A)  THE BUFFER IS FILLESO
)@@G@@D WITH THE NUMBER OF CHARACTERS     @C@@@@           SPECIFIED BY THE WISP
)@@G@@DTH OF THE WS.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINSQ
)@@G@@ARY)                           5-  3@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      SR

)@@G@@OCCURS@F@@@@           (SUCH AS AN ERROR REPORT, QUAD OUTPUT OR THE SIGNST
)@@G@@AL    @B@@@@           FLAG FOR EVALUATED INPUT).     @[@@@@      @F@@@@SU
)@@G@@      (C)  A REQUEST FOR QUOTE-QUAD INPUT (SEE BELOW) OCCURS.     @[@@@@SV
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ THIS  FEATURE  MAY  BE  USED  TO  BUILD PRINT IMAGES IN SUCSW
)@@G@@CESSIVE     @G@@@@ STATEMENTS SUCH AS IN LOOPS; THE SEVERAL STATEMENTS MSX
)@@G@@AY EVEN BE IN     @G@@@@ DIFFERENT FUNCTIONS.   IN ADDITION,  IT MAY BE SY

)@@G@@OR  A  'TYPE  AND  READ'@]@@@@ CAPABILITY.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@TA
)@@G@@  5. 2. 5.   STRING INPUT     @[@@@@      @G@@@@      WHEN NO SPECIFICATTB
)@@G@@ION SYMBOL APPEARS IMMEDIATELY TO THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ OF  THE  QUOTE-QUTC
)@@G@@AD SYMBOL,  APL\1100 INTERPRETS THIS AS A REQUEST     @G@@@@ FOR CHARACTTD
)@@G@@ER STRING INPUT.   UNDER NORMAL CIRCUMSTANCES (I.E. THE     @G@@@@ PRINTTE
)@@G@@  BUFFER  IS EMPTY),  IT WILL LEAVE THE CARRIER POSITIONED AT     @G@@@@TF
)@@G@@ THE  FAR  LEFT MARGIN AND WAIT FOR DATA TO BE TYPED IN.   ON TELE-     TG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TYPES,   APL  WILL SIGNAL ITS READINESS TO ACCEPT INPUT BY CAUSINTH
)@@G@@G     @G@@@@ THE  PRINT  BASKET  TO  AUDIBLY JUMP.   THE LINE OF INPUT TTI
)@@G@@YPED IN     @G@@@@ RESPONSE TO THIS WILL BE ACCEPTED AS A CHARACTER VECTTJ
)@@G@@OR OR SCALAR;     @C@@@@ TRAILING BLANK CHARACTERS WILL BE SURPRESSED.  TK
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@      IF THE PRINT BUFFER IS NOT EMPTY (I.E.  THE REQUTL
)@@G@@EST FOR INPUT     @G@@@@ HAS BEEN PRECEDED BY A QUOTE-QUAD OUTPUT OPERATTM
)@@G@@ION), THEN A QUOTE-     @G@@@@ QUAD  INPUT  REQUEST  WILL CAUSE THE BUFFTN
)@@G@@ER CONTENTS TO BE PRINTED     @G@@@@ AND THE SYSTEM WILL WAIT FOR FURTHETO
)@@G@@R INPUT TO BE TYPED ON THE SAME     @G@@@@ LINE (TYPE AND READ).   APL\1TP
)@@G@@100 ALWAYS ACCEPTS THE ENTIRE LINE AS     @G@@@@ IT APPEARS VISUALLY -- TQ
)@@G@@I.E. THE RESULT OF THE INPUT OPERATION WILL     @G@@@@ BE  A CHARACTER VTR
)@@G@@ECTOR,  THE LEFT PORTION OF WHICH WILL CONSIST OF     @G@@@@ THE  CHARACTS
)@@G@@TERS  WHICH WERE TYPED OUT,  THE RIGHT PORTION OF WHICH     @B@@@@ WILL TT
)@@G@@CONSIST OF THE CHARACTERS TYPED IN. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      TU
)@@G@@@A@@@@  5. 3.   FUNCTION DEBUGGING AIDS   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@TV
)@@G@@        ASSOCIATED   WITH   EVERY   DEFINED   FUNCTION   ARE   TWO@G@@@@TW
)@@G@@ PSEUDO-VARIABLES CALLED THE STOPVECTOR AND THE TRACEVECTOR.  THESE     TX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ARE VECTORS OF NUMBERS WHICH CORRESPOND TO THE LINE NUMBERS OF THTY
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ DEFINED  FUNCTION.    THE  NAMES OF THE TRACE AND STOPVECTOTZ
)@@G@@R FOR A     @G@@@@ GIVEN  FUNCTION  ARE THE CHARACTERS  T$M  OR  S$M  FOUA
)@@G@@LLOWED BY THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  NAME  -- THUS THE NAME OF THE TRACEVEUB
)@@G@@CTOR FOR A FUNCTION     @G@@@@ NAMED FRANG IS  T$MFRANG.  THE VALUE OF TUC
)@@G@@HE TRACE (OR STOP) VECTOR     @G@@@@ FOR  A GIVEN FUNCTION IS THE VECTORUD
)@@G@@ OF STATEMENT NUMBERS FOR WHICH     @G@@@@ THE  TRACE  (OR STOP) FLAG ISUE
)@@G@@ 'ON'.   WHEN A FUNCTION IS INITIALLY     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIUF
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           5-  4@[@@@@      UG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ DEFINED,   BOTH  OF  THESE  FLAGS  ARE  OUH
)@@G@@FF  FOR  ALL LINES OF THE     @]@@@@ FUNCTION.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      UI
)@@G@@ THE SPECIFICATION OPERATOR IS USED TO SET THE TRACE AND STOP     @G@@@@UJ
)@@G@@ FLAGS.  WHENEVER THE NAME OF THE TRACE OR STOPVECTOR OF A FUNCTION     UK
)@@G@@@G@@@@ APPEARS  ON  THE LEFT OF A SPECIFICATION,  THE LINES WHOSE NUMBERUL
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ APPEAR  IN  THE RIGHT ARGUMENT ARE FLAGGED,  AND THE FLAGS UM
)@@G@@FOR ALL     @G@@@@ OTHER LINES ARE TURNED OFF.  ANY VALUE IN THE RIGHT AUN
)@@G@@RGUMENT WHICH     @G@@@@ DOES  NOT  CORRESPOND  TO A LINE OF THE FUNCTIOUO
)@@G@@N IS IGNORED.   FOR     @]@@@@ EXAMPLE,   @[@@@@      @A@@@@           SUP
)@@G@@$MFRANG  $S  1  7  5  3 @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WILL  TURN  ON THE STOP FLAG UQ
)@@G@@FOR LINES 1,  3,  5 AND 7 OF FUNCTION     @G@@@@ FRANG,   AND  CLEAR THEUR
)@@G@@ STOP FLAGS FOR ALL OTHER STATEMENTS.   THE     @B@@@@ STOPVECTOR COULD US
)@@G@@BE CLEARED BY EITHER    @[@@@@      @D@@@@           S$MFRANG  $S  0   OUT
)@@G@@R   S$MFRANG  $S  $IO   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 3. 1.   THE SUU
)@@G@@TOPVECTOR   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AS  MENTIONED ABOVE,  THE STOPVECTOUV
)@@G@@R IS A VECTOR OF INTEGERS     @G@@@@ WHICH  INDICATES THE STATEMENTS IN UW
)@@G@@A FUNCTION WHOSE STOP FLAGS ARE     @G@@@@ ON.    WHENEVER  THE  STOP  FUX
)@@G@@LAG  IS ON FOR A LINE,  APL\1100 WILL     @G@@@@ SUSPEND  EXECUTION WHENUY
)@@G@@ IT REACHES THAT LINE, BEFORE EXECUTING IT.     @G@@@@ IT  WILL PRINT THUZ
)@@G@@E FUNCTION NAME AND LINE NUMBER,  AND THEN RETURN     @G@@@@ TO THE DESKVA
)@@G@@ CALCULATOR MODE.  SINCE THE FUNCTION IS SUSPENDED, ALL     @G@@@@ OF  IVB
)@@G@@TS  LOCAL  VARIABLES  ARE  ACTIVE,   AND  THEIR VALUES MAY BE     @G@@@@VC
)@@G@@ EXAMINED AND/OR CHANGED AT WILL USING NORMAL APL STATEMENTS.   FOR     VD
)@@G@@@C@@@@ MORE DETAILS ON SUSPEND FUNCTIONS, SEE BELOW.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@VE
)@@G@@      @ @@@@  5. 3. 2.   THE TRACEVECTOR  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  VF
)@@G@@TRACEVECTOR OF A FUNCTION IS THE SET OF LINE NUMBERS OF     @G@@@@ THAT VG
)@@G@@ FUNCTION FOR WHICH THE TRACE FLAG IS ON.   WHENEVER APL 1100     @G@@@@VH
)@@G@@ PROCESSES  A  LINE  WHOSE TRACE FLAG IS ON,  THE FUNCTION NAME AND     VI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ LINE  NUMBER  TOGETHER  WITH THE LAST (LEFTMOST) VALUE COMPUTED OVJ
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ THE LINE WILL BE PRINTED.   APL\1100 WILL CONTINUE EXECUTIOVK
)@@G@@N AFTER     @ @@@@ PRINTING THIS INFORMATION.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      VL
)@@G@@ THE  TRACEVECTOR  IS  REFERENCED  IN THE SAME FASHION AS THE     @G@@@@VM
)@@G@@ STOPVECTOR;  ITS NAME STARTS WITH THE CHARACTERS  T$M  RATHER THAN     VN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ S$M .   BOTH THE TRACEVECTOR AND THE STOPVECTOR MAY BE USED FREELVO
)@@G@@Y     @^@@@@ IN ANY APL EXPRESSION. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      VP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  VQ
)@@G@@                         5-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@VR
)@@G@@  5. 4.   THE BRANCHING OR GOTO OPERATOR $G     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      VS
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  5. 4. 1.   MONADIC BRANCHING@[@@@@      @G@@@@      VT
)@@G@@THE NORMAL SEQUENCE OF EXECUTION OF THE STATEMENTS IN A FUNC-     @G@@@@VU
)@@G@@ TION  IS  SEQUENTIAL;   THE  STATEMENTS  OF  THE FUNCTION BODY ARE     VV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ EXECUTED ONE AFTER THE OTHER UNTIL THE LAST ONE, THEN THE FUNCTIOVW
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ TERMINATES  AND CONTROL RETURNS TO THE POINT AT WHICH THE FVX
)@@G@@UNCTION     @G@@@@ NAME  WAS  REFERENCED.    THIS  STRICT SEQUENTIAL EXEVY
)@@G@@CUTION OF THE     @G@@@@ LINES  OF  A  FUNCTION  CAN  BE  ALTERED  BY  TVZ
)@@G@@HE  USE OF THE GOTO     @]@@@@ OPERATOR.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE MWA
)@@G@@ONADIC GOTO OPERATOR,  $G,  ACCEPTS A NUMERIC SCALAR OR     @G@@@@ VECTOWB
)@@G@@R AS ITS RIGHT ARGUMENT.  WHEN EXECUTED, IT CAUSES CONTROL OF     @G@@@@WC
)@@G@@ THE  PROGRAM TO PASS DIRECTLY TO THE LINE WHOSE VALUE IS THE FIRST     WD
)@@G@@@C@@@@ (OR ONLY) OF THE ARGUMENT.  THUS THE STATEMENT @[@@@@      @#@@@@WE
)@@G@@           $G 6   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WILL  CAUSE  CONTROL TO PASS TO LINWF
)@@G@@E 6.   THIS CAN ONLY BE USED TO     @G@@@@ TRANSFER  CONTROL  TO  A LINEWG
)@@G@@ IN THE SAME FUNCTION.   IF THE RIGHT     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT IS NOT A LEGALWH
)@@G@@ LINE NUMBER OF THE FUNCTION BEING EXECUTED     @G@@@@ THE  FUNCTION WILWI
)@@G@@L TERMINATE AT THAT POINT AND CONTROL WILL RETURN     @G@@@@ TO  THE  PLWJ
)@@G@@ACE FROM WHICH IT WAS CALLED.   THIS FEATURE IS USUALLY     @G@@@@ USED WK
)@@G@@ TO  CAUSE  A RETURN WITHOUT PASSING THROUGH THE LAST LINE OF     @G@@@@WL
)@@G@@ THE FUNCTION.  BY CONVENTION, SUCH A RETURN IS GENERATED BY A GOTO     WM
)@@G@@@#@@@@ LINE ZERO, I.E.  @[@@@@      @#@@@@           $GO    @[@@@@      WN
)@@G@@@A@@@@ ALWAYS CAUSES EXIT FROM A FUNCTION.@[@@@@      @G@@@@       WHEN WO
)@@G@@ THE RIGHT ARGUMENT OF THE BRANCHING OPERATOR IS A NULL     @F@@@@ VECTOWP
)@@G@@R,    THE   GOTO  IS  IGNORED  (I.E.   IS  EQUIVALENT  TO  A@G@@@@ NO-OPWQ
)@@G@@ERATION),   AND CONTROL PASSES TO THE LEFT OF THE GOTO ON THE     @G@@@@WR
)@@G@@ SAME  LINE.    IN  THIS  CASE,  THE VALUE OF THE GOTO OPERATION IS     WS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CONSIDERED  TO BE A NULL VECTOR.   IF THERE IS NOTHING TO THE LEFWT
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ OF  THE  GOTO,   THEN  CONTROL PASSES TO THE NEXT STATEMENTWU
)@@G@@ IN THE     @ @@@@ NORMAL SEQUENTIAL FASHION.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      WV
)@@G@@ BECAUSE  THE RIGHT ARGUMENT OF THE BRANCHING OPERATOR CAN BE     @G@@@@WW
)@@G@@ ANY  APL EXPRESSION,  IT CAN BE USED IN CONJUNCTION WITH OTHER APL     WX
)@@G@@@F@@@@ OPERATORS  TO  CREATE  SEVERAL  DIFFERENT  TYPES  OF  CONDITIONALWY
)@@G@@@]@@@@ BRANCHES.  @[@@@@      @^@@@@      THE CONSTRUCTION  @[@@@@      WZ
)@@G@@@B@@@@           $G N# $I <LOGICAL EXPRESSION>  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USERXA
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           5-  6@[@@@@XB
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ IS  OFTEN USED TO EFFECXC
)@@G@@T AN 'IF' CONDITION,  WHERE THE COMBINATION     @E@@@@ OF OPERATORS #$I XD
)@@G@@IS READ AS 'IF'.  THUS, THE STATEMENT     @[@@@@      @ @@@@           $XE
)@@G@@G 6 #$I A < 3     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ CAN  BE  READ  AS 'GO TO LINE SIX IXF
)@@G@@F A IS LESS THAN THREE'.   IF A     @G@@@@ WERE  NOT  LESS  THAN  THREE,XG
)@@G@@  CONTROL WILL CONTINUE SEQUENTIALLY.     @G@@@@ NOTICE  THAT SINCE THE XH
)@@G@@MONADIC INDEX GENERATOR $I IS ORIGIN DEPEN-     @D@@@@ DENT, THIS CONSTRXI
)@@G@@UCTION IS VALID ONLY IN ORIGIN 1.   @[@@@@      @D@@@@      OTHER CONSTRXJ
)@@G@@UCTIONS USEFUL IN BRANCHING ARE:    @[@@@@      @C@@@@ (1)  $G N $ V <VEXK
)@@G@@CTOR OF STATEMENT NUMBERS>    @[@@@@      @F@@@@           CONTROL WOULDXL
)@@G@@ PASS TO THE FIRST STATEMENT IF N WERE    @F@@@@           ZERO, THE SECXM
)@@G@@OND IF N WERE 1, ETC.  THIS IS ORIGIN     @^@@@@           INDEPENDENT. XN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @E@@@@ (2)  $G (<LOGICAL EXPRESSION 1>,<LOGICAL EXPRESSION 2XO
)@@G@@>)/N,M@[@@@@      @F@@@@           CONTROL WOULD GO TO N IF THE FIRST LOXP
)@@G@@GICAL EXPRESSION  @F@@@@           WERE TRUE.  IF NOT, THEN CONTROL WOULXQ
)@@G@@D TO TO M IF THE  @F@@@@           SECOND LOGICAL EXPRESSION WERE TRUE. XR
)@@G@@ IF NEITHER WERE  @F@@@@           TRUE, THE ARGUMENT OF THE $G WOULD BEXS
)@@G@@ NULL, AND CONTROL@A@@@@           WOULD PASS TO THE LEFT.  @[@@@@      XT
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@  5. 4. 2.   THE NILADIC BRANCH     @[@@@@      @G@@@@XU
)@@G@@       ALTHOUGH  NILADIC  (NO-ARGUMENT)  FUNCTIONS  CAN  EASILY  BE     XV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DEFINED,  THE ONLY APL PRIMITIVE OPERATOR WHICH CAN APPEAR WITHOUXW
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ A  RIGHT  ARGUMENT  IS  $G.    WHEN  USED IN THIS CONTEXT, XX
)@@G@@ THE $G     @G@@@@ OPERATOR  ESSENTIALLY MEANS STOP.   CONTROL IMMEDIATEXY
)@@G@@LY RETURNS TO     @G@@@@ THE  DESK  CALCULATOR  MODE,   AND ALL PENDANT XZ
)@@G@@FUNCTIONS AND LOCAL     @G@@@@ VARIABLES  ARE  ERASED  FROM  THE STATE IYA
)@@G@@NDICATOR BACK TO THE LAST     @G@@@@ SUSPENDED  FUNCTION.    WE  HAVE ALYB
)@@G@@READY DISCUSSED HOW THIS MAY BE     @G@@@@ USED  TO ESCAPE FROM AN EVALUYC
)@@G@@ATED INPUT LOOP.   IT CAN ALSO APPEAR     @G@@@@ IN ANY FUNCTION OR ON AYD
)@@G@@ LINE OF TEXT BEING UNQUOTED BY THE EXECUTE     @#@@@@ ($E) OPERATOR.   YE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  5. 4. 3.   RESUMPTION OF SUSPENDED FUNCTYF
)@@G@@IONS  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      AS MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY IN THE DISCUSSION YG
)@@G@@OF THE )SI AND )SIV     @G@@@@ COMMANDS,   IT IS POSSIBLE FOR THE EXECUTYH
)@@G@@ION OF AN APL FUNCTION TO     @G@@@@ BE  SUSPENDED  WHILE  IT IS EXECUTIYI
)@@G@@NG -- THIS MAY BE BECAUSE OF AN     @G@@@@ ERROR  IN A STATEMENT,  OR BEYJ
)@@G@@CAUSE THE STOPVECTOR HAS BEEN SET FOR     @G@@@@ DEBUGGING PURPOSES.   IYK
)@@G@@F THE ERROR IS MINOR, IT MAY BE POSSIBLE TO     @G@@@@ CORRECT  IT  BY  YL
)@@G@@RE-OPENING THE FUNCTION DEFINITION AND CORRECTING     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@YM
)@@G@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           5-  7YN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  STATEMENT;   ONE MIGHT TYO
)@@G@@HEN WANT TO CONTINUE EXECUTION OF THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  FROM THE POINYP
)@@G@@T AT WHICH IT WAS STOPPED,  OR PERHAPS EVEN     @G@@@@ FROM  A  PREVIOUSYQ
)@@G@@  LINE.   WHENEVER A SUSPENDED FUNCTION IS IN THE     @G@@@@ STATE  INDIYR
)@@G@@CATOR,  A MONADIC $G MAY BE EXECUTED IN DESK CALCULATOR     @G@@@@ MODE,YS
)@@G@@  AND  THE FUNCTION WILL RESUME AT THE SPECIFIED LINE NUMBER.     @G@@@@YT
)@@G@@ IF  ONE  DESIRES  INSTEAD  TO  ABORT  EXECUTION  OF  THE  FUNCTION     YU
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ENTIRELY,   A  'STOP'  FUNCTION  (NILADIC $G) WILL CLEAR THE STATYV
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ VECTOR  BACK TO THE PREVIOUS SUSPENDED FUNCTION, IF THERE WYW
)@@G@@AS ONE.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@  5. 5.   LABELS  YX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       BECAUSE  DEFINED  FUNCTIONS  ARE  AYY
)@@G@@LMOST ALWAYS LIABLE TO BE     @G@@@@ CHANGED  (BECAUSE  OF  AN  ERROR  OYZ
)@@G@@R TO ADD A NEW FEATURE),  IT IS     @G@@@@ USUALLY  UNWISE  TO  USE ABSOZA
)@@G@@LUTE LINE NUMBERS AS ARGUMENTS TO THE     @G@@@@ BRANCHING  OPERATOR.   ZB
)@@G@@INSERTION OR DELETION OF LINES OF THE FUNC-     @G@@@@ TION  WILL  CAUSEZC
)@@G@@  THE  LINE  NUMBERS TO CHANGE,  AND GOTO'S WHICH     @F@@@@ REFERENCED ZD
)@@G@@THE OLD LINE NUMBERS WILL NO LONGER OPERATE PROPERLY. @[@@@@      @G@@@@ZE
)@@G@@      TO ALLEVIATE THIS CONDITION,  APL\1100 ALLOWS LABEL VARIABLES     ZF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TO  BE  SPECIFIED  FOR  THE  LINES OF A FUNCTION.   WHEN A LINE IZG
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ LABELED,   ITS  LABEL  VARIABLE WILL ALWAYS HAVE THE CORRECZH
)@@G@@T VALUE     @G@@@@ REGARDLESS  OF  WHETHER  LINES  ARE INSERTED OR DELETZI
)@@G@@ED AT A LATER     @G@@@@ TIME.    BRANCHING  OPERATORS  WHICH REFERENCE ZJ
)@@G@@THE LABEL VARIABLES     @G@@@@ INSTEAD  OF  ACTUAL LINE NUMBERS WILL THEZK
)@@G@@N NOT HAVE TO BE MODIFIED     @ @@@@ IF THE LINE NUMBERS CHANGE.  @[@@@@ZL
)@@G@@      @G@@@@      WHEN SPECIFIED, A LABEL MUST BE THE LEFTMOST VARIABLE ZM
)@@G@@NAME ON     @G@@@@ A  LINE,   AND IT MUST BE SEPARATED FROM THE TEXT OF ZN
)@@G@@THE LINE BY A     @C@@@@ COLON.  A TYPICAL LABELED LINE IN A FUNCTION ISZO
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @B@@@@           [3] GETX: X $S 3 + 4 #$I Z     @[@@@@      ZP
)@@G@@@F@@@@ A BRANCH TO THIS LINE ELSEWHERE IN THE FUNCTION WOULD THEN BE    ZQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @#@@@@           $G GETX@[@@@@      @G@@@@        LABELS AREZR
)@@G@@ LOCAL VARIABLES IN FUNCTIONS.   THEY ARE CREATED     @G@@@@ AND  THEIR ZS
)@@G@@ VALUES  ASSIGNED  WHEN  THE  FUNCTION IS ENTERED,  AND     @G@@@@ DESTRZT
)@@G@@OYED  WHEN  THE  FUNCTION  TERMINATES.   SINCE LABELS ARE APL     @G@@@@ZU
)@@G@@ SCALAR VARIABLES, THEY MAY BE USED FREELY IN ANY COMPUTATION.  FOR     ZV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OBVIOUS  REASONS,   THEY  SHOULD  NOT  APPEAR  ON  THE  LEFT  OF ZW
)@@G@@A     @ @@@@ SPECIFICATION OPERATION.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@ZX
)@@G@@      @C@@@@  5. 6.   SYSTEM FUNCTIONS -- THE $Y OPERATOR   @[@@@@*****^ZY
)@@G@@@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                          ZZ
)@@G@@ 5-  8@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  SYSTEM FUNCTAA
)@@G@@ION OPERATOR $Y IS AN OPERATOR WHICH MAY BE     @G@@@@ USED TO OBTAIN CEAB
)@@G@@RTAIN INFORMATION ABOUT THE TERMINAL SESSION, THE     @G@@@@ WORKSPACE AAC
)@@G@@ND THE APL SYSTEM ITSELF.  THE SYSTEM FUNCTION OPERATOR     @G@@@@ IS  MAD
)@@G@@ONADIC,   AND  TAKES A 1-ELEMENT NUMERIC RIGHT OPERAND.   THE     @F@@@@AE
)@@G@@ VALUE  OF  THE  RIGHT  OPERAND  DETERMINES  WHAT  INFORMATION  IS@G@@@@AF
)@@G@@ RETURNED.    ANY RIGHT ARGUMENT OTHER THAN ONE OF THE VALUES TABU-     AG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ LATED  BELOW WILL RESULT IN A DOMAIN ERROR.   WHERE A SYSTEM FUNCAH
)@@G@@-     @G@@@@ TION  RETURNS A TIME VALUE,  THE TIME IS IN UNITS OF SIXIETAI
)@@G@@HS OF A     @G@@@@ SECOND.    THE  ALLOWED ARGUMENTS FOR THE SYSTEM FUNCAJ
)@@G@@TION OPERATOR     @[@@@@ ARE: @[@@@@      @E@@@@      $Y19     ACCUMULATAK
)@@G@@ED KEYING TIME -- AMOUNT OF TIME THE@E@@@@               TERMINAL HAS BEAL
)@@G@@EN WAITING TO ACCEPT INPUT.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      $Y20     TIME OF DAM
)@@G@@AY IN 60'THS OF A SECOND PAST MIDNIGHT.   @[@@@@      @F@@@@      $Y21  AN
)@@G@@   AMOUNT OF COMPUTER TIME USED SO FAR IN THE APL     @E@@@@            AO
)@@G@@   SESSION.  THIS MAY BE MEMORY TIME OR CPU TIME@F@@@@               DEPAP
)@@G@@ENDING ON THE INSTALLATION.  ONLY TIME SPENT    @F@@@@               IN AQ
)@@G@@APL IS COUNTED, THIS IS NOT THE TOTAL COMPUTER  @A@@@@               TIMAR
)@@G@@E FOR THE RUN.    @[@@@@      @F@@@@      $Y22     AMOUNT OF AVAILABLE SAS
)@@G@@TORAGE IN THE WORKSPACE, IN   @F@@@@               CHARACTERS.  A CLEAR AT
)@@G@@WORKSPACE IS APPROXIMATELY    @ @@@@               32K CHARACTERS.@[@@@@AU
)@@G@@      @D@@@@      $Y24     TIME OF DAY THE APL SESSION STARTED.   @[@@@@AV
)@@G@@      @F@@@@      $Y25     THE CURRENT DATE, A SIX DIGIT DECIMAL NUMBER AW
)@@G@@OF    @A@@@@               THE FORM MMDDYY.     @[@@@@      @F@@@@      AX
)@@G@@$Y26     THE LINE NUMBER OF THE CURRENTLY EXECUTING LINE    @F@@@@      AY
)@@G@@         OF A FUNCTION.  THIS IS THE SAME AS ($Y27)[1].     @[@@@@      AZ
)@@G@@@F@@@@      $Y27     THE VECTOR OF LINE NUMBERS IN THE STATE INDICATOR. BA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @F@@@@      $Y28     THE TYPE OF RUN AND TERMINAL DEVICE BEIBB
)@@G@@NG USED --  @F@@@@               5 IS A BATCH RUN, 6 IS A DEMAND RUN.  OBC
)@@G@@THER VALUES @ @@@@               ARE UNDEFINED. @[@@@@      @F@@@@      BD
)@@G@@$Y29     THE LIBRARY NUMBER FOR THIS SESSION.  WHEN EXAMIN- @F@@@@      BE
)@@G@@         ING THE VALUE OF THIS NUMBER, ONE SHOULD BE SURE   @F@@@@      BF
)@@G@@         THAT THE )DIGITS SPECIFICATION OF THE WORKSPACE    @F@@@@      BG
)@@G@@         IS AT LEAST 10, OR ALL OF THE DIGITS IN THIS NUMBER@A@@@@      BH
)@@G@@         MIGHT NOT BE PRINTED.@[@@@@      @G@@@@      IN ADDITION TO THEBI
)@@G@@ ABOVE, A NUMBER OF NON-PRIMITIVE FUNCTIONS     @G@@@@ OF A SIMILAR NATUBJ
)@@G@@RE MAY BE FOUND IN THE WORKSPACE 1 WSFNS.   THESE     @G@@@@ FUNCTIONS MBK
)@@G@@AY BE USED TO, FOR EXAMPLE, CHANGE THE WIDTH, DIGITS OR     @B@@@@ ORIGIBL
)@@G@@N SPECIFICATIONS OF A WORKSPACE.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO BM
)@@G@@APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           5-  9@[@@@@      @[@@@@BN
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@  5. 7.   FUZZING @[@@@@BO
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      BECAUSE OF THE NATURE OF ELECTRONIC COMPONBP
)@@G@@ENTS, FEW COMPUTERS     @G@@@@ DO  ARITHMETIC  IN THE DECIMAL NUMBER SYSBQ
)@@G@@TEM,  AND THE UNIVAC 1100     @G@@@@ SERIES  IS  NO  EXCEPTION TO THIS; BR
)@@G@@ ARITHMETIC IN A UNIVAC 1100 IS     @G@@@@ DONE IN THE BINARY NUMBER SYSBS
)@@G@@TEM.   APL,  HOWEVER, IS DESIGNED FOR     @G@@@@ USE BY HUMANS,  WHO USEBT
)@@G@@ THE DECIMAL SYSTEM - CONSEQUENTLY, IT ACTS     @D@@@@ AS IF IT WERE DOIBU
)@@G@@NG ITS COMPUTATIONS IN DECIMAL.     @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THIS  DIFFEBV
)@@G@@RENCE  IN  NUMBER  SYSTEMS IS NOT NOTICEABLE WHEN     @G@@@@ DEALING WITBW
)@@G@@H INTEGERS;  ALL INTEGERS CAN BE REPRESENTED EXACTLY IN     @G@@@@ BOTH BX
)@@G@@ SYSTEMS.   APL\1100 REPRESENTS ALL INTEGERS OF FEWER THAN 18     @F@@@@BY
)@@G@@ DIGITS EXACTLY, LARGER VALUES ARE KEPT TO 18 DIGIT ACCURACY.     @[@@@@BZ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@      IT IS NOT POSSIBLE,  HOWEVER,  TO REPRESENT ALL DECIMACA
)@@G@@L FRAC-     @G@@@@ TIONS EXACTLY IN THE BINARY NUMBER SYSTEM,  THE DECIMCB
)@@G@@AL VALUE ONE-     @G@@@@ TENTH, FOR EXAMPLE, IS A CONTINUING FRACTION INCC
)@@G@@ THE BINARY SYSTEM,     @^@@@@ AND THE EXPRESSION     @[@@@@      @^@@@@CD
)@@G@@           0.1# 10.0    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ MAY DIFFER SLIGHTLY FROM THE CE
)@@G@@EXPECTED VALUE OF 1 .  IF APL WERE TO     @G@@@@ DO ALL OF ITS CALCULATICF
)@@G@@ONS EXACTLY, THEN SOME RESULTS MIGHT NOT BE     @D@@@@ EXACTLY AS DESIRECG
)@@G@@D - FOR EXAMPLE, THE EXPRESSION     @[@@@@      @^@@@@           1 = 0.1CH
)@@G@@# 10.0@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WOULD BE FALSE,  WHILE FOR MOST APPLICATIONS, OCI
)@@G@@NE WOULD WANT IT TO     @]@@@@ BE TRUE.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      TO ALLCJ
)@@G@@EVIATE THIS CONDITION,  A TECHNIQUE CALLED 'FUZZING' IS     @G@@@@ USED.CK
)@@G@@    IF TWO QUANTITIES ARE EQUAL TO WITHIN A SPECIFIED PERCEN-     @G@@@@CL
)@@G@@ TAGE  ERROR,  THEY  ARE  TREATED  AS  IF  THEY WERE EXACTLY EQUAL.     CM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FUZZING  IS  APPLIED TO ALL OF THE RELATIONAL OPERATORS (=, $=, >CN
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ <,  ETC.),  WHEN USED AS SCALARS, AS PART OF A COMPOUND OPECO
)@@G@@RATION,     @G@@@@ OR WHEN IMPLICIT AS IN THE DYADIC 'INDEX OF' ($I) ANDCP
)@@G@@ 'MEMBERSHIP'     @G@@@@ ($E) OPERATORS.   IN ADDITION, IT IS USED IN THCQ
)@@G@@E CEILING AND FLOOR     @F@@@@ OPERATORS, AND IN THE EVALUATION OF INDICCR
)@@G@@ES FOR SUBSCRIPTING.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       ONE  SHOULD  REALIZE  TCS
)@@G@@HAT  ALTHOUGH  FUZZING  DOES GIVE THE     @G@@@@ DESIRED RESULT IN MOST CT
)@@G@@CASES,  IT DESTROYS THE TRANSITIVITY OF THE     @G@@@@ EQUALITY  RELATIOCU
)@@G@@N  - E.G.  IT IS POSSIBLE TO HAVE THREE VARIABLES     @G@@@@ A,   B AND CV
)@@G@@C SUCH THAT  A=B IS TRUE,  B=C IS TRUE,  BUT C=A IS NOT     @G@@@@ TRUE.CW
)@@G@@   SINCE SUBTRACTION IS NOT SUBJECT TO FUZZING, THIS COULD BE     @G@@@@CX
)@@G@@ DETECTED BY EXAMINING THE DIFFERENCES BETWEEN THESE VARIABLES.  IN     CY
)@@G@@@D@@@@ PRACTICE, THIS ANOMALY IS RARELY OF ANY CONSEQUENCE. @[@@@@      CZ
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)              DA
)@@G@@             5- 10@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       IT  IDB
)@@G@@S RECOGNIZED THAT IN CERTAIN APPLICATIONS (PARTICULARLY     @G@@@@ NUMERDC
)@@G@@ICAL  ANALYSIS), FUZZING IS A DISTINCTLY UNDESIRABLE FEATURE.     @G@@@@DD
)@@G@@ ALL  INTERNAL  CALCULATIONS IN APL\1100 ARE CARRIED TO AN ACCURACY     DE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OF 60 BITS,  BUT IN FUZZING, ONLY THE MOST SIGNIFICANT 48 BITS ARDF
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ CONSIDERED.   ASSOCIATED WITH EACH WORKSPACE IS A 'FUZZ CONDG
)@@G@@STANT';     @G@@@@ FOR  A  CLEAR  WORKSPACE ITS VALUE IS 12 (I.E.  60-48DH
)@@G@@).   THE FUZZ     @G@@@@ CONSTANT  FOR  A GIVEN WORKSPACE MAY BE CHANGEDDI
)@@G@@ THROUGH THE USE OF     @D@@@@ THE )FUZZ COMMAND OR THE FUNCTION FUZZ INDJ
)@@G@@  1 WSFNS.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@      EXTREME CAUTION SHOULD BE USED WHEN DK
)@@G@@CHANGING THE VALUE OF THE     @G@@@@ FUZZING CONSTANT.   A SMALL FUZZINGDL
)@@G@@ CONSTANT, OR NO FUZZING AT ALL     @G@@@@ CAN  CAUSE  THE  CEILING  ANDDM
)@@G@@  FLOOR  OPERATORS  TO GIVE UNDESIRED     @G@@@@ RESULTS,  AND CAN CAUSEDN
)@@G@@ ERRORS IN THE EVALUATION OF SUBSCRIPTS.  A     @G@@@@ LARGE FUZZING CONDO
)@@G@@STANT CAN CAUSE APL TO CONSIDER TWO QUANTITIES TO     @G@@@@ BE  EQUAL  DP
)@@G@@WHICH  CLEARLY  SHOULD  NOT  BE.   THE STANDARD FUZZING     @G@@@@ CONSTDQ
)@@G@@ANT  OF 12 IS AN OPTIMUM VALUE FOR ALMOST ALL WORK ON AN 1100     @#@@@@DR
)@@G@@ SERIES MACHINE.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@  5. 8.   COMMENTS@[@@@@DS
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       COMMENTS  MAY  BE ENTERED ON ANY LINE OF DT
)@@G@@INPUT TO APL EXCEPT     @G@@@@ THE HEADER LINE OF A FUNCTION.   COMMENTSDU
)@@G@@ ARE PRECEDED BY THE LAMP     @G@@@@ ($:) SYMBOL;  ANYTHING TO THE RIGHTDV
)@@G@@ OF THE LAMP IS CONSIDERED AS A     @G@@@@ COMMENT,  AND NOT PROCESSED BDW
)@@G@@Y APL.  A LINE CONTAINING ONLY A LAMP     @G@@@@ AND NOTHING ELSE (I.E. DX
)@@G@@ NULL COMMENTS) HAS SPECIAL SIGNIFICANCE IN     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  EDITINGDY
)@@G@@.     WHEN  IN  FUNCTION  DEFINITION  MODE,   ONE     @G@@@@ INDICATES TDZ
)@@G@@HAT A PARTICULAR LINE OF THE FUNCTION IS TO BE ENTIRELY     @G@@@@ DELETEA
)@@G@@ED  BY  TYPING A LINE CONTAINING ONLY A LAMP.   E.G.,  IN THE     @A@@@@EB
)@@G@@ FUNCTION DEFINITION MODE, THE LINE @^@@@@            [5]  $:     @D@@@@EC
)@@G@@ WILL CAUSE LINE 5 OF THE FUNCTION TO BE DELETED.     @[@@@@      @[@@@@ED
)@@G@@      @ @@@@  5. 9.   USE OF THE BREAK KEY@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@EE
)@@G@@       IT  IS SOMETIMES DESIRABLE TO INTERRUPT PROCESSING WHICH APL     EF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IS DOING.  THIS MAY OCCUR BECAUSE IT APPEARS AS IF AN APL FUNCTIOEG
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ IS LOOPING,  OR BECAUSE ONE WISHES TO CANCEL THE PRINTOUT OEH
)@@G@@F (SAY)     @C@@@@ THE TEXT OF A FUNCTION OR AN  )SI  DISPLAY.    @[@@@@EI
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       WHEN USING A TELETYPE,  APL MAY BE INTERRUPTED T ANY EJ
)@@G@@TIME BY     @G@@@@ DEPRESSING  THE 'BREAK' KEY.   THIS WILL RESULT IN A EK
)@@G@@RESPONSE FROM     @#@@@@ THE SYSTEM OF    @[@@@@      @B@@@@            EL
)@@G@@         INTRPT LAST LINE     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ AT THIS POINT,  ONE SHOEM
)@@G@@ULD PRESS THE  BRK-RLS  BUTTON, AND ENTER A     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USEREN
)@@G@@'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           5- 11@[@@@@EO
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@ CARRIAGE RETURN.  IF APL WAS PRINTIEP
)@@G@@NG AT THE TIME  BREAK  WAS HIT,     @G@@@@ A  FEW  MORE  LINES  OF  OUTPEQ
)@@G@@UT  MAY PRINT.   THE SYSTEM WILL THEN     @G@@@@ SUSPEND THE EXECUTING FER
)@@G@@UNCTION (F THERE WAS ONE) AND RETURN TO THE     @G@@@@ DESK  CALCULATOR ES
)@@G@@ MODE.   IF THE SYSTEM WAS IN FUNCTION DEFINITION     @G@@@@ MODE, IT WIET
)@@G@@LL NOT RETURN TO DESK CALCULATOR MODE, BUT WILL INSTEAD     @G@@@@ PROMPEU
)@@G@@T YOU FOR THE NEXT LINE OF INPUT TO THE FUNCTION.  ONE SHOULD     @G@@@@EV
)@@G@@ NOT  TYPE  THE  CHARACTER  X  IN RESPONSE TO THE  INTRPT LAST LINE     EW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ MESSAGE,   AS  THIS  WILL  CAUSE  EXEC 8 TO ABORT APL ENTIRELY ANEX
)@@G@@D     @A@@@@ RETURN TO THE EXEC 8 CONTROL MODE. @[@@@@      @G@@@@      EY
)@@G@@ A  SIMILAR  PROCEDURE  IS AVAILABLE WHEN USING DEVICES OTHER     @G@@@@EZ
)@@G@@ THAN  TELETYPES AS TERMINALS.   FOR EXAMPLE,  WHEN USING TERMINALS     FA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ COMPATIBLE WITH THE IBM 2741, THE  ATTN  KEY IS GENERALLY USED FOFB
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ THE  BREAK  FUNCTION.    ONE SHOULD CONSULT THE APPROPRIATEFC
)@@G@@ UNIVAC     @G@@@@ MANUALS  AND  ANY  SPECIAL SITE-DEPENDENT INFORMATIONFD
)@@G@@ TO DETERMINE     @D@@@@ THE EXACT PROCEDURE FOR DEVICES OTHER THAN TELEFE
)@@G@@TYPES.@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  5.10.   SIDE EFFECTS  FF
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@      SIDE EFFECTS ARE APPARENT ANOMALIES FG
)@@G@@IN A PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE     @G@@@@ WHICH  CAN  CAUSE  IT  TO GIVE OTHEFH
)@@G@@RWISE UNEXPECTED RESULTS.   ALL     @G@@@@ CONTEMPORARY  COMPUTER  LANGUFI
)@@G@@AGES  EXHIBIT  SIDE  EFFECTS  TO SOME     @G@@@@ DEGREE  OR OTHER.   ALTFJ
)@@G@@HOUGH THE ORIGINAL DESIGNERS OF APL[3] WERE     @G@@@@ CAREFUL  TO  ELIMFK
)@@G@@INATE  MOST  CASES  IN  WHICH  THEY  COULD OCCUR.     @G@@@@ NEVERTHELESFL
)@@G@@S, THE TWO AREAS IN WHICH THEY APPEAR ARE IN THE USE OF     @G@@@@ THE  FM
)@@G@@SPECIFICATION  ($S) OPERATOR,  AND IN THE MASKING OF VARIABLE     @ @@@@FN
)@@G@@ NAMES IN FUNCTION EXECUTION. @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  5.10. 1.  FO
)@@G@@ SPECIFICATION    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      TWO ANOMALIES EXIST IN THE USEFP
)@@G@@ OF THE SPECIFICATION OPERATOR,     @G@@@@ ONE  WHICH  MAY  BE  CAUSED  FQ
)@@G@@BY  THE  OCCURRENCE  OF AN ERROR IN A     @G@@@@ PROGRAM,  THE  OTHER  WFR
)@@G@@HEN THE $S OPERATOR IS USED IN PARENTHESES.     @G@@@@ TO  DEMONSTRATE TFS
)@@G@@HE FORMER, CONSIDER THE FOLLOWING APL STATEMENTS:     @[@@@@      @ @@@@FT
)@@G@@           J $S 1 + V$S 2     @ @@@@           A$S V + J$S 3 + J  @[@@@@FU
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ AFTER  THE EXECUTION OF THE SECOND STATEMENT,  THE VALUE OFFV
)@@G@@ J WILL     @G@@@@ BE SIX,  AND A WILL BE EIGHT.   CONSIDER NOW INSTEAD FW
)@@G@@THAT V IS UN-     @A@@@@ DEFINED - I.E. THE STATEMENTS ARE: @[@@@@      FX
)@@G@@@#@@@@           J $ S 3@A@@@@           A $ S V + J $S 3 + J     @[@@@@FY
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ IN THIS CASE,  A 'VALUE ERROR' WILL BE SIGNALLED WHEN APL AFZ
)@@G@@TTEMPTS     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  GA
)@@G@@                         5- 12@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@GB
)@@G@@ TO ADD V AND J.  BECAUSE APL OPERATES FROM RIGHT TO LEFT, HOWEVER,     GC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  VALUE  J  WILL  HAVE  BEEN  CHANGED  BEFORE  THE  ADDITION IGD
)@@G@@S     @F@@@@ ATTEMPTED.  IF ONE SPECIFIED THE VALUE OF V AT THIS POINT BGE
)@@G@@Y     @[@@@@      @#@@@@           V $S 2 @[@@@@      @A@@@@ AND THEN REGF
)@@G@@-EXECUTED THE STATEMENT @[@@@@      @ @@@@           A$S V + J $S 3 + J GG
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ THE  RESULT  WOULD  BE THAT J WOULD BE NINE AND A WOUGH
)@@G@@LD BE ELEVEN,     @G@@@@ RATHER THAN SIX AND EIGHT AS BEFORE.   THIS PARGI
)@@G@@TICULAR SIDE EFFECT     @G@@@@ IS  MOST  LIKELY  TO  SHOW  UP  WHEN  THEGJ
)@@G@@ STATEMENT WITH THE ERROR     @D@@@@ APPEARED IN A FUNCTION, CAUSING IT GK
)@@G@@TO BE SUSPENDED.  @G@@@@       SPECIFICATION WITHIN PARENTHESES CAN ALSOGL
)@@G@@ PRODUCE UNEXPECTED     @ @@@@ RESULTS.  THE STATEMENTS     @[@@@@      GM
)@@G@@@#@@@@           J $S 5 @ @@@@           X $S(J $S 2) + J   @[@@@@      GN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ COULD  SET  THE  VALUE OF  X  TO EITHER 4 (IF THE SPECIFICATION IGO
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ DONE FIRST) OR 7 (IF THE ADDITION IS DONE FIRST).   IN THE GP
)@@G@@CURRENT     @G@@@@ IMPLEMENTATION  OF APL\1100, THE RESULT OF THE ABOVE GQ
)@@G@@WILL BE FOUR;     @B@@@@ IF THE SECOND STATEMENT WERE CHANGED TO  @[@@@@GR
)@@G@@      @A@@@@           X $S(J $S 2) + J + 0     @[@@@@      @G@@@@ HOWEVGS
)@@G@@ER, APL\1100 (AS CURRENTLY IMPLEMENTED) WILL ASSIGN THE VALUE     @#@@@@GT
)@@G@@ SEVEN TO  X .    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       SINCE THE ORDER OF OPERATIONSGU
)@@G@@ IN CASES LIKE THE ABOVE IS NOT     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED  IN  THE  LANGUAGE,GV
)@@G@@  THE RESULTS OF SUCH STATEMENTS WILL     @G@@@@ ALWAYS  BE  IMPLEMENTATGW
)@@G@@ION DEPENDENT.   ONE SHOULD BE AWARE THAT A     @G@@@@ CHANGE  IN  THE  GX
)@@G@@IMPLEMENTATION  OF APL\1100 (OR AN ATTEMPT TO RUN     @G@@@@ SUCH  A PROGY
)@@G@@GRAM ON A DIFFERENT MACHINE) COULD CAUSE THE RESULTS OF     @ @@@@ SUCH GZ
)@@G@@STATEMENTS TO CHANGE.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  5.10. 2.   MASKIHA
)@@G@@NG OF VARIABLE NAMES    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AS  MENTIONED ABOVE IN HB
)@@G@@THE SECTIONS ON THE  )SI  COMMAND AND     @G@@@@ IN  FUNCTION EDITING,  HC
)@@G@@VARIABLE NAMES SPECIFIED ON THE HEADER LINE     @G@@@@ OF  A  FUNCTION  HD
)@@G@@AND  LABEL  NAMES WITHIN THE FUNCTION ARE 'LOCAL'     @G@@@@ VARIABLES OHE
)@@G@@F THAT FUNCTION.  IT IS POSSIBLE FOR THE LOCAL VARIABLE     @G@@@@ NAMESHF
)@@G@@  OF  A FUNCTION TO BE THE SAME AS THE NAMES OF OTHER OBJECTS     @G@@@@HG
)@@G@@ IN THE WORKSPACE.  WHENEVER A FUNCTION STARTS EXECUTION, ITS LOCAL     HH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VARIABLES  ARE  DEFINED AND TAKE PRECEDENCE OVER ANY OTHER OBJECTHI
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ IN  THE  WORKSPACE  WHICH MAY HAVE THE SAME NAME.   THIS 'MHJ
)@@G@@ASKING'     @G@@@@ TAKES PLACE EACH TIME A FUNCTION IS USED AND CAN EXTEHK
)@@G@@ND THROUGH AN     @G@@@@ ARBITRARY  DEPTH  OF  FUNCTION NESTING (I.E.  FHL
)@@G@@UNCTIONS WHICH CALL     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRHM
)@@G@@ELIMINARY)                           5- 13@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@HN
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ OTHER  FUNCTIONS  WHICH IN TURN.  .  .).   IN ALL CASES,  THO
)@@G@@HE MOST     @G@@@@ RECENT DEFINITION OF THE NAME (I.E.  THE ONE WHICH APHP
)@@G@@PEARS NEAREST     @G@@@@ THE  TOP  OF  THE  PASE  IN AN  )SIV  DISPLAY) HQ
)@@G@@IS THE ONE WHICH IS     @[@@@@ USED.@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  PRINCIHR
)@@G@@PAL  CAUSE  FOR  CONFUSION OCCURS WHEN A FUNCTION     @G@@@@ REFERS  TO HS
)@@G@@ AN  OBJECT  WHICH  IS  NOT ONE OF ITS LOCAL VARIABLES.     @B@@@@ CONSIHT
)@@G@@DER THE FUNCTION  FUNC  DEFINED BY  @[@@@@      @ @@@@               $F HU
)@@G@@Z $S FUNC Y @A@@@@           [1]    Z $S  $EY   $F    @[@@@@      @F@@@@HV
)@@G@@ WITH THE FUNCTION DEFINED AS ABOVE, THE FOLLOWING STATEMENTS     @[@@@@HW
)@@G@@      @^@@@@                X $S  3 @ @@@@                FUNC  '2$RX'  HX
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ WILL  YIELD  AS A RESULT THE NUMERIC VECTOR  3  3 .  HY
)@@G@@ ON THE OTHER     @B@@@@ HAND, IF  FUNC  WERE DEFINED INSTEAD AS  @[@@@@HZ
)@@G@@      @ @@@@                $F Z $S FUNC X@A@@@@           [1]     X $S IA
)@@G@@ $EX   $F   @[@@@@      @G@@@@ (NOTICE THAT ONLY THE NAME OF THE RIGHT AIB
)@@G@@RGUMENT HAS CHANGED) THEN     @^@@@@ THE SAME TWO STATEMENTS@[@@@@      IC
)@@G@@@^@@@@                X $S  3 @ @@@@                FUNC  '2$RX'  @[@@@@ID
)@@G@@      @G@@@@ WILL YIELD THE CHARACTER VECTOR  2$R  AS A RESULT.  IN BOTHIE
)@@G@@ CASES,     @E@@@@ THE STATEMENT EXECUTED AT LINE 1 OF  FUNC  WAS EFFECTIF
)@@G@@IVELY @[@@@@      @ @@@@                Z $S  2 $R X  @[@@@@      @G@@@@IG
)@@G@@ IN THE FIRST CASE, THE VALUE OF  X  USED WAS THE GLOBAL NUMERIC  3     IH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ;   IN THE SECOND CASE,  IT WAS THE LOCAL VARIABLE  X ,  I.E.  THII
)@@G@@E     @ @@@@ CHARACTER STRING  '2$RX'.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  IJ
)@@G@@ANOMALY NOTED ABOVE DOES NOT DEPEND UPON THE USE OF THE     @G@@@@ UNQUOIK
)@@G@@TE  OPERATOR - IT IS A DIRECT CONSEQUENCE OF MASKING.   FOR A     @G@@@@IL
)@@G@@ SIMILAR  RESULT,  CONSIDER THE TWO FUNCTIONS  PTOT  AND  QTOT  DE-     IM
)@@G@@@]@@@@ FINED BY:  @[@@@@      @D@@@@       $F Z $S PTOT A               IN
)@@G@@$F Z $S QTOT B    @D@@@@   [1]    Z $S A+C   $F         [1]    Z $S PTOTIO
)@@G@@ B $F @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WITH  THESE  FUNCTIONS  DEFINED  AS  ABOVE,   TIP
)@@G@@HE  RESULT  OF  THE     @]@@@@ STATEMENTS @[@@@@      @^@@@@            IQ
)@@G@@    C $S 5  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  IR
)@@G@@                         5- 14@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@IS
)@@G@@                QTOT  3 @[@@@@      @G@@@@ WOULD BE  8 ,  BUT IF THE FUNIT
)@@G@@CTION  QTOT  HAD BEEN DEFINED INSTEAD     @[@@@@ AS   @[@@@@      @ @@@@IU
)@@G@@                $F Z $S QTOT C@A@@@@           [1]     Z $S PTOT C  $F  IV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @^@@@@ THEN THE RESULT OF     @[@@@@      @^@@@@            IW
)@@G@@    C $S 5  @^@@@@                QTOT  3 @[@@@@      @#@@@@ WOULD BE  6IX
)@@G@@ .    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THESE  EXAMPLES SHOULD MAKE IT CLEAR THATIY
)@@G@@ ONE SHOULD BE VERY     @G@@@@ CAUTIOUS  IN  REFERRING  TO  NON-LOCAL  VIZ
)@@G@@ARIABLES IN THE BODY OF A     @G@@@@ DEFINED FUNCTION.  ONE WAY OF AVOIDJA
)@@G@@ING CONFLICTS WHICH COULD ARISE     @G@@@@ IS  BY  ADOPTING  A  CONVENTIJB
)@@G@@ON  FOR THE NAMING OF LOCAL VARIABLES     @G@@@@ WITHIN FUNCTIONS,  FOR JC
)@@G@@EXAMPLE, BY HAVING ALL LOCAL VARIABLE NAMES     @G@@@@ IN  A  PARTICULARJD
)@@G@@  FUNCTION  START WITH A PARTICULAR LETTER OF THE     @]@@@@ ALPHABET.  JE
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)              JF
)@@G@@             6-  1@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @F@@@@  6.   DIFFEJG
)@@G@@RENCES BETWEEN APL\1100 AND OTHER IMPLEMENTATIONS     @[@@@@      @[@@@@JH
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       A  GREAT  DEAL  OF EFFORT HAS BEEN EXPENDJI
)@@G@@ED TO MAKE APL\1100     @G@@@@ COMPATIBLE  WITH  OTHER APL PROCESSORS.  JJ
)@@G@@ THERE ARE NO DIRECT CON-     @G@@@@ FLICTS  IN  THE  SOURCE LANGUAGE THJK
)@@G@@AT WE KNOW OF;  ALL DIFFERENCES     @G@@@@ FALL  INTO  THREE  BROAD CATEJL
)@@G@@GORIES:   (1) TERMINAL-DEPENDENT FEA-     @G@@@@ TURES,   (2)  EXTENSIONJM
)@@G@@S  AND (3) FEATURES WHICH HAVE NOT YET BEEN     @#@@@@ IMPLEMENTED.     JN
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @B@@@@  6. 1.   TERMINAL DEPENDENT FJO
)@@G@@EATURES     @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 1. 1.   CHARAJP
)@@G@@CTER SET    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  POWER  AND UTILITY OF APL DERIJQ
)@@G@@VE TO A GREAT EXTENT FROM     @G@@@@ THE WEALTH OF PRIMITIVE OPERATORS DJR
)@@G@@EFINED.  DR. IVERSON'S ORIGINAL     @G@@@@ WORK  [1]  ON  THE  LANGUAGE JS
)@@G@@ WAS  NOT  DIRECTED TOWARD A SPECIFIC     @G@@@@ COMPUTER  IMPLEMENTATIOJT
)@@G@@N OF IT - HENCE UNIQUE SYMBOLS WERE DEFINED     @G@@@@ FOR  THE  OPERATOJU
)@@G@@RS WITHOUT REGARD FOR THE LIMITATIONS OF ANY PAR-     @G@@@@ TICULAR  COJV
)@@G@@MPUTER  PERIPHERAL.    A SPECIAL TYPE BALL HAS BEEN DE-     @G@@@@ SIGNEJW
)@@G@@D  FOR  THE  IBM  SELECTRIC TYPEWRITER WHICH HAS THE REQUIRED     @G@@@@JX
)@@G@@ SYMBOLS;   A 'DANCING BLOCK' FOR THE MODEL 37 TELETYPE ALSO EXISTS     JY
)@@G@@@G@@@@ WITH THEM.  THE ENTIRE SET OF SYMBOLS USED IN APL IS WELL OVER 12JZ
)@@G@@8     @G@@@@ -  EVEN  WHEN  USING TERMINAL DEVICES WITH SPECIAL PRINT ELKA
)@@G@@EMENTS,     @G@@@@ MANY APL CHARACTERS MUST BE FORMED BY BACKSPACING ANDKB
)@@G@@ OVERSTRIKING     @ @@@@ TWO OF THE OTHER SYMBOLS.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@KC
)@@G@@       FEW  1100  SERIES COMPUTER USERS HAVE ACCESS TO TERMINALS OF     KD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  ABOVE  TYPE;   MOST OF THEM USE MODEL 33 TELETYPES OR SIMILAKE
)@@G@@R     @G@@@@ DEVICES,   WHICH  ARE  LIMITED  TO  63  PRINTABLE CHARACTERKF
)@@G@@S.   IN     @G@@@@ ADDITION, APL\1100 WAS DESIGNED TO ACCEPT BATCH INPUTKG
)@@G@@ (FROM CARDS)     @G@@@@ IN  ADDITION  TO  TERMINAL  INPUT - THE FIELDATKH
)@@G@@A CARD CODE IS ALSO     @G@@@@ LIMITED  TO  63  NON-BLANK  CHARACTERS.  KI
)@@G@@  AS  A  CONSEQUENCE,   A     @G@@@@ CHARACTER  SET  HAD  TO BE DEFINED KJ
)@@G@@WHICH WOULD USE NO MORE THAN 63     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS;   THE  MOST NOTICKK
)@@G@@EABLE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN APL\1100 AND     @G@@@@ SIMILAR  APL TERMINAL SKL
)@@G@@YSTEMS IS IN THE USE OF THIS CHARACTER SET,     @C@@@@ AND THE RESULTINGKM
)@@G@@ APPEARANCE OF APL OUTPUT.    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       BECAUSE  THIS  MAKN
)@@G@@NUAL  WAS  PREPARED  FOR PRINTING ON A LINE     @G@@@@ PRINTER WITH ONLYKO
)@@G@@ 63 PRINTABLE CHARACTERS, THE 63 CHARACTER SET IS     @G@@@@ USED  THROUKP
)@@G@@GHOUT  IT.    FOR  THE MOST PART,  APL CHARACTERS WHICH     @G@@@@ CANNOKQ
)@@G@@T  BE  REPRESENTED  WITH  A  SINGLE  CHARACTER IN THE SET ARE     @G@@@@KR
)@@G@@ REPRESENTED  BY  DIGRAPHS  - I.E. A COMBINATION OF TWO CHARACTERS.     KS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IT  IS IMPORTANT TO REALIZE THAT APL\1100 CONSIDERS DIGRAPHS AS IKT
)@@G@@F     @G@@@@ THEY  WERE A SINGLE CHARACTER.   SINCE THE CONTENTS OF AN AKU
)@@G@@PL\1100     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)  KV
)@@G@@                         6-  2@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@KW
)@@G@@ WORKSPACE  ARE  INDEPENDENT  OF THE TERMINAL DEVICE USED TO CREATE     KX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IT,   A USER WITH ACCESS TO A TERMINAL WITH THE FULL CHARACTER SEKY
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ (SUCH  AS  AN IBM 2741) CAN FREELY USE WORKSPACES WHICH WERKZ
)@@G@@E INPUT     @G@@@@ FROM A TELETYPE OR A CARD DECK.  A SUMMARY OF THE 63-LA
)@@G@@CHARACTER SET     @ @@@@ IS CONTAINED IN APPENDIX A.  @[@@@@      @G@@@@LB
)@@G@@       APL\1100  USERS  WHO  HAVE  ACCESS  TO  TERMINALS  WHICH CAN     LC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ GENERATE THE APL 'REFERENCE' CHARACTER SET (E.G. IBM 2741'S OR TTLD
)@@G@@Y     @G@@@@ 37'S  WITH AN APPROPRIATE PRINT BLOCK) ARE NOT NECESSARILY LE
)@@G@@LIMITED     @G@@@@ TO  THE 63-CHARACTER TELETYPE SET.   APL\1100 HAS BEELF
)@@G@@N DESIGNED TO     @G@@@@ ACCEPT THE ENTIRE REFERENCE SET AT SITES WHERE LG
)@@G@@SUCH DEVICES EXIST.     @G@@@@ THE  USE  OF SUCH TERMINALS REQUIRES THATLH
)@@G@@ BOTH APL\1100 AND EXEC 8     @G@@@@ BE  CONFIGURED  TO  RECOGNIZE  THEMLI
)@@G@@.   USERS WHO HAVE SUCH DEVICES     @G@@@@ SHOULD  CHECK  WITH  THEIR  LLJ
)@@G@@OCAL SITE MANAGEMENT TO DETERMINE THE     @F@@@@ CONVENTIONS NEEDED FOR LK
)@@G@@THEIR USE IN A PARTICULAR EXEC 8 SYSTEM.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@LL
)@@G@@  6. 1. 2.   BACKSPACING@[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  INPUT EDITING FEATLM
)@@G@@URES OF MOST APL SYSTEMS ARE SOMEWHAT     @G@@@@ BUILT AROUND THE USE OFLN
)@@G@@ THE IBM 2741 COMMUNICATIONS TERMINAL AS AN     @G@@@@ INPUT DEVICE.  INLO
)@@G@@ PARTICULAR, THEY TAKE ADVANTAGE OF THE FACT THAT     @G@@@@ SUCH  TERMILP
)@@G@@NALS HAVE A BACKSPACING CAPABILITY,  AND IT IS POSSIBLE     @G@@@@ TO  ILQ
)@@G@@NSERT  CHARACTERS  IN  A LINE BY BACKSPACING AND OVERSTRIKING     @G@@@@LR
)@@G@@ BLANKS.    THE  MODELS  33  AND  35 TELETYPES CANNOT BE PHYSICALLY     LS
)@@G@@@]@@@@ BACKSPACED.@[@@@@      @G@@@@       SINCE  MOST  UNIVAC  1100  SELT
)@@G@@RIES USERS HAVE TELETYPES,  THE     @G@@@@ EDITING  FEATURES  OF APL\110LU
)@@G@@0 HAD TO BE GEARED TO THE LIMITATIONS     @F@@@@ OF THIS DEVICE.  THIS HLV
)@@G@@AS RESULTED IN THE FOLLOWING CONVENTIONS: @[@@@@      @G@@@@       (1)  LW
)@@G@@THE  NORMAL EXEC 8 CONVENTIONS WITH REGARD TO EDITING A     @F@@@@      LX
)@@G@@      LINE   BEFORE  TRANSMITTING  IT  TO  THE  PROGRAM  ARE@G@@@@      LY
)@@G@@      EFFECTIVE.    AN  ENTIRE LINE MAY BE CANCELLED (AND NOT     @G@@@@LZ
)@@G@@            TRANSMITTED)  BY  TYPING  A  QUESTION MARK.   A LOGICAL     MA
)@@G@@@G@@@@            BACKSPACE  AND ERASE IS EFFECTED BY TYPING A LEFT ARROMB
)@@G@@W     @G@@@@            (UNDERLINE  ON  SOME TELETYPES).   THIS ERASES TMC
)@@G@@HE LAST     @G@@@@            SIGNIFICANT CHARACTER ON THE LINE;  TWO SUMD
)@@G@@CCESSIVE LEFT     @G@@@@            ARROWS ERASES THE LAST 2 CHARACTERS,ME
)@@G@@  ETC. ON SOME 1100     @G@@@@            SYSTEMS,   THE DOUBLE QUOTE CHMF
)@@G@@ARACTER (UPPER CASE 2) IS     @G@@@@            USED AS THE CHARACTER DEMG
)@@G@@LETE, INSTEAD OF THE LEFT ARROW     @F@@@@            (UNDERLINE).     OMH
)@@G@@N   THESE  SYSTEMS,   THE  ALTERNATE@G@@@@            CHARACTERS  $W  ANMI
)@@G@@D  $H  MUST  BE  USED  FOR  QUAD  AND     @G@@@@            QUOTE-QUAD. MJ
)@@G@@   SIMILARLY,   THE QUESTION MARK (USED FOR     @G@@@@            ROLL  MK
)@@G@@AND  DEAL) MUST BE ENTERED AS THE ALTERNATE,   $Q     @^@@@@            ML
)@@G@@FROM TTY.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       (2)  THE  MECHANISM  FOR  MAKING  CMM
)@@G@@HANGES  TO THE INDIVIDUAL     @G@@@@            LINES  OF THE BODY OF A MN
)@@G@@FUNCTION HAVE BEEN CHANGED;  IN     @G@@@@            PARTICULAR  ["N]  MO
)@@G@@AND [N"M] FUNCTION DIFFERENTLY.   FOR     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIMP
)@@G@@DE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)                           6-  3@[@@@@      MQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @E@@@@            DETAILS, SEE THE CHAPTER ON FUMR
)@@G@@NCTION DEFINITION.@[@@@@      @G@@@@        THE  CHANGES  TO  LINE EDITIMS
)@@G@@NG ARE EFFECTIVE EVEN IF ONE IS     @G@@@@ USING  A TERMINAL SUCH AS THEMT
)@@G@@ IBM 2741 ON WHICH THE FULL CHARACTER     @#@@@@ SET IS AVAILABLE.@[@@@@MU
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  6. 2.   EXTENSIONS    @[@@@@      MV
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       SEVERAL  MINOR  EXTENSIONS  TO  THE  APL  LANGUMW
)@@G@@AGE HAVE BEEN     @G@@@@ INCORPORATED  INTO  APL\1100.    THESE  EXTENSIMX
)@@G@@ONS  ARE ALL UPWARD     @B@@@@ COMPATIBLE FROM OTHER VERSIONS OF APL.   MY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @A@@@@  6. 2. 1.   TRACE AND STOP VECTORS @[@@@@MZ
)@@G@@      @G@@@@       THERE  ARE  NO RESTRICTIONS ON THE USE OF THE TRACE ANA
)@@G@@ND STOP     @G@@@@ VECTORS  (EXCEPT,   OF  COURSE,  THAT THE PARTICULAR NB
)@@G@@FUNCTION MUST     @G@@@@ EXIST);  THESE QUANTITIES MAY BE USED IN ANY APNC
)@@G@@L EXPRESSION.  WHEN     @G@@@@ NONE  OF THE STATEMENTS IN A FUNCTION HAVND
)@@G@@E THEIR TRACE (STOP) BITS     @G@@@@ ON,   THE  VALUE  OF  THE TRACE (STNE
)@@G@@OP) VECTOR FOR THAT FUNCTION IS     @^@@@@ DEFINED TO BE  $IO .   @[@@@@NF
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 2. 2.   MONADIC BRANCHING@[@@@@      @G@@@@NG
)@@G@@       WHEN  THE  RIGHT ARGUMENT OF A MONADIC BRANCH ($G) IS A NULL     NH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VECTOR, CONTROL PASSES TO THE LEFT OF THE $G ON THE SAME LINE; THNI
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ VALUE OF THE BRANCH OPERATOR IS NULL.  IF THERE IS NOTHING NJ
)@@G@@MORE TO     @G@@@@ BE  EXECUTED  (I.E.  THE $G WAS ON THE FAR LEFT OF THNK
)@@G@@E LINE),  THE     @B@@@@ NEXT STATEMENT IN SEQUENCE IS EXECUTED.  @[@@@@NL
)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  6. 2. 3.   COMMENTS   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      NM
)@@G@@ THE LAMP SYMBOL ($:) MAY BE USED TO PUT COMMENTS ON ANY LINE     @F@@@@NN
)@@G@@ OF   APL   CODE   EXCEPT  A  FUNCTION  HEADER  LINE.    IN  OTHER@E@@@@NO
)@@G@@ IMPLEMENTATIONS, A COMMENT LINE MAY CONTAIN ONLY COMMENTS. @[@@@@      NP
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 2. 4.   THE QUOTE-QUAD   @[@@@@      @G@@@@      NQ
)@@G@@ IN  SOME  IMPLEMENTATIONS,   IT  IS  NOT POSSIBLE TO USE THE     @G@@@@NR
)@@G@@ QUOTE-QUAD  OPERATOR  FOR  A  TYPE  AND READ FUNCTION.  IN OTHERS,     NS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SUCCESSIVE USE OF THE QUOTE-QUAD FOR OUTPUT WILL PLACE THE RESULTNT
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ OF THE LAST QUOTE-QUAD IN THE PROPER PLACE IN THE BUFFER, BNU
)@@G@@UT WILL     @G@@@@ CAUSE  THE  PREVIOUS  BUFFER  CONTENTS  TO BE SET TO NV
)@@G@@BLANKS.   FOR     @G@@@@ COMPLETE INFORMATION ON THE FUNCTIONING OF QUOTNW
)@@G@@E-QUAD, SEE CHAPTER     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRNX
)@@G@@ELIMINARY)                           6-  4@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@NY
)@@G@@      @[@@@@ 6.   @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @#@@@@  6. 2. 5.   )FUZZ@[@@@@NZ
)@@G@@      @E@@@@      THE )FUZZ COMMAND HAS BEEN ADDED (SEE CHAPTER 4).     OA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 2. 6.   )COPY AND )PCOPY @[@@@@      OB
)@@G@@@G@@@@      IN SOME IMPLEMENTATIONS,  ONLY ONE OBJECT MAY BE SPECIFIED TOC
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ BE  COPIED  ON  A  )COPY  OR  )PCOPY,   RATHER THAN A LIST OD
)@@G@@OF SUCH     @G@@@@ OBJECTS.    AS  OF LEVEL 4.0,  A MINOR ERROR IN APL\1OE
)@@G@@100 EXISTS IN     @G@@@@ WHICH  THE  LIST  OF  NAMES OF OBJECTS NOT COPIOF
)@@G@@ED MAY SOMETIMES BE     @G@@@@ INCOMPLETE.    IF  THE  DIAGNOSTIC  'NOT OG
)@@G@@ COPIED' OCCURS,  ONE CAN     @G@@@@ DETERMINE WHICH OBJECTS WERE NOT COOH
)@@G@@PIED BY EXAMINING THE OUTPUT OF     @#@@@@ )VARS AND )FNS.  @[@@@@      OI
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 2. 7.   RANGE OF NUMBERS @[@@@@      @G@@@@      OJ
)@@G@@ CERTAIN PARAMETERS IN APL ARE DETERMINED BY THE WORD SIZE OF     @G@@@@OK
)@@G@@ THE  OBJECT  COMPUTER.    THE  UNIVAC  1100 SERIES HAS A WORD SIZE     OL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ LARGER THAN MANY OTHER COMPUTERS, HENCE THE RANGE OF NUMBERS WHICOM
)@@G@@H     @G@@@@ CAN  BE  EXPRESSED  IS ALSO LARGER.   THE EXPONENT OF A NUMON
)@@G@@BER MAY     @G@@@@ EXTEND  TO THREE,  RATHER THAN TWO DIGITS;  IN ADDITIOO
)@@G@@ON,  INTERNAL     @G@@@@ CALCULATIONS  ARE DONE WITH APPROXIMATELY 18 DEOP
)@@G@@CIMAL DIGITS RATHER     @]@@@@ THAN 16.   @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE IOQ
)@@G@@DENTITY VALUES FOR THE FLOOR AND CEILING VALUES ARE THE     @G@@@@ LARGEOR
)@@G@@ST  POSITIVE AND NEGATIVE NUMBERS WHICH CAN BE REPRESENTED ON     @G@@@@OS
)@@G@@ THE MACHINE BEING USED.   IN APL\1100,  THE ABSOLUTE VALUE OF THIS     OT
)@@G@@@]@@@@ QUANTITY IS@[@@@@      @A@@@@           8.98846567431157954E307  OU
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@ BECAUSE  OF  THE EXPANDED RANGE OF EXPONENTS,  APL\11OV
)@@G@@00 IS ABLE TO     @G@@@@ PROPERLY  HANDLE  CALCULATIONS  WHICH MIGHT OTHOW
)@@G@@ERWISE GIVE RISE TO     @C@@@@ DOMAIN ERRORS.  FOR EXAMPLE, THE STATEMENOX
)@@G@@T     @[@@@@      @^@@@@           1E50#2E50    @[@@@@      @G@@@@ MAY  OY
)@@G@@CAUSE  A  DOMAIN  ERROR  IN OTHER SYSTEMS,  BUT APL\1100 WILL     @C@@@@OZ
)@@G@@ RESPOND WITH THE CORRECT ANSWER OF  2E100 .    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PA
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @A@@@@  6. 3.   UNIMPLEMENTED FEATURES    @[@@@@      @[@@@@PB
)@@G@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINARY)        PC
)@@G@@                   6-  5@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      PD
)@@G@@@A@@@@  6. 3. 1.   PRIMITIVE OPERATORS    @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE  PE
)@@G@@ONLY  APL  PRIMITIVE OPERATOR WHICH HAS NOT BEEN IMPLE-     @G@@@@ MENTEPF
)@@G@@D IS THE MATRIX INVERSION OPERATOR, DOMINO (HOWEVER FUNCTIONS     @G@@@@PG
)@@G@@ WHICH  WILL  ACHIEVE  THE  SAME  RESULTS  ARE  IN  THE WORKSPACE 1     PH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DOMINO).  IN ADDITION, THERE ARE MINOR RESTRICTIONS ON SOME OF THPI
)@@G@@E     @#@@@@ OTHER OPERATORS--@[@@@@      @F@@@@       (1)  ENCODE AND DPJ
)@@G@@ECODE WILL NOT ACCEPT RIGHT ARGUMENTS     @E@@@@            OF RANK GREAPK
)@@G@@TER THAN VECTOR (SEE CHAPTER 5).    @[@@@@      @E@@@@       (2)  THE INPL
)@@G@@NERMOST DIMENSION OF OPERANDS IN AN INNER @E@@@@            PRODUCT IS NPM
)@@G@@OT EXTENDED.  TO BE CONFORMABLE, THE@C@@@@            INNERMOST DIMENSIOPN
)@@G@@NS MUST BE EQUAL. @[@@@@      @F@@@@       (3)  'OVERTAKE' IS NOT OPERATPO
)@@G@@IONAL; NO VALUE IN THE LEFT   @F@@@@            OPERAND OF A 'TAKE' OPERPP
)@@G@@ATION MAY EXCEED THE LENGTH   @F@@@@            OF THE CORRESPONDING DIMPQ
)@@G@@ENSION OF THE RIGHT OPERAND.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 3. 2.  PR
)@@G@@ SYSTEM COMMANDS  @[@@@@      @G@@@@       THE COMMANDS  )GRP, )GRPS ANDPS
)@@G@@  )GROUPS  ARE NOT OPERATIONAL.     @G@@@@ IN  ADDITION,  THE COMMANDS  PT
)@@G@@)MSG,  )MSGN AND  )PORTS  DEPEND UPON     @G@@@@ THE  INSTALLATION  OF CPU
)@@G@@ERTAIN CHANGES TO THE EXEC 8 SYSTEM ITSELF.     @G@@@@ THESE  CHANGES MAPV
)@@G@@Y OR MAY NOT HAVE BEEN MADE AT A PARTICULAR SITE.     @G@@@@ IF  THEY HAPW
)@@G@@VE BEEN INSTALLED, THE COMMANDS WILL FUNCTION PROPERLY,     @F@@@@ IF NOPX
)@@G@@T, THEY WILL GIVE AN 'UNIMPLEMENTED FEATURE' DIAGNOSTIC.    @[@@@@      PY
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @ @@@@  6. 3. 3.   MISCELLANEOUS    @[@@@@      @G@@@@      PZ
)@@G@@ WHEN  AN  ERROR OCCURS IN THE EXECUTION OF AN APL STATEMENT,     @G@@@@QA
)@@G@@ THE OFFENDING STATEMENT IS PRINTED,  AND THE POSITION OF THE ERROR     QB
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IN  THE  STATEMENT IS MARKED.   FOR CERTAIN FEW TYPES OF ERRORS IQC
)@@G@@N     @F@@@@ APL\1100, THE MARKING OF THE POSITION OF THE ERROR IS NOT DQD
)@@G@@ONE.  @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @^@@@@  6. 4.   FUTURE PLANS  QE
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @G@@@@       AT  THE  PRESENT  TIME,   WORK  IS QF
)@@G@@BEING DONE ON APL\1100 TO     @G@@@@ IMPLEMENT  ALL OF THE FEATURES NOTEQG
)@@G@@D ABOVE AS BEING UNIMPLEMENTED.     @G@@@@ IN ADDITION, THE FOLLOWING MAQH
)@@G@@JOR AREAS OF EXTENSION ARE IN VARIOUS     @B@@@@ STAGES OF DESIGN AND/ORQI
)@@G@@ DEVELOPMENT:     @[@@@@      @B@@@@       (1)  VARIABLE SIZED WORKSPACEQJ
)@@G@@S     @[@@@@      @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRELIMINQK
)@@G@@ARY)                           6-  6@[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      QL
)@@G@@@ @@@@       (2)  FILE INPUT/OUTPUT @[@@@@      @D@@@@       (3)  PRIMITQM
)@@G@@IVES FOR LIST PROCESSING OPERATIONS @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO QN

)@@G@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @C@@@@  7. 1.   TTQQ
)@@G@@Y/FIELDATA CHARACTER SET SUMMARY    @[@@@@      @[@@@@      @[@@@@      QR
)@@G@@@G@@@@       THE  APL CHARACTER SET FOR TELETYPES IS AS CLOSE AS POSSIBLQS
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ TO  THE  SET USED ON THE IBM 2741 TERMINAL.   ALL CHARACTERQT
)@@G@@S WHICH     @G@@@@ ARE  THE  SAME ON BOTH DEVICES HAVE THE SAME MEANING QU
)@@G@@ON EACH, I.E.     @G@@@@ THE ALFAMERICS AND SUCH SYMBOLS AS + AND -;  UNQV
)@@G@@DERLINED ALFABETICS     @#@@@@ ARE NOT ALLOWED. @G@@@@       THE  REMAINQW
)@@G@@ING CHARACTERS ARE REPRESENTED BY EITHER DEFINING     @G@@@@ SOME  OF  TQX
)@@G@@HE NORMALLY UNUSED TTY SYMBOLS,  OR USING DIGRAPHS (TWO     @G@@@@ TTY  QY
)@@G@@CHARS  FOR ONE APL CHARACTER).   MOST DIGRAPHS USE THE DOLLAR     @G@@@@QZ
)@@G@@ SIGN AS THE 1ST CHARACTER,  SOME USE THE MASTER SPACE.   EXCEPT AS     RA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NOTED,   THE  FIELDATA CHARACTER SET USES THE SAME GRAPHICS AS THRB
)@@G@@E     @D@@@@ TTY SET.  THE FOLLOWING TABLE GIVES THE TRANSLATION: @[@@@@RC
)@@G@@      @D@@@@ APL USAGE            TELETYPE/FIELDATA        NOTES  @F@@@@RD

)@@G@@N,$A,$O,@A,@O     @C@@@@ LESS,LEQ,EQ,NEQ,GEQ,GTR     <,$<,=,$=,$>,>     RL

)@@G@@ DEL (LOCKED FUNC DEFN)      $K     @F@@@@ LAMP                        $SI
)@@G@@:     FOR COMMENTS (SEE ALSO BELOW) @F@@@@ DELTA                       $SJ
)@@G@@M     MARK CHAR FOR TRACEVECTOR, AND@C@@@@                              SK
)@@G@@      STOPVECTOR  @F@@@@ SUPERSCRIPT BAR             &      NEGATIVE CONSL
)@@G@@STANT INDICATOR   @C@@@@ BRANCH OR TRANSFER          $G     FOR 'GO TO' SM
)@@G@@@[@@@@      @G@@@@       IN  ADDITION  TO  THE  SYMBOLS ABOVE,  SEVERAL SN
)@@G@@OTHER USES OF     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS  ARE DEFINED WHICH ARE NOT REALLY PASO
)@@G@@RT OF THE LANGUAGE,     @B@@@@ BUT WHICH ARE NEEDED FOR HOUSKEEPING---  SP
)@@G@@@F@@@@      (1)  TO   ESCAPE  FROM  A  QUOTE-QUAD  INPUT  LOOP,   USE  2SQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@           DOLLARSIGNS TOGETHER,  WHICH CORRESPONDS TO OVERSTRIKINSR
)@@G@@G     @ @@@@           O-U-T ON A 2741.   @G@@@@      (2)  IN  FUNCTION SS
)@@G@@ EDITING,   DELETION  OF  AN ENTIRE LINE IS     @G@@@@           EFFECTEST
)@@G@@D  BY ENTERING A LINE CONSISTING OF A SINGLE LAMP     @G@@@@           (SU
)@@G@@$:),  WITH NO COMMENTS FOLLOWING IT.   ENTERING A BLANK     @C@@@@      SV
)@@G@@     LINE WILL NOT CAUSE LINE DELETION.   @G@@@@      (3)  IT IS NOT POSSW
)@@G@@SIBLE TO CONTINUE A CHARACTER CONSTANT FROM     @G@@@@           ONE  LISX
)@@G@@NE  TO  THE NEXT BY OMITTING THE RIGHTMOST SINGLE     @G@@@@           QSY
)@@G@@UOTE-A  'LEXICAL  ERROR'  WILL  RESULT.    THE FUNCTION     @G@@@@      SZ
)@@G@@     'TEXT'  IN  THE  PUBLIC WORKSPACE '1 WSFNS' IS AVAILABLE     @D@@@@TA
)@@G@@           FOR THE INPUT OF CHARACTER  CONSTANTS.     @G@@@@      (4)  TTB
)@@G@@HE  TELETYPE 'BREAK' KEY SERVES THE ATTENTION FUNCTION.     @G@@@@      TC
)@@G@@     HITTING  BREAK  FOLLOWED  BY  (ON  THE  NEXT  LINE)  ANY     @G@@@@TD
)@@G@@           CHARACTER  OTHER  THAN  'X'  (USUALLY CARRIAGE RETURN IS     TE
)@@G@@@G@@@@           USED) WILL SUSPEND THE CURRENTLY EXECUTING APL FUNCTIONTF
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@           BUT  KEEP  YOU  SIGNED  ON  IN APL.   IN ACCORDANTG
)@@G@@CE WITH     @G@@@@           NORMAL EXEC8 PROCEDURES, BREAK FOLLOWED BY TH
)@@G@@'X' WILL TAKE     @F@@@@           YOU OUT OF APL, AND BACK TO THE EXEC8TI
)@@G@@ CONTROL MODE.    @G@@@@      (5)  SOME  VERSIONS  OF  THE  EXEC  8 SYSTTJ
)@@G@@EM DO NOT ALLOW THE     @G@@@@           INPUT OF THE CHARACTERS DOUBLE TK
)@@G@@QUOTE ("), NUMBER SIGN(#)     @G@@@@           OR  UP ARROW (^) FROM TELTL
)@@G@@ETYPES.  TO HANDLE THESE CASES,     @G@@@@           ALTERNATE  SYMBOLS TM
)@@G@@MAY BE USED FOR TELETYPE INPUT OF THE     @G@@@@           MULTIPLY QUADTN
)@@G@@, QUOTE-QUAD, TAKE AND DROP SYMBOLS.  THESE     @F@@@@           ALTERNATO
)@@G@@TES   ARE   DOLLARSIGN  PERCENT,  DOLLARSIGN  W,@G@@@@           DOLLARSTP
)@@G@@IGN H,  MASTER SPACE (I.E.  AT SIGN) T AND MASTER     @A@@@@           STQ
)@@G@@PACE D, RESPECTIVELY.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@A USER'S GUIDE TO APL\1100 (PRTR
