)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        1-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@GS
)@@G@@@^@@@@  1.   INTRODUCTION     @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  1. 1GT
)@@G@@.   THE NPL LANGUAGE    @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  1. 1. 1.   BACKGROUND GU
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL, WHICH STANDS FOR N.Y.U. PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE, IS AN EFGV
)@@G@@FORT OF     @G@@@@ THE  NEW  YORK  UNIVERSITY SYSTEMS DEVELOPMENT GROUP GW
)@@G@@TO PROVIDE TO     @G@@@@ THE  EXPERIENCED  USER OF THE UNIVAC 1108 AS MUGX
)@@G@@CH OF THE POWER AND     @G@@@@ FLEXIBILITY  OF  THE  1108 HARDWARE AND OGY
)@@G@@PERATING SYSTEM AS CAN BE     @G@@@@ MADE  AVAILABLE  IN  AN  INTERPRETIGZ
)@@G@@VE  PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE.   THE     @G@@@@ IMPETUS  FOR  THE  DEVELOPMENHA
)@@G@@T  OF NPL WAS PROVIDED BY THE SPECIAL     @G@@@@ NEEDS  IN  THE JOINT ARHB
)@@G@@EAS OF FILE DESIGN AND DATABASE MANAGEMENT.     @G@@@@ NPL  IS  AN  ATTEHC
)@@G@@MPT  TO PROVIDE THE DATABASE MANAGER AN EFFICIENT     @G@@@@ MEANS  OF  HD
)@@G@@RUNNING  BOTH  'ONE-SHOT' FILE MAINTENANCE ROUTINES AND     @G@@@@ HIGHLHE
)@@G@@Y  FORMATTED  FILE  DIAGNOSTIC  PROGRAMS.     NPL  HAS  GROWN     @G@@@@HF
)@@G@@ STEADILY,   HOWEVER,   AND  IS  NOW  ALSO  WELL  ADAPTED TO REPORT     HG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ GENERATION   AND   APPLICATIONS   REQUIRING   STRING   AND  SYMBOHH
)@@G@@L     @G@@@@ MANIPULATION,  IN ADDITION TO NUMERIC CALCULATIONS IN BOTH HI
)@@G@@INTEGER     @ @@@@ AND FLOATING POINT MODES.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  HJ
)@@G@@DISCUSSIONS  OF  THE  VARIOUS  NPL STATEMENTS ASSUME THAT THE     @G@@@@HK
)@@G@@ READER  HAS  SOME  ACQUAINTANCE WITH THE 'HIGHER LEVEL' LANGUAGES,     HL
)@@G@@@B@@@@ SUCH AS FORTRAN, ALGOL, OR EVEN BASIC.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  1. 1HM
)@@G@@. 2.   HIGHLIGHTS AND FEATURES@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  1. 1. 2. 1.   OPERATORHN
)@@G@@S     @@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  OFFERS  A  FULL COMPLEMENT OF OPERATORS FOR THE HO
)@@G@@EVALUATION OF     @E@@@@ ARITHMETIC, LOGICAL, RELATIONAL AND STRING EXPRHP
)@@G@@ESSIONS.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@  1. 1. 2. 2.   MIXED MODE IN NUMERIC EXPRHQ
)@@G@@ESSIONS     @@@@@@@G@@@@ MIXED  INTEGER  AND FLOATING POINT MODES IN EXPHR
)@@G@@RESSIONS IS HANDLED     @G@@@@ AUTOMATICALLY  BY  THE NPL INTERPRETER,  HS
)@@G@@AND THE USER PROGRAM NEED     @G@@@@ NOT  KEEP  TRACK  OF  THE  MODE OF HT
)@@G@@VARIABLES.   WHEN AN INTEGER IS     @G@@@@ REQUIRED AND THE MODE OF THE HU
)@@G@@ITEM IN QUESTION IS REAL, THE ITEM IS     @G@@@@ TRUNCATED.    LIKEWISE,HV
)@@G@@  AN INTEGER IS CONVERTED TO FLOATING POINT     @^@@@@ FORMAT IF NECESSAHW
)@@G@@RY.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NHX
)@@G@@PL   REV.23        1-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  1. 1. 2. 3HY
)@@G@@.   VARIABLES     @@@@@@@G@@@@ UNDIMENSIONED  VARIABLES HAVE FIXED ADDREHZ
)@@G@@SS ASSIGNMENTS PERMITTING     @G@@@@ FAST  RETRIEVAL  AND  STORAGE  OF  IA
)@@G@@RESULTS.     ARRAY  STORAGE  IS     @G@@@@ DYNAMICALLY  ALLOCATED  ALLOWIB
)@@G@@ING THE REDIMENSIONING OF SUBSCRIPTED     @G@@@@ VARIABLES  AS OFTEN AS IC
)@@G@@DESIRED.   THE DESCRIPTOR AND LOOKUP TABLES     @G@@@@ FOR  ARRAYS  HAVEID
)@@G@@  FIXED  ADDRESS  ASSIGNMENTS  FACILITATING QUICK     @ @@@@ REFERENCE BIE
)@@G@@Y THE INTERPRETER.@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  1. 1. 2. 4.   DYNAMIC STORAGE     IF
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ CORE  STORAGE  IS ALLOCATED AS NEEDED FOR PROGRAMS,  FUNCTIIG
)@@G@@ONS AND     @E@@@@ ARRAYS, WITH LITTLE USER COGNIZANCE OF STORAGE ALLOCAIH
)@@G@@TION. @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  1. 1. 2. 5.   STRING MANIPULATION @@@@@@@G@@@@II
)@@G@@ NPL  PROVIDES  FOR THE REFERENCE OF STRINGS AND STRING EXPRESSIONS     IJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AS  DISTINCT  DATA  TYPES,   AND  PROVIDES  OPERATORS  FOR  STRINIK
)@@G@@G     @C@@@@ MATCHING, CONCATENATION, REPLACEMENT, ETC.     @@@@@@@@@@@@IL
)@@G@@@ @@@@  1. 1. 2. 6.   GRAPH PLOTTING@E@@@@ INCLUDED IN NPL AS A BUILT-INIM
)@@G@@ ROUTINE IS A GRAPH PLOTTER.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@  1. 1. 2. 7.   COMPILERIN
)@@G@@/INTERPRETER INTERFACE  @@@@@@@F@@@@ PROGRAMS    CAN   SUBMIT   STRING  IO
)@@G@@ EXPRESSIONS   TO   THE   NPL @G@@@@ COMPILER/INTERPRETER FOR EVALUATIONIP
)@@G@@.   IN THIS WAY,  AN ASSIGNMENT     @G@@@@ STATEMENT CAN BE DYNAMICALLY IQ
)@@G@@FORMATTED AND EXECUTED AT RUN TIME BY     @G@@@@ ANY NPL PROGRAM.  ALL OIR
)@@G@@F THE FACILITIES NORMALLY AVAILABLE FOR USE     @D@@@@ IN NUMERIC EXPRESIS
)@@G@@SIONS MAY BE USED IN THIS MANNER.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  1. 1. 2. 8.   EXIT
)@@G@@EC8 INTERFACE     @@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  PROGRAMS  CAN MAKE ALMOST FULL USE OIU
)@@G@@F THE FACILITIES PROVIDED     @G@@@@ BY  THE  EXEC8 OPERATING SYSTEM THRIV
)@@G@@OUGH USE OF THE 'EXEC' AND 'ER'     @]@@@@ LINKAGES.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@IW
)@@G@@  1. 1. 2. 9.   INPUT/OUTPUT  @@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  PROVIDES MEANS FOR BOTH IX
)@@G@@BINARY AND FORMATTED I/O,  AS WELL AS     @B@@@@ FORMATTED CORE TO CORE IY
)@@G@@DATA TRANSFERS.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING IZ
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        1-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  1. 1. 2.10JA
)@@G@@.   DIAGNOSTICS   @@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  PROVIDES  EXTENSIVE  DIAGNOSTIC  MESJB
)@@G@@SAGES AT BOTH COMPILE AND     @G@@@@ EXECUTION TIME,  FACILITATING PROGRJC
)@@G@@AM DEBUGGING.   ADDITIONALLY, A     @G@@@@ STATEMENT  BY  STATEMENT  PROJD
)@@G@@GRAM  TRACE,   AND DIAGNOSTIC DUMPING     @G@@@@ FACILITIES  ARE AVAILABJE
)@@G@@LE,  AS WELL AS WALK BACK TRACE THROUGH ALL     @D@@@@ LEVELS OF PROGRAMJF
)@@G@@ EXECUTION IN THE EVENT OF AN ERROR.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEJG
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@JH
)@@G@@@#@@@@  2.   NPL SYNTAX @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 1.   INJI
)@@G@@TRODUCTION  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ TWO  CONVENTIONS WILL BE FOLLOWED IN THE JJ
)@@G@@SUBSEQUENT DISCUSSIONS OF     @G@@@@ NPL  SYNTAX:    1) ITEMS ENCLOSED IJK
)@@G@@N SQUARE BRACKETS ('[]') DENOTE     @G@@@@ OPTIONAL ELEMENTS,  THOSE WHIJL
)@@G@@CH MAY BE CODED AS SHOWN, BUT ARE NOT     @G@@@@ REQUIRED.    2)  ITEMS JM
)@@G@@ ENCLOSED IN ANGULAR BRACKETS ('<>') DENOTE     @G@@@@ METALINGUISTIC  EJN
)@@G@@LEMENTS,  I.E.,  BASIC UNITS OF SYNTAX,  WITH THE     @^@@@@ FOLLOWING AJO
)@@G@@BBREVIATIONS@@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@              <IDENT>  ANY IDENTIFIER     JP
)@@G@@@A@@@@              <VAR>    ANY VARIABLE @D@@@@              <STRING> AJQ
)@@G@@NY STRING OR STRING EXPRESSION@E@@@@              <EXPR>   ANY NUMERIC EJR
)@@G@@XPRESSION OR NUMBER     @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 2.   CONSTANTS     @@@@@@JS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A CONSTANT IS ONE OF THE FOLLOWING:   1) A DECIMAL INTEGER.JT
)@@G@@  2) AN     @G@@@@ OCTAL INTEGER.   3) A FLOATING POINT NUMBER.   4) A LJU
)@@G@@ITERAL STRING     @G@@@@ OF  SIX  OR  FEWER  CHARACTERS.    CONSTANTS  HJV
)@@G@@AVE  THE  FOLLOWING     @#@@@@ RESTRICTIONS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@      JW
)@@G@@             THE MAGNITUDE OF A CONSTANT MAY NOT@B@@@@                  JX
)@@G@@ EXCEED 34359738367.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@                   THE RANGE OJY
)@@G@@F A FLOATING POINT NUMBER IS  @E@@@@                   RESTRICTED TO APPJZ
)@@G@@ROXIMATELY 1.7E-38 TO   @ @@@@                   1.7E+38.   @@@@@@@@@@@@KA
)@@G@@@E@@@@                   AN OCTAL INTEGER IS A NUMBER PREFIXED    @E@@@@KB
)@@G@@                   WITH A ZERO, AND MAY NOT CONTAIN THE     @B@@@@      KC
)@@G@@             CHARACTER '8' OR '9'.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  2. 3.   LITERALSKD
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ LITERALS   ARE   DENOTED  BY  A  CHARACTER  STRING  SKE
)@@G@@URROUNDED  BY     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING KF
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ APOSTROPHESKG
)@@G@@.   AN APOSTROPHE THAT IS TO BE INCLUDED AS A PART OF A     @G@@@@ LITERKH
)@@G@@AL IS REPRESENTED BY TWO APOSTROPHES IN SUCCESSION.  THUS THE     @]@@@@KI
)@@G@@ STRING:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@                 ISN'T IT A FINE DAY?     KJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@ IS REPRESENTED BY THE LITERAL:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@KK
)@@G@@                 'ISN''T IT A FINE DAY?'  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ LITERALS  OKL
)@@G@@F  SIX  CHARACTERS  OR  FEWER  MAY  BE  USED IN NUMERIC     @G@@@@ CONTEKM
)@@G@@XTS.   IN THIS CASE,  THE LITERAL WILL BE RIGHT JUSTIFIED AND     @C@@@@KN
)@@G@@ ZERO FILLED TO THE LEFT IN A COMPUTER WORD.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF THKO
)@@G@@E LETTER  'B'  IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWS A LITERAL,    THE COUNT OF     @G@@@@KP
)@@G@@ CHARACTERS IN THAT LITERAL WILL BE ROUNDED TO THE NEXT MULTIPLE OF     KQ
)@@G@@@F@@@@ SIX, AND THE LITERAL ITSELF WILL BE BLANK FILLED TO THIS COUNT.  KR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ EXAMPLE:   @A@@@@                             'AB'   KS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@F@@@@ IS A TWO CHARACTER LITERAL, COMPOSED OF THE CHARACTER STRINKT
)@@G@@G AB. @@@@@@@A@@@@                            'AB'B   @@@@@@@F@@@@ BECOMKU
)@@G@@ES THE SIX CHARACTER LITERAL 'AB    '.  THE CONSTRUCTION    @@@@@@@A@@@@KV
)@@G@@                            ''B     @@@@@@@D@@@@ CREATES A SIX CHARACTERKW
)@@G@@ LITERAL CONSISTING OF SPACES.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NOTE:    IN  SOME  CASEKX
)@@G@@S  IT WILL BE NECESSARY TO PREFIX A NUMERIC     @G@@@@ LITERAL  WITH  A KY
)@@G@@ REDUNDANT  UNARY  PLUS  SIGN OR SURROUND IT WITH     @G@@@@ REDUNDANT  KZ
)@@G@@PARENTHESES  TO  ELIMINATE CONFUSION BETWEEN USAGE AS A     @G@@@@ NUMERLA
)@@G@@IC  LITERAL  AND A STRING EXPRESSION.   THIS IS REQUIRED ONLY     @D@@@@LB
)@@G@@ WHEN A DATA ITEM MAY BE EITHER STRING OR NUMERIC.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@LC
)@@G@@  2. 4.   IDENTIFIERS   @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NELD
)@@G@@W YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  3@@@@@@LE
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 4. 1.   DESCRIPTION@@@@@@@G@@@@ IDENTIFIERSLF
)@@G@@  ARE  THE  NAMES  OF STATEMENT LABELS, NPL DIRECTIVES,     @G@@@@ PROGRLG
)@@G@@AMS,  FUNCTIONS AND VARIABLES.   AN IDENTIFIER IS A STRING OF     @G@@@@LH
)@@G@@ FROM  ONE  TO  SIX LETTERS,  NUMBERS AND DOLLAR SIGNS,  WHICH MUST     LI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ START  WITH  A  LETTER.    (STATEMENT  LABELS  ARE  RESTRICTED  TLJ
)@@G@@O     @ @@@@ FIVE CHARACTERS, HOWEVER.)   @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ EXAMPLES OFLK
)@@G@@ IDENTIFIERS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                    A  STAT$  A1B2C3LL
)@@G@@  L$ABEL    @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  2. 4. 2.   NAME OPERATOR %  @@@@@@LM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE NAME OPERATOR IS USED WHEN THE NAME OF,  RATHER THAN ANY VALULN
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ ASSOCIATED   WITH,    AN  IDENTIFIER  IS  REQUIRED  IN  A  LO
)@@G@@NUMERIC     @G@@@@ EXPRESSION.   THE NAME OPERATOR IS A UNARY OPERATOR, LP
)@@G@@ AND MAY ONLY     @D@@@@ BE USED BY PREFIXING IT TO AN IDENTIFIER.  EXAMLQ
)@@G@@PLES: @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@                    %IDENT  %B  %CORE$    @@@@@@LR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  FOLLOWING  STATEMENT  RESULTS  IN  THE  VARIABLE  A0'SLS
)@@G@@  BEING     @E@@@@ ASSIGNED THE VALUE OF THE CONTENTS OF THE VARIABLE H3LT
)@@G@@.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@                   A0 = H3    @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@LU
)@@G@@ HOWEVER, WERE THE FOLLOWING STATEMENT EXECUTED:@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@      LV
)@@G@@             A0 = %H3   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  VARIABLE  A0  WOULD  NOTLW
)@@G@@  BE  SET  EQUAL  TO THE VALUE OF THE     @G@@@@ CONTENTS  OF  H3, BUT WLX
)@@G@@OULD INSTEAD BE SET EQUAL TO THE NAME 'H3',     @A@@@@ RIGHT JUSTIFIED ALY
)@@G@@ND ZERO FILLED.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  2. 4. 3.   INDIRECT REFERENCLZ
)@@G@@E $   @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE   INDIRECT   IDENTIFIER  REFERENCE  IS  USED  TO MA
)@@G@@ RETRIEVE  AN     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING MB
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  4@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IDENTIFIER MC
)@@G@@ WHOSE  NAME  IS  NOT  EXPLICITLY  STATED.     INDIRECT     @G@@@@ REFERMD
)@@G@@ENCE  MAY  BE  USED  IN ANY CONTEXT IN WHICH AN IDENTIFIER IS     @]@@@@ME
)@@G@@ REQUIRED.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@ THE FORMAT OF AN INDIRECT IDENTIFIER REFEMF
)@@G@@RENCE IS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                         $(<EXPR>)  @A@@@@MG
)@@G@@              OR         $VARIABLE  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <EXPR>  IS  ANY  MH
)@@G@@NUMBER  OR NUMERIC EXPRESSION.   THE EFFECT IS TO     @G@@@@ CAUSE EVALUMI
)@@G@@ATION OF <EXPR>,  AND THE RESULTANT VALUE,  IF LEGAL AS     @G@@@@ AN IDMJ
)@@G@@ENTIFIER, WILL BE USED IN THE GIVEN CONTEXT.  THE SECOND FORM     @G@@@@MK
)@@G@@ OF INDIRECT REFERENCE MAY BE USED IF ONLY THE VALUE OF 'VARIABLE',     ML
)@@G@@@G@@@@ WITH OR WITHOUT QUALIFICATION AND/OR SUBSCRIPT,   IS TO BE USED AMM
)@@G@@S     @B@@@@ THE IDENTIFIER IN QUESTION.  EXAMPLE:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@MN
)@@G@@                   A0 = %END  [OR]  A0 = +'END' @^@@@@                  MO
)@@G@@ $A0  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE VARIABLE A0 IS ASSIGNED THE NAME 'END',  RAMP
)@@G@@THER THAN ANY VALUE     @G@@@@ ASSOCIATED  WITH 'END' ('END',  AN NPL DIMQ
)@@G@@RECTIVE,  NORMALLY HAS NO     @G@@@@ VALUE  ASSOCIATED  WITH  IT,   HOWEMR
)@@G@@VER,   IT  COULD BE AN EXTERNAL     @G@@@@ FUNCTION OR EQUIVALENCE).   TMS
)@@G@@HE SECOND STATEMENT IN THE EXAMPLE IS     @G@@@@ AN  INDIRECT IDENTIFIERMT
)@@G@@ REFERENCE.   THE EXPRESSION,  IN THIS CASE     @G@@@@ THE VARIABLE 'A0'MU
)@@G@@,  IS EVALUATED,  AND THE VALUE 'END' IS RETURNED     @G@@@@ AS  THE  IDMV
)@@G@@ENTIFIER  REFERENCED.    'END'  IS  VERIFIED AS A LEGAL     @G@@@@ IDENTMW
)@@G@@IFIER, AND THE EXECUTION OF THE STATEMENT CONTINUES, WITH THE     @C@@@@MX
)@@G@@ DIRECTIVE 'END' CAUSING TERMINATION OF NPL.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF THMY
)@@G@@E OPERAND OF THE INDIRECT IDENTIFIER REFERENCE NAMES AN ARRAY     @G@@@@MZ
)@@G@@ AND  A SUBSCRIPT FOR THIS ARRAY IS TO BE SPECIFIED,  THE SUBSCRIPT     NA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FOLLOWS  THE  INDIRECT  REFERENCE JUST AS IF THE NAME OF THE ARRANB
)@@G@@Y     @G@@@@ HAD BEEN EXPLICITLY STATED.  THUS, THE FOLLOWING SERVES TO NC
)@@G@@SET THE     @C@@@@ VARIABLE N4 EQUAL TO THE CONTENTS OF J$(88):   @@@@@@ND
)@@G@@@@@@@@@ @@@@                    K3 = %J$  @A@@@@                    N4 =NE
)@@G@@ $(K3)(88)  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE VARIABLE K3 MUST BE SURROUNDED BY PARNF
)@@G@@ENTHESES TO FORCE THE USE     @G@@@@ OF THE SUBSCRIPT (88) WITH THE VARING
)@@G@@ABLE NAME RETURNED (J$), RATHER     @B@@@@ THAN AS A SUBSCRIPT ON THE VANH
)@@G@@RIABLE K3.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUANI
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23        2-  5@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 4. 4.  NJ
)@@G@@ MODE MIX @ @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  MODE MIX OPERATOR IS USED WHEN A VARIABLE NK
)@@G@@TYPED AS REAL IS TO     @G@@@@ BE USED AS AN INTEGER,  OR WHEN ONE TYPEDNL
)@@G@@ INTEGER IS TO BE USED AS     @G@@@@ A  REAL VARIABLE.   THIS SITUATION NM
)@@G@@CAN OCCUR IF,  FOR INSTANCE,  A     @G@@@@ REAL  ARRAY IS BEING USED AS NN
)@@G@@A STACK,  WITH THE POINTER TO THE TOP     @G@@@@ OF THE STACK STORED IN NO
)@@G@@ARRAY(0).   REFERENCING THE CELL POINTED TO     @G@@@@ BY  THE  POINTER NP
)@@G@@ TO THE TOP AS ARRAY(ARRAY),  WHILE SYNTACTICALLY     @G@@@@ CORRECT,   NQ
)@@G@@WILL PROBABLY RESULT IN A FLOATING POINT UNDERFLOW,  AS     @G@@@@ THE  NR
)@@G@@STACK  POINTER IS, IN ALL LIKELIHOOD, INTEGER AND AN INTEGER,     @G@@@@NS
)@@G@@ UNLESS  EXCEPTIONALLY  LARGE (OR SMALL),  WILL NOT BE A NORMALIZED     NT
)@@G@@@E@@@@ FLOATING POINT NUMBER.  USE OF THE MODE MIX OPERATOR AS:   @@@@@@NU
)@@G@@@A@@@@                   ARRAY(@ARRAY)    @@@@@@@G@@@@ IS  THE  WAY  TO NV
)@@G@@ REFERENCE THE TOP OF THE STACK WITHOUT CAUSING A     @^@@@@ HARDWARE INNW
)@@G@@TERRUPT.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 5.   VARIABLES     @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@NX
)@@G@@@^@@@@  2. 5. 1.   GENERAL    @@@@@@@G@@@@ THERE ARE TWO TYPES OF VARIABNY
)@@G@@LES IN NPL:  1) NATURAL VARIABLES AND     @G@@@@ 2)  KEYWORDS.   EITHER NZ
)@@G@@TYPE MAY BE A SINGLE UNDIMENSIONED VARIABLE     @D@@@@ OR AN ARRAY REFEROA
)@@G@@ENCED WITH OR WITHOUT SUBSCRIPTS.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  2. 5. 2.  OB
)@@G@@ NATURAL VARIABLES@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  NATURAL  VARIABLE NAME MAY BE A SINGLEOC
)@@G@@ LETTER,  A SINGLE LETTER     @G@@@@ FOLLOWED BY A SINGLE DIGIT,  OR EITOD
)@@G@@HER FOLLOWED BY THE DOLLAR SIGN     @G@@@@ ($).    ARRAY  NAMES ENDING WOE
)@@G@@ITH $ ARE STRING ARRAYS.   ARRAYS ARE     @G@@@@ DECLARED  THROUGH  THE OF
)@@G@@USE OF THE 'DIM' STATEMENT.   ALL ARRAYS IN     @G@@@@ NPL  HAVE  A  ZEROG
)@@G@@O SUBSCRIPT ELEMENT,  BUT NEGATIVE SUBSCRIPTS ARE     @G@@@@ DISALLOWED.OH
)@@G@@  ARRAY IMPLEMENTATION IS LIMITED TO VECTORS, THERE ARE     @G@@@@ NO  MOI
)@@G@@ULTIDIMENSIONAL  ARRAYS.    IF  AN  ARRAY  NAME IS REFERENCED     @G@@@@OJ
)@@G@@ WITHOUT  A  SUBSCRIPT,   THE  ZEROTH  ELEMENT WILL BE USED IF IN A     OK
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NUMERIC CONTEXT,  OR,  IF THE ARRAY IS A STRING,  THE STRING VALUOL
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ WILL  BE USED IN A STRING CONTEXT.   NPL IMPOSES AN UPPER LOM
)@@G@@IMIT OF     @G@@@@ 131071  (0377777)  AS  THE  LARGEST ADDRESS OF ANY ITON
)@@G@@EM IN DYNAMIC     @G@@@@ STORAGE.   THIS EFFECTIVELY RESTRICTS THE MAXIMOO
)@@G@@UM SIZE OF A SINGLE     @G@@@@ ARRAY RESIDING IN DYNAMIC STORAGE TO ABOUOP
)@@G@@T 125000 WORDS.   AS MORE     @F@@@@ ARRAY ARE DIMENSIONED, THIS NUMBER OQ
)@@G@@DECREASES PROPORTIONATELY.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKOR
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  6@@@@@@@@@@@@OS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 5. 3.   KEYWORDS   @@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL PROVIDES PREDOT
)@@G@@EFINED VARIABLES FOR THE COMMUNICATION OF CERTAIN     @G@@@@ INFORMATIONOU
)@@G@@  BETWEEN  THE NPL INTERPRETER AND USER PROGRAMS.   ALL     @G@@@@ KEYWOOV
)@@G@@RDS,   EXCEPT 'PI',  'EE'  AND 'TOLER',  ARE TYPED IMPLICITLY     @G@@@@OW
)@@G@@ INTEGER ('PI', 'EE' AND 'TOLER' ARE IMPLICITLY REAL), AND THE MODE     OX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OF  KEYWORDS  MAY  NOT BE CHANGED BY USE OF THE MODE MIX OPERATOROY
)@@G@@.     @G@@@@ (USE OF THE 'MIX' INTRINSIC FUNCTION, HOWEVER, ALLOWS KEYWOOZ
)@@G@@RD MODE     @E@@@@ REVERSAL.)  THE FOLLOWING TABLE SUMMARIZES NPL KEYWORPA
)@@G@@DS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PB
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   STLIM     :    STATEMENT EXECUTION LIMIPC
)@@G@@T           :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PD
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   STCNT     :    COUNT OF STATEMENTS EXECPE
)@@G@@UTED        :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PF
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   OPTS      :    PROGRAM OPTIONS - SEE ALPG
)@@G@@SO 'TMP'    :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PH
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   TMP*      :    FOUR WORD TEMPORARY STORPI
)@@G@@AGE ARRAY   :     @F@@@@     :   TMP0      :    THE INDIVIDUAL WORDS AREPJ
)@@G@@ ALSO       :     @F@@@@     :   TMP1      :    ADDRESSABLE AS TMP0, TMPPK
)@@G@@1, TMP2 AND :     @F@@@@     :   TMP2      :    TMP3                    PL
)@@G@@            :     @F@@@@     :   TMP3      :    TMP0 HAS THE SAME ADDRESPM
)@@G@@S AS OPTS   :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PN
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   ANCHOR    :    SEE DISCUSSION OF STRINGPO
)@@G@@ OPERATORS  :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PP
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   TRANSP    :    IF NON-NEGATIVE, TRANSPAPQ
)@@G@@RENT CHAR   :     @F@@@@     :             :    FOR PATTERN MATCHING OPEPR
)@@G@@RATIONS     :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PS
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   PI        :    CONSTANT VALUE OF 3.1415PT
)@@G@@9           :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PU
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   EE        :    CONSTANT VALUE OF 2.7182PV
)@@G@@8           :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PW
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   TOLER     :    TOLERANCE FOR FP EQUALITPX
)@@G@@Y TESTING   :     @F@@@@     :             :    INITIAL VALUE IS 1.0E-5 PY
)@@G@@(1/100000)  :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------PZ
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   INFOR*    :    SEE APPENDIX A          QA
)@@G@@            :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------QB
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   GETDRC    :    REFER TO THE CHAPTER DESQC
)@@G@@CRIBING     :     @F@@@@     :             :    THE OPERATING SYSTEM INTQD
)@@G@@ERFACE      :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------QE
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   DRCCON*   :    REFER TO THE CHAPTER DESQF
)@@G@@CRIBING     :     @F@@@@     :             :    THE OPERATING SYSTEM INTQG
)@@G@@ERFACE      :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------QH
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   CLOCK     :    ACCUMULATED TIME BETWEENQI
)@@G@@ CLOCK      :     @F@@@@     :             :    START AND CLOCK STOP    QJ
)@@G@@            :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------QK
)@@G@@------------:     @F@@@@     :   INPUT$*   :    LAST IMAGE READ FROM ANYQL
)@@G@@ UNIT       :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------QM
)@@G@@------------:     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING QN
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  7@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :   STRQO

)@@G@@------------------------------------------------:     @D@@@@            QT

)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@  2. 6.   PARTIAL WORDS AND QUALIFICATION @@@@@@@@@@@@SC
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 6. 1.   GENERAL    @@@@@@@G@@@@ PARTIAL  WORD  OPERATIOSD
)@@G@@NS  ARE  ALLOWED  ANY  TIME  A  VARIABLE IS     @G@@@@ REFERENCED  OR  ASE
)@@G@@  FUNCTION  IS EVALUATED IN A NUMERIC EXPRESSION.     @G@@@@ THE  PARTIASF
)@@G@@L  WORD DESIGNATOR CONSISTS OF A PERIOD FOLLOWED BY THE     @G@@@@ MNEMOSG
)@@G@@NIC  OF  THE DESIRED PARTIAL WORD.   A SAMPLE REFERENCE WOULD     @[@@@@SH
)@@G@@ BE:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@                   A$(7).H2   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@SI
)@@G@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2-  9SJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE PARTIAL WORD MNEMONICS ARE OUTLSK
)@@G@@INED IN THE TABLE BELOW.   NOTE     @G@@@@ THAT  THE  '.'  IS NOT PART OSL
)@@G@@F THE NAME,  IT IS PUNCTUATION.   THE     @G@@@@ PARTIAL WORD MNEMONIC MSM
)@@G@@AY BE INDIRECTLY REFERENCED.   THE INDIRECT     @G@@@@ REFERENCE  PARENTSN
)@@G@@HETICAL EXPRESSION IS STILL PRECEDED BY A PERIOD.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@SO
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@SP
)@@G@@     :    W        :    WHOLE WORD BITS 35-0                :     @F@@@@SQ
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@SR
)@@G@@     :    H1       :    LEFT HALF BITS 35-18                :     @F@@@@SS
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@ST
)@@G@@     :    H2       :    RIGHT HALF BITS 17-0                :     @F@@@@SU
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@SV
)@@G@@     :    T1       :    FIRST THIRD BITS 35-24              :     @F@@@@SW
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@SX
)@@G@@     :    T2       :    SECOND THIRD BITS 23-12             :     @F@@@@SY
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@SZ
)@@G@@     :    T3       :    THIRD THIRD BITS 11-0               :     @F@@@@TA
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TB
)@@G@@     :    Q1       :    FIRST QUARTER BITS 35-27            :     @F@@@@TC
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TD
)@@G@@     :    Q2       :    SECOND QUARTER BITS 26-18           :     @F@@@@TE
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TF
)@@G@@     :    Q3       :    THIRD QUARTER BITS 17-9             :     @F@@@@TG
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TH
)@@G@@     :    Q4       :    FOURTH QUARTER BITS 8-0             :     @F@@@@TI
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TJ
)@@G@@     :    S1       :    FIRST SIXTH BITS 35-30              :     @F@@@@TK
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TL
)@@G@@     :    S2       :    SECOND SIXTH BITS 29-24             :     @F@@@@TM
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TN
)@@G@@     :    S3       :    THIRD SIXTH BITS 23-18              :     @F@@@@TO
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TP
)@@G@@     :    S4       :    FOURTH SIXTH BITS 17-12             :     @F@@@@TQ
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TR
)@@G@@     :    S5       :    FIFTH SIXTH BITS 11-6               :     @F@@@@TS
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TT
)@@G@@     :    S6       :    SIXTH SIXTH BITS 5-0                :     @F@@@@TU
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TV
)@@G@@     :    M        :    PART WORD UNDER MASK*               :     @F@@@@TW
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TX
)@@G@@     :    XH1      :    SIGN EXTENDED H1**                  :     @F@@@@TY
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@TZ
)@@G@@     :    XH2      :    SIGN EXTENDED H2**                  :     @F@@@@UA
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@UB
)@@G@@     :    XT1      :    SIGN EXTENDED T1**                  :     @F@@@@UC
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@UD
)@@G@@     :    XT2      :    SIGN EXTENDED T2**                  :     @[@@@@UE
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23 UF
)@@G@@       2- 10@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :------------------------------UG
)@@G@@------------------------:     @F@@@@     :    XT3      :    SIGN EXTENDEUH
)@@G@@D T3**                  :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------UI
)@@G@@------------------------:     @F@@@@     :    U, XU    :    ITEM ADDRESSUJ
)@@G@@, XU IS SIGN EXTENDED   :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------UK
)@@G@@------------------------:     @F@@@@     :    D$       :    CORE CONTROLUL
)@@G@@ DESCRIPTOR OF THE ITEM :     @F@@@@     :------------------------------UM
)@@G@@------------------------:     @E@@@@       TABLE OF PARTIAL WORD AND QUAUN
)@@G@@LIFICATION DESIGNATORS  @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@         NOTE: *  EXECUTION OFUO
)@@G@@ A = B.M  SETS THE BITS @E@@@@                  IN 'A' CORRESPONDING TO UP
)@@G@@BITS SET IN 'MASK'@E@@@@                  TO THE CORRESPONDING BITS OF 'UQ
)@@G@@B'.  THE    @F@@@@                  REMAINING BITS OF A ARE SET TO ZERO.UR
)@@G@@  THUS,     @E@@@@                  IF 'MASK' EQUALS -0 (ALL BITS SET), US
)@@G@@THE   @E@@@@                  ABOVE ASSIGNMENT IS EQUIVALENT TO A WHOLE UT
)@@G@@@E@@@@                  WORD TRANSFER. EXECUTION OF A.M = B  SETS @D@@@@UU
)@@G@@                  THE CORRESPONDING BITS OF 'A' AS    @D@@@@            UV
)@@G@@      ABOVE, BUT DOES NOT CHANGE THE OTHER@ @@@@                  BITS IUW
)@@G@@N 'A'.@@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@               ** IF THE SIGN EXTENSION PART WORUX
)@@G@@D DESIGNATORS     @E@@@@                  APPEAR ON THE LEFT OF THE EQUAUY
)@@G@@LS SIGN IN  @D@@@@                  AN ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT, THE RESULT UZ
)@@G@@@D@@@@                  OBTAINED IS THE SAME AS FOR THE     @E@@@@      VA
)@@G@@            CORRESPONDING NONEXTENDED DESIGNATORS.    @E@@@@            VB
)@@G@@      ON REFERENCE TO A VARIABLE, HOWEVER, THE  @E@@@@                  VC
)@@G@@SPECIFICATION OF SIGN EXTENSION RESULTS   @E@@@@                  IN FILVD
)@@G@@LING THE RESULT WORD TO THE LEFT    @D@@@@                  WITH BITS EQVE
)@@G@@UAL TO THE VALUE OF THE @D@@@@                  HIGH ORDER BIT IN THE PAVF
)@@G@@RTIAL WORD. @@@@@@@B@@@@  2. 6. 2.   QUALIFIER SYNONYM DEFINITION @@@@@@VG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  'QSYN' STATEMENT IS AVAILABLE AS A MEANS OF DEFINING SYNONYMVH
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ FOR  THE  PREDEFINED  PARTIAL  WORD AND QUALIFICATION DESIGVI
)@@G@@NATORS.     @B@@@@ THE FORMAT OF THE 'QSYN' STATEMENT IS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@VJ
)@@G@@@C@@@@              QSYN <SYNONYM> = <QUALIFIER>,...  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@VK
)@@G@@ <SYNONYM>   IS   ANY   LEGAL   IDENTIFIER   (POSSIBLY   INDIRECTLY     VL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ REFERENCED),   AND  <QUALIFIER>  IS THE NAME OF AN ALREADY DEFINEVM
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ QUALIFIER  OR  PARTIAL WORD DESIGNATOR.   <SYNONYM> MAY NOTVN
)@@G@@ NAME A     @G@@@@ QUALIFIER WHICH APPEARS IN THE TABLE ABOVE.   HOWEVERVO
)@@G@@, IT MAY NAME     @G@@@@ ANOTHER  QUALIFIER  SYNONYM.    THE  MAXIMUM NUVP
)@@G@@MBER OF SYNONYMS IS     @B@@@@ OUTLINED IN THE APPENDIX ON NPL MAXIMUMS.VQ
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   RVR
)@@G@@EV.23        2- 11@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ TO  CLEAR  A  QUALIFIER SYNONVS
)@@G@@YM,  THE 'QSYN' STATEMENT IS CODED AS     @E@@@@ ABOVE, EXCEPT THAT THE VT
)@@G@@<QUALIFIER> FIELD IS OMITTED, THUS: @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                  VU
)@@G@@  QSYN <SYNONYM> =@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7.   FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@@@@@@VV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FUNCTIONS  IN  NPL  ARE  OF THREE TYPES:   EXTERNAL,  INTERNAL ANVW
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ INTRINSIC.    EXTERNAL  AND INTERNAL FUNCTIONS ARE CREATED VX
)@@G@@THROUGH     @G@@@@ THE USE OF THE 'FUNC' AND 'EFUNC' DIRECTIVES,  RESPECVY
)@@G@@TIVELY, WHICH     @G@@@@ WILL  BE DESCRIBED IN MORE DETAL LATER.    INTRVZ
)@@G@@INSIC FUNCTIONS ARE     @G@@@@ PROVIDED  BY NPL TO PERFORM SOME OF THE MWA
)@@G@@ORE COMMON ARITHMETIC AND     @^@@@@ LOGICAL OPERATIONS.    @@@@@@@@@@@@WB
)@@G@@@G@@@@ A  FUNCTION  NEED NOT BE CALLED WITH ANY ARGUMENTS.   IN THIS CASWC
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ THE  PARENTHESES  SURROUNDING WHAT WOULD BE THE ARGUMENT LIWD
)@@G@@ST MUST     @G@@@@ NOT APPEAR,  AND ANY REFERENCE TO ARGUMENTS WITHIN THWE
)@@G@@E BODY OF THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  WILL REFERENCE THE IMPLICIT ARGUMENT WF
)@@G@@ZERO.   LIKEWISE IT     @G@@@@ IS  NOT  CONSIDERED AN ERROR IF A FUNCTIOWG
)@@G@@N IS CALLED WITH TOO MANY     @D@@@@ ARGUMENTS, THE EXTRANEOUS ARGUMENTSWH
)@@G@@ ARE IGNORED.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IN  THE FOLLOWING DISCUSSIONS OF INWI
)@@G@@TRINSIC FUNCTIONS,  THE LETTERS     @G@@@@ (A  R  I)  FOLLOWING  THE  ARWJ
)@@G@@GUMENT COUNT REFER TO THE MODE OF THE     @G@@@@ RESPECTIVE  ARGUMENT.  WK
)@@G@@  (R)  MEANS THE ARGUMENT IS EXPECTED TO BE     @G@@@@ REAL,  (I) INTEGEWL
)@@G@@R,  AND (A) EITHER REAL OR INTEGER.   THE MODE OF     @G@@@@ THE  FUNCTIWM
)@@G@@ON  RETURN  WILL  BE CONSISTENT WIITH THAT OF THE FIRST     @G@@@@ ARGUMWN
)@@G@@ENT UNLESS OTHERWISE NOTED.  THE ARGUMENT DOES NOT HAVE TO BE     @G@@@@WO
)@@G@@ OF THE MODE INDICATED,  AS MENTIONED PREVIOUSLY, NPL WILL MAKE ANY     WP
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NECESSARY  CONVERSIONS  TO  ASSURE THAT THE MODE OF ANY ITEM IN AWQ
)@@G@@N     @D@@@@ ARITHMETIC EXPRESSION IS CONSISTENT WITH THE CONTEXT.@@@@@@WR
)@@G@@@A@@@@  2. 7. 1.   ARITHMETIC FUNCTIONS   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 1.   ABWS
)@@G@@S     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A) @A@@@@ VALUE:  ABS(A) = MAGNITWT
)@@G@@UDE OF A.   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 2.   NEG     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENWU
)@@G@@TS:  1  (A) @B@@@@ VALUE:  NEG(A) = NEGATIVE MAGNITUDE OF A.@@@@@@@^@@@@WV
)@@G@@  2. 7. 1. 3.   REM     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (I,I)     @B@@@@WW
)@@G@@ VALUE:  REM(A,B) = REMAINDER OF A/B.     @@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEWX
)@@G@@W YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 12@@@@@@WY
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 4.   MOD     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2WZ
)@@G@@  (I,I)     @G@@@@ VALUE:   MOD(A,B) = LEAST POSITIVE INTEGER CONGRUENT XA
)@@G@@TO A (MOD B).     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 5.   MAX     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF AXB
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1 TO N  (ALL I)    @D@@@@ VALUE:  MAX(A,B,C,...) = MAXIMUM OFXC
)@@G@@ THE ARGUMENTS.   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 6.   MIN     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF AXD
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1 TO N  (ALL I)    @D@@@@ VALUE:  MIN(A,B,C,...) = MINIMUM OFXE
)@@G@@ THE ARGUMENTS.   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 7.   DIM     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF AXF
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1 TO N  (ALL I)    @G@@@@ VALUE:   DIM(A,B,C,...) = MAX(0,A-(XG
)@@G@@B+C+...)), POSITIVE DIFFERENCE.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 8.   SGN     XH
)@@G@@@E@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS VARIABLE    @G@@@@XI
)@@G@@ VALUE:   SGN(A) = SIGNUM FUNCTION, -1 IF A<0; +1 IF A>0; 0 IF A=0.     XJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SGN(A,B) = A WITH SIGN OF B.   IF CALLED WITH ONE ARGUMENT, RESULXK
)@@G@@T     @F@@@@ IS INTEGER, OTHERWISE, RESULT IS SAME TYPE AS FIRST ARGUMENXL
)@@G@@T.    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1. 9.   FLD     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  3XM
)@@G@@  (I,I,A)  RESULT IS (I)@G@@@@ VALUE:  FLD(A,B,C) = BIT FIELD OF WIDTH BXN
)@@G@@ STARTING AT BIT POSITION     @B@@@@ A OF C (SIGN BIT IS CONSIDERED BIT XO
)@@G@@0).   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.10.   AND     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2XP
)@@G@@  (A,A)  RESULT IS (I)  @C@@@@ VALUE:  AND(A,B) = LOGICAL PRODUCT OF A AXQ
)@@G@@ND B. @@@@@@@#@@@@  2. 7. 1.11.   OR@C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (A,AXR
)@@G@@)  RESULT IS (I)  @B@@@@ VALUE:  OR(A,B) = LOGICAL SUM OF A AND B.@@@@@@XS
)@@G@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.12.   XOR     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (A,A)  RESXT
)@@G@@ULT IS (I)  @D@@@@ VALUE:  XOR(A,B) = LOGICAL DIFFERENCE OF A AND B.    XU
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.13.   CMB     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (I,IXV
)@@G@@)     @B@@@@ VALUE:  CMB(A,B) = COMBINATIONS (A B).   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7XW
)@@G@@. 1.14.   PRM     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (I,I)     @B@@@@ VALUEXX
)@@G@@:  PRM(A,B) = PERMUTATIONS (A B)    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.15.   FCT     XY
)@@G@@@ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @A@@@@ VALUE:  FCT(A) = A! (FACTORIAXZ
)@@G@@L).   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NYA
)@@G@@PL   REV.23        2- 13@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.16.   ODYB
)@@G@@D     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @B@@@@ VALUE:  ODD(I) = 1 IF IYC
)@@G@@ IS ODD, ELSE 0.  @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.17.   PRIME   @ @@@@ NUMBER OF AYD
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1  (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:  PRIME(I) = 1  IF  I  IS  A  PRIME  NUMBYE
)@@G@@ER, ELSE 0.  IF THE     @F@@@@ MAGNITUDE OF I EXCEEDS 753,447,601, RESULYF
)@@G@@TS ARE NOT GUARANTEED.  @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.18.   PRIMES  @ @@@@ NUMBEYG
)@@G@@R OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:  PRIMES(I) = THE ITH PRIME NUMBER,YH
)@@G@@  I GREATER THAN OR EQUAL     @B@@@@ TO 1 AND LESS THAN OR EQUAL TO 3,00YI
)@@G@@0.    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.19.   TEP     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1YJ
)@@G@@ OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS I     @G@@@@ VALUE:   TEP(I) RETURNS A BOOLEAN 'YK
)@@G@@TRUE' IF AN EVEN NUMBER OF BITS     @G@@@@ ARE SET IN ITS ARGUMENT.  IF YL
)@@G@@A SECOND ARGUMENT IS GIVEN THE PARITY     @C@@@@ OF THE LOGICAL AND OF TYM
)@@G@@HE ARGUMENTS IS TESTED. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.20.   TOP     @D@@@@ NUMBEYN
)@@G@@R OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS I     @G@@@@ VALUE:    TOP(I) YO
)@@G@@RETURNS A BOOLEAN 'TRUE' IF AN ODD NUMBER OF BITS     @F@@@@ ARE SET IN YP
)@@G@@ITS ARGUMENT.  A SECOND ARGUMENT IS USED AS IN 'TEP'. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7YQ
)@@G@@. 1.21.   BTC     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULT IS I@B@@@@YR
)@@G@@ VALUE:  BTC(I) = NUMBER OF BITS SET IN I.@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.22.   MSYS
)@@G@@B     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULT IS I@G@@@@ VALUE:   MSYT
)@@G@@B(I)  =  BIT POSITION OF THE MOST SIGNIFICANT BIT OF I.     @G@@@@ IF I YU
)@@G@@IS ZERO, MSB(I) EQUALS -1.   BIT COUNTING IS RIGHT TO LEFT, 0     @]@@@@YV
)@@G@@ TO 35.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.23.   GCD     @B@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENYW
)@@G@@TS:  2 TO N  (ALL I)    @G@@@@ VALUE:    GCD(A,B,...)  =  GREATEST COMMOYX
)@@G@@N DIVISOR OF THE ABSOLUTE     @F@@@@ VALUES OF THE ARGUMENTS.  AT LEAST YY
)@@G@@ONE ARGUMENT MUST BE NONZERO. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 1.24.   LCM     @B@@@@YZ
)@@G@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2 TO N  (ALL I)    @G@@@@ VALUE:    LCM(A,B,...) ZA
)@@G@@ =  LEAST  COMMON  MULTIPLE OF THE ABSOLUTE     @ @@@@ VALUES OF THE ARGZB
)@@G@@UMENTS.     @@@@@@@ @@@@  2. 7. 2.   LOGICAL FUNCTIONS@@@@@@@G@@@@ LOGICZC
)@@G@@AL  FUNCTIONS RETURN A VALUE OF 1 OR 0,  CORRESPONDING TO THE     @A@@@@ZD
)@@G@@ CONDITIONS OF 'TRUE' AND 'FALSE'.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEZE
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 14@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ZF
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 2. 1.   BOOL    @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A) ZG
)@@G@@ RESULT IS (I)    @B@@@@ VALUE:  BOOL(A) = 0 IF A=0, 1 OTHERWISE. @@@@@@ZH
)@@G@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 2. 2.   NOT     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULZI
)@@G@@T IS (I)    @B@@@@ VALUE:  NOT(A) = 1 IF A=0, 0 OTHERWISE.  @@@@@@@^@@@@ZJ
)@@G@@  2. 7. 2. 3.   CNJ     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 TO N  (ALL A)  REZK
)@@G@@SULT IS (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:    CNJ(A,B,C,...)  =  CONJUNCTIVE OF (A,B,C,..ZL
)@@G@@.),  1 IF ALL     @A@@@@ ARGUMENTS NONZERO, 0 OTHERWISE.    @@@@@@@^@@@@ZM
)@@G@@  2. 7. 2. 4.   DSJ     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 TO N  (ALL A)  REZN
)@@G@@SULT IS (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:    DSJ(A,B,C,...)  =  DISJUNCTIVE OF (A,B,C,..ZO
)@@G@@.),  1 IF ANY     @C@@@@ ARGUMENT NONZERO, 0 IF ALL ARGUMENTS ZERO.     ZP
)@@G@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  2. 7. 3.   RELATIONAL FUNCTIONS   @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  RELATIZQ
)@@G@@ONAL  FUNCTIONS  RETURN  A  VALUE OF 0 OR 1,  AS DO THE     @G@@@@ RELATZR
)@@G@@IONAL  OPERATORS.    UNLIKE  THE  OPERATORS,  HOWEVER,  THESE     @G@@@@ZS
)@@G@@ FUNCTIONS  WILL  NOT  PROVIDE THE EXPECTED RESULTS IF ANY OF THEIR     ZT
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ARGUMENTS  IS  NOT INTEGER, EXCEPT FOR TESTING A RELATION TO ZEROZU
)@@G@@.     @G@@@@ THE  RELATIONAL  FUNCTIONS  AND  THEIR  OPERATOR  COUNTERPAZV
)@@G@@RTS ARE     @#@@@@ OUTLINED BELOW:  @@@@@@@B@@@@                    EQ(AZW
)@@G@@,B)   <==>   A = B@@@@@@@C@@@@                    NE(A,B)   <==>   A <> ZX
)@@G@@B     @@@@@@@B@@@@                    LT(A,B)   <==>   A < B@@@@@@@C@@@@ZY
)@@G@@                    LE(A,B)   <==>   A <= B     @@@@@@@B@@@@            ZZ
)@@G@@        GT(A,B)   <==>   A > B@@@@@@@C@@@@                    GE(A,B)   AA
)@@G@@<==>   A => B     @@@@@@@ @@@@  2. 7. 4.   STRING FUNCTIONS @@@@@@@^@@@@AB
)@@G@@  2. 7. 4. 1.   DEC     @F@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,I)  RESUAC
)@@G@@LT IS (I) IF NUMERIC    @G@@@@ VALUE:    DEC(A,B)  =  FIELDATA  REPRESENAD
)@@G@@TATION  OF  A EDITED TO B     @F@@@@ CHARACTERS.  IF B IS OMITTED THE WIAE
)@@G@@DTH OF THE FIELD IS VARIABLE. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 4. 2.   OCT     @F@@@@AF
)@@G@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,I)  RESULT IS (I) IF NUMERIC    @G@@@@AG
)@@G@@ VALUE:   OCT(A,B) = OCTAL FIELDATA REPRESENTATION OF A EDITED TO B     AH
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   RAI
)@@G@@EV.23        2- 15@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@ CHARACTERS.  IF B IS OMITTED AJ
)@@G@@THE FIELD WIDTH IS VARIABLE.  @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 4. 3.   WRD     @E@@@@AK
)@@G@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULT IS (I) IF NUMERIC     @G@@@@ VALUEAL
)@@G@@:    WRD(A) = A STRING OF FROM 0 TO 6 CHARACTERS WHICH IS THE     @G@@@@AM
)@@G@@ FIELDATA  VALUE  OF  A  WITH  ALL  BLANKS  AND MASTER SPACES ('@')     AN
)@@G@@@]@@@@ REMOVED.   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 4. 4.   STR     @F@@@@ NUMBER OF AAO
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,I)  RESULT IS (I) IF NUMERIC    @G@@@@ VALUE:  STRAP
)@@G@@(A,B) = A STRING OF THE FIRST B CHARACTERS OF A, OR, IF     @G@@@@ B<0, AQ
)@@G@@  THE RIGHTMOST ABS(B) CHARACTERS OF A.   IF B IS OMITTED THE     @A@@@@AR
)@@G@@ FIELD WIDTH WILL BE SIX CHARACTERS.@@@@@@@ @@@@  2. 7. 5.   SPECIAL FUNAS
)@@G@@CTIONS@@@@@@@#@@@@  2. 7. 5. 1.   PR@E@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2 AT
)@@G@@ (I,I)  RESULT IS VARIABLE    @G@@@@ VALUE:    PR(A)  =  THE  ATH  ARGUMAU
)@@G@@ENT  TO  THE  NPL PROGRAM BEING     @G@@@@ EXECUTED.    IF  FEWER  THAN AV
)@@G@@ A ARGUMENTS WERE PASSED THE VALUE OF     @#@@@@ PR(A) IS ZERO.   @@@@@@AW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PR(A,B)  = THE BTH WORD OF THE ATH ARGUMENT TO THE PROGRAM,  VALIAX
)@@G@@D     @D@@@@ ONLY IF THE ARGUMENT WAS A STRING OR ARRAY NAME.     @@@@@@AY
)@@G@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 2.   ARG     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @G@@@@AZ
)@@G@@ VALUE:    ARG(A)  = THE ITEM DESCRIPTOR OF THE ATH ARGUMENT TO THE     BA
)@@G@@@E@@@@ PROGRAM BEING EXECUTED.  THE FORMAT OF A DESCRIPTOR IS:    @@@@@@BB
)@@G@@@F@@@@         SIGN BIT     - SET IF ITEM IS A STRING, CLEAR OTHERWISE. BC
)@@G@@@D@@@@         BITS 34-18   - MAXIMUM SUBSCRIPT PERMITTED.  @F@@@@      BD
)@@G@@   BIT 17       - IF SET, BITS 34-18 ARE QUALIFIER INDEX.   @D@@@@      BE
)@@G@@   BITS 16-0    - ADDRESS OF START OF ITEM.     @@@@@@@E@@@@         THEBF
)@@G@@ DESCRIPTOR = 0 IF THERE WAS NO ARGUMENT PASSED.@@@@@@@#@@@@  2. 7. 5. 3BG
)@@G@@.   FN@D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I)  RESULT IS VARIABLE     @G@@@@BH
)@@G@@ VALUE:    FN(A)  = THE VALUE OF THE ATH ARGUMENT TO AN EXTERNAL OR     BI
)@@G@@@^@@@@ INTERNAL FUNCTION.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 4.   ITM     @A@@@@BJ
)@@G@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (I,I)     @G@@@@ VALUE:    ITM(A,B)  IS A MEANBK
)@@G@@S OF CONVERTING A PROGRAM OR FUNCTION     @G@@@@ INTO  AN ARRAY.   ITM RBL
)@@G@@EFERENCES THE BTH WORD IN THE ITEM NAMED BY     @G@@@@ A.   EXAMPLE:   IBM
)@@G@@F  'PROG1'  IS  THE  NAME  OF  A DEFINED PROGRAM,     @E@@@@ ITM('PROG1'BN
)@@G@@,6) REFERENCES THE 6TH WORD IN THE PROGRAM.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 5BO
)@@G@@.   IND     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUABP
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23        2- 16@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENBQ
)@@G@@TS:  1  (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:    IND(A) USES THE LOW ORDER 18 BITS OF A AS TBR
)@@G@@HE ADDRESS OF     @^@@@@ THE ITEM REFERENCED.   @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 6BS
)@@G@@.   FLS     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  2  (I,I)     @G@@@@ VALUE:    FBT
)@@G@@LS(A,B)  =  THE ATH WORD IN THE FACILITY CONTROL PACKET     @G@@@@ ASSOCBU
)@@G@@IATED  WITH  I/O  UNIT  B.    REFER TO THE EXEC8 PROGRAMMER'S     @G@@@@BV
)@@G@@ REFERENCE  MANUAL  (PRM)  FOR DETAILS ON THE INFORMATION AVAILABLE     BW
)@@G@@@]@@@@ FROM 'FLS'.@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 7.   IOP     @A@@@@ NUMBER OF ABX
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  2  (I,I)     @G@@@@ VALUE:  IOP(A,B) = THE ATH WORD IN THE I/BY
)@@G@@O CONTROL PACKET FOR UNIT     @G@@@@ B.    THE  CHAPTER  ON  I/O IN THE BZ
)@@G@@EXEC8 PRM HAS DETAILS ABOUT I/O     @#@@@@ CONTROL PACKETS. @@@@@@@^@@@@CA
)@@G@@  2. 7. 5. 8.   IOS     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @G@@@@ VALUECB
)@@G@@:   IOS(A) = I/O STATUS WORD FOR UNIT A.  MEANINGFUL ONLY FOR     @G@@@@CC
)@@G@@ UNITS 0 TO 9.   IF THE VALUE OF IOS IS NEGATIVE,  AN I/O ERROR HAS     CD
)@@G@@@G@@@@ OCCURRED  ON THE UNIT IN QUESTION,  AND THE MAGNITUDE OF THE VALUCE
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OF  IOS IS THE STATUS.  IF IOS RETURNS A POSITIVE (OR ZERO)CF
)@@G@@ VALUE,     @G@@@@ THE  PREVIOUS  I/O OPERATION COMPLETED NORMALLY,  ANDCG
)@@G@@ THE VALUE OF     @C@@@@ IOS IS THE ACTUAL NUMBER OF WORDS TRANSFERRED. CH
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5. 9.   MODE    @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) CI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VALUE:  MODE(A) = THE I/O MODE OF UNIT A.  MODE IS 0 IF CLOSED ANCJ
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ AVAILABLE FOR BINARY I/O,  1 IF OPEN FOR FORMATTED OUTPUT, CK
)@@G@@OR 2 IF     @ @@@@ OPEN FOR FORMATTED INPUT.    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5.10CL
)@@G@@.   RND     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:   RND(A)  CM
)@@G@@= A RANDOM NUMBER RANGING IN VALUE FROM 0 TO A-1,     @^@@@@ OR, IF A<0,CN
)@@G@@ -0 TO A+1. @@@@@@@#@@@@  2. 7. 5.11.   FC@ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1CO
)@@G@@  (I) @G@@@@ VALUE:    FC(A)  =  THE  NULL STRING.   FC IS USED TO SET TCP
)@@G@@HE LINE     @G@@@@ SPACING  INCREMENT  FOR  THE PROMPT MESSAGE WHEN READCQ
)@@G@@ING FROM UNIT     @#@@@@ 10.  EXAMPLE:    @@@@@@@D@@@@            READ (CR
)@@G@@10,EOF,'ENTER INPUT '+FC(3)) G$     @@@@@@@G@@@@ PROMPTS  FOR  A  VALUE CS
)@@G@@FOR G$ WITH THE MESSAGE 'ENTER INPUT' AFTER     @B@@@@ SPACING DOWN THRECT
)@@G@@E LINES ON THE TERMINAL.@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 5.12.   EXE     @B@@@@ NUMBECU
)@@G@@R OF ARGUMENTS:  2 OR 3  (ALL I)    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVECV
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 17@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@CW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VALUE:    THE  VALUE  OF  EXE  IS THE FIRST ARGUMENT IF THE SECONCX
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  EVALUATES TO A BOOLEAN 'FALSE'.   IF THE SECOND ACY
)@@G@@RGUMENT     @G@@@@ EVALUATES TO BOOLEAN 'TRUE',  AN ERROR TYPE 73 OCCURSCZ
)@@G@@.   SINCE NPL     @G@@@@ FUNCTIONS  CANNOT  CONTAIN  ANY  EXECUTABLE  STDA
)@@G@@ATEMENTS,   THE EXE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  IS  PROVIDED  AS A MEANS FOR A DB
)@@G@@FUNCTION EVALUATION TO BE     @G@@@@ ABORTED  IF  A  PREDEFINED  ERROR  DC
)@@G@@CONDITION  OCCURS.   IF A THIRD     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT IS PROVIDED, IT SHOUDD
)@@G@@LD BE A ONE TO SIX CHARACTER LITERAL,     @G@@@@ AND  WILL  BE  PRINTED DE
)@@G@@ WITH THE ERROR MESSAGE AS AN INDICATION OF     @#@@@@ WHAT WENT WRONG. DF
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@  2. 7. 6.   FLOATING POINT FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7DG
)@@G@@. 6. 1.   REC     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (R) @A@@@@ VALUE:  RECDH
)@@G@@(I) = RECIPROCAL OF I.  @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 2.   FIX     @C@@@@ NUMBEDI
)@@G@@R OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (R)  RESULT IS (I)    @G@@@@ VALUE:    FIX(I) CONVERDJ
)@@G@@TS THE REAL VALUE I TO INTEGER FORM.    THE     @G@@@@ NUMBER  IS  ROUNDDK
)@@G@@ED  UP  BY  ADDING  0.5 TO IT THEN TRUNCATING THE     @#@@@@ FRACTIONAL DL
)@@G@@PART. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 3.   INT     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1DM
)@@G@@  (R)  RESULT IS (I)    @G@@@@ VALUE:   INT(I)  CONVERTS  THE  REAL  VALDN
)@@G@@UE  I  TO INTEGER FORM BY     @A@@@@ TRUNCATING THE FRACTIONAL PART.    DO
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 4.   FLT     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (I) DP
)@@G@@ RESULT IS (R)    @F@@@@ VALUE:  FLT(I) CONVERTS THE INTEGER I TO FLOATIDQ
)@@G@@NG POINT FORM.    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 5.   FRP     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF ADR
)@@G@@RGUMENTS:  1  (R) @C@@@@ VALUE:  FRP(I) = THE FRACTIONAL PART OF I.     DS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 6.   FLR     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (R) DT
)@@G@@ RESULT IS (R)    @G@@@@ VALUE:   FLOOR(A) = GREATEST INTEGER LESS THAN DU
)@@G@@OR EQUAL TO A.  THE     @A@@@@ RESULT IS IN FLOATING POINT FORMAT.@@@@@@DV
)@@G@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 7.   CEI     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (R)  RESULDW
)@@G@@T IS (R)    @G@@@@ VALUE:   CEILING(A) = LEAST INTEGER GREATER THAN A.  DX
)@@G@@THE RESULT IS     @ @@@@ IN FLOATING POINT FORMAT.    @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7DY
)@@G@@. 6. 8.   FPN     @C@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULT IS (I)    DZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ VALUE:  FPN(I) RETURNS THE BOOLEAN VALUE 'TRUE' IF ITS ARGUMENT IEA
)@@G@@S     @F@@@@ FLOATING POINT, OR THE VALUE 'FALSE' IF ITS ARGUMENT IS INTEB
)@@G@@EGER. @@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAEC
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23        2- 18@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 6. 9.   MIED
)@@G@@X     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1  (A)  RESULT IS OPPOSITE     @G@@@@EE
)@@G@@ VALUE:   MIX(A) = A,  WITH THE MODE OF A REVERSED.   THE EFFECT IS     EF
)@@G@@@A@@@@ THAT OF THE MIX OPERATOR ('@').    @@@@@@@D@@@@  2. 7. 7.   MISCEEG
)@@G@@LLANEOUS MATHEMATICAL FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@D@@@@ THE FOLLOWING MATHEMATIEH
)@@G@@CAL FUNCTIONS ARE AVAILABLE:  @@@@@@@D@@@@           SQR  CBR  SIN  COS EI
)@@G@@ TAN  COT  EXP  LOG     @@@@@@@G@@@@ COMPUTING  RESPECTIVELY  THE SQUAREEJ
)@@G@@ ROOT, CUBE ROOT, SINE, COSINE,     @G@@@@ TANGENT,  COTANGENT,  EXPONENEK
)@@G@@TIAL (BASE E), AND LOGARITHM OF THEIR     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT.  THE ARGUMENTEL
)@@G@@ IS EXPECTED TO BE IN RADIANS FOR SIN, COS,     @G@@@@ TAN,   AND  COT. EM
)@@G@@  ALL ARGUMENTS AND VALUES ARE REAL.   ALL OF THE     @G@@@@ ABOVE  ENUMEN
)@@G@@ERATED  FUNCTIONS  EXPECT ONLY ONE ARGUMENT EXCEPT LOG,     @G@@@@ WHICHEO
)@@G@@  CAN  HAVE  ONE  OR  TWO.    IF  LOG IS CALLED WITH A SECOND     @G@@@@EP
)@@G@@ ARGUMENT,  WHICH IS THE INTEGER 10,  THE LOGARITHM CALCULATED WILL     EQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ BE TO THE BASE TEN,  OTHERWISE THE LOGARITHM CALCULATED WILL BE TER
)@@G@@O     @F@@@@ THE BASE E (2.718282).  ANY VALUE OTHER THAN 10 WILL BE IGNES
)@@G@@ORED. @@@@@@@G@@@@ TWO  ADDITIONAL  SPECIAL  FUNCTIONS  ARE PROVIDED FORET
)@@G@@ USE WITH THE     @G@@@@ TRIGONOMETRIC  FUNCTIONS.   RAD(X), WHERE X IS EU
)@@G@@A VALUE IN DEGREES,     @G@@@@ RETURNS THE EQUIVALENT VALUE IN RADIANS. EV
)@@G@@ LIKEWISE, DEG(X) RETURNS     @E@@@@ A VALUE IN DEGREES FOR AN ARGUMENT EW
)@@G@@EXPRESSED IN RADIANS.   @@@@@@@B@@@@  2. 7. 8.   ASCII HANDLING FUNCTIONEX
)@@G@@S     @@@@@@@G@@@@ ALTHOUGH  THE  CHARACTER  SET USED INTERNALLY BY NPL EY
)@@G@@IS THE UNIVAC     @G@@@@ SIX BIT FIELDATA CODE, CREATION AND MANIPULATIOEZ
)@@G@@N OF STRINGS IN THE     @G@@@@ ASCII  CHARACTER SET IS POSSIBLE ON A LIMFA
)@@G@@ITED BASIS THROUGH USE OF     @G@@@@ THE  QUARTER  WORD  QUALIFICATION  FB
)@@G@@DESIGNATORS  AND  THE FUNCTIONS     @#@@@@ DESCRIBED BELOW: @@@@@@@^@@@@FC
)@@G@@  2. 7. 8. 1.   ASC     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 TO 3  (ALL A)  REFD
)@@G@@SULT IS I   @G@@@@ VALUE:  ASC(I) = THE ASCII EQUIVALENT OF THE FIELDATAFE
)@@G@@ CHARACTER I.     @G@@@@ IF A THIRD ARGUMENT IS GIVEN,   IT IS USED TO CFF
)@@G@@HANGE A CALL ON ASC     @G@@@@ INTO A CALL ON 'ALC' (ASCII LOWER CASE, 3FG
)@@G@@RD ARGUMENT BITS 1,0 = 0)     @G@@@@ OR 'ACC' (ASCII CONTROL CODE, BITS FH
)@@G@@1,0 = 1).  ANY VALUE OTHER THAN     @G@@@@ ZERO  OR  ONE  IN  THE LOW ORFI
)@@G@@DER TWO BITS OF THE THIRD ARGUMENT TO     @F@@@@ ASC IS IGNORED.  SEE BEFJ
)@@G@@LOW FOR USAGE OF THE SECOND ARGUMENT.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 8. 2.   ALFK
)@@G@@C     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS I     @G@@@@FL
)@@G@@ VALUE:  ALC(I)  =  THE LOWER CASE ASCII CHARACTER CORRESPONDING TO     FM
)@@G@@@C@@@@ THE FIELDATA CHARACTER I.  SEE NOTE BELOW.     @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7FN
)@@G@@. 8. 3.   ACC     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS FO
)@@G@@I     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NFP
)@@G@@PL   REV.23        2- 19@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ VALUE:     ACC(I)  =   FQ
)@@G@@THE ASCII CONTROL CODE CORRESPONDING TO THE     @B@@@@ FIELDATA CHARACTEFR
)@@G@@R I.  SEE NOTE BELOW.   @@@@@@@G@@@@ NOTE:  ASC, ALC AND ACC ALL USE ONLFS
)@@G@@Y THE LOW ORDER SIX BITS OF THE     @G@@@@ FIRST ARGUMENT.  THE REMAINDEFT
)@@G@@R OF THE WORD IS IGNORED.  THE SECOND     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  TO THESE FUNCFU
)@@G@@TIONS IS USED TO DEFINE THE PARITY STATE OF     @G@@@@ THE ASCII CHARACTFV
)@@G@@ER RETURNED.  THE VALUE OF THE LOW ORDER TWO BITS     @ @@@@ IS USED AS FW
)@@G@@OUTLINED BELOW:   @@@@@@@D@@@@            BITS 1,0 = 0    PARITY BIT ALWFX
)@@G@@AYS CLEAR   @C@@@@            BITS 1,0 = 1    FORCE ODD PARITY    @C@@@@FY
)@@G@@            BITS 1,0 = 2    FORCE EVEN PARITY   @E@@@@            BITS 1FZ
)@@G@@,0 = 3    PARITY BIT ALWAYS MARKED (SET)  @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE PARITY BIT ISGA
)@@G@@ POSITION 7  (COUNTING FROM 0),     AND IS SET BY     @D@@@@ PERFORMING GB
)@@G@@THE LOGICAL OR OF THE CHARACTER AND 0200. @@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 7. 8. 4.   AFGC
)@@G@@D     @D@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS:  1 OR 2  (A,A)  RESULT IS I     @G@@@@GD
)@@G@@ VALUE:  AFD(I) = THE FIELDATA CHARACTER CORRESPONDING TO THE ASCII     GE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CHARACTER REPRESENTED BY THE LOW ORDER SEVEN BITS OF I.  THE USAGGF
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ OF THE SECOND ARGUMENT IS AS FOLLOWS:    IF THE SECOND ARGUGG
)@@G@@MENT IS     @G@@@@ 'FALSE' (ZERO) TRANSLATION OF ASCII CONTROL CODES (0 GH
)@@G@@TO 037) IS TO     @G@@@@ FIELDATA SPACES (05).   IF THE SECOND ARGUMENT GI
)@@G@@IS 'TRUE' (NONZERO)     @G@@@@ ASCII  CONTROL  CODES  ARE  TRANSLATED  TGJ
)@@G@@O  THE FIELDATA CHARACTER     @G@@@@ CORRESPONDING  TO THE ASCII CHARACTGK
)@@G@@ER FORMED BY OR'ING THE CONTROL     @#@@@@ CODE WITH 0100.  @@@@@@@A@@@@GL
)@@G@@  2. 7. 9.   NOTES ON FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  FOLLOWING  FUNCTIOGM
)@@G@@NS ARE VALID ON THE LEFT OF THE EQUALS SIGN     @ @@@@ IN AN ASSIGNMENT GN
)@@G@@STATEMENT:  @@@@@@@C@@@@                FLD  IND  FN  PR  FLS  IOP  ITM GO
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ N.B.    PR  MAY  APPEAR  ON THE LEFT OF THE EQUALS SIGN ONLGP
)@@G@@Y IF AN     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  WAS ACTUALLY PASSED CORRESPONDING TO THE ARGQ
)@@G@@GUMENT TO PR.     @G@@@@ IF PR(X) REFERENCES THE IMPLICIT ARGUMENT ZERO GR
)@@G@@BECAUSE NO ARGUMENT     @G@@@@ NUMBER  X  WAS  PASSED,  ASSIGNING A VALUGS
)@@G@@E TO PR(X),  ALTHOUGH NOT     @G@@@@ ERRONEOUS, DOES NOTHING USEFUL, EITGT
)@@G@@HER.  CHECK THE VALUE OF ARG(X)     @B@@@@ TO DETERMINE IF AN ARGUMENT WGU
)@@G@@AS PASSED.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  2. 8.   OPERATORS     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@GV
)@@G@@ NPL OPERATORS ARE DIVIDED INTO TWO CLASSES:   1) NUMERIC OPERATORS     GW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AND  2) STRING OPERATORS.   THERE IS NO HIERARCHY WITHIN THE CLASGX
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ OF  NUMERIC  OPERATORS:    PRECEDENCE  MUST  BE  FORCED AS GY
)@@G@@DESIRED     @G@@@@ THROUGH THE USE OF PARENTHETICAL GROUPINGS.  IN THE CGZ
)@@G@@ASE OF STRING     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING HA
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 20@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ OPERATORS, HB
)@@G@@  ALL  PATTERN  MATCH  AND  REPLACEMENT  OPERATIONS ARE     @G@@@@ COMPLHC
)@@G@@ETED  BEFORE  ANY  CONCATENATION TAKES PLACE.   OPERATORS ARE     @A@@@@HD
)@@G@@ SUMMARIZED IN THE TABLES BELOW:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :------------HE
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   +        HF
)@@G@@ :    ADDITION, UNARY PLUS                :     @F@@@@     :------------HG
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   -        HH
)@@G@@ :    SUBTRACTION, UNARY MINUS            :     @F@@@@     :------------HI
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   *        HJ
)@@G@@ :    MULTIPLICATION                      :     @F@@@@     :------------HK
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   /        HL
)@@G@@ :    DIVISION                            :     @F@@@@     :------------HM
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   //       HN
)@@G@@ :    COVERED DIVISION                    :     @F@@@@     :            HO
)@@G@@ :    A//B = (A+B-1)/B                    :     @F@@@@     :------------HP
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   ^        HQ
)@@G@@ :    EXPONENTIATION                      :     @F@@@@     :------------HR
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   ** &     HS
)@@G@@ :    LOGICAL AND (LOGICAL PRODUCT)       :     @F@@@@     :------------HT
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   ++ !     HU
)@@G@@ :    LOGICAL OR (LOGICAL SUM)            :     @F@@@@     :------------HV
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   -- #     HW
)@@G@@ :    LOGICAL XOR (LOGICAL DIFFERENCE)    :     @F@@@@     :------------HX
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   */       HY
)@@G@@ :    LOGICAL SHIFT                       :     @F@@@@     :            HZ
)@@G@@ :    A*/B = A SHIFTED B BITS             :     @F@@@@     :            IA
)@@G@@ :    IF B>0, SHIFT LEFT, IF B<0 RIGHT    :     @F@@@@     :------------IB
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   +/       IC
)@@G@@ :    CIRCULAR SHIFT, AS ABOVE            :     @F@@@@     :------------ID
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   -/       IE
)@@G@@ :    ALGEBRAIC SHIFT                     :     @F@@@@     :            IF
)@@G@@ :    A-/B = A SHIFTED RIGHT B BITS,      :     @F@@@@     :            IG
)@@G@@ :    WITH SIGN FILL TO THE LEFT          :     @F@@@@     :------------IH
)@@G@@------------------------------------------:     @C@@@@                  II
)@@G@@ NPL ARITHMETIC OPERATORS     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY IJ
)@@G@@PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 21@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@IK
)@@G@@ THE FOLLOWING TABLE DESCRIBES RELATIONAL OPERATORS.  THE RESULT OF     IL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PERFORMING A RELATIONAL OPERATION IS EITHER ONE OR ZERO, DEPENDINIM
)@@G@@G     @E@@@@ ON THE TRUTH OR FALSITY, RESPECTIVELY, OF THE RELATION.    IN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A WORD ABOUT COMPARING FLOATING POINT VALUES:   THE EIO
)@@G@@QUALITY ('=')     @G@@@@ AND INEQUALITY ('<>' AND '><') TESTS ARE SUBJECIP
)@@G@@T TO A USER PROGRAM     @G@@@@ DEFINED TOLERANCE.     THE VALUE OF THE TIQ
)@@G@@OLERANCE IS STORED IN THE     @B@@@@ KEYWORD 'TOLER', AND IS USED AS FOLIR
)@@G@@LOWS: @@@@@@@C@@@@ FOR THE TEST 'A=B' OR 'A<>B', THE QUANTITY     @@@@@@IS
)@@G@@@A@@@@                    ABS((A-B)/A)    @@@@@@@G@@@@ IS CALCULATED.   IT
)@@G@@IF THIS RESULT IS LESS THAN ABS(TOLER),  TOLER<0,     @G@@@@ OR LESS THAIU
)@@G@@N OR EQUAL TO TOLER,  TOLER>0, A IS CONSIDERED EQUAL TO     @G@@@@ B.   IV
)@@G@@THE CONVERSE IS TRUE FOR THE INEQUALITY TESTS.  IF 'TOLER' IS     @F@@@@IW
)@@G@@ EQUAL TO ZERO, EQUALITY TESTING IS REDUCED TO IDENTITY TESTING.  @@@@@@IX
)@@G@@@@@@@@@D@@@@ THE INITIAL VALUE OF 'TOLER' IS 1.0E-5 (1/100000).   @@@@@@IY
)@@G@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------IZ
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   =         :    EQUALITY                            JA
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JB
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   <         :    LESS THAN                           JC
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JD
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   >         :    GREATER THAN                        JE
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JF
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   <> ><     :    INEQUALITY                          JG
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JH
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   <= =<     :    LESS THAN OR EQUAL                  JI
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JJ
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :   => >=     :    GREATER THAN OR EQUAL               JK
)@@G@@:     @F@@@@     :------------------------------------------------------JL
)@@G@@:     @D@@@@                   TABLE OF NPL RELATIONAL OPERATORS  @@@@@@JM
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  STRING  OPERATORS  WORK  ON  STRINGS  AND  STRING  VARJN
)@@G@@IABLES.     @G@@@@ PERFORMING A STRING OPERATION RESULTS IN A NEW STRINGJO
)@@G@@, AND, IN THE     @G@@@@ CASE OF PATTERN MATCH/REPLACEMENT,  A NUMERIC VJP
)@@G@@ALUE.   THE NUMERIC     @G@@@@ VALUE,    ASSIGNED  TO  THE  KEYWORD  'MAJQ
)@@G@@TCH',   CONSISTS  OF  THE     @G@@@@ ALTERNATION  COMPONENT THAT MATCHEDJR
)@@G@@ IN BITS 35-18,  AND THE COLUMN     @G@@@@ AT  WHICH  THE  MATCH WAS SUCJS
)@@G@@CESSFUL IN BITS 17-0.   THE FOLLOWING     @B@@@@ TABLE DESCRIBES THE STRJT
)@@G@@ING OPERATORS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@     :------------------------------JU
)@@G@@------------------------:     @F@@@@     :   +         :    CONCATENATIOJV
)@@G@@N,                      :     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY JW
)@@G@@PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        2- 22@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@JX
)@@G@@     :             :    'ABC'+'123'='ABC123'.               :     @F@@@@JY
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@JZ
)@@G@@     :   /         :    PATTERN MATCH,                      :     @F@@@@KA
)@@G@@     :             :    STRING1/STRING2 RETURNS THE NULL    :     @F@@@@KB
)@@G@@     :             :    STRING AS THE STRING VALUE, BUT     :     @F@@@@KC
)@@G@@     :             :    RESULTS IN THE SETTING OF 'MATCH' AS:     @F@@@@KD
)@@G@@     :             :    OUTLINED ABOVE.  'MATCH' IS SET TO  :     @F@@@@KE
)@@G@@     :             :    -1 IF A PATTERN MATCH FAILS.        :     @F@@@@KF
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@KG
)@@G@@     :   ^         :    MATCH ASSIGNMENT,  CODING A PATTERN :     @F@@@@KH
)@@G@@     :             :    MATCH AS  STRING / PATTERN ^ VAR    :     @F@@@@KI
)@@G@@     :             :    OR  STRING = PATTERN ^ VAR  HAS     :     @F@@@@KJ
)@@G@@     :             :    EFFECT OF ASSIGNING THE STRING      :     @F@@@@KK
)@@G@@     :             :    'PATTERN' TO 'VAR' IF THE MATCH OF  :     @F@@@@KL
)@@G@@     :             :    THIS ALTERNATION COMPONENT IS       :     @F@@@@KM
)@@G@@     :             :    SUCCESSFUL.  IF ANY VAR FIELD IS    :     @F@@@@KN
)@@G@@     :             :    OMITTED, EXCEPT FOR THE FIRST, THE  :     @F@@@@KO
)@@G@@     :             :    LAST VAR SPECIFICATION GIVEN WILL   :     @F@@@@KP
)@@G@@     :             :    BE USED.                            :     @F@@@@KQ
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@KR
)@@G@@     :   =         :    STRING EQUALITY,                    :     @F@@@@KS
)@@G@@     :             :    SIMILAR TO PATTERN MATCH, EXCEPT    :     @F@@@@KT
)@@G@@     :             :    THAT STRING1 MUST BE IDENTICAL TO   :     @F@@@@KU
)@@G@@     :             :    STRING2.                            :     @F@@@@KV
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@KW
)@@G@@     :   !         :    PATTERN ALTERNATION,                :     @F@@@@KX
)@@G@@     :             :    IN A STRING EXPRESSION OF THE FORM  :     @F@@@@KY
)@@G@@     :             :    STRING1/STRING2!STRING3!...         :     @F@@@@KZ
)@@G@@     :             :    THE SCANNER ATTEMPTS TO FIND A MATCH:     @F@@@@LA
)@@G@@     :             :    IN STRING1 WITH ANY OF THE STRING2  :     @F@@@@LB
)@@G@@     :             :    ... STRINGN.                        :     @F@@@@LC
)@@G@@     :             :    BITS 35-18 OF 'MATCH' ARE SET TO THE:     @F@@@@LD
)@@G@@     :             :    RELATIVE POSITION WITHIN THE        :     @F@@@@LE
)@@G@@     :             :    ALTERNATION LIST OF THE COMPONENT   :     @F@@@@LF
)@@G@@     :             :    THAT SUCCESSFULLY MATCHED.          :     @F@@@@LG
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @F@@@@LH
)@@G@@     :   =         :    STRING REPLACEMENT,                 :     @F@@@@LI
)@@G@@     :             :    STRING1/PATTERN=REPLACEMENT         :     @F@@@@LJ
)@@G@@     :             :    IF 'PATTERN' IS FOUND IN 'STRING1', :     @F@@@@LK
)@@G@@     :             :    IT IS REPLACED BY 'REPLACEMENT'.    :     @F@@@@LL
)@@G@@     :             :    THUS, 'ABCDEF'/'CD'='...'           :     @F@@@@LM
)@@G@@     :             :    RESULTS IN THE STRING 'AB...EF'     :     @F@@@@LN
)@@G@@     :             :    WITH 'MATCH' = 01000003.            :     @F@@@@LO
)@@G@@     :------------------------------------------------------:     @C@@@@LP
)@@G@@                   SUMMARY OF STRING OPERATORS  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ N.B. LQ
)@@G@@ 'ANCHOR' IS AN NPL KEYWORD WHOSE VALUE DEFINES THE COLUMN AT     @G@@@@LR
)@@G@@ WHICH A PATTERN MATCH IS TO OCCUR.  ANCHOR IS IGNORED FOR A STRING     LS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ EQUALITY MATCH.  IF ANCHOR IS POSITIVE, EACH MATCH MUST SUCCEED ALT
)@@G@@T     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NLU
)@@G@@PL   REV.23        2- 23@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THAT  COLUMN  NUMBER.  LV
)@@G@@  IF  ANCHOR  IS NEGATIVE,  EACH MATCH MUST     @G@@@@ SUCCEED  AT  OR  LW
)@@G@@AFTER  COLUMN  ABS(ANCHOR).   A VALUE OF ZERO FOR     @G@@@@ ANCHOR  ONLLX
)@@G@@Y  ALLOWS  MATCHING  THE NULL STRING (EXCEPT FOR STRING     @C@@@@ EQUALLY
)@@G@@ITY).  THE INITIAL VALUE OF ANCHOR IS -1. @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKLZ
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        3-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@MA
)@@G@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  3.   STATEMENTS @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  3. 1MB
)@@G@@.   GENERAL @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AN  NPL  STATEMENT  CONSISTS  OF  AN OPTIMC
)@@G@@ONAL LABEL FOLLOWED BY AN     @G@@@@ OPERATION  FIELD.   THE OPERATION FMD
)@@G@@IELD MAY BE A PROGRAM CALL,  AN     @G@@@@ NPL  DIRECTIVE  OPERATION OR ME
)@@G@@AN ASSIGNMENT.   STATEMENTS MAY START     @G@@@@ ANYWHERE  ON  THE  CARDMF
)@@G@@  (OR  LINE  INPUT FROM A DEMAND TERMINAL).     @G@@@@ BLANKS ARE SIGNIFMG
)@@G@@ICANT ONLY AS SEPARATORS BETWEEN IDENTIFIERS, AND     @G@@@@ MAY   BE   MH
)@@G@@USED   NEARLY  ANYWHERE  IN  ANY  QUANTITY  TO  IMPROVE     @#@@@@ READAMI
)@@G@@BILITY.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ BLANKS  MAY  NOT APPEAR IN THE FOLLOWING MJ
)@@G@@THREE PLACES:   BETWEEN A     @G@@@@ LABEL AND ITS COLON.   BETWEEN A VAMK
)@@G@@RIABLE OR FUNCTION NAME AND ITS     @G@@@@ OPEN  PARENTHESIS.    SURROUNML
)@@G@@DING THE SLASH IN A PROGRAM CALL WITH     @G@@@@ OPTIONS.    AT  LEAST  MM
)@@G@@ONE  BLANK  MUST  BE CODED FOLLOWING AN NPL     @G@@@@ DIRECTIVE UNLESS MN
)@@G@@THE NEXT FIELD IN THE STATEMENT IS A LITERAL,  IN     @A@@@@ WHICH CASE MO
)@@G@@NO BLANKS ARE NEEDED.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  STATEMENT  MAY  COMPRISE  MP
)@@G@@A WHOLE LINE INPUT,  OR MORE THAN ONE     @G@@@@ STATEMENT MAY BE CODED MQ
)@@G@@ON A SINGLE LINE.   IN THE LATTER CASE, THE     @G@@@@ VARIOUS  STATEMENMR
)@@G@@TS  ARE  SEPARATED BY SEMICOLONS.  THE SECTION ON     @G@@@@ CONTINUATIOMS
)@@G@@N  DESCRIBES HOW TO CONTINUE A STATEMENT OVER MORE THAN     @^@@@@ ONE LMT
)@@G@@INE INPUT TO NPL. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  STATEMENT  WHOSE OPERATION FIELDMU
)@@G@@ STARTS WITH A LITERAL,  RATHER     @G@@@@ THAN  WITH  A DIRECTIVE OR PRMV
)@@G@@OGRAM CALL,  IS ASSUMED TO BE A PRINT     @B@@@@ STATEMENT, AND WILL BE MW
)@@G@@EXECUTED AS SUCH. @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  3. 2.   LABELS  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@MX
)@@G@@ STATEMENT LABELS ARE ONE TO FIVE CHARACTER IDENTIFIERS,  WHICH MAY     MY
)@@G@@@G@@@@ BE SUBSCRIPTED OR UNSUBSCRIPTED,  IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWED BY A COLONMZ
)@@G@@.     @G@@@@ (THE  COLON  IMMEDIATELY  FOLLOWS  THE  CLOSED  PARENTHESISNA
)@@G@@  OF  A     @G@@@@ SUBSCRIPTED LABEL,   WITH NO INTERVENING BLANKS.)    NB
)@@G@@SUBSCRIPTS ON     @G@@@@ LABELS MAY RANGE FROM ZERO TO 62.  A LABEL WITHNC
)@@G@@ NO SUBSCRIPT AND A     @G@@@@ LABEL WITH SUBSCRIPT ZERO ARE NOT THE SAMND
)@@G@@E, AND BOTH MAY APPEAR IN     @G@@@@ THE SAME PROGRAM.  STATEMENT LABELSNE
)@@G@@ ARE FREE FORM, I.E., THEY NEED     @G@@@@ NOT   START  IN  ANY  PARTICUNF
)@@G@@LAR  COLUMN,   AND THEY MAY DUPLICATE     @G@@@@ VARIABLE AND/OR DIRECTING
)@@G@@VE NAMES WITH NO CONFUSION.   LABELS MAY BE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NENH
)@@G@@W YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        3-  2@@@@@@NI
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ DEFINED ONCE ONLY IN A PROGRAM OR PROGRAM UNIT,  HOWENJ
)@@G@@VER,  AND MAY     @G@@@@ NOT  BE  DEFINED  INDIRECTLY  ($  OPERATOR).   NK
)@@G@@ A PROGRAM MAY CALL     @E@@@@ ANOTHER PROGRAM, THOUGH, WITH ONE OR MORENL
)@@G@@ LABELS IN COMMON.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ LABEL SUBSCRIPTS MAY BE EXPRESSED ANM
)@@G@@S OCTAL OR DECIMAL CONSTANTS OR     @G@@@@ AS SINGLE CHARACTER LITERALS.NN
)@@G@@    A LABEL SUBSCRIPT MAY NOT BE LESS     @G@@@@ THAN  ZERO  NOR  GREATENO
)@@G@@R  THAN  62.    THE SUBSCRIPT 63 IS APPLIED     @G@@@@ INTERNALLY TO LABNP
)@@G@@ELS WHICH WERE UNSUBSCRIPTED AT COMPILATION TIME.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@NQ
)@@G@@ AN EXAMPLE OF A STATEMENT WITH A LABEL IS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@      NR
)@@G@@                LABEL:  GO TAG@@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@ AN EXAMPLE OF A SUBSCRINS
)@@G@@PTED LABEL DEFINITION MIGHT BE:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                  NT
)@@G@@  TAG(34):  CALL SUBR,A,B     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  STATEMENT  MAY CONSINU
)@@G@@ST OF A LABEL WITH NO OPERATION FIELD.   IN     @G@@@@ THIS  CASE THE LANV
)@@G@@BEL WILL APPLY TO THE NEXT STATEMENT,  EVEN IF IT     @G@@@@ HAS A LABELNW
)@@G@@ OF ITS OWN.   A STATEMENT MAY THUS HAVE AS MANY LABELS     @A@@@@ AS ARNX
)@@G@@E DESIRED ATTACHED TO IT.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  ELSEWHERE  IN  TNY
)@@G@@HIS  MANUAL  USE  OF  A  STATEMENT LABEL IS     @G@@@@ INDICATED,   THE NZ
)@@G@@ LABEL  REFERENCE  MAY  BE  TO  A  SUBSCRIPTED OR     @^@@@@ UNSUBSCRIPTOA
)@@G@@ED LABEL.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@  3. 3.   LABEL ASSIGNMENT TO VARIABLES   OB
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ STATEMENT LABELS ARE DISTINCT DATA TYPES,   AND MAY BOC
)@@G@@E ASSIGNED TO     @G@@@@ VARIABLES FOR USE WITH THE INDIRECT REFERENCE OOD
)@@G@@PERATOR.   HOWEVER,     @G@@@@ IT  IS  NOT  SUFFICIENT  TO ASSIGN ONLY TOE
)@@G@@HE NAME OF THE LABEL IN A     @G@@@@ SIMPLE ARITHMETIC STATEMENT, EVEN FOF
)@@G@@OR AN UNSUBSCRIPTED LABEL.  THE     @G@@@@ 'ASSIGN' STATEMENT,  WHOSE FOOG
)@@G@@RMAT IS OUTLINED BELOW,  MUST BE USED     @#@@@@ FOR THIS PURPOSE:@@@@@@OH
)@@G@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                    ASSIGN <LABEL> TO <VAR>     @@@@@@@@@@@@OI
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE <LABEL> SPECIFIED IS ASSIGNED TO THE VARIABLE DENOTED BY <VAROJ
)@@G@@>     @G@@@@ AND <VAR> MAY ITSELF BE SUBSCRIPTED OR UNSUBSCRIPTED.   WHEOK
)@@G@@N <VAR>     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAOL
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23        3-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IS REFERENCED INDOM
)@@G@@IRECTLY TO RETRIEVE THE LABEL REFERENCE,   IT MAY     @G@@@@ NOT HAVE ANON
)@@G@@OTHER LEVEL OF SUBSCRIPTING FOR THE PURPOSE OF CHANGING     @G@@@@ THE  OO
)@@G@@ORIGINAL  LABEL  SUBSCRIPT.   ARITHMETIC  OPERATIONS  MAY  BE     @G@@@@OP
)@@G@@ PERFORMED ON <VAR>,   HOWEVER,  TO CHANGE THE LABEL SUBSCRIPT,  AS     OQ
)@@G@@@E@@@@ LONG AS THE SUBSCRIPT IS NOT THUS CAUSED TO EXCEED 62.     @@@@@@OR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  <LABEL>  REFERENCED  BY THE 'ASSIGN' STATEMENT MUST HAOS
)@@G@@VE BEEN     @D@@@@ DEFINED WITHIN THE PROGRAM UNIT AT COMPILATION TIME. OT
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  3. 4.   CONTINUATION  @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@ NPL STATEMEOU
)@@G@@NTS MAY BE CONTINUED IN ONE OF THREE WAYS:@@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@          1)OV
)@@G@@    ENDING A LINE WITH THE AMPERSAND (&)  @D@@@@          2)    ENDING AOW
)@@G@@ LINE WITH THE SEMICOLON (;)  @C@@@@          3)    ENDING A LINE WITH TOX
)@@G@@HE COMMA (,)@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IN  DEMAND  MODE,   INPUT  IS  PROMPTED WOY
)@@G@@ITH THE GREATER THAN SIGN     @G@@@@ ('>').   IF CONTINUATION IS SPECIFIOZ
)@@G@@ED,  THE '>' IS PRECEDED BY THE     @G@@@@ NUMBER OF WORDS ALREADY ENTERPA
)@@G@@ED.   A WARNING MESSAGE IS PRINTED AS     @G@@@@ INPUT APPROACHES THE BUPB
)@@G@@FFER LIMIT.  INPUT IS NOT PROMPTED IN BATCH     @G@@@@ MODE,   AND  IN  PC
)@@G@@THIS MODE,  EACH LINE READ IS ECHOED IN THE RUN'S     @G@@@@ OUTPUT.    PD
)@@G@@THE CHARACTER '?' (OR BACK ARROW) AS THE LAST CHARACTER     @E@@@@ IN A PE
)@@G@@LINE CAUSES NPL TO DISCARD ANY INPUT ALREADY ACCEPTED.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@PF
)@@G@@ EXECUTION OF AN NPL PROGRAM WILL NOT OCCUR UNTIL A LINE IS ENTERED     PG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ WHICH  DOES  NOT SPECIFY CONTINUATION.   AMPERSAND CONTINUATION IPH
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ THE  MOST  GENERAL  FORM,   AND IS THE ONLY METHOD OF CONTIPI
)@@G@@NUATION     @G@@@@ GUARANTEED  TO  PRESERVE  THE PROPER NUMBER OF BLANKSPJ
)@@G@@ IN LITERALS.     @G@@@@ IF CONTINUATION IS EFFECTED THROUGH THE USE OF PK
)@@G@@THE AMPERSAND,  THE     @G@@@@ FIRST CHARACTER OF THE CONTINUATION LINE PL
)@@G@@REPLACES THE AMPERSAND IN     @G@@@@ THE LINE BEING CONTINUED,  AND THE PM
)@@G@@SUBSEQUENT CHARACTERS ARE MOVED     @G@@@@ INTO THEIR SAME RELATIVE POSIPN
)@@G@@TIONS WITHIN THE BODY OF THE PROGRAM.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ CONTINUATIOPO
)@@G@@N  MAY  ALSO OCCUR BECAUSE THE LAST CHARACTER OF A LINE     @G@@@@ ENTERPP
)@@G@@ED  IS ONE OF THE PUNCTUATION CHARACTERS, COMMA OR SEMICOLON.     @G@@@@PQ
)@@G@@ AS  MENTIONED  EARLIER, THE SECMICOLON IS THE STATEMENT SEPARATOR.     PR
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  COMMA  IS  USED  AS  A BREAK CHARACTER WITHIN THE BODY OF NPPS
)@@G@@L     @G@@@@ STATEMENTS,  AND WHEREVER A COMMA IS A PART OF THE SYNTAX, PT
)@@G@@ IT MAY     @G@@@@ BE  USED  FOR CONTINUATION.   WHEN A LINE IS ACCEPTEDPU
)@@G@@ BY NPL WHICH     @G@@@@ DOES NOT REQUEST CONTINUATION, THE PROGRAM INPUPV
)@@G@@T WILL BE EXECUTED.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEPW
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        3-  4@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@PX
)@@G@@@#@@@@  3. 5.   COMMENTS@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ COMMENTS  MAY  BE  INSERTED  PY
)@@G@@INTO  AN NPL PROGRAM IN EITHER OF TWO     @G@@@@ WAYS:    USE  OF  THE  PZ
)@@G@@'REMARK' STATEMENT,  THE EFFECT OF WHICH IS     @G@@@@ ESSENTIALLY A NO QA
)@@G@@OPERATION, OR BY SURROUNDING A STRING WITH SQUARE     @G@@@@ BRACKETS.  QB
)@@G@@  THE ONLY RESTRICTION ABOUT BRACKETED COMMENTS IS THAT     @G@@@@ ALL AQC
)@@G@@POSTROPHES AND NESTED BRACKETS BE MATCHED.  THIS IS TO INSURE     @G@@@@QD
)@@G@@ THAT  A  COMMENT FIELD WILL NOT BE PREMATURELY TERMINATED IF IT IS     QE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ USED TO 'COMMENT OUT' SEVERAL LINES OF CODE,  ONE OR MORE OF WHICQF
)@@G@@H     @G@@@@ CONTAIN  LITERALS  THEMSELVES  CONTAINING  SQUARE BRACKETS.QG
)@@G@@   IF A     @G@@@@ COMMENT  FIELD  HAS  NOT BEEN CLOSED WHEN THE COMPILEQH
)@@G@@R REACHES THE     @C@@@@ END OF THE PROGRAM, A WARNING MESSAGE IS GIVEN.QI
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   RQJ
)@@G@@EV.23        4-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  4.   THE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENQK
)@@G@@T     @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  4. 1.   TYPES OF ASSIGNMENTSQL
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@ THERE ARE FOUR TYPES OF ASSIGNMENTS IN NPL:    @@@@@@QM
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@         1)        ARITHMETIC/ARITHMETIC  @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@QN
)@@G@@         2)        ARITHMETIC/STRING@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@         3)       QO
)@@G@@ STRING/STRING    @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@         4)        EXCHANGE ASSIGNMEQP
)@@G@@NT    @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@ EACH TYPE IS DESCRIBED IN MORE DETAIL IN THE FOQQ
)@@G@@LLOWING SECTIONS. @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  4. 1. 1.   ARITHMETIC/ARITHMQR
)@@G@@ETIC  @@@@@@@C@@@@ THE PURE ARITHMETIC ASSIGNMENT HAS THE FORMAT: @@@@@@QS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                   <VAR> = <EXPR>   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHEREQT
)@@G@@ <VAR> IS ANY LEGAL VARIABLE NAME,  AND <EXPR> IS ANY NUMERIC     @G@@@@QU
)@@G@@ EXPRESSION.   IF THE FIRST ELEMENT IN <EXPR> IS A NUMERIC LITERAL,     QV
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IT  MUST  BE SURROUNDED BY PARENTHESES OR BE PREFIXED WITH A UNARQW
)@@G@@Y     @G@@@@ PLUS  OR  MINUS  TO  PREVENT  THE  INTERPRETER  FROM  TREATQX
)@@G@@ING THE     @A@@@@ ASSIGNMENT AS ARITHMETIC/STRING.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@QY
)@@G@@ <VAR>  MAY  BE  APPENDED WITH A PARTIAL WORD DESIGNATOR,  IN WHICH     QZ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CASE  ONLY THE PARTIAL WORD REFERENCED WILL BE SET TO THE VALUE ORA
)@@G@@F     @]@@@@ <EXPR>.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NUMERIC  EXPRESSIONS ARE SCANRB
)@@G@@NED RECURSIVELY,  ALLOWING THE USE OF     @G@@@@ FULL  NUMERIC  EXPRESSIRC
)@@G@@ONS  AS  SUBSCRIPTS  OR FUNCTION ARGUMENTS.     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NERD
)@@G@@W YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        4-  2@@@@@@RE
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THERE  IS  NO  OPERATOR  PRECEDENCE IN NPL,  BUT PRECRF
)@@G@@EDENCE CAN BE     @D@@@@ FORCED THROUGH THE USE OF PARENTHETICAL GROUPINRG
)@@G@@GS.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  4. 1. 2.   ARITHMETIC/STRING@@@@@@@G@@@@RH
)@@G@@ IN  THE  ARITHMETIC/STRING  ASSIGNMENT,  AN ARITHMETIC VARIABLE IS     RI
)@@G@@@F@@@@ ASSIGNED THE NUMERIC RESULT OF EVALUATING A STRING EXPRESSION:   RJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                   <VAR> = <STRING> @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@RK
)@@G@@ ANY  STRING  VALUE  RESULTING  FROM  THE EVALUATION OF <STRING> IS     RL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DISCARDED,   BUT  ANY NUMERIC VALUE RESULTING FROM A PATTERN MATCRM
)@@G@@H     @G@@@@ (VALUE OF 'MATCH') IS ASSIGNED TO <VAR>, AS WELL AS BEING ARN
)@@G@@SSIGNED     @G@@@@ TO  'MATCH'.    IF  <STRING> DOES NOT CONTAIN ANY PATRO
)@@G@@TERN MATCHING     @E@@@@ OPERATIONS, THE LAST 'MATCH' RESULT IS STORED IRP
)@@G@@NTO <VAR>.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ EXAMPLE:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@       ANCHORQ
)@@G@@R = -1@^@@@@       TRANSP = +'$'    @F@@@@       K3 = 'ABCDEFGH' / 'BDE'RR
)@@G@@ ! 'HGF' ! 'D$' ^ A$ ! 'DDDDD' ^    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  VARIABLE K3 RS
)@@G@@ASSUMES THE VALUE (IN OCTAL) 03000004,  SINCE THE     @G@@@@ PATTERN  MART
)@@G@@TCH  WAS  SUCCESSFUL  AT  COLUMN  4,   WITH  THE  THIRD     @G@@@@ ALTERRU
)@@G@@NATION COMPONENT SUCCESSFULLY MATCHING 'D$'.  NOTICE THAT THE     @G@@@@RV
)@@G@@ '$' WAS DEFINED AS A TRANSPARENT CHARACTER,  THEREBY AUTOMATICALLY     RW
)@@G@@@G@@@@ MATCHING  ANY  CHARACTER.    SINCE  THE MATCH WAS SUCCESSFUL,  THRX
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  A$  RECEIVES  THE  STRING  'DE',   WHICH  WAS THERY
)@@G@@ ACTUAL     @G@@@@ SUBSTRING MATCHED BY 'D$'.  ALSO, HAD THE MATCH SUCCERZ
)@@G@@EDED WITH THE     @G@@@@ STRING  'DDDDD',  THE FOURTH ALTERNATION COMPONSA
)@@G@@ENT,  A$ WOULD HAVE     @G@@@@ BEEN  ASSIGNED  THAT  STRING BECAUSE OF TSB
)@@G@@HE IMPLIED MATCH VARIABLE     @G@@@@ ASSIGNMENT  SPECIFIED  BY  THE  OPESC
)@@G@@RATOR  '^'  NOT  FOLLOWED  BY A     @#@@@@ VARIABLE NAME.   @@@@@@@@@@@@SD
)@@G@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  4. 1. 3.   STRING/STRING    @@@@@@@G@@@@ THE   STRING/STRISE
)@@G@@NG   ASSIGNMENT  ASSIGNS  THE  STRING  RESULT  OF     @G@@@@ PERFORMING SF
)@@G@@STRING OPERATIONS TO A STRING VARIABLE.  THE FORMAT IS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@SG
)@@G@@@A@@@@                   <VAR> = <STRING> @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKSH
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        4-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@SI
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ 'MATCH'  IS  SET  AS OUTLINED ABOVE,  AND <VAR>SJ
)@@G@@ ASSUMES THE STRING     @G@@@@ VALUE  OF  <STRING>.    AN  ERROR WILL OCSK
)@@G@@CUR IF <VAR> HAS NOT BEEN     @G@@@@ DIMENSIONED LARGE ENOUGH TO RECEIVESL
)@@G@@ <STRING>.  THE MAXIMUM SIZE IN     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS  TO WHICH A STRINGSM
)@@G@@ EXPRESSION CAN GROW IS DETERMINED BY     @G@@@@ THE  VALUE  OF  THE  KESN
)@@G@@YWORD 'STRING',  WHOSE INITIAL VALUE IS 378     @#@@@@ (CHARACTERS).    SO
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  A  STRING/STRING  ASSIGNMENT  SPECIFIES  PATTERN SP
)@@G@@MATCH WITH OR     @G@@@@ WITHOUT  REPLACEMENT,  AND THE PATTERN MATCH FASQ
)@@G@@ILS,  NO ASSIGNMENT     @G@@@@ TAKES PLACE,  AND THE VALUE OF <VAR> REMASR
)@@G@@INS UNCHANGED.  THE VALUE     @G@@@@ OF  'MATCH'  CAN BE INTERROGATED THSS
)@@G@@ROUGH THE USE OF THE RELATIONAL     @G@@@@ OPERATORS  AND/OR  THE VARIOUST
)@@G@@S CONDITIONAL STATEMENTS TO DETERMINE     @ @@@@ IF A MATCH WAS SUCCESSFSU
)@@G@@UL.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AN  ALTERNATIVE  MEANS  OF DETERMINING THE SUCCSV
)@@G@@ESS OR FAILURE OF A     @G@@@@ STRING/STRING  ASSIGNMENT SPECIFYING PATTSW
)@@G@@ERN MATCHING IS TO CODE A     @G@@@@ FAILURE  GOTO  FIELD AS THE LAST ITSX
)@@G@@EM IN THE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT.     @A@@@@ THE FORMAT OF THE FAILURE GOTSY
)@@G@@O IS: @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@          <STRING VAR> = <STRING EXPR>  (<FAILURSZ
)@@G@@E GOTO>)    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <FAILURE  GOTO>  IS THE LABEL OF A STATEMTA
)@@G@@ENT TO RECEIVE CONTROL IF     @G@@@@ THE ASSIGNMENT STATEMENT FAILS BECATB
)@@G@@USE A PATTERN MATCH FAILED.  IT     @G@@@@ IS CODED AS SHOWN, SURROUNDEDTC
)@@G@@ BY PARENTHESES.  THE KEYWORD 'MATCH'     @A@@@@ IS SET NORMALLY, AS OUTTD
)@@G@@LINED ABOVE.@@@@@@@A@@@@  4. 1. 4.   THE EXCH STATEMENT     @@@@@@@G@@@@TE
)@@G@@ THE  'EXCH'  STATEMENT  PROVIDES A MEANS TO EXCHANGE THE VALUES OF     TF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ TWO  VARIABLES  WITHOUT THE NEED FOR A THIRD TEMPORARY CELL.   ITTG
)@@G@@S     @]@@@@ FORMAT IS: @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                    EXCH A = BTH
)@@G@@,...  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  EFFECT  OF  THE  'EXCH'  STATEMENT IS THE TI
)@@G@@SAME AS THAT OF THE     @A@@@@ FOLLOWING THREE STATEMENT SEQUENCE:@@@@@@TJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@ @@@@                    TEMP = A  @ @@@@                    A = TK
)@@G@@B     @ @@@@                    B = TEMP  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKTL
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        4-  4@@@@@@@@@@@@TM
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ PARTIAL WORD QUALIFICATION IS ALLOWED WITHIN THE 'EXCH' STATN
)@@G@@TEMENT,     @G@@@@ AS  IS  THE  IMPLIED  DO  MECHANISM  AS OUTLINED IN TTO
)@@G@@HE CHAPTER ON     @C@@@@ INPUT/OUTPUT, SECTION ON FORMATTED I/O LIST.   TP
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   RTQ
