)@@G@@EV.23        5-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  5.   PROGRAMS   @@@@@@@@@@@@TR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AN  NPL PROGRAM CONSISTS OF ONE OR MORE NPL STATEMENTS EXECTS
)@@G@@UTED AS     @G@@@@ A  UNIT.    STATEMENTS  WITHIN  PROGRAMS ARE EXECUTEDTT
)@@G@@ SEQUENTIALLY     @G@@@@ UNLESS A TRANSFER OF CONTROL OCCURS WITHIN THE TU
)@@G@@PROGRAM.   PROGRAMS     @G@@@@ CAN  BE  COMPLETE  IN  THEMSELVES OR THEYTV
)@@G@@ MAY CALL OTHER PROGRAMS.     @G@@@@ ANY  PROGRAM  WILL  HAVE  AVAILABLETW
)@@G@@  TO  IT  ANY  OTHER  PROGRAM'S     @G@@@@ VARIABLES  AND  ARRAYS.    ANTX
)@@G@@  ARRAY  OR  VARIABLE MAY BE DECLARED     @G@@@@ 'LOCAL' BY A PROGRAM,  TY
)@@G@@HOWEVER,  IN WHICH CASE IT WILL BE RESTORED     @G@@@@ TO  THE  STATE  ITZ
)@@G@@T  WAS  IN  AT  THE TIME OF PROGRAM CALL WHEN THE     @#@@@@ PROGRAM EXIUA
)@@G@@TS.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  PROGRAMS MAY BE NAMED OR UNNAMED.   AN UNNUB
)@@G@@AMED PROGRAM IS ONE     @G@@@@ ENTERED  FROM  THE  PRIMARY  INPUT  DEVICUC
)@@G@@E  (CARD READER OR DEMAND     @G@@@@ TERMINAL) BY SPECIFYING CONTINUATIOUD
)@@G@@N,  AS NECESSARY,  AS DESCRIBED     @G@@@@ EARLIER.    AN  UNNAMED  PROGUE
)@@G@@RAM  MAY NOT BE SAVED,  NOR MAY IT BE     @G@@@@ RE-EXECUTED UNLESS REDEUF
)@@G@@FINED.   A NAMED PROGRAM CAN BE SAVED,  AND     @B@@@@ CAN BE EXECUTED AUG
)@@G@@S MANY TIMES AS DESIRED.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  NAMED PROGRAM REFERENCE ISUH
)@@G@@ REALLY THE TRIVIAL CASE OF EXECUTING     @D@@@@ AN UNNAMED PROGRAM WHICUI
)@@G@@H CALLS THE NAMED PROGRAM.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  5. 1.   NAMED PROGRAMSUJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@  5. 1. 1.   THE PROG (OR PROGRM) DIRECTIVE     UK
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@ THE FORMAT OF THE 'PROG' DIRECTIVE IS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@UL
)@@G@@                        PROG <IDENT>@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <IDENT>  IS THE NUM
)@@G@@AME TO BE GIVEN TO THE PROGRAM BEING DEFINED.   A     @G@@@@ CALL TO REFUN
)@@G@@ERENCE THE PROGRAM THUS DEFINED WOULD BE A REFERENCE TO     @G@@@@ <IDENUO
)@@G@@T> IN THE OPERATION FIELD OF A STATEMENT.  ALL THE STATEMENTS     @G@@@@UP
)@@G@@ IN  THE  PROGRAM  CONTAINING THE 'PROG' DIRECTIVE UP TO THE END OF     UQ
)@@G@@@C@@@@ THE PROGRAM OR UP TO A STATEMENT OF THE FORM:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@UR
)@@G@@                           <IDENT>^ @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  <IDENT>  IUS
)@@G@@S  THE  SAME  NAME  AS  APPEARED  ON  THE  'PROG'     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@UT
)@@G@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  2UU
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ DIRECTIVE, FORM THE BODY OF THE NAMED PROGRAM. UV
)@@G@@ THUS A PROGRAM MAY     @G@@@@ BE WRITTEN WHOSE PURPOSE IS TO DEFINE OTHUW
)@@G@@ER PROGRAM.  FOR EXAMPLE:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  1.               PROG UX
)@@G@@PROG1;@E@@@@  2.      DEFST:   PRINT '''PROG1'' IS A PROGRAM TO DEFINE';UY
)@@G@@@E@@@@  3.               PRINT 'ANOTHER PROGRAM CALLED ''PROG2''';@ @@@@UZ
)@@G@@  4.               PROG PROG2;@E@@@@  5.               PRINT 'THIS PROGRVA
)@@G@@AM IS CALLED PROG2';    @^@@@@  6.               EXIT;@ @@@@  7.        VB
)@@G@@       PROG2^;    @F@@@@  8.               PRINT 'PROG1 IS FINISHED, PROVC
)@@G@@G2 IS DEFINED';   @ @@@@  9.               PROG1^     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@VD
)@@G@@ EXPLANATION:    LINE  1  IS  THE 'PROG' DIRECTIVE THAT SETS UP THE     VE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DEFINITION  OF  THE  PROGRAM  NAMED  'PROG1'.    LINES 2 AND 3 ARVF
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ 'PRINT'  STATEMENTS  IN  THE PROGRAM 'PROG1'.   LINE 4 IS AVG
)@@G@@ 'PROG'     @G@@@@ DIRECTIVE SETTING UP THE DEFINITION OF 'PROG2'.  LINEVH
)@@G@@S 5 AND 6 ARE     @G@@@@ STATEMENTS IN 'PROG2'.  LINE 7 IS THE SENTINEL VI
)@@G@@DEFINING THE END OF     @G@@@@ THE  PROGRAM 'PROG2'.   LINE 8 IS THE LASVJ
)@@G@@T EXECUTABLE STATEMENT IN     @G@@@@ 'PROG1',   AND  LINE  9  IS THE SENVK
)@@G@@TINEL TERMINATING DEFINITION OF     @G@@@@ 'PROG1'.  UPON EXECUTION OF TVL
)@@G@@HE UNNAMED PROGRAM LISTED ABOVE, ONLY     @G@@@@ 'PROG1'  IS  DEFINED.  VM
)@@G@@ IT ITSELF MUST BE CALLED BEFORE 'PROG2' IS     @A@@@@ DEFINED AND AVAILVN
)@@G@@ABLE FOR USE.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@ EXECUTION OF 'PROG1' RESULTS IN THEVO
)@@G@@ FOLLOWING OUTPUT:@@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@                    'PROG1' IS A PROVP
)@@G@@GRAM TO DEFINE    @D@@@@                    ANOTHER PROGRAM CALLED 'PROGVQ
)@@G@@2'    @E@@@@                    PROG1 IS FINISHED, PROG2 IS DEFINED     VR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF 'PROG2' IS THEN CALLED, IT PRINTS THE FOLLOWING LIVS
)@@G@@NE AND EXITS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@                    THIS PROGRAM IS VT
)@@G@@CALLED 'PROG2'    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ LINE  9  IN  THE  EXAMPLE,  THE 'PRVU
)@@G@@OG1^' STATEMENT,  IS NOT REALLY     @G@@@@ REQUIRED, SINCE THE END OF THVV
)@@G@@E PROGRAM CONTAINING THE 'PROG PROG1'     @G@@@@ STATEMENT  IS  ALSO THEVW
)@@G@@ END OF THE PROGRAM 'PROG1'.   THE 'PROG2^'     @G@@@@ LINE,   HOWEVER, VX
)@@G@@ IS REQUIRED,  SINCE IF IT WERE NOT PRESENT,  THE     @G@@@@ INTERPRETERVY
)@@G@@ WOULD NOT KNOW THAT THE DEFINITION OF 'PROG2' ENDED AT     @G@@@@ LINE VZ
)@@G@@6, AND 'PROG2' WOULD CONTAIN STATEMENT NUMBER EIGHT, WHICH IS     @ @@@@WA
)@@G@@ REALLY A PART OF 'PROG1'.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKWB
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@WC
)@@G@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  5. 2.   INVOKING NAMED PROGRAMS   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  NAWD
)@@G@@MED  PROGRAM  IS  CALLED  FOR  USE WITH THE 'INVOKE' OR 'XQT'     @]@@@@WE
)@@G@@ STATEMENT: @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@                    INVOKE <PROGNAME> [OPTWF
)@@G@@IONAL FIELD(S)]   @D@@@@                    XQT <PROGNAME> [OPTIONAL FIEWG
)@@G@@LD(S)]@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE THE OPTIONAL FIELDS MAY BE PROGRAM OPTIONWH
)@@G@@S AND/OR ARGUMENTS,     @G@@@@ AS  DESCRIBED  BELOW.    IN  MOST  CASES,WI
)@@G@@  HOWEVER,  THE CODING OF     @G@@@@ 'INVOKE'  OR 'XQT' IS NOT NECESSARYWJ
)@@G@@,  AS USAGE OF THE PROGRAM NAME     @G@@@@ IN  THE DIRECTIVE FIELD OF ANWK
)@@G@@ NPL STATEMENT IS SUFFICIENT TO CAUSE     @G@@@@ PROGRAM  LOAD  AND EXECWL
)@@G@@UTION,  ASSUMING THAT THE PROGRAM NAME DOES     @G@@@@ NOT DUPLICATE THAWM
)@@G@@T OF AN NPL STATEMENT DIRECTIVE.   IN THIS LATTER     @G@@@@ CASE,  THOUWN
)@@G@@GH, THE PRESENCE OF AN OPTIONS FIELD OR COMMA FOLLOWING     @G@@@@ THE  WO
)@@G@@NAME  WILL SERVE TO DISTINGUISH THE PROGRAM NAME FROM THAT OF     @G@@@@WP
)@@G@@ AN  NPL  DIRECTIVE.    THE  'INVOKE' AND 'XQT' DIRECTIVES ARE MOST     WQ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ USEFUL  AS  MEANS  OF  IMPROVING THE READABILITY AND DOCUMENTATIOWR
)@@G@@N     @^@@@@ VALUE OF NPL PROGRAMS. @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  5. 3.   PROGRAM WS
)@@G@@ARGUMENTS   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NAMED  PROGRAMS MAY HAVE ARGUMENTS PASSEDWT
)@@G@@ TO THEM AT THE TIME THAT     @G@@@@ THEY  ARE  CALLED.    THE  MAXIMUM WU
)@@G@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS ALLOWED IS     @G@@@@ DEFINED IN THE APPENDIX ON NPWV
)@@G@@L MAXIMUMS.  PROGRAM ARGUMENTS MAY BE     @G@@@@ EITHER  STRING  OR  NUMWW
)@@G@@ERIC  EXPRESSIONS OR NAMES.   ARGUMENTS ARE     @G@@@@ PASSED  BY  NAME WX
)@@G@@ AND  APPEAR  ON  THE PROGRAM CALL LINE IN A LIST     @ @@@@ SEPARATED BWY
)@@G@@Y COMMAS, THUS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                    PROG[,]ARG1,ARG2WZ
)@@G@@,...,ARGN   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE COMMA FOLLOWING THE PROGRAM NAME IS OXA
)@@G@@PTIONAL,  BUT MUST APPEAR     @G@@@@ IF  THE  PROGRAM  NAME  DUPLICATES XB
)@@G@@AN NPL DIRECTIVE.   THUS,  IF A     @G@@@@ PROGRAM  NAMED 'PROG' (DUPLICXC
)@@G@@ATES A DIRECTIVE) WERE TO BE EXECUTED     @D@@@@ WITH THE SINGLE ARGUMENXD
)@@G@@T '9', IT WOULD BE CALLED AS: @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@                    PROGXE
)@@G@@,9    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  THE  SAME  PROGRAM  WERE  TO  BE CALLED WITXF
)@@G@@HOUT ANY ARGUMENTS,     @G@@@@ EITHER A DUMMY ARGUMENT CAN BE SUPPLIED, XG
)@@G@@OR THE PROGRAM NAME FIELD     @G@@@@ MAY  BE  TERMINATED  WITH THE ASTERXH
)@@G@@ISK (*) OR SLASH (/).   BOTH OF     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEXI
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  4@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@XJ
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THESE CHARACTERS HAVE SPECIAL MEANINGS:   THE ASTERISK DEFINES THXK
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ ENTRY  POINT  FOR THIS PROGRAM,  AND THE SLASH DEFINES THE XL
)@@G@@PROGRAM     @G@@@@ OPTIONS FIELD.   HOWEVER, BOTH SERVE TO DISTINGUISH AXM
)@@G@@ PROGRAM NAME     @G@@@@ FROM A DIRECTIVE NAME,  AND IF, FOR INSTANCE, NXN
)@@G@@O OPTIONS ARE TO BE     @G@@@@ PASSED,   THE  PRESENCE  OF  THE  OPTIONSXO
)@@G@@ FIELD DELIMITER IS STILL     @G@@@@ SYNTACTICALLY  CORRECT.    A  SAMPLXP
)@@G@@E  CALL  IN  THIS CASE MIGHT BE     @G@@@@ 'PROG/'.    SINCE  PROGRAMS  XQ
)@@G@@ARE  NOT DEFINED WITH FORMAL ARGUMENT     @G@@@@ LISTS  AS IN MANY OTHERXR
)@@G@@ LANGUAGES,  IT IS DEFINITELY NOT ERRONEOUS     @C@@@@ TO INCLUDE EXTRANXS
)@@G@@EOUS ARGUMENTS TO A PROGRAM.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  IT  IS  WISHED  TO XT
)@@G@@ PASS  A STATEMENT LABEL WITHIN THE CALLING     @G@@@@ PROGRAM TO A CALLXU
)@@G@@ED PROGRAM FOR USE WITH NONSTANDARD EXIT (SEE THE     @G@@@@ DISCUSSION XV
)@@G@@OF THE 'EXIT' STATEMENT),    THE LABEL REFERENCE IN THE     @G@@@@ ARGUMXW
)@@G@@ENT  LIST  OF  THE CALLED PROGRAM IS CODED WITH A PRECEDING &     @D@@@@XX
)@@G@@ (AMPERSAND).  THE LABEL IS NOT TESTED FOR DEFINITION.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@XY
)@@G@@ AS MENTIONED IN THE SECTION ON IDENTIFIERS,  A PROGRAM NAME MAY BE     XZ
)@@G@@@E@@@@ REFERENCED INDIRECTLY.  ALL THE RULES OUTLINED ABOVE APPLY.@@@@@@YA
)@@G@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  5. 4.   PROGRAM OPTIONS     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  AN  NPLYB
)@@G@@  PROGRAM  IS CALLED WITH A SLASH ('/') TERMINATING THE     @G@@@@ PROGRYC
)@@G@@AM NAME FIELD, THE INTERPRETER WILL SCAN THE NEXT FIELD AS AN     @G@@@@YD
)@@G@@ OPTIONS  FIELD,   AND  WILL  STORE  INTO  THE  KEYWORD  'OPTS' THE     YE
)@@G@@@G@@@@ MASTER-BIT NOTATION OF THE STRING OF OPTION LETTERS SPECIFIED.  IYF
)@@G@@N     @G@@@@ MASTER-BIT  NOTATION,   BIT  25  IS  SET  IF  THE  'A'  OPTYG
)@@G@@ION WAS     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED,  ETC.,  TO BIT 0 FOR 'Z'.  IF THE OPTIONS YH
)@@G@@FIELD IS VOID     @G@@@@ OR  OMITTED,  THE VALUE OF 'OPTS' WILL BE ZERO.YI
)@@G@@   WHEN OPTIONS ARE     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED,  THE PROGRAM ARGUMENTS FOLLOW YJ
)@@G@@NORMALLY,  SEPARATED FROM     @E@@@@ THE PROGRAM BY EITHER A SPACE OR COYK
)@@G@@MMA, AS OUTLINED ABOVE. @@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ EXAMPLE:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@YL
)@@G@@                    PROG/ABJ 9@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NOTICE THAT EVEN THOUGHYM
)@@G@@ 'PROG' DUPLICATES AN NPL DIRECTIVE NAME, A     @G@@@@ COMMA  IS NOT REQYN
)@@G@@UIRED PRECEDING THE ARGUMENTS FIELD SINCE THE '/'     @E@@@@ DEFINING THYO
)@@G@@E OPTIONS FIELD SERVES TO CAUSE A PROGRAM LOAD. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ 'OPTSYP
)@@G@@'  WILL  HAVE  THE VALUE IN OCTAL 000300200000 REFLECTING THE     @#@@@@YQ
)@@G@@ OPTIONS 'ABJ'.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING YR
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  5@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  5. 5.   ARYS
)@@G@@GUMENT RETRIEVAL  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ PROGRAM ARGUMENTS ARE REFERENCED WIYT
)@@G@@THIN THE BODY OF AN NPL PROGRAM     @G@@@@ THROUGH THE USE OF THE IMPLICYU
)@@G@@IT ARRAY 'PR'.   THE VALUE OF THE NTH     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  PASSED TO ANYYV
)@@G@@ PROGRAM IS RETRIEVED BY REFERENCING PR(N).     @G@@@@ THE  TOTAL NUMBERYW
)@@G@@ OF ARGUMENTS PASSED TO A PROGRAM IS AVAILABLE BY     @G@@@@ REFERENCINGYX
)@@G@@ BITS 17-0 OF PR(0) (OR 'PR' WITH NO SUBSCRIPTS).  BITS     @G@@@@ 35-18YY
)@@G@@ OF PR(0) DESCRIBE THE MODES OF THE ARGUMENTS, SUCH THAT IF A     @G@@@@YZ
)@@G@@ PARTICULAR  BIT IS SET,  THE CORRESPONDING ARGUMENT IS REAL,  WITH     ZA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ BIT 35 REFERRING TO PR(0) (ALWAYS CLEAR), BIT 34 DESCRIBING PR(1)ZB
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ ETC.    IF  A  REFERENCE  IS MADE TO PR(X) WHERE X IS GREATZC
)@@G@@ER THAN     @G@@@@ PR(0).H2,   THE  ARGUMENT  REFERENCED  IS TO THE IMPLZD
)@@G@@ICIT ARGUMENT     @B@@@@ ZERO.  THIS IS NOT AN ERROR CONDITION.   @@@@@@ZE
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL PROGRAM ARGUMENTS ARE PASSED BY NAME (ADDRESS),  NOT VAZF
)@@G@@LUE, SO     @G@@@@ THAT  IF AN ARGUMENT IS A VARIABLE OR ARRAY NAME,  ANZG
)@@G@@D THE PROGRAM     @G@@@@ WISHES TO CHANGE THE VALUE OF THE ARGUMENT BY AZH
)@@G@@SSIGNING A VALUE TO     @G@@@@ THE  APPROPRIATE  PR(X),   THE  VARIABLE ZI
)@@G@@ OR  ARRAY IN THE CALLING     @G@@@@ PROGRAM  WILL  BE  PROPERLY  ASSIGNZJ
)@@G@@ED.   HOWEVER,  IF THE ARGUMENT     @G@@@@ PASSED WAS AN EXPESSION, THE ZK
)@@G@@ADDRESS STORED IS THAT OF A TEMPORARY     @G@@@@ CELL  IN  WHICH THE RESZL
)@@G@@ULT WAS STORED.   ASSIGNING A VALUE TO THAT     @D@@@@ ARGUMENT HAS NO EZM
)@@G@@FFECT OUTSIDE OF THE CALLED PROGRAM.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ BECAUSE  OF THE MZN
)@@G@@ETHOD USED FOR PASSING ARGUMENTS BY ADDRESS,  ANY     @G@@@@ QUALIFIER  ZO
)@@G@@APPENDED  TO  A  VARIABLE NAME PASSED AS AN ARGUMENT IS     @G@@@@ MAINTZP
)@@G@@AINED,  AND ANY REFERENCE TO SUCH AN ARGUMENT MAY NOT SPECIFY     @G@@@@ZQ
)@@G@@ QUALIFICATION  OF  THE  APPROPRIATE  PR(X).   FOR EXAMPLE,  IF THE     ZR
)@@G@@@G@@@@ PROGRAM CALL 'PROG, A.H2' WERE EXECUTED, AND THE ASSIGNMENT 'PR(1ZS
)@@G@@)     @G@@@@ =  99'  WERE  PERFORMED,  THE EFFECT WOULD BE THAT OF THE SZT
)@@G@@EQUENCE     @G@@@@ 'PROG,  A',  'PR(1).H2 = 99'.  HOWEVER, THE SEQUENCE ZU
)@@G@@'PROG, A.H2',     @G@@@@ PR(1).H2  =  99' WOULD RESULT IN AN ERROR.   IFZV
)@@G@@ ONLY THE EFFECTIVE     @G@@@@ VALUE,   NOT  THE  ADDRESS,   IS DESIRED,ZW
)@@G@@  AND A QUALIFIER MUST BE     @G@@@@ SPECIFIED  TO  REFERENCE THE PROPERZX
)@@G@@ VALUE,  A UNARY PLUS SIGN OR A     @G@@@@ PAIR  OF  REDUNDANT PARENTHESZY
)@@G@@ES WILL PRODUCE THE REQUIRED RESULTS,     @B@@@@ I.E., 'PROG, +A.H2' OR ZZ
)@@G@@'PROG, (A.H2)'.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  SAMPLE  PROGRAM  TO  PRINT  ALL AA
)@@G@@ THE ARGUMENTS WITH WHICH IT IS     @#@@@@ CALLED WOULD BE: @@@@@@@@@@@@AB
)@@G@@@B@@@@                    IF NOT(PR(0).H2), EXIT@B@@@@                  AC
)@@G@@  DO LABEL A=1,PR(0).H2 @A@@@@          LABEL:    PRINT PR(A)     @^@@@@AD
)@@G@@                    EXIT@@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEAE
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  6@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@AF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  INTRINSIC FUNCTION 'NOT' RETURNS A VALUE OF 1 IF ITS ARGUMENAG
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ IS  ZERO,  SO THAT IF NO ARGUMENTS WERE PASSED,  THE PROGRAAH
)@@G@@M EXITS     @G@@@@ WITHOUT  ATTEMPTING  TO  EXECUTE  A  DO  LOOP  FROM 1AI
)@@G@@ TO 0 (WHICH,     @G@@@@ HOWEVER LEGAL,  IS NOT WHAT WE WANT!).  THE RESAJ
)@@G@@T OF THE PROGRAM IS     @#@@@@ SELF-EXPLANATORY.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  TAK
)@@G@@HE ARRAY PR IS REFERENCED WITH ONLY ONE SUBSCRIPT,  THE VALUE     @G@@@@AL
)@@G@@ OF  THE  ARGUMENT IS THE STRING SPECIFIED OR THE NUMERIC RESULT OF     AM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AN  EXPRESSION  SCAN.    THE CONTEXT IN WHICH THE ARGUMENT IS USEAN
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ DETERMINES  WHETHER  A  STRING  IS  TO BE USED AS A STRING AO
)@@G@@OR AS A     @G@@@@ NUMERIC LITERAL.  IF AN ARGUMENT IS A STRING, BUT IS AP
)@@G@@TO BE USED IN     @G@@@@ A NUMERIC CONTEXT, OR IS AN ARRAY AND OTHER THAAQ
)@@G@@N THE FIRST CELL IS     @G@@@@ TO BE REFERENCED,  A SECOND SUBSCRIPT MAYAR
)@@G@@ BE GIVEN,  IN WHICH CASE     @G@@@@ THE  VALUE OF THE ARGUMENT IS THE NAS
)@@G@@UMERIC VALUE OF THE NTH WORD IN     @G@@@@ THE  STRING,  WHERE 'N' IS THAT
)@@G@@E VALUE OF THE SECOND SUBSCRIPT.   IF     @G@@@@ 'N' EXCEEDS THE LENGTH AU
)@@G@@OF THE STRING PASSED, AN ERROR WILL RESULT.     @G@@@@ REMEMBER,   WORD AV
)@@G@@ ZERO  OF  A  STRING  ARRAY  HOLDS  THE LENGTH IN     @ @@@@ CHARACTERS AW
)@@G@@OF THE STRING.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@ FOR EXAMPLE, SUPPOSE THE FOLLOWING AX
)@@G@@PROGRAM CALL WERE EXECUTED:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@            GETWRD 'THISAY
)@@G@@ IS A STRING PASSED AS AN ARGUMENT',3     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AND  THE  PAZ
)@@G@@ROGRAM  'GETWRD'  ASSIGNS  TO  THE VARIABLE Z4 THE WORD     @G@@@@ WITHIBA
)@@G@@N THE FIRST ARGUMENT CORRESPONDING TO THE POSITION DENOTED BY     @B@@@@BB
)@@G@@ THE SECOND ARGUMENT.  THE ASSIGNMENT:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@            BC
)@@G@@        Z4 = PR(1,PR(2))@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ ILLUSTRATES THE USE OF THE SEBD
)@@G@@COND SUBSCRIPT TO PR,  WHICH IS LEGAL     @G@@@@ IN  THIS  CASE  BECAUSEBE
)@@G@@ THE ARGUMENT IN QUESTION IS A STRING,  AND     @E@@@@ SERVES TO ASSIGN BF
)@@G@@TO Z4 THE SIX CHARACTER STRING 'RING P'.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  5. 6.   ARBG
)@@G@@GUMENT TYPE @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AN NPL PROGRAM CAN DETERMINE THE TYPE OF BH
)@@G@@ARGUMENT FOR ANY PR(N) BY     @G@@@@ REFERENCING THE INTRINSIC FUNCTION BI
)@@G@@'ARG', WHERE ARG(N) CORRESPONDS     @G@@@@ TO  THE  PARTICULAR PR(N) IN BJ
)@@G@@QUESTION.   IF THE VALUE OF ARG(N) IS     @G@@@@ EQUAL TO ZERO,  N IS GRBK
)@@G@@EATER THAN PR(0),  AND NO ARGUMENT NUMBER N     @G@@@@ WAS PASSED.  IF ABL
)@@G@@RG(N) IS GREATER THAN ZERO, THE ARGUMENT PR(N) IS     @G@@@@ NUMERIC,   BM
)@@G@@AND  ARG(N) IS ITS DESCRIPTOR.   IF ARG(N) IS LESS THAN     @G@@@@ ZERO,BN
)@@G@@   PR(N)  IS  A STRING,  AND BITS 34-18 OF ARG(N) DEFINES THE     @[@@@@BO
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23 BP
)@@G@@       5-  7@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ SUBSCRIPT LIMIT AND BITS 17-0 DEFINBQ
)@@G@@E THE ADDRESS OF THE FIRST WORD     @A@@@@ OF THE STRING (CHARACTER COUNBR
)@@G@@T).   @@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  5. 7.   RECURSION     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL  BS
)@@G@@PROGRAMS ARE INTERPRETED IN A RECURSIVE MANNER,  ALLOWING ANY     @G@@@@BT
)@@G@@ PROGRAM  TO  CALL  ITSELF,   IN ADDITION TO ITS BEING ABLE TO CALL     BU
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ANOTHER  PROGRAM.  IT IS THE PROGRAMMER'S RESPONSIBILITY, HOWEVERBV
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ TO ASSURE THAT A RECURSIVE CALL ON A PROGRAM DOES NOT RESULBW
)@@G@@T IN AN     @#@@@@ ENDLESS LOOP.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  5. 8.   INTERNALBX
)@@G@@ SUBPROGRAMS@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  PROGRAM  MAY  CALL AN INTERNAL SUBPROGBY
)@@G@@RAM BY EXECUTING A 'CALL'     @ @@@@ STATEMENT.  THE FORMAT IS:   @@@@@@BZ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@D@@@@              CALL <LABEL>[/<OPTIONS>][,][<ARGUMENTS>]@@@@@@CA
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  <LABEL>  IS THE ENTRY OF THE SUBPROGRAM AND MUST BE CB
)@@G@@DEFINED     @G@@@@ WITHIN THE PROGRAM EXECUTING THE CALL.  THE OPTIONAL CC
)@@G@@<OPTIONS> AND     @G@@@@ <ARGUMENTS>  FIELDS  ARE  AS  DESCRIBED  PREVIOCD
)@@G@@USLY.    THE CALLED     @G@@@@ SUBPROGRAM  HAS  AVAILABLE  TO  IT  THE CCE
)@@G@@ALLER'S EQUIVALENCES (SEE     @G@@@@ BELOW)  AND  MODE  DECLARATIONS.  TCF
)@@G@@HESE MAY BE REDEFINED, HOWEVER,     @G@@@@ AND WILL BE RESTORED WHEN THECG
)@@G@@ SUBPROGRAM EXITS.   VARIABLES MAY BE     @G@@@@ DECLARED LOCAL IN AN INCH
)@@G@@TERNAL SUBPROGRAM.   AN INTERNAL SUBPROGRAM     @G@@@@ IS  MUCH  THE  SACI
)@@G@@ME  AS A RECURSIVE CALL ON THE EXECUTING PROGRAM,     @G@@@@ SPECIFYING CJ
)@@G@@ENTRY AT <LABEL> (SEE BELOW, MULTIPLE ENTRIES), HOWEVER     @G@@@@ THE  CK
)@@G@@OVERHEAD IS LESS IN A CALL ON AN INTERNAL SUBPROGRAM,  AS THE     @G@@@@CL
)@@G@@ DYNAMIC CORE EXPANSION NECESSARY TO CREATE THE CONTROL INFORMATION     CM
)@@G@@@E@@@@ USED TO EXECUTE AN EXTERNAL SUBPROGRAM IS NOT NECESSARY.   @@@@@@CN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  5. 9.   MULTIPLE ENTRIES    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  PROGRAM CO
)@@G@@ MAY  BE  ENTERED  AT OTHER THAN ITS FIRST STATEMENT BY     @G@@@@ CODINCP
)@@G@@G AS THE LAST ARGUMENT '*LABEL', WHERE 'LABEL' IS A STATEMENT     @G@@@@CQ
)@@G@@ LABEL  DEFINED WITHIN THE PROGRAM.   THE STATEMENT LABELED 'LABEL'     CR
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AND  THE  STATEMENTS  FOLLOWING IT WILL BE EXECUTED AS IF STANDARCS
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ ENTRY WERE EMPLOYED AND THE FIRST STATEMENT IN THE PROGRAM CT
)@@G@@WERE AN     @G@@@@ UNCONDITIONAL JUMP TO 'LABEL'.   IF THE LAST ARGUMENTCU
)@@G@@ TO A PROGRAM     @G@@@@ IS  JUST  THE  SINGLE  CHARACTER  '*',   ENTRY CV
)@@G@@ WILL  BE MADE TO A     @F@@@@ STATEMENT WHOSE LABEL IS THE SAME AS THE CW
)@@G@@NAME OF THE PROGRAM.    @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRACX
)@@G@@MMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  8@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  5.10CY
)@@G@@.   PROGRAM EXIT  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'EXIT' STATEMENT IS USED TO TECZ
)@@G@@RMINATE THE CURRENTLY EXECUTING     @G@@@@ PROGRAM  AND RETURN CONTROL TDA
)@@G@@O THE STATEMENT IMMEDIATELY FOLLOWING     @E@@@@ THE PROGRAM CALL, OR TODB
)@@G@@ EXIT FROM AN INTERNAL SUBPROGRAM.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@ THE FORMAT IS:   DC
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@                    EXIT@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF   THE  'DD
)@@G@@EXIT'  STATEMENT  HAS  AN  OPERAND  WHICH  IS  A  LEGAL     @G@@@@ IDENTDE
)@@G@@IFIER, CONTROL WILL NOT RETURN TO THE STATEMENT FOLLOWING THE     @G@@@@DF
)@@G@@ PROGRAM  CALL;  RATHER,  CONTROL WILL BE GIVEN TO THE STATEMENT IN     DG
)@@G@@@D@@@@ THE CALLING PROGRAM WHOSE LABEL IS GIVEN.  EXAMPLE:  @@@@@@@@@@@@DH
)@@G@@@A@@@@                        EXIT $PR(4) @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ TERMINATES DI
)@@G@@ THE  CURRENTLY  EXECUTING PROGRAM AND GIVES CONTROL TO     @G@@@@ THE SDJ
)@@G@@TATEMENT IN THE CALLING PROGRAM WHOSE LABEL WAS PASSED AS THE     @G@@@@DK
)@@G@@ FOURTH ARGUMENT TO THE PROGRAM NOW EXITING.   THE ONLY RESTRICTION     DL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IMPOSED  UPON NONSTANDARD RETURN IS THAT RETURN MAY NOT BE MADE IDM
)@@G@@N     @D@@@@ THIS WAY TO A STATEMENT WHOSE LABEL WAS SUBSCRIPTED. @@@@@@DN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@  5.11.   THE STOP AND ERROR STATEMENTS   @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@DO
)@@G@@ THE FORMAT OF THE 'STOP' AND 'ERROR' STATEMENTS IS:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@DP
)@@G@@                    STOP [<STRING>] @A@@@@                    ERROR [<STDQ
)@@G@@RING>]@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE 'STOP' STATEMENT CAUSES TERMINATION OF THE DR
)@@G@@CURRENTLY EXECUTING     @G@@@@ AND  ANY  NESTED  PROGRAMS.    ITS  EFFECDS
)@@G@@T  IS  THAT OF THE 'EXIT'     @G@@@@ STATEMENT  WHEN  EXECUTED  AT PROGRDT
)@@G@@AM EXECUTION LEVEL ZERO.   IF A     @G@@@@ STRING  EXPRESSION APPEARS ONDU
)@@G@@ THE 'STOP' STATEMENT,  IT IS PRINTED     @G@@@@ AS THE STOP MESSAGE.   DV
)@@G@@IF NO STRING APPEARS,  THE MESSAGE 'PROGRAM     @^@@@@ STOPPED' IS PRINTDW
)@@G@@ED.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE 'ERROR' STATEMENT IS LIKE THE 'STOP' STATEMDX
)@@G@@ENT,  EXCEPT THAT A     @G@@@@ WALKBACK SEQUENCE IS ALSO PRINTED.   IF TDY
)@@G@@HE OPTIONAL STRING IS NOT     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY DZ
)@@G@@PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        5-  9@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@EA
)@@G@@ PRESENT, A BLANK LINE IS PRINTED.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEEB
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        6-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@EC
)@@G@@@#@@@@  6.   FUNCTIONS  @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  6. 1.   GEED
)@@G@@NERAL @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NPL    INTERNAL  AND  EXTERNAL  FUNCTIONS  ARE EE
)@@G@@ ONE  LINE  NUMERIC     @G@@@@ EXPRESSIONS  WHICH  UPON EVALUATION RETUREF
)@@G@@N A SINGLE NUMERIC RESULT     @G@@@@ (THE  'VALUE OF THE THE FUNCTION').EG
)@@G@@   FUNCTIONS ARE DEFINED BY THE     @B@@@@ 'FUNC' DIRECTIVE AND ITS VARIEH
)@@G@@ATIONS.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  6. 2.   FUNCTION DEFINITION @@@@@@@@@@@@EI
)@@G@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  6. 2. 1.   EXTERNAL FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@B@@@@ THE FORMAT EJ
)@@G@@OF THE 'EFUNC' DIRECTIVE IS:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@                    EFUNEK
)@@G@@C <IDENT> = <EXPR>@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  <IDENT>  IS  THE  NAME  OF TEL
)@@G@@HE FUNCTION,  AND <EXPR> IS THE     @G@@@@ NUMERIC  EXPRESSION  TO  BE  EM
)@@G@@EVALUATED  TO DERIVE THE VALUE OF THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION.    NPL  FUNCTEN
)@@G@@IONS  MAY  BE  ONLY  ONE  LINE  OF  NUMERIC     @G@@@@ EXPRESSION,  HOWEEO
)@@G@@VER,  AMPERSAND OR COMMA CONTINUATION MAY BE USED     @G@@@@ IF  THE  FUEP
)@@G@@NCTION  IS  TOO LONG TO FIT ON ONE LINE.   BY VIRTUE OF     @G@@@@ FUNCTEQ
)@@G@@ION  SYNTAX  THERE MAY BE NO EXECUTABLE STATEMENTS WITHIN THE     @G@@@@ER
)@@G@@ BODY OF THE FUNCTION.   HOWEVER,  BECAUSE OF THE RECURSIVE SCAN OF     ES
)@@G@@@G@@@@ NUMERIC  EXPRESSIONS,   <EXPR>  MAY BE AS COMPLEX AS SYSTEM LIMITET
)@@G@@S     @E@@@@ ALLOW, BUT EXTERNAL FUNCTIONS THEMSELVES ARE NOT RECURSIVE.EU
)@@G@@@@@@@@@A@@@@  6. 2. 2.   INTERNAL FUNCTIONS     @@@@@@@G@@@@ INTERNAL FUEV
)@@G@@NCTIONS ARE SIMILAR TO EXTERNAL FUNCTIONS,  EXCEPT THAT     @G@@@@ THEY EW
)@@G@@ MAY  NOT  BE REFERENCED OUTSIDE OF THE PROGRAM IN WHICH THEY     @D@@@@EX
)@@G@@ ARE DEFINED.  THE FORMAT OF THE 'FUNC' DIRECTIVE IS: @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@EY
)@@G@@                  NAME:   FUNC (<EXPR>)   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  'NAMEZ
)@@G@@E'  IS  A  STATEMENT  LABEL,   AND  IS  THE NAME OF THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTFA
)@@G@@ION.    <EXPR>  IS  AS  DESCRIBED  IN THE SECTION ON EXTERNAL     @G@@@@FB
)@@G@@ FUNCTIONS.    'NAME' MAY NOT BE REFERENCED WITHIN THE PROGRAM AS A     FC
)@@G@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   RFD
)@@G@@EV.23        6-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ STATEMENT  LABEL.   IF CONTROFE
)@@G@@L FLOWS INTO A 'FUNC' STATEMENT,  THE     @G@@@@ STATEMENT  IS  IGNORED.FF
)@@G@@    AN  INTERNAL  FUNCTION  MAY  BE DEFINED     @G@@@@ ANYWHERE IN THE PFG
)@@G@@ROGRAM,  AND THE DEFINITION MAY APPEAR PHYSICALLY     @G@@@@ AFTER  THE FH
)@@G@@FIRST REFERENCE.   'NAME' MAY DUPLICATE THE LABEL OF AN     @G@@@@ EXECUFI
)@@G@@TABLE  STATEMENT  ONLY  IF THE FUNCTION IS DEFINED BEFORE THE     @G@@@@FJ
)@@G@@ EXECUTABLE STATEMENT'S LABEL IS DEFINED.   MULTIPLE DEFINITIONS OF     FK
)@@G@@@G@@@@ A FUNCTION HAVE NO EFFECT,  ONLY THE FIRST DEFINITION WILL EVER BFL
)@@G@@E     @]@@@@ REFERENCED.@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  6. 3.   FUNCTION MODES@@@@@@FM
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE MODE OF FUNCTIONS DEFINED BY THE 'FUNC' AND 'EFUNC' DIRFN
)@@G@@ECTIVES     @G@@@@ 'FLOATS'  ON  THE  MODE  DECLARED  FOR  THE  INITIAL FO
)@@G@@LETTER OF THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  NAME,   I.E.,   IF  G  HAS  BEEN  DECFP
)@@G@@LARED REAL (SEE THE     @G@@@@ DISCUSSION  OF  THE  'REAL'  AND  'INTEGRFQ
)@@G@@'  STATEMENTS),  THEN THE     @G@@@@ FUNCTION  'GAMMA',  DEFINED AS 'GAMFR
)@@G@@MA:  FUNC (...  ETC)' OR 'EFUNC     @G@@@@ GAMMA  =  ...  ETC' WILL BE EFS
)@@G@@VALUATED AS A REAL FUNCTION,  AND ITS     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT  LIST  SCANNEDFT
)@@G@@  FOR  REAL  VALUES.    IF THE MODE OF G IS     @G@@@@ CHANGED TO INTEGEFU
)@@G@@R,  THEN 'GAMMA' WILL BE AN INTEGER FUNCTION.  TO     @G@@@@ FORCE  A FUFV
)@@G@@NCTION TO BE EITHER INTEGER OR REAL,  REGARDLESS OF THE     @G@@@@ TYPE FW
)@@G@@ DECLARED  FOR ITS INITIAL LETTER,  THE DIRECTIVES 'IFUNC' OR     @C@@@@FX
)@@G@@ 'RFUNC' (OR 'EIFUNC' OR 'ERFUNC') ARE USED.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ NOTE:FY
)@@G@@    EXTERNAL  FUNCTIONS  CREATED  BY THE 'CODE' DIRECTIVE ARE     @F@@@@FZ
)@@G@@ ALWAYS 'FLOATED' ON THE MODE OF THE INITIAL LETTER OF THE NAME.  @@@@@@GA
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@  6. 4.   FUNCTION ARGUMENT RETRIEVAL     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@GB
)@@G@@ FUNCTION ARGUMENTS ARE RETRIEVED IN A MANNER SIMILAR TO THE WAY IN     GC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ WHICH PROGRAM ARGUMENTS ARE REFERENCED.  IN THE CASE OF FUNCTIONSGD
)@@G@@,     @G@@@@ HOWEVER,  THE  IMPLICIT  ARRAY  OF ARGUMENTS IS ADDRESSED AGE
)@@G@@S 'FN',     @G@@@@ AND,   UNLIKE  PROGRAM  ARGUMENTS,   THE  ONLY STRINGGF
)@@G@@S ALLOWED ARE     @G@@@@ LITERALS SUITABLE FOR NUMERIC CONTEXTS,  I.E., GG
)@@G@@THOSE OF 6 OR FEWER     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS.   THUS, THE VALUE OF THE 5TH GH
)@@G@@ARGUMENT TO A FUNCTION IS     @G@@@@ REFERENCED  FROM  WITHIN  THE  FUNCGI
)@@G@@TION AS FN(5).   LIKEWISE,  THE     @G@@@@ NUMBER OF ARGUMENTS PASSED,  GJ
)@@G@@ALTHOUGH OF LITTLE IMMEDIATE USE,  IS     @G@@@@ REFERENCED AS FN(0).H2.GK
)@@G@@  FN(0).H1 CONTAINS BIT SETTINGS DESCRIBING     @G@@@@ THE  MODES  OF THGL
)@@G@@E ARGUMENTS:  IF A BIT IS SET,  THE CORRESPONDING     @G@@@@ ARGUMENT ISGM
)@@G@@ REAL.  BIT 35 DESCRIBES FN(0) (ALWAYS INTEGER), BIT 34     @]@@@@ FN(1)GN
)@@G@@, ETC.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  ARGUMENTS  TO  A  FUNCTION  ARE  SCANNED, GO
)@@G@@  AND  CONVERTED IF     @G@@@@ NECESSARY,   IN  A WAY TO BE CONSISTENT WGP
)@@G@@ITH THE MODE OF THE VALUE     @G@@@@ THAT WILL BE RETURNED BY THE FUNCTIGQ
)@@G@@ON.  I.E., IF THE FUNCTION WILL     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVEGR
)@@G@@RSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        6-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@GS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RETURN A REAL RESULT, THE ARGUMENTS ARE FORCED REAL.  THIS FEATURGT
)@@G@@E     @^@@@@ MAY NOT BE OVERRIDEN.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AN  EXAMPLE  OF AGU
)@@G@@ FUNCTION TO RETURN THE CHARACTER IN A PARTICULAR     @C@@@@ COLUMN POSIGV
)@@G@@TION OF A STRING ARRAY WOULD BE:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@       EIFUNC CHR=GW
)@@G@@FLD(MOD(FN(2)-1,6)*6,6,$(FN(1))(FN(2)//6))@@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@ A REFERENCEGX
)@@G@@ TO 'CHR' MIGHT BE:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@                    A = CHR(%IGY
)@@G@@NPUT$,34)   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE RESULT IS TO ASSIGN TO THE VARIABLE 'GZ
)@@G@@A' THE FIELDATA CHARACTER     @C@@@@ IN COLUMN 34 OF THE NPL KEYWORD ARRHA
)@@G@@AY 'INPUT$'.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AS ILLUSTRATED, ANY NUMERIC EXPRESSION ISHB
)@@G@@ LEGAL WITHIN THE BODY OF     @G@@@@ A FUNCTION,  INCLUDING ARRAY REFEREHC
)@@G@@NCE, ANOTHER FUNCTION CALL, AND     @A@@@@ INDIRECT IDENTIFIER REFERENCEHD
)@@G@@.     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NHE
)@@G@@PL   REV.23        7-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  7.   PROGRAM LIBRARIESHF
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  7. 1.   USER LIBRARY  @@@@@@@@@@@@HG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ UPON EXECUTION OF THE NPL PROCESSOR,   THE FILE TPF$,  ATTACHED THH
)@@G@@O     @G@@@@ ALL RUNS IN THE EXEC8 SYSTEM,   IS GIVEN THE INTERNAL NAME HI
)@@G@@NPL$PF.     @G@@@@ PROGRAMS  TO BE COMPILED,  LOADED AND/OR SAVED BY NPLHJ
)@@G@@ ARE EXPECTED     @G@@@@ TO  RESIDE IN A FILE WITH THE INTERNAL NAME NPLHK
)@@G@@$PF ASSIGNED TO THE     @G@@@@ PARTICULAR  RUN.    THE  ASSOCIATION  OF HL
)@@G@@ NPL$PF MAY BE CHANGED TO     @E@@@@ ANOTHER FILE THROUGH THE EXECUTION HM
)@@G@@OF THE 'LIB' DIRECTIVE. @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  7. 2.   THE LIB DIRECTIVE   HN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@ THE FORMAT OF THE 'LIB' DIRECTIVE IS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@HO
)@@G@@@A@@@@                    LIB [<STRING>]  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE <STRIHP
)@@G@@NG> IS ANY STRING EXPRESSION OR LITERAL.  THE EFFECT IS     @G@@@@ TO  RHQ
)@@G@@ELEASE  THE  NAME  NPL$PF  FROM WHATEVER FILE IT IS CURRENTLY     @G@@@@HR
)@@G@@ ATTACHED TO AND ASSIGN IT TO THE FILE WHOSE NAME IS REPRESENTED BY     HS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ <STRING>.   UPON EXECUTION OF THE 'LIB' DIRECTIVE,  PROGRAMS FOUNHT
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ IN  THE  FILE  NAMED  BY  <STRING>  MAY  BE  REFERENCED BY HU
)@@G@@THE NPL     @G@@@@ PROCESSOR.    THE  FACILITY  STATUS  BITS  RETURNED  HV
)@@G@@BY  THE EXEC8     @G@@@@ OPERATING  SYSTEM  UPON  EXECUTION  OF  THE 'LIHW
)@@G@@B' STATEMENT MAY BE     @G@@@@ INSPECTED BY REFERENCING THE KEYWORD 'EXEHX
)@@G@@C' IF THE 'LIB' STATEMENT     @G@@@@ FAILS.    REFER TO THE EXEC8 PRM FOHY
)@@G@@R DETAILS ON THE MEANING OF THE     @A@@@@ VARIOUS FACILITY BIT SETTINGSHZ
)@@G@@.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@F@@@@ IF THE OPTIONAL <STRING> IS OMITTED, NPL ASSUMEIA
)@@G@@S THE NAME 'TPF$'.@@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ EXAMPLE:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@      IB
)@@G@@              LIB 'MYPROJ*MYFILE/READIT'  @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  7. 3.   THIC
)@@G@@E PUBLIC LIBRARY  @@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY ID
)@@G@@PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        7-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@IE
)@@G@@ THE  FILE  SYS$*NPL$  IS  ASSIGNED  DYNAMICALLY  TO  EACH RUN THAT     IF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ EXECUTES NPL.  IN IT ARE PROVIDED SEVERAL USEFUL PROGRAMS THAT ARIG
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ MADE  AVAILABLE  TO  ALL USERS OF NPL.   IF A PROGRAM REFERIH
)@@G@@ENCE IS     @G@@@@ MADE TO A PROGRAM THAT HAS NOT BEEN DEFINED OR LOADEDII
)@@G@@ FROM NPL$PF,     @G@@@@ SYS$*NPL$  IS SEARCHED AND IF THE PROGRAM IS FOIJ
)@@G@@UND THERE,  WILL BE     @G@@@@ EXECUTED.   BY THE SAME TOKEN,  IF A FUNCIK
)@@G@@TION REFERENCE FAILS WHEN     @G@@@@ EVALUATING  A NUMERIC EXPRESSION,  IL
)@@G@@THE PUBLIC LIBRARY FILE WILL BE     @G@@@@ SEARCHED FOR THE FUNCTION NAMIM
)@@G@@E,  AND,  IF FOUND, THE FUNCTION WILL     @B@@@@ BE AUTOMATICALLY LOADEDIN
)@@G@@ AND EVALUATED.   @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING IO
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        8-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@  8.   PROGRIP
)@@G@@AM CONTROL  @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  8. 1.   THE SAVE DIRECIQ
)@@G@@TIVE  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'SAVE'  DIRECTIVE IS USED TO SAVE A NAMED IR
)@@G@@PROGRAM OR FUNCTION     @G@@@@ TO  THE  USER  LIBRARY  FILE  NPL$PF.    IS
)@@G@@THE  FORMAT OF THE 'SAVE'     @#@@@@ STATEMENT IS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@IT
)@@G@@                    SAVE <NAME1>,<NAME2>,...    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  IU
)@@G@@PROGRAMS  AND/OR FUNCTIONS REFERENCED ARE COPIED TO NPL$PF AS     @G@@@@IV
)@@G@@ ABSOLUTE ELEMENTS, AND MAY BE LATER RETRIEVED AND EXECUTED WITHOUT     IW
)@@G@@@ @@@@ REQUIRING RECOMPILATION.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  8. 2.   THE LOADIX
)@@G@@ DIRECTIVE  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'LOAD'  DIRECTIVE  IS USED TO RETRIEIY
)@@G@@VE PROGRAMS AND FUNCTIONS     @G@@@@ PREVIOUSLY  SAVED  BY  THE  'SAVE' IZ
)@@G@@ STATEMENT.   THE FORMAT OF THE     @G@@@@ 'LOAD'  STATEMENT  IS  SIMILAJA
)@@G@@R  TO  THAT  OF THE 'SAVE' STATEMENT,     @G@@@@ EXCEPT  THAT  IF  <NAMEJB
)@@G@@>*  INSTEAD  OF  <NAME> IS REFERENCED,  THE     @G@@@@ PROGRAM  IS  LOADJC
)@@G@@ED  FROM  THE PUBLIC LIBRARY RATHER THAN FROM THE     @#@@@@ USER LIBRARJD
)@@G@@Y.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  8. 3.   THE UNLOAD DIRECTIVE@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@JE
)@@G@@ THE  'UNLOAD'  DIRECTIVE  IS USED TO SPECIFY THE NAMES OF PROGRAMS     JF
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AND/OR  FUNCTIONS  WHICH  ARE  NO LONGER NEEDED,  AND WHICH MAY BJG
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ UNLOADED  TO  MAKE  THEIR  SPACE  AVAILABLE  TO  OTHER PROGJH
)@@G@@RAMS OR     @]@@@@ FUNCTIONS. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  FORMAT  OF  THE 'UJI
)@@G@@NLOAD' STATEMENT IS THE SAME AS THAT OF THE     @#@@@@ 'SAVE' STATEMENT.JJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  8. 4.   THE LIST DIRECTIVE  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  JK
)@@G@@'LIST'  DIRECTIVE,   WHOSE  SYNTAX IS LIKE THAT OF 'SAVE' AND     @[@@@@JL
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23 JM
)@@G@@       8-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ 'UNLOAD', IS USED TO LIST THE TEXT JN
)@@G@@OF PROGRAMS AND FUNCTIONS.  THE     @G@@@@ NAME  OF  THE  ITEM BEING LISJO
)@@G@@TED IS PRINTED ALONG WITH ITS SIZE IN     @G@@@@ WORDS  ON  A  HEADING  JP
)@@G@@LINE.    THEREAFTER,  EACH STATEMENT OF THE     @G@@@@ PROGRAM, OR THE TJQ
)@@G@@EXT OF THE FUNCTION ITSELF, IS PRINTED ON A LINE,     @G@@@@ PREFIXED  BJR
)@@G@@Y THE LINE NUMBER AND THE RELATIVE WORD POSITION OF THE     @G@@@@ CONTRJS
)@@G@@OL  WORD  FOR  THE  START  OF  THE  STATEMENT RELATIVE TO THE     @A@@@@JT
)@@G@@ BEGINNING OF THE PROGRAM UNIT.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF A 'LIST' DIRECJU
)@@G@@TIVE WITH NO OPERAND(S) IS EXECUTED, A MAP OF THE     @B@@@@ NPL DYNAMICJV
)@@G@@ CORE AREA WILL BE PRINTED.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  8. 5.   BLOCK DEFINITIJW
)@@G@@ON    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'BEGIN'  DIRECTIVE IS USED TO DEFINE BLOCKJX
)@@G@@S WITHIN A PROGRAM.     @G@@@@ THE  'BEGIN' DIRECTIVE ITSELF IS IGNORED,JY
)@@G@@ AND THE REMAINDER OF THE     @G@@@@ STATEMENT CONTAINING IT IS EXECUTEDJZ
)@@G@@.  HOWEVER,  IF A PROGRAM BEING     @G@@@@ LISTED CONTAINS 'BEGIN' DIRECKA
)@@G@@TIVES,    NPL WILL SKIP A LINE BEFORE     @G@@@@ PRINTING  THE  LINE CONKB
)@@G@@TAINING THE 'BEGIN' AND THE FOLLOWING LINES     @G@@@@ UP TO THE NEXT 'BKC
)@@G@@EGIN'.   PROGRAM READABILITY CAN THUS BE IMPROVED     @#@@@@ IN THIS WAYKD
)@@G@@.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  8. 6.   RESTORE @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'RESTOKE
)@@G@@RE'  DIRECTIVE  IS USED TO CLEAR ALL NATURAL VARIABLES,     @G@@@@ AND TKF
)@@G@@O UNLOAD ALL PROGRAMS,  FUNCTIONS AND NATURAL ARRAYS RESIDING     @G@@@@KG
)@@G@@ IN DYNAMIC STORAGE.   THE 'RESTORE' DIRECTIVE EFFECTIVELY RESTORES     KH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  NPL  DATA  AREA TO THE STATE IT WAS IN WHEN THE PROCESSOR WAKI
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ INITIALLY CALLED. 'RESTORE' WAITS ON ALL I/O COMPLETIONS, BKJ
)@@G@@UT DOES     @G@@@@ NOT  DRAIN  ANY  OUTSTANDING BUFFERS,  SO OUTPUT UNITKK
)@@G@@S WILL NOT BE     @#@@@@ NORMALLY CLOSED. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ 'RESTORE'  KL
)@@G@@MUST APPEAR AS A COMMAND TO NPL AS THE FIRST ITEM INPUT     @G@@@@ DURINKM
)@@G@@G A COMPILATION, AND NOTHING ELSE MAY APPEAR ON THE 'RESTORE'     @#@@@@KN
)@@G@@ DIRECTIVE LINE.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING KO
)@@G@@LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        9-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  9.   PROGRKP
)@@G@@AM COMPILATION    @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@  9. 1.   GENERAL KQ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ SO FAR TWO METHODS OF DEFINING PROGRAMS HAVE BEEN DISKR
)@@G@@CUSSED:   THE     @G@@@@ 'PROG'  DIRECTIVE AND THE 'LOAD' DIRECTIVE.   AKS
)@@G@@ THIRD METHOD IS TO     @G@@@@ CALL UPON NPL TO COMPILE A SOURCE ELEMENTKT
)@@G@@,  AGAIN, RESIDING IN THE     @G@@@@ FILE  NPL$PF.  THIS IS ACCOMPLISHEDKU
)@@G@@ BY USING THE 'CODE' DIRECTIVE.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@  9. 2.   THE CODEKV
)@@G@@ DIRECTIVE  @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@ THE FORMAT OF A 'CODE' STATEMENT IS:     KW
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@               CODE <NAME1>[*],<NAME2>[*],...   @@@@@@KX
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  VARIOUS NAMES SPECIFIED ARE THE NAMES OF SYMBOLIC ELEMKY
)@@G@@ENTS IN     @G@@@@ NPL$PF.    THE TEXT OF EACH ELEMENT IS READ,  AND THEKZ
)@@G@@ NPL COMPILER     @G@@@@ TRANSLATES  THE SOURCE LANGUAGE INTO EXECUTABLELA
)@@G@@ NPL INTERNAL CODE.     @G@@@@ IF THE OPTIONAL ASTERISK IS PRESENT AFTERLB
)@@G@@ ANY PROGRAM NAME,   THAT     @F@@@@ PROGRAM WILL BE LISTED AS IT IS BEILC
)@@G@@NG INPUT TO THE COMPILER.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@ THE FOLLOWING RESTRICTILD
)@@G@@ON APPLIES TO COMPILED FUNCTIONS:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@   WHEN AN EXTERNALE
)@@G@@L FUNCTION IS BEING COMPILED, IT MUST BE  @E@@@@   SURROUNDED BY REDUNDALF
)@@G@@NT PARENTHESES.  ADDITIONALLY, THE  @E@@@@   FUNCTION MAY NOT BE DECLARELG
)@@G@@D AS FORCED INTEGER OR REAL.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ FOR  EACH PROGRAM OR FULH
)@@G@@NCTION COMPILED,  ERROR DIAGNOSTIC MESSAGES     @G@@@@ MAY BE DISPLAYED.LI
)@@G@@   HOWEVER, ONLY THE FIRST TEN ERROR MESSAGES ARE     @G@@@@ PRINTED.  ALJ
)@@G@@T THE END OF EACH COMPILATION THERE IS PRINTED A SINGLE     @G@@@@ LINE LK
)@@G@@DESCRIBING THE NUMBER OF LINES COMPILED, THE SIZE IN WORDS OF     @G@@@@LL
)@@G@@ THE  OUTPUT  ABSOLUTE  PROGRAM  OR FUNCTION,  THE NUMBER OF ERRORS     LM
)@@G@@@G@@@@ ENCOUNTERED,   AND  THE  TIME  IN  CPU  SECONDS  REQUIRED  FOR THLN
)@@G@@E     @#@@@@ COMPILATION.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ UPON  COMPILATION  OF  LO
)@@G@@A  PROGRAM  OR  FUNCTION,   THE ITEM MAY BE     @G@@@@ REFERENCED  JUST LP
)@@G@@ AS  IF  IT  HAD BEEN LOADED,  OR CREATED VIA THE     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@LQ
)@@G@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23        9-  2LR
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@ 'PROG' DIRECTIVE.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORKLS
)@@G@@ UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23       10-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@LT
)@@G@@@@@@@@@^@@@@ 10.   MODE DECLARATION @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  MODE  LU
)@@G@@OF  VARIABLES  MAY  BE  DECLARED THROUGH THE USE OF THE     @D@@@@ 'REALLV
)@@G@@' AND 'INTEGR' STATEMENTS, WHOSE FORMATS ARE:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@      LW
)@@G@@              REAL <LETTER> [ - <LETTER>],...   @D@@@@                  LX
)@@G@@  INTEGR <LETTER> [ - <LETTER>],... @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <LETTER> MAY BE ALY
)@@G@@ SINGLE LETTER OR AN IDENTIFIER.  IN EITHER CASE,     @G@@@@ ALL  VARIABLZ
)@@G@@LES,   INCLUDING KEYWORDS,  BEGINNING WITH <LETTER> (OR     @G@@@@ WITH MA
)@@G@@ THE  INITIAL OF AN IDENTIFIER USED) WILL BE TYPED AS REAL OR     @G@@@@MB
)@@G@@ INTEGER  DEPENDING  ON  THE  STATEMENT EXECUTED.   IF THE OPTIONAL     MC
)@@G@@@G@@@@ RANGE IS CODED,  SUCH AS 'REAL B-R',  ALL LETTERS IN THE RANGE ARMD
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ TYPED APPROPRIATELY ('REAL B-R' IS EQUIVALENT TO 'REAL R-B'ME
)@@G@@).  THE     @G@@@@ MODE OF ALL VARIABLES IS INITIALLY INTEGER.   MODES AMF
)@@G@@RE MAINTAINED     @G@@@@ BY PROGRAM LEVEL,  THUS A PARTICULAR SET OF VARMG
)@@G@@IABLES MAY BE TYPED     @G@@@@ REAL BY A CALLING PROGRAM, AND RETYPED BYMH
)@@G@@ THE CALLED PROGRAM, WITH     @E@@@@ THE ORIGINAL MODES RESTORED WHEN THMI
)@@G@@E CALLED PROGRAM EXITS. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AS  MENTIONED EARLIER,  THE MMJ
)@@G@@ODE OF INTRINSIC AND PSEUDO-FUNCTIONS     @G@@@@ IS IMPLICITLY DEFINED AMK
)@@G@@ND MAY NOT BE CHANGED BY THE EXECUTION OF A     @ @@@@ 'REAL' OR 'INTEGRML
)@@G@@' STATEMENT.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAMM
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23       11-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@ 11.   ARRAYS     MN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 11. 1.   THE DIM STATEMENT   @@@@@@MO
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IN  THE  FOLLOWING  DISCUSSION,   REFERENCE  WILL BE MADE TMP
)@@G@@O ARRAY     @G@@@@ DECLARATION  THROUGH  USE  OF THE 'DIM' STATEMENT.   MQ
)@@G@@HOWEVER,  FOR     @G@@@@ PURPOSES OF READABILITY,  AND TO ADD TO THE DOCMR
)@@G@@UMENTATION VALUE OF     @G@@@@ NPL  PROGRAMS,   THE FOLLOWING DIRECTIVESMS
)@@G@@ ARE PROVIDED AS SYNONYMS     @]@@@@ FOR 'DIM': @@@@@@@B@@@@            MT
)@@G@@ VECTOR  STRING  STACK  QUEUE @@@@@@@G@@@@ ALL  OF  THESE  DIRECTIVES  AMU
)@@G@@RE  IDENTICAL IN EVERY RESPECT.   THE     @E@@@@ GENERAL FORMAT OF THE 'MV
)@@G@@DIM' AND RELATED STATEMENTS IS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                  MW
)@@G@@  DIM <IDENT>[(<EXPR>)],...   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <IDENT> MUST NAME A LEGMX
)@@G@@AL NATURAL VARIABLE NAME.   IF <IDENT> ENDS     @G@@@@ WITH  THE  DOLLARMY
)@@G@@  SIGN,  IT  WILL  BE  DEFINED AS A STRING ARRAY.     @G@@@@ <EXPR>,  SUMZ
)@@G@@RROUNDED  BY  PARENTHESES,  IS  ANY NUMERIC EXPRESSION,     @G@@@@ WHOSENA
)@@G@@  VALUE  MUST  BE  AT  LEAST  ZERO,  AND SERVES TO DEFINE THE     @F@@@@NB
)@@G@@ HIGHEST SUBSCRIPT THAT MAY BE USED WHEN REFERENCING <IDENT>.     @@@@@@NC
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  THE <EXPR> FIELD IS NOT CODED,  ITS VALUE IS ASSUMED TOND
)@@G@@ BE THE     @G@@@@ CONFIGURED INITIAL MAXIMUM SIZE FOR STRINGS, REPRESENNE
)@@G@@TED AS A WORD     @G@@@@ COUNT.   REFER TO THE TABLE OF CONFIGURED PARAMNF
)@@G@@ETERS FOR THE VALUE     @#@@@@ OF THIS NUMBER.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF <ENG
)@@G@@XPR> EQUALS ZERO IN A 'DIM' STATEMENT, THE ARRAY IS UNLOADED,     @G@@@@NH
)@@G@@ AND  MAY NOT REFERENCED AGAIN AS AN ARRAY UNTIL REDIMENSIONED TO A     NI
)@@G@@@ @@@@ NON-ZERO SUBSCRIPT RANGE.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ ARRAYS  HAVE  RESNJ
)@@G@@ERVED  <EXPR>+1  WORDS  IN DYNAMIC STORAGE.   ALL     @G@@@@ ARRAYS  ARENK
)@@G@@  CLEARED TO ZERO BY NPL WHEN DIMENSIONED.   ALL ARRAYS     @G@@@@ HAVE NL
)@@G@@ A  ZEROTH  ELEMENT,   WHICH IS THE ELEMENT REFERENCED IF THE     @G@@@@NM
)@@G@@ ARRAY  NAME  IS  USED  WITHOUT A SUBSCRIPT.   ARRAY REFERENCES ARE     NN
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FACILITATED BY THE FACT THAT WITHIN NUMERIC EXPRESSIONS, SUBSCRIPNO
)@@G@@T     @G@@@@ EXPRESSIONS  MAY  INCLUDE ANY FUNCTION OR OTHER ARRAY REFERNP
)@@G@@ENCE IN     @E@@@@ ADDITION TO OPERATIONS ON CONSTANTS AND SIMPLE VARIABNQ
)@@G@@LES.  @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NNR
)@@G@@PL   REV.23       11-  2@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A STRING ARRAY IS SIMILNS
)@@G@@AR TO AN ARITHMETIC ARRAY, EXCEPT THAT WHEN     @G@@@@ A STRING ARRAY RENT
)@@G@@FERENCE IS MADE WITHOUT SPECIFYING A SUBSCRIPT IN     @G@@@@ A STRING CONU
)@@G@@NTEXT, THE STRING ITSELF, RATHER THAN THE NUMERIC VALUE     @G@@@@ OF ARNV
)@@G@@RAY(0) IS USED.   THE ZEROTH CELL OF STRING ARRAYS IS USED TO     @G@@@@NW
)@@G@@ HOLD THE CHARACTER COUNT OF THE LAST STRING ASSIGNED TO THE ARRAY.     NX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ IF  A STRING ARRAY IS USED IN A NUMERIC CONTEXT,  IT IS TREATED ANY
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ IF IT WERE AN ARITHMETIC ARRAY.  IN THE CASE OF STRING ARRANZ
)@@G@@YS, THE     @G@@@@ VALUE  OF  <EXPR>  MUST  BE  AT  LEAST  SIX  TIMES  TOA
)@@G@@HE  NUMBER OF     @G@@@@ CHARACTERS  IN  THE  LONGEST STRING TO BE ASSIGOB
)@@G@@NED TO IT.   STRING     @G@@@@ ARRAY NAMES,  UNSUBSCRIPTED, MAY BE USED OC
)@@G@@IN ANY CONTEXT IN WHICH A     @G@@@@ LITERAL  IS  LEGAL.  ANY ARRAY NAMEOD
)@@G@@, SUBSCRIPTED OR UNSUBSCRIPTED,     @A@@@@ MAY BE USED IN A NUMERIC CONTOE
)@@G@@EXT.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ ANY NUMBER OF ARRAYS MAY BE DECLARED ON ONE 'DIOF
)@@G@@M' STATEMENT.   THE     @B@@@@ PARAMETER LISTS ARE SEPARATED BY COMMAS. OG
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE   STATIC   STORAGE   TABLE   (WHERE  THE  VALUES OH
)@@G@@ ASSIGNED  TO     @G@@@@ UNDIMENSIONED  VARIABLES  ARE  STORED) IS AN IMOI
)@@G@@PLICIT ARRAY WITHIN     @G@@@@ ITSELF.    AN UNDIMENSIONED VARIABLE MAY OJ
)@@G@@BE TREATED AS AN ARRAY BY     @G@@@@ AFFIXING  IT  WITH A SUBSCRIPT EXPROK
)@@G@@ESSION.   THE HIGHEST DIMENSION     @G@@@@ FOR  ANY  PARTICULAR  VARIABLOL
)@@G@@E  IS  THE  NUMBER  OF WORDS FROM ITS     @G@@@@ POSITION  TO THE END OFOM
)@@G@@ THE STATIC STORAGE TABLE.   THIS TABLE MAY     @G@@@@ BE THOUGHT OF AS ON
)@@G@@52 ROWS OF 11 COLUMNS EACH, WHERE EACH ROW STARTS     @G@@@@ WITH  THE VOO
)@@G@@ARIABLE WHOSE NAME IS A LETTER (A, B, C, FOR INSTANCE),     @G@@@@ OR A OP
)@@G@@LETTER AND THE DOLLAR SIGN (A$, B$, C$, ETC.).  A0 WOULD THEN     @G@@@@OQ
)@@G@@ BE  EQUIVALENT  TO  A(1),  ETC.,  TO Z9$'S BEING THE EQUIVALENT OF     OR
)@@G@@@]@@@@ Z$(10).    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ HOWEVER,  IF,  FOR  INSTANCE, A$ ISOS
)@@G@@ NOT DIMENSIONED, BUT A0$, A1$,     @G@@@@ AND AND A2$ ARE,  A$ MAY BE COT
)@@G@@ONSIDERED AN ARRAY OF STRINGS,  FOR A     @G@@@@ REFERENCE  TO  A$(1)  WOU
)@@G@@ILL  REFERENCE  THE STRING A0$,  A$(2) WILL     @G@@@@ REFERENCE  A1$,  OV
)@@G@@ AND  SO FORTH.   THE SAME IS TRUE FOR ARITHMETIC     @F@@@@ ITEMS, IN WOW
)@@G@@HICH CASE IT IS POSSIBLE TO HAVE ARRAYS OF ARRAYS.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@OX
)@@G@@ THE FOLLOWING SPECIAL FORMAT OF THE 'DIM' STATEMENT: @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@OY
)@@G@@                      DIM *<IDENT>(<EXPR>),...  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IS  UOZ
)@@G@@SED  WHEN  <IDENT>  NAMES  A  PREVIOUSLY  DEFINED ARRAY BEING     @G@@@@PA
)@@G@@ REDEFINED AND THE CONTENTS OF THE OLD ARRAY IDENT ARE TO BE PLACED     PB
)@@G@@@G@@@@ INTO  THE NEW ONE.   THE NUMBER OF WORDS TRANSFERRED IS DETERMINEPC
)@@G@@D     @G@@@@ BY THE MINIMUM OF THE OLD SIZE AND THE NEW SIZE.  THE REMAIPD
)@@G@@NDER OF     @C@@@@ THE NEW ARRAY, IF ANY, IS THEN CLEARED TO ZERO.@[@@@@PE
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23 PF
)@@G@@      11-  3@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THIS  FEATURE  IS  ESPECIALLY  USEFPG
)@@G@@UL  IN APPLICATIONS DOING TABLE     @G@@@@ HANDLING  OPERATIONS WHEN, INPH
)@@G@@ THE CASE OF TABLE OR STACK OVERFLOW,     @G@@@@ THE  PROGRAM  CAN REDIMPI
)@@G@@ENSION THE TABLE OR STACK,  AND PRESERVE IN     @F@@@@ THE NEW DATA STRUPJ
)@@G@@CTURE ALL THE INFORMATION FROM THE OLD ONE.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 11. 2PK
)@@G@@.   ARRAY ASSIGNMENT    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE 'ARRAY' STATEMENT IS PROVPL
)@@G@@IDED AS AN EFFICIENT MEANS OF COPYING     @G@@@@ ONE ARRAY TO ANOTHER ORPM
)@@G@@ TO INITIALIZE ALL OR PART OF AN ARRAY TO A     @A@@@@ CONSTANT VALUE.  PN
)@@G@@ITS FORMAT IS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@                    ARRAY A1 = B1, APO
)@@G@@2 = B2,...  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE THE A'S MUST BE DIMENSIONED ARRAYS PP
)@@G@@AND THE B'S MAY BE ARRAYS     @G@@@@ OR EXPRESSIONS.  IF BOTH THE A'S ANPQ
)@@G@@D B'S ARE ARRAYS, THEY NEED NOT     @G@@@@ HAVE  THE  SAME SUBSCRIPT LIMPR
)@@G@@ITS:  THE SIZE OF THE SMALLER IS USED     @G@@@@ AS THE TRANSFER COUNT. PS
)@@G@@ IF ANY OF THE B'S NAME A VARIABLE WHICH IS     @G@@@@ NOT AN ARRAY, OR PT
)@@G@@IS A NUMERIC EXPRESSION, THE ARRAY TO THE LEFT OF     @G@@@@ THE EQUALS PU
)@@G@@SIGN, UNDER CONTROL OF ANY QUALIFICATION DESIGNATOR, IS     @E@@@@ INITIPV
)@@G@@ALIZED TO THE VALUE OF THE VARIABLE OR EXPRESSION.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@PW
)@@G@@ PARTIAL   WORD   QUALIFICATION   IS  ALLOWED  WITHIN  THE  'ARRAY'     PX
)@@G@@@G@@@@ STATEMENT.   HOWEVER,   IF  BOTH  THE  FROM  AND TO ARRAYS SPECIFPY
)@@G@@Y     @G@@@@ QUALIFICATION,  THE RESULTS WILL BE UNPREDICTABLE,  AS THE PZ
)@@G@@LOGICAL     @G@@@@ SUM  OF  THE  QUALIFICATION  DESIGNATOR INDICES WILL QA
)@@G@@DETERMINE THE     @ @@@@ PARTIAL WORD TRANSFERRED.    @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@QB
)@@G@@ 11. 3.   THE DATA STATEMENT  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE  'DATA'  STATEMENT QC
)@@G@@ IS  USED  TO  ASSIGN NUMERIC VALUES TO THE     @B@@@@ ELEMENTS OF AN ARQD
)@@G@@RAY.  ITS FORMAT IS:    @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@           DATA <IDENT>\[<EXPRQE
)@@G@@>],[<EXPR>],...\[,]...  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <IDENT>  NAMES  ANY  ARRAY,  QF
)@@G@@ NATURAL OR NPL KEYWORD.   THE <EXPR>     @G@@@@ FIELDS,  AS SHOWN,  AREQG
)@@G@@ OPTIONAL, AND IF ANY <EXPR> IS ABSENT, THE     @G@@@@ CORRESPONDING  ELQH
)@@G@@EMENT  OF  THE  ARRAY  NAMED  BY  <IDENT> IS LEFT     @G@@@@ UNCHANGED. QI
)@@G@@  OTHERWISE, THE VALUES OF THE SUCCESSIVE <EXPR> FIELDS     @G@@@@ ARE SQJ
)@@G@@TORED IN THE SUCCESSIVE WORDS OF THE ARRAY <IDENT>.   <IDENT>     @G@@@@QK
)@@G@@ NEED  NOT NAME THE ZEROTH CELL OF AN ARRAY,  NOR MUST THERE BE THE     QL
)@@G@@@E@@@@ SAME NUMBER OF <EXPR> FIELDS AS ARE WORDS IN THE ARRAY.    @[@@@@QM
)@@G@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23 QN
)@@G@@      11-  4@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ EXAMPLE:   @@@@@@@@@@@@QO
)@@G@@@C@@@@                  DATA A3$(3)\34,56,78,,23\     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@QP
)@@G@@ A3$(3)  RECEIVES  THE VALUE 34, A3$(4) RECEIVES THE VALUE 56, ETC.     QQ
)@@G@@@C@@@@ A3$(6) IS UNCHANGED, AS ARE A3$(0)-A3$(2).     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@QR
)@@G@@ ANY NUMBER OF ARRAY INITIALIZATIONS MAY BE SPECIFIED BY ONE 'DATA'     QS
)@@G@@@G@@@@ STATEMENT.   THE SECOND AND SUBSEQUENT ARRAY NAMES AND VALUE LISTQT
)@@G@@S     @A@@@@ ARE SEPARATED BY OPTIONAL COMMAS.  @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 11. 4QU
)@@G@@.   THE EQUIV STATEMENT @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE 'EQUIV' STATEMENT IS USEDQV
)@@G@@ TO PROVIDE AN ALTERNATE NAME FOR ANY     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  OR  KEYWORD, QW
)@@G@@ WITH OR WITHOUT SUBSCRIPT.   A NAME MAY BE     @G@@@@ EQUIVALENCED  TO QX
)@@G@@ A  NAME,   NAME AND SUBSCRIPT,  OR EITHER WITH A     @ @@@@ PARTIAL WORQY
)@@G@@D DESIGNATOR.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@B@@@@ THE FORMAT OF THE 'EQUIV' STATEMENTQZ
)@@G@@ IS:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@                EQUIV <IDENT1>/<IDENT2>[(<EXPR>)RA
)@@G@@][.<PART>]  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AS  MANY  EQUIVALENCE DEFINITIONS AS DESIRB
)@@G@@RED MAY BE SPECIFIED ON A     @G@@@@ SINGLE 'EQUIV' STATEMENT.   AN 'EQURC
)@@G@@IV' NAME MAY REDEFINE ANY OTHER     @G@@@@ VARIABLE  NAME,  AND THE TABLRD
)@@G@@E OF 'EQUIV' NAMES IS SEARCHED BEFORE     @G@@@@ ANY  OTHER TABLE TO SATRE
)@@G@@ISFY AN IDENTIFIER REFERENCE (IN NUMERIC OR     @G@@@@ STRING  CONTEXTS)RF
)@@G@@.    IF THE EQUIVALENCE IS DEFINED WITH A PARTIAL     @G@@@@ WORD  DESIGRG
)@@G@@NATOR,  NO SUCH DESIGNATOR MAY BE USED WHEN REFERENCING     @G@@@@ THE  RH
)@@G@@'EQUIV'  NAME.    IF  NO DESIGNATOR WAS SPECIFIED,  OR IF THE     @G@@@@RI
)@@G@@ DESIGNATOR USED IS 'W' (WHOLE WORD),  A PARTIAL WORD REFERENCE MAY     RJ
)@@G@@@C@@@@ BE MADE AT THE TIME OF USE OF THE 'EQUIV' NAME.@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@RK
)@@G@@ IF  <IDENT2>  ON  THE  'EQUIV' STATEMENT IS AN ARRAY AND IT IS NOT     RL
)@@G@@@G@@@@ FOLLOWED  BY  A  SUBSCRIPT,   <IDENT1> WILL BE EQUIVALENCED TO THRM
)@@G@@E     @E@@@@ WHOLE ARRAY, AND MAY ITSELF BE SUBSCRIPTED WHEN REFERENCED.RN
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ EQUIVALENCES  ARE  MAINTAINED  BY PROGRAM LEVEL,  ANDRO
)@@G@@ A PARTICULAR     @G@@@@ PROGRAM'S EQUIVALENCES ARE UNDEFINED WHEN THE PRP
)@@G@@ROGRAM EXITS.   FOR     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRARQ
)@@G@@MMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23       11-  5@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THIS RR
)@@G@@ REASON,   A  PROGRAM WHICH HAS DEFINED EQUIVALENCES MAY CALL     @G@@@@RS
)@@G@@ ANOTHER  PROGRAM  WHICH  USES  THE  SAME  EQUIVALENCE  NAME(S) FOR     RT
)@@G@@@G@@@@ DIFFERENT   VARIABLES,     AND  THE  FIRST  PROGRAM'S  EQUIVALENCRU
)@@G@@E     @E@@@@ DEFINITIONS WILL BE RESTORED WHEN THE CALLED PROGRAM EXITS.RV
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  THE  EQUIV  NAME  ENDS  WITH  A DOLLAR SIGN AND TRW
)@@G@@HE ITEM BEING     @G@@@@ EQUIVALENCED  IS  AN ARRAY,  REFERENCE TO THE ERX
)@@G@@QUIV NAME WILL BE A     @G@@@@ STRING  REFERENCE.    LIKEWISE,  IF THE ERY
)@@G@@QUIV NAME IS NOT A STRING     @G@@@@ NAME, AND THE ITEM BEING EQUIVALENCRZ
)@@G@@ED IS A STRING ARRAY, REFERENCE     @E@@@@ TO THE EQUIV NAME WILL NOT RESA
)@@G@@SULT IN A STRING REFERENCE.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ TO  CLEAR AN EQUIVALENCSB
)@@G@@E, THE 'EQUIV' STATEMENT IS CODED AS ABOVE,     @D@@@@ EXCEPT THAT THE <SC
)@@G@@IDENT2> FIELD IS OMITTED, THUS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                  SD
)@@G@@  EQUIV <IDENT1>/ @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 11. 5.   THE LOCAL STATEMENT @@@@@@SE
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE 'LOCAL' STATEMENT IS USED TO NAME VARIABLES AND/OR ARRASF
)@@G@@YS THAT     @G@@@@ WILL BE USED WITHIN THE EXECUTING PROGRAM,  BUT ARE TSG
)@@G@@O BE RESTORED     @G@@@@ TO THEIR ORIGINAL STATE WHEN THE PROGRAM EXITS.SH
)@@G@@  THE FORMAT OF THE     @^@@@@ 'LOCAL' STATEMENT IS:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@D@@@@SI
)@@G@@                LOCAL <IDENT1>,<IDENT2>,...,<IDENTN>  @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@SJ
)@@G@@ THE  <IDENT>  SPECIFICATIONS  MAY NAME ARRAYS,  STRING ARRAYS,  OR     SK
)@@G@@@G@@@@ SIMPLE  VARIABLES.   NO SUBSCRIPTS ARE PERMITTED.   HOWEVER,  IF SL
)@@G@@A     @G@@@@ NAME  APPEARING  ON  A  'LOCAL'  IS AN 'EQUIV' NAME,  AND HSM
)@@G@@AS BEEN     @G@@@@ EQUIVALENCED  TO  A  PARTICULAR  ELEMENT  OF AN ARRAYSN
)@@G@@,  THAT ARRAY     @G@@@@ ELEMENT WILL BE DECLARED LOCAL, AND IT ONLY, NOSO
)@@G@@T THE ENTIRE ARRAY,     @G@@@@ WILL BE RESTORED.   OTHERWISE,  IF <IDENTSP
)@@G@@> NAMES AN ARRAY (NUMERIC     @G@@@@ OR  STRING),   THE ENTIRE ARRAY IS SQ
)@@G@@SAVED,  THEN THE ARRAY SPACE IS     @G@@@@ UNLOADED,   AND  THE  EXECUTISR
)@@G@@NG  PROGRAM  MUST DIMENSION IT ('DIM'     @G@@@@ STATEMENT) BEFORE IT MASS
)@@G@@Y USE THE SPECIFIED NAME AS AN ARRAY AGAIN.     @G@@@@ IF  A  NAME  APPEST
)@@G@@ARING  ON A 'LOCAL' STATEMENT IS AN UNDIMENSIONED     @G@@@@ VARIABLE,  SU
)@@G@@ AND  THE  EXECUTING PROGRAM DIMENSIONS THAT NAME,  THE     @G@@@@ ARRAYSV
)@@G@@  IS DELETED WHEN THE PROGRAM EXITS,  AND THE SIMPLE VARIABLE     @^@@@@SW
)@@G@@ VALUE IS RESTORED.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ IF  NO  'LOCAL' STATEMENT APPSX
)@@G@@EARS WITHIN A PROGRAM,  ALL VARIABLES     @G@@@@ REFERENCED  BY  THAT  PSY
)@@G@@ROGRAM WILL REMAIN GLOBAL,  AND WILL NOT BE     @G@@@@ RESTORED  WHEN  TSZ
)@@G@@HE  PROGRAM EXITS.   LOCAL VARIABLES ARE RESTORED     @[@@@@*****^@G@@@@TA
)@@G@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23       11-  6TB
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ AUTOMATICALLY  BY  NPL,  AND THE USER PROGRAM NTC
)@@G@@EED DO NO MORE THAN     @G@@@@ EXECUTE  A  'LOCAL'  STATEMENT  TO CAUSE TD
)@@G@@SAVE AND RESTORE OF LOCAL     @]@@@@ VARIABLES. @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  SPTE
)@@G@@ECIAL  FEATURE  OF THE LOCAL STATEMENT ALLOWS REFERENCING THE     @G@@@@TF
)@@G@@ PREVIOUS VALUE OF A LOCAL VARIABLE.  NORMALLY A SIMPLE VARIABLE IS     TG
)@@G@@@G@@@@ CLEARED TO ZERO WHEN DECLARED LOCAL.   HOWEVER, IF ANOTHER NAME ITH
)@@G@@S     @G@@@@ EQUIVALENCED  TO THE VARIABLE NAME BEFORE THE 'LOCAL' STATETI
)@@G@@MENT IS     @G@@@@ EXECUTED,   AND  THE  EQUIVALENCE  NAME  APPEARS  ON TJ
)@@G@@ THE  'LOCAL'     @G@@@@ STATEMENT,   THE  VARIABLE  WILL  NOT  BE  CLEATK
)@@G@@RED.    CAUTION  IS     @G@@@@ INDICATED,   HOWEVER,  FOR IF THE EQUIVALTL
)@@G@@ENCE NAME IS ALSO A LEGAL     @G@@@@ NPL  VARIABLE  NAME,  THE VARIABLE TM
)@@G@@OF THAT NAME,  WHETHER LOCAL OR     @G@@@@ NOT,  WILL  BE  CLEARED!   THTN
)@@G@@IS  IS BECAUSE THE 'LOCAL' STATEMENT,     @G@@@@ UNLIKE THE EXPRESSION STO
)@@G@@CANNER,  CHECKS THE VALIDITY OF THE NAME AS     @G@@@@ THAT   OF  A  NATTP
)@@G@@URAL  VARIABLE  BEFORE  SENSING  THAT  IT  IS  AN     @F@@@@ EQUIVALENCETQ
)@@G@@D NAME.  THE FOLLOWING EXAMPLES MAY CLARIFY MATTERS:  @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@TR
)@@G@@                    LOCAL C   @A@@@@                    EQUIV CCC/C     TS
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE PREVIOUS VALUE OF C IS SAVED,  C IS CLEARED TO ZETT
)@@G@@RO,  THEN THE     @C@@@@ NAME 'CCC' IS EQUIVALENCED TO THE VARIABLE C.  TU
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@]@@@@ HOWEVER,   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                    EQUITV
)@@G@@V CCC/C     @ @@@@                    LOCAL CCC @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ ALTHOTW
)@@G@@UGH  SAVING THE VALUE OF C,  AND EQUIVALENCING THE NAME 'CCC'     @A@@@@TX
)@@G@@ TO IT, DOES NOT CLEAR C TO ZERO.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@                  TY
)@@G@@  EQUIV CCC/C     @ @@@@                    LOCAL C   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@TZ
)@@G@@ IN THIS EXAMPLE,  C IS SAVED,  'CCC' IS EQUIVALENCED,  BUT BECAUSE     UA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ THE  NAME  SPECIFIED  ON  THE  'LOCAL'  STATEMENT IS C,  A NATURAUB
)@@G@@L     @A@@@@ VARIABLE, THE VARIABLE IS CLEARED. @@@@@@@@@@@@@#@@@@ IN THUC
)@@G@@IS EXAMPLE, @@@@@@@@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAUD
)@@G@@MMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23       11-  7@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@      UE
)@@G@@              EQUIV D/C @ @@@@                    LOCAL D   @ @@@@      UF
)@@G@@              D = 99    @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ THE NAME 'D' IS EQUIVALENCED UG
)@@G@@TO THE VARIABLE C, BUT BECAUSE 'D' IS     @G@@@@ A NATURAL VARIABLE NAMEUH
)@@G@@,  THE 'LOCAL' STATEMENT SAVES THE VALUE OF     @G@@@@ THE VARIABLE D,  UI
)@@G@@NOT C.   HOWEVER,  THE ASSIGNMENT STORES INTO THE     @B@@@@ LOCATION C UJ
)@@G@@BECAUSE OF THE EQUIVALENCE.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ REMEMBER,   THE  'LOCALUK
)@@G@@' STATEMENT SENSES THE VARIABLE NAME BEFORE     @G@@@@ ANY EQUIVALENCE AUL
)@@G@@TTACHED TO IT.  THE EXPRESSION SCANNER SENSES THE     @^@@@@ EQUIVALENCEUM
)@@G@@ NAME FIRST.@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEW YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAUN
)@@G@@GE   NPL   REV.23       12-  1@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@^@@@@ 12.   GRAPH PLOTTUO
)@@G@@ING   @@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 12. 1.   THE PLOT STATEMENT  UP
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ A  MEANS  TO  PLOT  THE VALUES OF TWO ARRAYS AGAINST UQ
)@@G@@EACH OTHER IS     @G@@@@ PROVIDED AS A BUILT-IN ROUTINE IN NPL.  THIS FEUR
)@@G@@ATURE IS INVOKED BY     @E@@@@ EXECUTING A 'PLOT' STATEMENT, WHOSE GENERUS
)@@G@@AL FORMAT IS:     @@@@@@@@@@@@@E@@@@         PLOT <ARRAY1>,<ARRAY2>[,<N>UT
)@@G@@[,<LX>[,<LY>[,<TYPE>]]]]@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ WHERE  <ARRAY1> AND <ARRAY2> UU
)@@G@@ARE THE ARRAYS WHOSE VALUES ARE TO BE     @G@@@@ PLOTTED.   BOTH <ARRAY1UV
)@@G@@> AND <ARRAY2> MUST BE TYPED REAL.   <N> IS     @G@@@@ THE  NUMBER  OF  UW
)@@G@@VALUES  FROM <ARRAY1> AND <ARRAY2> TO BE PLOTTED.     @G@@@@ <N>  IS  OPUX
)@@G@@TIONAL,   AND,   IF OMITTED,  WILL BE ASSUMED TO BE THE     @G@@@@ MINIMUY
)@@G@@UM OF THE SIZES OF THE TWO ARRAYS.   IF <N> IS SPECIFIED,  IT     @G@@@@UZ
)@@G@@ MUST BE LESS THAN OR EQUAL TO THE MINIMUM OF THE ARRAY SIZES,  AND     VA
)@@G@@@G@@@@ AT  LEAST  ONE,  WITH AN UPPER LIMIT OF 10000.   <LX> AND <LY> ARVB
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ RESPECTIVELY  THE  LENGTHS  IN  INCHES  OF  THE  COORDINATEVC
)@@G@@  AXES.     @G@@@@ <ARRAY1>  IS  PLOTTED  AS  THE X-AXIS, AND <ARRAY2> AVD
)@@G@@S THE Y-AXIS.     @G@@@@ BOTH  <LX> AND <LY> MUST BE AT LEAST ONE,  WITHVE
)@@G@@ UPPER LIMITS OF 12     @G@@@@ AND 100,  RESPECTIVELY.   ASSUMED VALUES VF
)@@G@@FOR THESE PARAMETERS,  IF     @G@@@@ OMITTED,  ARE <LX> = 12 (6 IF IN DEVG
)@@G@@MAND MODE),  AND <LY> = 8 (4 IF     @#@@@@ IN DEMAND MODE). @@@@@@@@@@@@VH
)@@G@@@G@@@@ <ARRAY1> AND <ARRAY2> MAY BE SUBSCRIPTED,  E.G.,  THE VALUES TO BVI
)@@G@@E     @G@@@@ PLOTTED  FROM  EACH  ARRAY  NEED NOT START AT THE BEGINNINGVJ
)@@G@@ OF THE     @G@@@@ ARRAY.  IN ANY CASE, THE VALUE USED FOR DETERMINING TVK
)@@G@@HE MINIMUM OF     @G@@@@ THE  SIZES  OF  THE  ARRAYS  WILL BE CALCULATEDVL
)@@G@@ FROM THE NUMBER OF     @G@@@@ WORDS IN EACH ARRAY FROM THE SPECIFIED SUVM
)@@G@@BSCRIPT TO THE END OF THE     @]@@@@ ARRAY.     @@@@@@@@@@@@@A@@@@ 12. 2VN
)@@G@@.   TYPES OF GRAPHS AVAILABLE @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@ <TYPE>  IS  A STRING ORVO
)@@G@@ STRING EXPRESSION WHICH DESCRIBES THE TYPE     @D@@@@ OF GRAPH DESIRED,VP
)@@G@@ WITH THE FOLLOWING LEGAL VALUES:   @@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@   'NORMAL'  -  THVQ
)@@G@@E AXES ARE SCALED AND LABELED SUCH THAT THE GRAPH     @D@@@@ FILLS AS MUVR
)@@G@@CH OF THE REQUESTED SPACE AS POSSIBLE.    @@@@@@@[@@@@*****^@G@@@@THE NEVS
)@@G@@W YORK UNIVERSITY PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE   NPL   REV.23       12-  2@@@@@@VT
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@G@@@@   'DY=DX' OR 'DX=DY' - LIKE 'NORMAL',  THE AXES ARE SVU
)@@G@@CALED SO THAT     @G@@@@ THE  GRAPH  FILLS  AS  MUCH SPACE AS POSSIBLE, VV
)@@G@@ BUT WITH THE ADDED     @G@@@@ RESTRICTION THAT THE AXES BE SCALED THE SVW
)@@G@@AME,  I.E., HAVE THE SAME     @ @@@@ NUMBER OF UNITS PER INCH.    @@@@@@VX
)@@G@@@G@@@@   'POLAR' - SAME AS 'DY=DX',  EXCEPT THAT THE ZERO ON EACH AXIS IVY
)@@G@@S     @E@@@@ PLACED AS CLOSELY AS POSSIBLE TO THE CENTER OF THE AXIS.   VZ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@G@@@@   'SPEC'  -  THIS TYPE REQUEST SPECIFIES THAT THE GRAPH IS WA
)@@G@@TO BE A     @G@@@@ SPECIAL TYPE,  I.E.,  THE USER DEFINES THE SCALE EXTEWB
)@@G@@RNALLY.   THE     @G@@@@ VALUE  FOR  THE  NUMBER OF UNITS PER INCH IS PLWC
)@@G@@ACED IN THE <NTH+1>     @G@@@@ CELLS  OF  <ARRAY1>  AND <ARRAY2>.   LIKEWD
)@@G@@WISE,  THE VALUES FOR THE     @G@@@@ LOWER  LIMITS  OF  THE AXES ARE PLAWE
)@@G@@CED IN THE <NTH+2> CELLS OF THE     @G@@@@ ARRAYS  TO  BE PLOTTED.   IF WF
)@@G@@THE 'SPEC' TYPE IS USED,  <N> MUST BE     @G@@@@ SMALLER  THAN THE MINIMWG
)@@G@@UM OF THE SIZES OF <ARRAY1> AND <ARRAY2> BY     @G@@@@ AT LEAST TWO.   TWH
)@@G@@HE NUMBER OF UNITS PER INCH PARAMETERS ARE STORED     @A@@@@ IN THE ARRAWI
)@@G@@YS IN FLOATING POINT.   @@@@@@@@@@@@@ @@@@ 12. 3.   EXAMPLE OF OUTPUT   WJ
)@@G@@@@@@@@@@@@@@@C@@@@ THE GRAPH BELOW WAS OBTAINED WITH THIS CALL:   @@@@@@WK
)@@G@@@@@@@@@B@@@@               PLOT X,Y,16,5,3,'NORMAL'   @@@@@@@F@@@@      WL
)@@G@@0.0E+ 0   1.0E+ 0   2.0E+ 0   3.0E+ 0   4.0E+ 0   5.0E+ 0   @F@@@@      WM
)@@G@@    .+---------+---------+---------+---------+---------+.   @F@@@@ -4.0EWN
)@@G@@+ 1 +                                                   +   @F@@@@      WO
)@@G@@    :                              *                    :   @F@@@@      WP
)@@G@@    :                           *                       :   @F@@@@      WQ
)@@G@@    :                        *        *                 :   @F@@@@      WR
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      WS
)@@G@@    :                  *  *                             :   @F@@@@ -6.0EWT
)@@G@@+ 1 +               *                    *              +   @F@@@@      WU
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      WV
)@@G@@    :            *                                      :   @F@@@@      WW
)@@G@@    :*  *  *  *                                         :   @F@@@@      WX
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      WY
)@@G@@    :                                       *           :   @F@@@@ -8.0EWZ
)@@G@@+ 1 +                                          *        +   @F@@@@      XA
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      XB
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      XC
)@@G@@    :                                             *     :   @F@@@@      XD
)@@G@@    :                                                   :   @F@@@@      XE
